I primarily built this website as an extension of my Curriculum Vitae.pdf and I have since expanded it to cover in far more detail all my work within academia, as well as several other projects I am currently working on. Its primary scope is to provide the reader with a compact yet detailed image of myself in those aspects that may be most relevant to them.\nTo achieve this, the core of the website is dedicated to my academic work, divided into Academic Writings and Notes &amp; Papers. In the former, I list my essays, thoughts, questions, and any other writings related to my Research Areas, while in the latter, I collect papers I have read, along with brief comments on them, as well as lecture notes from most of the undergraduate courses I have attended. Despite this division, I also provide a mixed indexation, organised into the Index of Bachelor Works and the Index of Master Works. Additionally, I present an overview of my Research Areas and document notes and decisions regarding my academic life in the Academic Diary.\nFor the current academic year, my primary focus is on two major entrepreneurial projects. The first is ColivingLiguria, a venture transforming villas into hubs for remote workers and creatives. The second is Luna, a manufacturing startup developing innovative lighting solutions. Both projects represent the practical application of my academic and personal interests.\nFinally, I have added several other pages that enable different functions of this website, which I list in This Website. EU Grant."},"Luna/index":{"slug":"Luna/index","filePath":"Luna/index.md","title":"Luna - Portable Intense Exterior Illumination","links":["ColivingLiguria/Financials/Public-Financial-Aid/FESR-Azione-1.3.3.-EU-Grant","To-Share-Page---Luna","Legal/Regulatory-Research","Luna/Production/Luna-Lab","System/Calendar-Luna","Product-Engineering/Lift-and-Buoyancy","Product-Engineering/Lighting-System","Product-Engineering/Thermal-Management","Product-Engineering/Wind-Stability","Product-Engineering/Safety-and-Sensors","Product-Engineering/Software-Architecture","Product-Engineering/Technical-Overview","Financials/Market-Analysis","Financials/Competitor-Analysis","Financials/Business-Model","Financials/Growth-Strategy","Financials/Ecological-Impact","Legal/Patent-Information","ColivingLiguria","Luna/People/Simone-Testino","ColivingLiguria/System/Archive/MicroSturtupHub/ColivingLiguria-for-Startups-and-Cofounders","People/Simone-Testino","System/Contacts-Luna","Product-Engineering/Luna-Engineering","Product-Engineering/Materials-Guide","Product-Engineering/Physical-Models/Physical-Models","Financials/DBU-Funding-for-Luna","Legal/Legal-Concerns-on-Luna","Production/Luna-Lab","Production/Luna-Production","Marketing/Luna-Marketing"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nLuna is an innovative helium balloon lighting system designed to revolutionize exterior illumination for construction sites, events, and emergency operations. Combining superior light quality with breakthrough affordability, Luna offers a compelling alternative to traditional light towers through advanced engineering and sustainable design.\n\n\n\nVision and Innovation\nThe Luna project reimagines portable lighting by addressing fundamental inefficiencies in traditional light towers. Our solution delivers exceptional illumination quality from heights up to 50 meters while maintaining dramatically lower costs and minimal environmental impact. Every design decision is validated through rigorous mathematical modeling and simulation before physical prototyping.\nCore Competitive Advantages\n\nSuperior Light Quality: Diffused, uniform illumination from elevated position eliminates harsh shadows and glare\nExceptional Affordability: Production cost of ‚Ç¨750 vs ‚Ç¨2,000-5,000 for comparable light towers\nExtreme Portability: 15kg total weight (packable) vs 400kg+ for traditional towers\nHigh Efficiency: 190 lm/W LED performance with helium cooling system\nMinimal Ecological Footprint: 95% lower CO‚ÇÇ emissions per illuminated area\n\nProject Status\nCurrent Phase: Engineering validation and regulatory approval (as of November 2025)\n\n‚úÖ April 2025: Comprehensive technical documentation and business plan completed\n‚úÖ July 29, 2025: FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant acceptance received (with ColivingLiguria)\n‚úÖ August 2025: Core technology patent filed\nüîÑ October-November 2025: Legal approval process with ENAC/EASA ongoing\nüìÖ December 2025: First prototype construction planned at Luna Lab\nüìÖ January 2026: Market validation phase begins\n\nSee the complete Project Timeline for detailed milestones.\nTechnical Overview\nLuna is a 5-10 m¬≥ helium-filled balloon constructed from specialized Mylar material, housing high-efficiency LED modules cooled by an innovative helium circulation system. The entire assembly weighs under 2kg and operates at heights of 10-25 meters.\nKey Specifications\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSpecificationValueLuminous Output100,000 lumensOperating Height10-50 mLED Power600WLuminous Efficacy190 lm/WMaximum Wind Rating35 m/sTotal Weight&lt; 2 kgIlluminated Radius (‚â•10 lux)25 m\nSystem Architecture\nThe system integrates several innovative subsystems:\n\nLift System: Helium buoyancy with optimized volume-to-weight ratio\nOptical System: High-efficiency LED arrays with advanced diffusion\nCooling System: Forced helium convection leveraging 6√ó thermal conductivity vs air\nStabilization System: Three-point nylon anchoring with calculated tension distribution\nSafety Systems: Dual redundant sensors with autonomous emergency protocols\nControl Software: Two-tiered architecture for simulation and real-time operation\n\nRead the complete Technical Documentation for detailed engineering analysis.\nMarket Position\nLuna targets the ‚Ç¨1.7 billion European light tower market (5.2% CAGR), with particular focus on high-growth segments:\n\nConstruction Sites (35-40% of market): Superior cost-effectiveness for temporary lighting\nEvents (luxury and recreational): Premium diffused lighting with aesthetic appeal\nEmergency &amp; Disaster Relief (9.8% CAGR): Lightweight deployment in difficult terrain\n\nOur analysis shows Luna can be profitably offered at ‚Ç¨1,250 sale price or ‚Ç¨125/day rental - dramatically undercutting competitors while maintaining 40-60% margins.\nExplore our Market Research and Competitive Analysis.\nBusiness Model\nLuna employs a phased market entry strategy optimized for the rental-dominated market (60% share, 8.5% CAGR):\n\nPhase 1 - Local Rental Testing: Validate product-market fit with supervised deployments\nPhase 2 - Scalable Rental Model: European expansion with user-friendly packages\nPhase 3 - Manufacturing &amp; Sales: Direct sales alongside subscription tiers (‚Ç¨200-1,500/year)\n\nSee detailed business model and scaling strategy.\nSustainability Leadership\nLuna delivers exceptional environmental performance through multiple pathways:\n\nEnergy Efficiency: 3√ó illuminated area per watt vs average light towers\nEmissions Reduction: 0.05 g CO‚ÇÇ/hr¬∑m¬≤ vs 0.77 g for typical diesel towers\nLED Adoption Catalyst: Lowest-cost LED solution accelerates market transition from inefficient alternatives\nTransportation Impact: Negligible shipping emissions vs dedicated truck delivery for 400kg+ towers\n\nFull analysis in our Sustainability Report.\nLegal and Regulatory Status\nLuna is classified as a tethered gas balloon for commercial operations under European aviation regulations. Our comprehensive regulatory research has engaged:\n\nEASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency): CS 31GB.28 classification\nENAC (Italian Civil Aviation Authority): Formal inquiry submitted May 2025\n\nWe are currently awaiting official guidance on operational boundaries for construction sites and event venues. See complete regulatory analysis and patent details.\nDevelopment Resources\nDocumentation and Code\n\nGitHub Repository: Luna Project Software - Physical models and safety systems\nOverleaf Documentation: Original technical docs - Comprehensive LaTeX source\nPython Physical Models: Full simulation environment for thermal, optical, and fluid dynamics analysis\n\nCollaboration Opportunities\nLuna is a flagship project within the ColivingLiguria ecosystem and actively seeks co-founders in:\n\nMaterials Science: Advanced polymers and textiles for envelope optimization\nRobotics &amp; Below is a reflection on my school and early university years, illustrating how I navigated various challenges and transitions, leading me to where I am today.\nSchool Years\nI was born in Genoa, where I spent my entire childhood until my first year of high school (at 14 years old). After that, I moved to Baden, Switzerland, with my father, and attended Liceo Vermigli, an Italian private school in Zurich. Aspiring for better integration and academic competitiveness, I decided to switch to the Swiss Cantonal School, and, in order to make the transition, I improved my German from A1 to B2.\nFor the next two years, I studied at the Swiss Cantonal School in Baden. By the middle of the second year, however, I started to feel uneasy there as well. My interest in studying the humanities more rigorously grew, and because of both inevitable linguistic challenges and the technical nature of the Swiss school system, I began considering a move back to Italy.\nUpon returning to Genoa, my goal was to attend Liceo Classico A. D‚ÄôOria to fully pursue my passion for the humanities. However, due to the number of subjects I had not studied in Switzerland, I first spent a year at Liceo Scientifico Cassini, a scientific school offering Latin but no Greek. To enrol, I passed exams in six subjects that were not part of the Swiss curriculum.\nAfter spending the summer studying ancient Greek, I finally transferred to the Liceo Classico, where I completed my fifth and final year of high school, graduating with a score of 96/100 High School Diploma.pdf.\nUniversity Years\nI began my university education at the University of Constance, officially enrolled in the B.A. Philosophy programme, but I also followed all the courses in the B.Sc. Mathematics. The professors I became closest to were Leon Horsten and Sam Roberts in analytic philosophy, and Mateusz Micha≈Çek in algebra. Originally, I had planned to attend the LMU Munich for its excellence in analytic philosophy, but bureaucratic issues with the application process led me to seek alternatives. I consider myself fortunate to have ended up at the University of Constance, where the philosophy department closely aligned with my academic interests.\nDespite feeling comfortable in Constance, after my first year, I decided to return to my original plan and transferred to LMU Munich, where I continued both my B.A. Philosophy (LMU) and B.Sc. Mathematics (LMU). At LMU, I particularly enjoyed the MCMP, attending various lectures. I became particularly close to John Dougherty, who supervised my B.A. Philosophy Thesis, and Alessandra Marra.\nIn August 2024, I completed my B.A. Philosophy (LMU) before moving to Amsterdam to begin my M.Sc. Logic (UvA) at the ILLC Amsterdam. I also plan to return to Munich to complete the final exams required for my B.Sc. Mathematics (LMU).\nDuring my first year of the M.Sc., I managed to complete the vast majority of the coursework necessary for the degree. This strategic planning has allowed me to dedicate my second year almost exclusively to my Master Thesis and related research projects, which can be conducted remotely.\nThis newfound flexibility has enabled me to pursue other significant entrepreneurial projects outside of my Research Areas, which I collect under ExAcademia. My primary focus for the current academic year is on two major ventures:\n\nColivingLiguria: A project dedicated to transforming traditional villas into vibrant hubs for remote workers, creatives, and entrepreneurs.\nLuna: A manufacturing startup developing innovative, patented, and funded high-intensity portable lighting solutions.\n"},"System/Documents":{"slug":"System/Documents","filePath":"System/Documents.md","title":"Documents","links":["System/Attachments/Curriculum-Vitae.pdf","System/Attachments/Curriculum_Vitae_Professional.pdf","System/Attachments/CV-06.23.pdf","System/Attachments/ID-Photo.jpg","System/Attachments/High-School-Diploma.pdf","System/Attachments/LogicSummerSchoolCertficate_signed.pdf","System/Attachments/Immatrikulation-Constance.pdf","System/Attachments/Transcript-of-Records-Contance.pdf","System/Attachments/BIP-Poznan-Certificate-of-Attendance.jpg","System/Attachments/Hobbes-Course-Certificate.pdf","System/Attachments/Immatrikulationsbescheinigung_04.06.24.pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.A.-Philosophy-(LMU)","System/Attachments/B.A.-Philosophy-Diploma-(English).pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.Sc.-Mathematics-(LMU)","System/Attachments/Transcript_of_Records_HF_Mathe_03.12.24.pdf","System/Attachments/Transcript_of_Records_NF_Philo_03.12.24.pdf","System/Attachments/Schein_Cat.Th._LMU.pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Structure-on-Models","System/Attachments/Philosophy-of-Logic-Certificate-(LMU).pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/What-a-Logic-Could-not-Be","System/Attachments/ToR_MSc_Logic_UvA_03.12.24.pdf","CAE-English-Certificate-(C1).pdf","TestDaf-German-Certificate-(C1).pdf"],"tags":[],"content":"Here It details the legal framework for our collaborators and lists the key strategies and tasks for promoting projects associated with Coliving Liguria.\n\n\n\nOur Approach to Community &amp; Customers\nAt Coliving Liguria, we are looking to engage with two primary groups of people:\n\nCollaborators: Individuals who wish to participate in the life of our community. This is a general term for residents who align with our vision and contribute to the house‚Äôs atmosphere and projects in various legally defined ways. You can find more on our recruitment strategies for collaborators here.\nCustomers: Guests who book a stay with us for short or long-term periods. Our approach to attracting them is detailed in our page on Ads for Customers.\n\nOur communication and marketing methods are tailored to these different groups, with our Whatsapp Community serving as a central hub for interaction. For a detailed breakdown of our customer segments, please refer to our Rentals Customer Matrix page.\nThe following sections detail the social media strategies that our collaborators can engage in.\nOur Collaborative Social Media Framework\nIt is essential to understand the legal premise of our collaborative model. The social media tasks outlined here are not framed as work performed for Coliving Liguria. Instead, they are considered independent activities undertaken by collaborators who are developing their own projects while in residence.\nThese individuals are formally renting spaces and resources from Coliving Liguria to build their own ventures, such as a photography school or language courses. The social media work they perform has a dual benefit: it primarily promotes their own project, and in doing so, it also enhances the visibility and appeal of Coliving Liguria. This advertising is therefore done in collaboration with these external ventures, a list of which can be found on our Supplementary Projects page. This structure ensures that everyone is working for themselves, and no employment relationships exist unless formally established by one of the supplementary projects themselves.\nKey Social media Tasks &amp; Strategies\n1. Facebook Group Outreach\nA primary task is to engage with relevant communities on Facebook to attract guests, clients, and future collaborators.\n\nObjective: To raise awareness of both the collaborator‚Äôs independent project and Coliving Liguria within targeted online groups (e.g., digital nomads, slow travel, remote workers in Italy).\nKey Actions:\n\nCompile a Curated List: The first step is to research and create a precise list of the most relevant and active Facebook groups that align with our target audience.\nDevelop Messaging Templates: Create a set of clear, engaging, and customisable messages that can be posted in these groups.\nEngage Authentically: Post the messages and actively participate in conversations, responding to comments and inquiries in a helpful and authentic manner.\n\n\n\n2. Influencer &amp; Creator Collaborations\nAnother key strategy is to partner with content creators and influencers whose audience aligns with our values. This involves identifying potential partners and developing mutually beneficial collaboration proposals, as detailed on our Influencer &amp; Creator Collaboration Programme page.\n\n\n\n                  \n                  Legal Remark \n                  \n                \n\n\nThe tasks outlined on this page are primarily intended to support the independent projects of our resident collaborators. Any work that is exclusively for the direct and sole benefit of the Coliving Liguria business entity will be performed by the founder, Simone Testino.\n\n\n"},"ColivingLiguria/Advertising/Influencer--and--Creator-Collaboration-Programme":{"slug":"ColivingLiguria/Advertising/Influencer--and--Creator-Collaboration-Programme","filePath":"ColivingLiguria/Advertising/Influencer & Creator Collaboration Programme.md","title":"Influencer & Creator Collaboration Programme","links":["ColivingLiguria/People/Volunteers/Volunteers","ColivingLiguria/People/Simone-Testino","ColivingLiguria/System/Contact"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nThis page outlines a special, limited-time collaboration offer for content creators and influencers. As we launch Coliving Liguria, we are seeking to partner with creative individuals to help share our story. In exchange for promotion, we are offering free or heavily discounted stays at our villa. This is a unique opportunity to experience the Ligurian countryside while helping us grow our community from the very beginning.\n\n\n\nTo celebrate our launch, we are offering a unique opportunity for influencers on TikTok, Instagram, YouTube, and Facebook to collaborate with us. This is our way of building an authentic presence through genuine experiences, making it the most cost-effective advertising we can afford. Please note that this programme is only available during the initial phase of our activity.\nOur Offer: Stay For Free, Share Your Story\nThe offer is structured in tiers based on your follower count. All stays are for a vocational (holiday) purpose, with no volunteering work required.\nTier 1: 100,000+ Followers\n\nA full month (up to 30 nights) completely free.\nAccommodation in our VIP private bedroom, our best room with the highest quality amenities we can provide.\nAfter the first month, we can discuss a personalised long-term arrangement.\n\nTier 2: 50,000+ Followers\n\nOne full week (7 nights) completely free.\n\nTier 3: 10,000+ Followers\n\nThe first two nights are completely free.\nA 50% discount for the remainder of the first week (the following 5 nights).\n\nTier 4: 1,000+ Followers\n\nWe offer a significant discount on a case-by-case basis, with a guaranteed minimum of 50% off for the first week (7 nights).\nThis offer is conditional on you posting stories about your stay and sharing our default sponsorship story, which will be provided to you.\n\n[Our Sponsorship Story PNG will be attached here]\n\n\n\nAll discounts are based on our standard vocational stay prices, which will be published on our website soon. A link will be available here once the page is live.\n\nWant to Stay Longer for Free? The Volunteering Option\nIf you fall in love with the project and wish to extend your stay, we are very open to it! The offers above can be extended if you choose to contribute as a volunteer.\nSocial media management is a key area where we need help, and your expertise would be highly valued. If you decide to volunteer, your stay could become entirely free, following the same rules and agreements as our other Volunteers. I navigated the entire process of securing European funds, writing a business plan, and handling Italian bureaucracy by myself. While doing so, I definitely felt the need for someone who had already been through it. My goal is to use my first-hand experience to help you take the most efficient steps and avoid the mistakes I made.\n\n\n\nWhile I am not academically trained in economics, my background is in Mathematics and Logic from the University of Amsterdam and the University of Munich. This project is the result of extensive self-education and practical, hands-on experience. I am currently studying to become a certified financial advisor in Italy and believe in a fully transparent, ‚Äúopen book‚Äù approach, which is why I also share my Personal Finance journey; on top of this I am also the founder of Luna, a technical startup in the field of illumination for the industry and events. You can learn more about me on my main page: Simone Testino.\nServices Offered\nMy consultancy is designed to provide practical, actionable guidance through every stage of your project‚Äôs inception, from funding to launch.\n1. Securing European Funds\nFinding and successfully applying for public grants is often the biggest hurdle. Vi riconosciamo un canone fisso mensile che funge da acconto. Al termine, si procede al rogito per il saldo.\nB.2: Acquisto con Partecipazione ai Ricavi: Il prezzo di vendita viene coperto tramite una percentuale sui ricavi netti generati dalla struttura, potendo accelerare i tempi di acquisto.\n\nTrasparenza Contrattuale\nLa fiducia e la chiarezza sono le fondamenta della nostra partnership. sotto‚Äî\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nAs we begin the intensive renovation phase of Ville Chiappella, we must be strategic about who joins the community first. While we aim to be open to everyone, practical necessities dictate our current priorities. This page outlines the factors we consider when evaluating applications and the specific roles that currently take precedence to ensure the project‚Äôs sustainability and rapid development.\n\n\n\nGeneral Evaluation Factors\nBefore looking at specific roles, there are universal qualities we value in every applicant. These factors can significantly boost your priority level, regardless of your intended role.\n\nMotivation &amp; Knowledge: There is a vast amount of information on this website. Demonstrating that you have read it thoroughly and understand our project is the primary indicator of your motivation. So you can start with the Homepage and read all attached pages to it.\nProactive Planning: While immediate availability is welcomed, what is essential is planning ahead. The sooner you Contact us to lock in precise dates, your room, and your potential role, the better we can organise.\nCompleting Onboarding: Priority goes to those who swiftly complete the official Onboarding process. Finalising the contract and sending the security deposit early is crucial for our initial organisation.\nFinancial &amp; Contractual Sustainability: As detailed in Limiti Legali del Volontariato, long-term free stays require a ‚Ç¨200 government registration tax paid purely to the state. For our initial phases, we often highly prefer simpler short-term agreements with a small contribution (e.g., ‚Ç¨30/week), which come with little to no taxes, as outlined in the Contract for Residents. This avoids bureaucratic hurdles and helps us immediately cover basic utilities (water and electricity), which the registration tax does not.\n\nOur Current Priorities\nDuring this initial construction phase, space is limited. In peak times, lower-priority applicants may only have access to shared rooms rather than private accommodation.\nPriority 1: The Builders\nOur absolute top priority is finding skilled individuals who can legally and significantly reduce our renovation costs.\n\nWho they are: Professionals who already have, or can swiftly activate, a registered Italian construction business (Ditta Edile/Partita IVA).\nWhy them: Only properly registered professionals can legally undertake the necessary Extraordinary Maintenance works.\nKey Roles: The Carpenter is currently our most critical opening.\n\nPriority 2: The Storytellers\nClose behind are those who can document this journey. We need to capture the transformation of the villas right now to build our future audience.\n\nWho they are: Creatives capable of staying long-term and generating income‚Äîeither directly through social channels or by increasing the project‚Äôs perceived value.\nKey Roles: The Social Media Manager and the Model (the ‚Äúface‚Äù of our daily content) are essential now to ensure we don‚Äôt miss documenting these foundational moments. This also involves Photographer and Web Designer.\n\nPriority 3: The Entrepreneurs (Partnerships)\nWe highly prioritise individuals who fit firmly into our other Openings or who bring a solid, viable Concept Proposal.\n\nWho they are: Proactive individuals ready to launch initiatives like the Farmer or Mountain Bike Guide &amp; Trail Designer. More importantly that also involves Startup Founders.\nNote: A strong, well-planned personal project can easily move you to the top of our priority list, depending on our current needs.\n\nPriority 4: Full-Paying Guests (Financial Support)\nThose joining purely as residents who pay full rent are vital for our immediate cash flow.\n\nWho they are: Digital Nomads or remote workers.\nBenefit: They provide necessary financial fuel for the project and typically secure priority access to our best private rooms.\n\nPriority 5: Community Residents\nFinally, we welcome those joining with a ‚Äúvolunteer spirit‚Äù to enjoy community life.\n\nWho they are: Residents on standard contracts who contribute to daily Ordinary Maintenance (cooking, cleaning) but have no other professional obligations.\nReality Check: We love having you, but during heavy renovation phases, you will likely have access to shared rooms. Private room availability will depend entirely on the volume of higher-priority residents. If things are planned a long time ahead though, there may still be availability!\n\nA Final Note on Flexibility\nThis list is a general guide, not a rigid rule. A fantastic human being with great energy can always find a place here. If you are motivated, please still apply through our Contact page‚Äîwe might just be looking for exactly what you offer.\n\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nMentre iniziamo l‚Äôintensa fase di ristrutturazione di Ville Chiappella, dobbiamo essere strategici riguardo a chi si unisce per primo alla comunit√†. For information on how to request payments from us, please see the specific section at the bottom of this page.\n\n\n\nBank Transfer Details\nOur primary method for receiving payments is via direct bank transfer. Please use the following details for all transactions:\n\nAccount Holder: Simone Testino\nIBAN:\n\n IT94I0338501601100080084122\n\n\nBIC/SWIFT:\n\nISYBITMM\n\n\nBank Name: Isybank by Intesa San Paolo, Italy\n\nImportant: Payment Description (Causale)\nIt is mandatory to include a clear description (causale) with every bank transfer, regardless of any prior verbal or written agreements.\n\nIf you have a contract: You must include the unique Identifier Number of your Contract for Residents.\nIf you do not have a contract yet: You must write a clear explanation of what the payment is for and what you expect in return (e.g., ‚ÄúSecurity Deposit for [Your Name] - Nov 2025‚Äù).\nRule of Thumb: Never assume we know what a payment is for. Always write it down clearly in the transaction notes.\n\nTiming and Deadlines\nPlease be aware that many bank transfers are not instant. It may take several business days for funds to clear, especially for international transfers.\n\nDeadline Policy: For any payment with a deadline (e.g., securing a booking), we only consider the time of actual receipt into our bank account, not the time you initiated the transfer. Please plan accordingly to ensure funds arrive on time.\n\nOfficial Receipts\nTransparency is paramount. Every valid payment received by Coliving Liguria will be followed by an official digital receipt.\n\nThe Process: You will receive an email from our Certified Email address (PEC): simone.testino@legalmail.it.\nThe Content: This email will contain a standard PDF receipt and a legally binding .p7m file (digitally signed), detailing exactly what we received, how it has been recorded in our system, and what that payment guarantees you in return.\nTiming: By Italian law, we must send this within 10 days, but we typically aim to send it within 24 hours of receiving the funds.\nDid not receive it? If you do not receive this official PEC email within 24 hours of when you believe the funds should have arrived, please Contact me, Simone Testino, immediately to verify the transaction.\n\n\n\n                  \n                  Payment Claims against Us \n                  \n                \n\n\nAny payment request or claim of debt against Coliving Liguria must strictly follow our official Richieste di Pagamento non Autorizzate via PEC or Registered Mail. If you‚Äôre here to volunteer, you‚Äôre not just joining a project‚Äîyou‚Äôre joining a personal mission. This is the story of why I‚Äôm trading my city life for a toolkit, and why I‚Äôm looking for hands-on people to join me in building this place from the ground up.\n\n\n\nThe Search\nIt all started with a search. I‚Äôm a student, and for most of my life, I‚Äôve bounced between Italy, Switzerland, and Germany, driven by a dual passion for big ideas (philosophy) and complex problems (mathematics).\nIn 2024, I was planning my next move‚Äîto Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA)‚Äîafter finishing my B.A. Philosophy (LMU) and while wrapping up my B.Sc. Mathematics (LMU). But as I looked for a place to live, I was hit by a wave of frustration. The rent was impossibly high. The options were small, uninspiring rooms in shared flats.\nI found myself searching for something that felt just out of reach, a place that could be:\n\nAffordable: A place where I wouldn‚Äôt have to stress about rent.\nCommunal: I wanted to be surrounded by interesting, driven people, not just anonymous roommates.\nIn Nature: I craved space, fresh air, and a view that wasn‚Äôt a brick wall.\nConnected: I didn‚Äôt want to be forced into buying a car. I needed reliable public transport to stay autonomous and connected.\n\nI searched everywhere. I found expensive city coliving spaces, isolated rural houses with no connections, and cheap spots in cold, grey climates. But the simple combination of community, nature, autonomy, and affordability? It just didn‚Äôt exist.\nSo, I decided I would have to build it myself‚Äîliterally.\nThe Accelerator\nThat personal frustration was only half the story.\nAt the same time, I was starting to work on my other entrepreneurial project, a hardware startup called Luna. As I planned the R&amp;D, I hit the exact same wall, but from a professional angle.\nWhere could I possibly find the space to build a lab? What landlord, especially in a city, would let me set up prototyping equipment, test large-scale hardware, and run a workshop?\nThat‚Äôs when the vision for ColivingLiguria snapped into focus. This wouldn‚Äôt just be a solution to my housing problem. It would be the physical launchpad for my other company‚Äîa project that, like ColivingLiguria, has since been validated by securing funding from the FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant.\nTo get it all running, I wouldn‚Äôt need a team of expensive contractors. I would need a community. I would need volunteers.\nThe Solution: A Blank Canvas\nColivingLiguria is the answer. It‚Äôs the home I was looking for, and it‚Äôs the workshop Luna needed.\nBut right now, it‚Äôs also a blank canvas. The properties we are acquiring, like Casa del Noce and Casa del Forno, are solid and beautiful, but they need life. They are rustic. They need deep cleaning, new paint, gardens to be planted, and community spaces to be built.\nThis is where you come in.\nMy mission is to create the space I couldn‚Äôt find, and I‚Äôm looking for people who want to co-create it with me. It‚Äôs for the remote worker, the artist, and the entrepreneur‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs especially for the doer, the builder, and the person who isn‚Äôt afraid to get their hands dirty to build something unique from the ground up.\nThis is a place to live, to connect, and to build. It‚Äôs a direct invitation to be part of the foundation.\n\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nSono Simone, il fondatore di ColivingLiguria. Se sei qui per fare volontariato, non stai solo partecipando a un progetto: stai partecipando a una missione personale. This page details our revenue streams, pricing strategy, and unit economics.\n\n\n\nRevenue Streams\nWe have identified three distinct revenue models to capture different market segments.\n1. Local Rental (The ‚ÄúCash Cow‚Äù)\nTarget: Construction Sites &amp; Local Events (Liguria/Piedmont)\n\nModel: Direct rental of Luna units including setup and support.\nPrice: ‚Ç¨125 / day (Standard Rate).\nCost: ~‚Ç¨50 (Helium + Transport + Technician Time).\nMargin: ~60% (‚Ç¨75/day).\nAdvantage: High margin, builds direct customer relationships, validates product durability.\n\n2. Manufacture &amp; Ship (The ‚ÄúScale Up‚Äù)\nTarget: Rental Companies &amp; Large Construction Firms (Europe-wide)\n\nModel: B2B Sales of Luna units.\nPrice: ‚Ç¨1,250 (Unit Price).\nCOGS: ‚Ç¨650 - ‚Ç¨750 (Materials + Assembly + Overhead).\nMargin: ~40-48% (‚Ç¨500 - ‚Ç¨600/unit).\nAdvantage: Rapid scaling without operational overhead. Shifts logistics burden to the customer.\n\n3. Subscription / ‚ÄúLighting-as-a-Service‚Äù\nTarget: Long-term Infrastructure Projects\n\nModel: Annual fee for guaranteed lighting availability + maintenance.\nTiers:\n\nBasic (‚Ç¨200/year): Priority support, discounted spares.\nPro (‚Ç¨1,500/year): Includes 2 replacement units/year + 24/7 support.\n\n\nAdvantage: Recurring revenue, customer lock-in.\n\nUnit Economics\nCost of Goods Sold (COGS) Breakdown\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nComponentCost EstimateEnvelope &amp; Frame‚Ç¨110LED &amp; Electronics‚Ç¨250Cable &amp; Tether‚Ç¨30Assembly Labor (2 hrs)‚Ç¨60Packaging &amp; Manuals‚Ç¨50Total Production Cost~‚Ç¨500Buffer (15%)‚Ç¨75Total COGS‚Ç¨575\nProfitability Analysis\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMetricRental ModelSales ModelRevenue‚Ç¨125 / day‚Ç¨1,250 / unitDirect Cost‚Ç¨50 (Ops)‚Ç¨575 (COGS)Gross Profit‚Ç¨75‚Ç¨675Margin60%54%Break-Even~8 Rental Days~10 Units Sold (to cover R&amp;D)\n\n\n                  \n                  SUCCESS\n                  \n                \n\n\nThe low production cost allows us to break even on a unit after just 8 days of rental. This is an exceptionally fast ROI compared to traditional towers (ROI ~12-18 months).\n\n\n\nPricing Strategy\nWhy ‚Ç¨1,250?\n\nPsychological Pricing: Significantly cheaper than the cheapest diesel tower (‚Ç¨5,000+).\nAuthority: High enough to signal quality (not a ‚Äútoy‚Äù).\nCompetitiveness: Undercuts Airstar (‚Ç¨3,000+) by &gt;50%.\n\nWhy ‚Ç¨125/day?\n\nMarket Standard: Aligns with typical generator/tower rental rates (‚Ç¨100-200).\nValue Add: Includes the ‚Äúwow factor‚Äù and zero-emission benefits for free.\n\nFinancial Projections (Year 1 - Post Launch)\nAssuming 10 active rental units and 50 unit sales.\n\nRental Revenue:\n\n10 units x 100 days utilization x ‚Ç¨125 = ‚Ç¨125,000\n\n\nSales Revenue:\n\n50 units x ‚Ç¨1,250 = ‚Ç¨62,500\n\n\nTotal Gross Revenue: ‚Ç¨187,500\nTotal Costs (COGS + Ops): ~‚Ç¨80,000\nGross Profit: ~‚Ç¨107,500\n\nThis projection confirms that Luna can be a sustainable, profitable business with modest initial volume.\nSee Growth Strategy for how we plan to scale from here."},"Luna/Financials/Competitor-Analysis":{"slug":"Luna/Financials/Competitor-Analysis","filePath":"Luna/Financials/Competitor Analysis.md","title":"Competitor Analysis","links":["Financials/Business-Model"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nLuna competes with both traditional light towers and niche balloon lighting products. Our analysis shows a clear advantage in cost, portability, and light quality against both categories.\n\n\n\nCompetitive Landscape\nWe categorize competitors into two main groups:\n\nTraditional Light Towers: The incumbents (Diesel/Hybrid masts).\nBalloon Lights: Niche products (mostly for film/cinema).\n\n1. Traditional Light Towers (The Incumbents)\nKey Players: Generac, Atlas Copco, Wacker Neuson, LuxTower (Benchmark).\nBenchmark: LuxTower ‚ÄúLux M10‚Äù\nA standard hybrid/diesel light tower used in construction.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFeatureLuxTower M10LunaAdvantageWeight365 kg&lt; 2 kgLuna (Extreme Portability)Height8.5 m10 - 50 mLuna (Area Coverage)Light Output~120,000 lm100,000 lmComparableTransportTruck / TrailerCar Trunk / BackpackLuna (‚Ç¨0 Logistics)Setup Time10 min15 minNeutralPurchase Price‚Ç¨5,200‚Ç¨1,250Luna (4x Cheaper)Rental Price‚Ç¨150 - ‚Ç¨200 / day‚Ç¨125 / dayLuna\n\n\n                  \n                  Traditional Weakness \n                  \n                \n\n\nThe ‚ÄúMast‚Äù is the problem. It accounts for 90% of the weight and cost but serves only to hold the light up. Luna replaces the mast with helium, removing the weight and cost.\n\n\n\n2. Balloon Lights (The Niche)\nKey Player: Airstar (Inventor of balloon lighting).\nProduct: Airstar Scirocco / Sirocco series.\nBenchmark: Airstar Sirocco 2000\nA stand-mounted or suspended balloon light, primarily for events and film sets.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFeatureAirstar SiroccoLunaAdvantagePlatformStand / CraneSelf-Flying (Helium)Luna (Height)CoolingAir (Fan)Helium (Convection)Luna (Efficiency)Price‚Ç¨3,000 - ‚Ç¨9,000‚Ç¨1,250Luna (Disruptive)FocusCinema / High-EndIndustrial / GeneralLuna (Scalability)\n\n\n                  \n                  Competitor Weakness \n                  \n                \n\n\nExisting balloon lights are often ‚Äúdumb‚Äù diffusers put on a stick or hung from a crane. They lack the autonomous flight and active thermal management that make Luna a standalone infrastructure replacement.\n\n\n\nThe ‚ÄúBlue Ocean‚Äù Strategy\nLuna creates a new market space:\n\nCheaper than industrial towers.\nMore Capable (higher altitude) than stand-mounted balloons.\nSmarter (IoT/Safety) than both.\n\nTransportation Cost: The Hidden Killer\nFor a rental company, moving a 400kg tower costs ~‚Ç¨150-300 (truck, driver, fuel).\nMoving Luna costs ‚Ç¨0 (fits in the technician‚Äôs van).\n\\rightarrow This logistics saving alone pays for the helium.\nFeature Comparison Matrix\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFeatureLunaDiesel TowerLED MastAirstarZero Emissions‚úÖ‚ùå‚úÖ‚úÖSilent‚úÖ‚ùå‚úÖ‚úÖ360¬∞ Glare-Free‚úÖ‚ùå‚ùå‚úÖHeight &gt; 10m‚úÖ‚ùå‚ùå‚ùåOne-Person Setup‚úÖ‚ùå‚úÖ‚úÖSmart Safety‚úÖ‚ùå‚ùå‚ùåPrice$$$$$$$$$$\nSee Business Model to see how these advantages translate into profit margins."},"Luna/Financials/DBU-Funding-for-Luna":{"slug":"Luna/Financials/DBU-Funding-for-Luna","filePath":"Luna/Financials/DBU Funding for Luna.md","title":"DBU Funding for Luna","links":["ColivingLiguria/Financials/Public-Financial-Aid/FESR-Azione-1.3.3.-EU-Grant","Financials/Ecological-Impact","Financials/Growth-Strategy","Luna","ColivingLiguria","Luna/People/Simone-Testino"],"tags":[],"content":"title: DBU Funding for Luna\ndate: 2025-11-22\ndraft: false\n\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nThe Deutsche Bundesstiftung Umwelt (DBU) is one of Europe‚Äôs largest environmental foundations. This page details our strategy for securing funding based on Luna‚Äôs significant ecological benefits.\n\n\n\nFunding Status\n\nCurrent Status: Proposal Phase.\nPrimary Grant: FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant (Secured July 2025).\nSecondary Target: DBU Project Funding for environmental innovation.\n\nThe Pitch to DBU\nLuna aligns perfectly with DBU‚Äôs mission to support innovative, exemplary environmental projects.\nKey Alignment Points\n\n\nClimate Protection:\n\nLuna reduces CO‚ÇÇ emissions by 95% compared to diesel light towers.\nSee Ecological Impact Analysis.\n\n\n\nResource Efficiency:\n\nLuna uses &lt; 2kg of material vs 400kg+ for traditional towers.\nRadical dematerialization of infrastructure.\n\n\n\nHealth &amp; Safety:\n\nEliminates noise and diesel fumes from work sites.\nReduces light pollution through directed, shielded optics.\n\n\n\nNext Steps\n\nFinalize Prototype: Use FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant funds to build the ‚ÄúLuna Type One‚Äù MVP.\nGather Data: Collect real-world emissions data from pilot tests.\nSubmit Application: Target DBU‚Äôs ‚ÄúSME Innovation‚Äù track.\n\nSee Growth Strategy for the broader funding roadmap.\n‚ÄúFunding for international projects beyond CEE is possible in individual cases.‚Äù Our application will be based on this exception, arguing that Luna‚Äôs high degree of innovation and its exemplary model character for environmental relief make it a strong candidate.\nTarget Funding Programme: Green Start-up\nWe have decided to focus our application on the DBU Green Start-up programme. This programme is much more suitable for our current liquidity situation. It offers a non-repayable grant of up to ‚Ç¨125,000, which covers up to 100% of the costs.\nThis funding is primarily intended as a ‚Äúliving allowance‚Äù for founders (max. ‚Ç¨2,000/month per person) but also covers material costs and external services to a lesser extent. This aligns perfectly with our strategic needs. The existing FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant grant can be used for material procurement, while the DBU grant would be strategically used to cover personnel costs (e.g., funding a salary for a new team member). This is a highly efficient use of the combined funds, as the FESR grant is not well-suited for covering salaries.\nProject Suitability &amp; Thematic Alignment\nThe Luna project is a strong candidate for DBU funding due to its high degree of innovation and its potential for significant environmental relief.\nThe project‚Äôs primary alignment is with Topic 6: Renewable energy, energy conservation and energy efficiency. Luna is fundamentally an energy-efficiency technology. Its high-efficiency, low-consumption LEDs, combined with a novel helium-based cooling system, are designed to directly reduce energy consumption in industrial applications, such as construction sites and event management, which currently rely on inefficient, often diesel-powered, light towers.\nA secondary alignment is Topic 3: Environmentally-friendly products. The project focuses on the complete life-cycle design and development of a sustainable alternative to existing industrial products.\nFunding Conditions\nWe have considered two key exclusion criteria and determined they do not represent a conflict for this application.\n\n\nProjects Already Started: The DBU normally does not fund projects that have already begun. This is not an issue, as the core research and development phase of the Luna project, for which this funding is sought, has not yet commenced.\n\n\nMultiple Funding Sources: The DBU lists ‚ÄúAccumulation of funds from other sponsors‚Äù as a potential exclusion criterion. Although a FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant grant was secured, those funds are allocated exclusively for real estate purposes (associated with ColivingLiguria) and do not finance the core business, R&amp;D, or operational activities of the Luna project. The DBU ‚ÄúGreen Start-up‚Äù funding is, therefore, necessary specifically for the operational costs (founder subsistence and development) that the Fesr grant does not cover.\n\n\nApplication Process\nThe application process for the Green Start-up programme is a multi-stage selection. It begins with a detailed online application. As all legally binding documents and the application itself must be submitted in German, this entire process will be handled by Simone Testino.\nThe application must be submitted with supporting documents, including CVs and a specific cost plan (using the DBU‚Äôs Excel template). This written application is the basis for the first selection round, which may be followed by an in-depth interview. All official guidelines can be found on the DBU‚Äôs download page."},"Luna/Financials/Ecological-Impact":{"slug":"Luna/Financials/Ecological-Impact","filePath":"Luna/Financials/Ecological Impact.md","title":"Ecological Impact","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nLuna is not just cheaper; it is radically greener. By replacing diesel engines with efficient LEDs and helium cooling, we achieve a 95% reduction in CO‚ÇÇ emissions. This page details our environmental impact analysis.\n\n\n\nThe Problem: Diesel Light Towers\nThe construction industry relies on diesel-powered light towers.\n\nConsumption: ~0.5 - 1.0 liters of diesel per hour.\nEmissions: ~2.6 kg CO‚ÇÇ per liter.\nEfficiency: &lt; 100 lm/W (often old metal halide lamps).\nNoise: 60-80 dB (Noise pollution).\n\nThe Solution: Luna\nLuna eliminates the combustion engine entirely.\n\nPower Source: Grid power or small battery/hybrid generator.\nEfficiency: 190 lm/W (High-efficiency LEDs).\nCooling: Passive/Active Helium cooling (No heavy AC needed).\n\nCO‚ÇÇ Emissions Comparison\nWe compare the emissions per hour of operation for a standard illuminated area (1000 m^2).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMetricDiesel TowerLuna (Grid EU Mix)ReductionPower DrawN/A (Engine)0.6 kW-Fuel/Energy0.7 L/hr Diesel0.6 kWh-CO‚ÇÇ Emissions1.82 kg/hr0.15 kg/hr-92%Emissions/m^21.82 g0.15 g-92%\n\n\n                  \n                  NOTE\n                  \n                \n\n\nIf Luna is powered by a green source (solar/battery or renewable grid), emissions drop to zero.\n\n\n\nTransportation Impact: The Hidden Benefit\nThe biggest environmental win is in logistics.\n\nScenario: Delivering a light tower to a site 50km away.\nTraditional: Requires a flatbed truck (High emissions).\nLuna: Fits in a standard car or van (Low emissions).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTransport LegTruck (Diesel Tower)Car (Luna)Fuel Cons.25 L/100km6 L/100kmCO‚ÇÇ (100km)65 kg15 kgReduction-77%\nCompliance with Regulations\nLuna positions companies to easily meet increasingly strict environmental standards:\n\nEU Stage V Standards: Limits emissions for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (NRMM). Luna is exempt/compliant by default (no engine).\nNoise Regulations: Luna is silent (&lt; 20 dB fans), allowing 24/7 operation in residential zones where diesel towers are banned at night.\nESG Goals: Adopting Luna contributes directly to corporate sustainability targets (Scope 1 &amp; 3 emissions reduction).\n\nMaterial Sustainability\n\nReusability: The Mylar envelope is durable but eventually degrades. We are exploring bio-based plastics for future iterations.\nRecyclability: Aluminum frame and electronics are fully recyclable.\nHelium: We use standard balloon gas. While helium is a non-renewable resource, Luna‚Äôs sealed design minimizes loss (&lt; 5% per 1000h), making it a responsible user of the gas compared to party balloons.\n\nLuna proves that sustainability does not have to cost more. In fact, it costs less."},"Luna/Financials/Growth-Strategy":{"slug":"Luna/Financials/Growth-Strategy","filePath":"Luna/Financials/Growth Strategy.md","title":"Growth Strategy","links":["Production/Luna-Lab","ColivingLiguria/Financials/Public-Financial-Aid/FESR-Azione-1.3.3.-EU-Grant"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nFrom a garage prototype to a European market leader. This page outlines the strategic roadmap for scaling Luna, funding milestones, and long-term vision.\n\n\n\nPhase 1: Validation &amp; MVP (Current - Late 2026)\nGoal: Prove the product works and people want it.\n\nMilestone 1: Regulatory Clearance: Obtain ENAC/EASA clarification (Ongoing).\nMilestone 2: Working Prototype: Build ‚ÄúLuna Type One‚Äù at Luna Lab.\nMilestone 3: First Pilot: 5-10 supervised rentals to friendly local customers (Construction/Events in Liguria).\n\nMetric: Customer Net Promoter Score (NPS) &gt; 9/10.\nFunding: Bootstrapped + FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant.\n\n\n\nPhase 2: Market Entry (2027)\nGoal: Establish a repeatable sales/rental model.\n\nStrategy: ‚ÄúRegime Forfettario‚Äù Optimization.\n\nLeverage the Italian tax regime for startups (up to ‚Ç¨85k revenue/year with flat 5-15% tax).\nKeep overheads low. Founder-led sales.\n\n\nTarget:\n\n20 Active Rental Units.\n50 Unit Sales.\nRevenue: ~‚Ç¨100k - ‚Ç¨150k.\n\n\nTeam: Hire 1st employee (Technician/Assembly).\n\nPhase 3: Scaling &amp; Industrialization (2028+)\nGoal: Expand beyond Italy and industrialize production.\n\nFunding: Seed Round / Series A.\n\nSeek ‚Ç¨500k - ‚Ç¨1M investment.\nTarget VCs specializing in Hardware/ConstructionTech.\n\n\nOperations:\n\nMove to dedicated manufacturing facility.\nEstablish distribution partners in DACH region (Germany, Austria, Switzerland).\nLaunch ‚ÄúLuna Pro‚Äù (ATEX certified for Oil &amp; Gas).\n\n\nMarketing:\n\nAttend major trade shows (Bauma, SaMoTer).\nDigital marketing campaign targeting rental companies.\n\n\n\nFunding Strategy\n1. Grants &amp; Public Funding (Non-Dilutive)\nWe actively pursue non-repayable grants to fund R&amp;D.\n\nFESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant: Secured (July 2025).\nDBU (German Federal Environmental Foundation): Potential partner for ecological innovation.\nEIT Manufacturing: European innovation network opportunities.\n\n2. Bootstrapping\nReinvesting early rental profits to fund growth.\n\nPros: Retain equity/control.\nCons: Slower growth.\nPlan: Use for Phase 1 &amp; 2.\n\n3. Equity Investment\nBringing in external capital for rapid scaling.\n\nTrigger: When demand exceeds our ability to self-fund production.\nValuation Driver: Proven unit economics and IP (Patent).\n\nStrategic Partnerships\n\nColivingLiguria: Our incubator and HQ. Provides space, community, and initial network.\nUniversity of Genoa: Potential collaboration for aerodynamic validation.\nRental Chains (e.g., Boels, Kiloutou): The ultimate goal is to become a supplier for these major networks.\n\nExit Strategy (Long Term)\n\nAcquisition: By a major light tower manufacturer (Generac, Atlas Copco) looking to green their portfolio.\nIndependence: Growing into a sustainable SME dominating the niche of balloon lighting.\n\nLuna is built to be a real business from day one, with a clear path from prototype to profit."},"Luna/Financials/Market-Analysis":{"slug":"Luna/Financials/Market-Analysis","filePath":"Luna/Financials/Market Analysis.md","title":"Market Analysis","links":["Financials/Competitor-Analysis"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nThe European light tower market is a ‚Ç¨1.7 billion industry ripe for disruption. This page details the market size, segmentation, and the strategic opportunity for Luna to replace expensive, polluting diesel towers with a sustainable, cost-effective alternative.\n\n\n\nMarket Overview\nThe global light tower market is substantial and growing, driven by infrastructure development, safety regulations, and the events industry.\n\nEuropean Market Size: ‚Ç¨1.7 Billion USD (2025 Estimate)\nCAGR: 5.2% (Compound Annual Growth Rate)\nKey Drivers:\n\nStrict emissions regulations (EU Stage V).\nDemand for safer work environments (better lighting).\nGrowth in outdoor events and festivals.\n\n\n\nMarket Segmentation\nWe analyze the market by Application, Technology, and Business Model.\n1. By Application\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSegmentShareRelevance to LunaConstruction35-40%Primary Target. High need for robust, powerful lighting. Cost sensitivity is high.Oil &amp; Gas25%Secondary. Requires ATEX certification (future roadmap).Mining20%Secondary. Rugged terrain favors Luna‚Äôs portability.Events &amp; Other15-20%Strategic Entry Point. High value placed on aesthetics and light quality (glare-free).\n2. By Technology\n\nDiesel: Historically dominant but declining due to noise, emissions, and fuel costs.\nLED: 55% Market Share and growing. Luna aligns with this trend but offers a superior form factor.\nSolar/Hybrid: Growing niche, but limited by battery capacity and weather.\n\n3. By Business Model\n\nRental: 60% of the market.\n\nTrend: Increasing at 8.5% CAGR. Companies prefer OpEx (renting) over CapEx (owning).\nLuna Strategy: Our low COGS allows for highly profitable rental margins (‚Ç¨125/day).\n\n\nSales: 40% of the market.\n\nLuna Strategy: Direct sales to rental companies and large construction firms.\n\n\n\nTarget Customer Profiles\nA. The Construction Manager\n\nPain Points: High fuel costs, noise complaints in urban areas, transport logistics (need a truck for towers), harsh shadows causing accidents.\nLuna Value: Silent, zero emissions, fits in a car trunk, superior shadow-free light.\n\nB. The Event Organizer (Weddings, Festivals)\n\nPain Points: Ugly industrial towers ruin the atmosphere, blinding glare for guests, noisy generators.\nLuna Value: ‚ÄúMoon-like‚Äù aesthetic, soft light, silent operation, branding opportunity (logos on balloon).\n\nC. Civil Protection / Emergency Relief\n\nPain Points: Access to disaster zones (roads blocked), need for rapid deployment.\nLuna Value: Can be carried by backpack to remote sites, deployed in 15 minutes.\n\nGeographic Focus\nInitial Market: Northern Italy &amp; DACH Region (Germany, Austria, Switzerland).\n\nHigh construction activity.\nStrict environmental regulations.\nStrong events sector.\nProximity to our HQ in Liguria.\n\nStrategic Opportunity\nThe market is shifting towards Sustainability and Efficiency. Traditional manufacturers are merely retrofitting diesel towers with LEDs (creating ‚ÄúHybrid‚Äù towers that are still heavy and expensive).\nLuna is a leapfrog technology: It abandons the ‚Äútower‚Äù concept entirely for a solution that is inherently lighter, cheaper, and greener.\nSee Competitor Analysis to see how we stack up against the incumbents."},"Luna/Legal/Legal-Concerns-on-Luna":{"slug":"Luna/Legal/Legal-Concerns-on-Luna","filePath":"Luna/Legal/Legal Concerns on Luna.md","title":"Legal Concerns on Luna","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"Our research indicates that Luna‚Äôs classification is a ‚Äútethered gas balloon for commercial operations.‚Äù This is a critical distinction that appears to place it outside the two most common regulatory frameworks:\n\n\nEuropean Union (EASA) Regulations: The official EASA Balloon Rule Book specifies that its regulations do not apply to tethered gas balloons, deferring governance to individual national authorities. This means Luna‚Äôs legality is determined at the country level.\n\n\nItalian Drone (APR) Regulations: Luna does not seem to fall into the drone category, as it is not remotely piloted to navigate. Its only remote functions are for safety and lighting control, not flight.\n\n\nThe specific Italian regulations for tethered balloons appear to be exclusively focused on vehicles designed for the transport of people, which does not apply to Luna‚Äôs purpose. This leaves Luna in a legally ambiguous category that requires direct clarification from the authorities.\nKey Questions Submitted to ENAC\nTo resolve this ambiguity, we have formally asked ENAC for clarification on the following points:\n\n\nPermitted Flight Zones: Is it permissible to operate Luna over ‚Äúcongested areas‚Äù? We require a clear distinction between operations at industrial/construction sites versus public events with gatherings of people.\n\n\nOperational Procedures: What is the official process required to conduct a flight operation? Specifically, we need to know if each flight requires a unique permit (like a NOTAM), or if a single certification for the device model would be sufficient.\n\n\nPersonnel Requirements: Are certified personnel required to be on-site during setup or operation, given that Luna is not actively piloted?\n\n\nGeographical Restrictions: Are there any blanket restrictions on operating in specific locations, such as urban centers, parks, or beaches?\n\n\nNext Steps\nDespite sending several emails, the legal framework for Luna remains unclear. We will now pursue more direct contact with ENAC offices to obtain the definitive answers needed to move forward with the project in Italy."},"Luna/Legal/Patent-Information":{"slug":"Luna/Legal/Patent-Information","filePath":"Luna/Legal/Patent Information.md","title":"Patent Information","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nIntellectual Property protection is a cornerstone of Luna‚Äôs value proposition. We have filed for patent protection on the core innovations that make an autonomous, helium-cooled lighting balloon possible.\n\n\n\nPatent Status\n\nStatus: Filed / Pending\nFiling Date: August 2025\nJurisdiction: Italy (with option to extend to PCT/Europe within 12 months).\n\nCore Claims\nThe patent application covers the specific integration of technologies that differentiates Luna from generic balloon lights.\n1. The Helium Cooling Method\nThe use of the lifting gas as a primary heat transfer medium.\n\nClaim: A system where forced convection of the lifting gas (helium) is used to cool the light source (LEDs) and transfer heat to the envelope for dissipation.\nInnovation: Eliminates the need for heavy heatsinks or external air intake (which introduces impurities).\n\n2. The Autonomous Safety Architecture\nThe specific logic of the fail-safe system.\n\nClaim: A dual-redundant sensor and control system that autonomously manages internal pressure, temperature, and lift (via helium release) without ground intervention.\nInnovation: Enables ‚Äúunmanned‚Äù operation, classifying the device as a safe infrastructure tool rather than a piloted aircraft.\n\n3. The Stabilization Geometry\nThe specific 3-point anchoring ratio.\n\nClaim: The specific ratio of tether length to balloon height (d \\approx 2h) combined with the internal load distribution frame.\nInnovation: Maximizes stability in high winds with minimal material weight.\n\nIP Strategy\n\nDefensive: Prevent competitors (especially large incumbents) from copying our specific cooling and safety innovations.\nValuation: Increases the company‚Äôs value for potential investors or acquirers.\nLicensing: Potential to license the ‚ÄúHelium Cooling Core‚Äù technology to other aerial platforms (e.g., tethered drones, communication relays).\n\nFreedom to Operate\nWe have conducted a preliminary search of existing patents (e.g., Airstar‚Äôs portfolio).\n\nMost early balloon light patents have expired (20+ years).\nOur specific ‚ÄúHelium Cooling‚Äù approach appears novel and distinct from existing ‚ÄúAir Cooled‚Äù or ‚ÄúPassive‚Äù designs.\n\n\n\n                  \n                  NOTE\n                  \n                \n\n\nFull patent text and drawings are confidential pending publication. This page provides a summary for stakeholders.\n\n\n"},"Luna/Legal/Regulatory-Research":{"slug":"Luna/Legal/Regulatory-Research","filePath":"Luna/Legal/Regulatory Research.md","title":"Regulatory Research and Compliance","links":["Product-Engineering/Technical-Overview","Financials/Market-Analysis","Financials/Business-Model","System/Calendar-Luna","Legal/Patent-Information","Legal/Legal-Concerns-on-Luna","Product-Engineering/Safety-and-Sensors"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nThis page documents the comprehensive regulatory research conducted to ensure Luna‚Äôs compliance with European and Italian aviation regulations. It details our engagement with ENAC and EASA, the regulatory frameworks analyzed, and the open questions awaiting official guidance.\n\n\n\nOverview\nLuna is classified as a tethered gas balloon for commercial operations under aviation regulations. Unlike remotely piloted aircraft systems (drones), Luna has no propulsion or remote control capabilities - it is anchored to the ground and controlled only through power modulation and safety systems.\nThis unique classification requires careful navigation of both European (EASA) and national (ENAC) regulations. Our research has identified applicable frameworks while revealing gaps in existing regulations for our specific use case.\nRegulatory Classification\nEuropean Classification (EASA)\nFollowing definitions in EASA Balloon Rule Book, Luna is classified as:\n\nType: Tethered gas balloon (pallone a gas vincolato)\nPurpose: Commercial operations\nRegulation Code: CS 31GB.28\n\nKey Finding: Page 22 of the regulation explicitly states: ‚ÄúThis Regulation does not apply to air operations with tethered gas balloons.‚Äù\nThis indicates that tethered gas balloons for commercial use are regulated at the national level, not European level. No further stringent regulations were found in EASA Regulations.\nReference Guidelines\nWhile not legally binding for Luna, the SORA guidelines (Specific Operations Risk Assessment) provide useful risk management frameworks developed for drones in the specific category.\nItalian National Regulations (ENAC)\nTethered Balloon Regulations\nENAC specifies that balloon regulations cover tethered gas balloons at the national level. However, existing documentation primarily addresses passenger transport balloons, which clearly does not apply to Luna.\nAvailable forms and modules may be relevant but require official clarification.\nHarmlessness Criteria Analysis\nThough Luna is not a remotely piloted aircraft (APR), we analyzed the LG 2016/003 NAV guidelines on harmlessness to confirm Luna‚Äôs safety profile:\nMass Requirement ‚úì\n\nLimit: &lt; 2 kg total solid mass\nLuna: ~1.9 kg (0.2kg payload + 1.4kg envelope + 0.3kg cable)\nStatus: Compliant (assuming helium mass is excluded)\n\nStructural Integrity (¬ß5.1) ‚úì\n\nMylar 125Œºm and nylon materials meet standard structural requirements\nMaterials commonly used in similar applications with proven track record\n\nFire Protection (¬ß5.7) ‚úì\n\nHigh helium concentration prevents combustion\nNo lithium battery required (only sensors with backup)\nInternal temperature continuously monitored\nAutomatic power reduction on critical temperature\n\nOther Criteria (¬ß5.2-5.6, ¬ß5.8) ‚úì\n\nEasily satisfied or not applicable to Luna‚Äôs design\n\nOperational Restrictions\nThe most relevant restriction comes from ENAC APR Regulation ¬ß10.7:\n\n‚ÄúFlight over assemblies of people, for parades, sporting events or forms of entertainment or otherwise where there are unusual concentrations of people is in any case prohibited.‚Äù\n\nHowever, this regulation applies to remotely piloted aircraft (APR), a category Luna does not fall under.\nCongested Areas Definition\nFrom ENAC APR Regulations:\n\nCongested Areas: areas or agglomerations used as residential, industrial, commercial, sports zones, and in general areas where there may be gatherings, even temporary, of people.\n\nKey distinction: The regulation does not prohibit APR flight over all congested areas - only over assemblies/unusual concentrations. This suggests construction sites and industrial areas without significant gatherings may be permitted.\nPotential Compliance Strategy\nEven if similar restrictions were applied to tethered balloons, Luna could maintain functionality by:\n\nPositioning the ground projection of Luna at sufficient distance (20-50m) from the illuminated area\nAngling internal LED arrays to direct light away from directly beneath the balloon\nThis strategy preserves Luna‚Äôs key advantage of elevated, diffused illumination\n\nOfficial Inquiry to ENAC\nEmail Submitted: May 2025\nWe submitted a formal inquiry to ENAC addressing our regulatory questions. The email was sent to:\n\ncertificazione.prodotti@enac.gov.it\noperazioni.volo@enac.gov.it\n\nEmail Content Summary\nSubject: Domanda ENAC - Pallone Aerostatico ad Elio per Illuminazione (Luna Project)\nThe inquiry provided:\n\nProject Description: Technical overview of Luna‚Äôs construction, operation, and commercial purpose\nRealistic Parameters: Estimated specifications (subject to physical validation)\n\nPayload weight: &lt; 200g\nTotal solid mass: &lt; 2kg\nLuminous output: 75 klm\nOperating temperature: &lt; 50¬∞C\nWind resistance: 15 m/s operational, resistant to extreme weather\n\n\nRegulations Consulted: Summary of EASA and ENAC frameworks reviewed\nTarget Markets: Construction sites, industrial areas, and events (luxury and recreational)\n\nAttachments Provided\n\nDomanda ENAC.tex: Detailed regulatory questions (this page‚Äôs source)\nProject: Type One: Complete technical documentation\nBusiness Plan: Market analysis and business model\n\nOpen Questions Awaiting ENAC Response\n1. Flight Over Assemblies\nQ: Is flight over assemblies permitted for Luna?\nIf not, do any of the following conditions change the answer?\na) If harmlessness criteria (outlined above) are met?\nb) If locations are congested areas (e.g., construction/industrial sites) rather than assemblies of people?\nc) If 20-50m distance is maintained between ground projection and assembly/worksite?\n2. Operational Procedures\nQ: What process must be followed to conduct flight operations with Luna?\nReference: ENAC NI-2018-006 states it does not apply to tethered gas balloons except those for passenger transport.\nSpecific sub-questions:\na) NOTAM Requirement: Is a NOTAM (Notice to Airmen) required for each operation, as mentioned in this article?\nb) Response Timeline: If NOTAM is required, what are expected approval timelines? (Concern: a user comment mentioned 20-day wait times, making rental business model impractical)\nc) Type Certification: Can a Luna model receive single certification allowing operations under defined safety conditions, requiring only notification rather than per-operation approval?\nd) Operator Requirements:\n\nIs an attendant required during flight operations?\nIs an attendant required during setup/installation?\nWhat qualifications/certifications are needed for setup personnel or monitoring personnel?\n\ne) Geographic Restrictions: Do regulations vary by location type (urban spaces, beaches, natural parks)?\n3. Weight Calculation Methodology\nQ: What components must be included in Luna‚Äôs weight calculation?\nGiven that helium mass is obviously excluded, must we include:\n\nPower cable weight?\nNylon anchor tether weight?\nMylar envelope weight, or only internal payload (electronics and frame)?\n\n4. Design Recommendations\nQ: Do you have recommendations for modifications to Luna‚Äôs design that would facilitate compliance with European and national regulations?\nQ: Do you have safety design recommendations based on similar systems?\nQ: Can you provide contacts for technical or legal expertise relevant to this project?\nCurrent Status\nStatus as of November 2025: Awaiting official response from ENAC\nThe regulatory approval process is on our critical path for Q4 2025. We have allocated October-November 2025 for legal clarity before committing to physical prototype construction.\nContingency Planning\nIf Italian regulations prove prohibitive:\nStrategy: Manufacturing in Italy for export to countries with more favorable tethered balloon regulations. This preserves:\n\nTechnical development and IP protection in Italy\nManufacturing jobs and supply chain\nExport revenue and market validation in permissive jurisdictions\nOption to revisit Italian market if regulations evolve\n\nHelium Transportation Regulations\nWhile not a flight regulation, helium transport has compliance requirements.\nEuropean Framework\nECHA lists regulations for helium, particularly Directive 2008/68 on dangerous goods transport.\nKey Finding: Article 6 provides routine exemptions for small quantities. Regulations are primarily national-level.\nPractical Impact: Unofficial sources indicate this should not constitute a difficulty. The main challenge may be finding shipping companies willing to handle the material rather than regulatory prohibition.\nRelated Documentation\n\nPatent Status\nGeneral Legal Concerns\nSafety System Design\nBusiness Model Impact\n\nReferences\n\n\nEASA Balloon Rule Book (IR + AMC/GM &amp; CS + AMC/GM) eRules, 2020. Link\n\n\nENAC LG 2016/003 NAV - Risk Assessment Guidelines for Remotely Piloted Aircraft Operations, 2016. Link\n\n\nENAC APR Regulation - Remotely Piloted Aircraft Systems Regulation, Ed. 2, Amendment 3, October 2024. Link\n\n\nENAC NI-2018-006 - Operational Guidance on Provincial Airworthiness Activities, April 2024. Link\n\n\nEU Directive 2008/68 - Dangerous Goods Transport. Link\n\n\n\nLast updated: November 2025"},"Luna/People/Join-the-Team":{"slug":"Luna/People/Join-the-Team","filePath":"Luna/People/Join the Team.md","title":"Join the Luna Team","links":["ColivingLiguria/Financials/Public-Financial-Aid/FESR-Azione-1.3.3.-EU-Grant","Financials/Business-Model","ColivingLiguria","Luna","Product-Engineering/Technical-Overview","ColivingLiguria/System/Archive/MicroSturtupHub/ColivingLiguria-for-Startups-and-Cofounders","System/Contacts-Luna","People/Simone-Testino"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  ABSTRACT\n                  \n                \n\n\nLuna is seeking co-founders and key collaborators to join a funded startup at the ground level. We categorize needs into three risk classes:\nFirst-Order Needs (Highest Equity)\nEssential before customer testing - highest risk, highest reward\nSecond-Order Needs (Moderate Equity)\nImportant for mature-phase growth - moderate risk\nDemand-Led Needs (Cash + Vesting)\nOnly necessary after market validation - lowest risk, preferred cash compensation\nTechnical Positions\nMaterials Scientist\nPrimary Responsibilities:\n\nAdvanced polymer and textile selection for balloon envelope\nHelium permeability optimization\nOptical properties validation (haze, transparency)\nWeather resistance testing and certification\nMaterial sourcing and supplier relationships\n\nRequired Expertise:\n\nPolymer chemistry or materials engineering degree\nExperience with gas-barrier films (Mylar, PET, EVOH)\nKnowledge of optical material properties\nIndustrial supplier network helpful\n\nWhy This Matters:\nThe envelope material is Luna‚Äôs most critical component, affecting lift capacity, helium retention, light diffusion quality, and operational lifespan.
