of Courses\nThe semester is divided in two periods, in each one of the periods I plan to have four courses that begin and end in the period (of 6EC each) and three courses that last the whole semester. This means that I would make 24EC per period + 17EC for the latter three courses, hence for a total of 24 + 24 + 17 = 65. To this, one shall add the research projects, that I plan to do for 12 EC (see Bureaucracy), getting to a total of 77 EC. This scenario guarantees me the possibility to write the thesis during the 6th Semester and finish the M.Sc. Logic (UvA) in one year.\n1st Year, 1st Period\nThe courses of a period make up to 24EC + 17EC\n\nCategory Theory (Lecture), (link, 8EC*)\nIntroduction to Modal Logic (Lecture), (link, 6EC*)\nLogic, Language and Computation (Lecture), (link, 3EC*)\nKnowledge, Representation and Reasoning (Lecture), (link, 6EC)\nPhilosophy of Science (Lecture), (link, 6EC)\nMeaning, Reference and Modality (Lecture), (link, 6EC)\nMathematical Proof Methods for Logic (Lecture), (link, 6EC)\n\n1st Year, 2nd Period\nThe courses of a period make up to 24 + 17EC\n\nCategory Theory (Lecture), (link, 8EC*)\nIntroduction to Modal Logic (Lecture), (link, 6EC*)\nLogic, Language and Computation (Lecture), (link, 3EC*)\nProof Theory (Lecture) (link, 6EC)\nDynamic Epistemic Logic (Lecture) (link 6EC, [Essay])\nPhilosophy of Logic (Lecture) (link, 6EC, [Essay])\nPhilosophy of Cognition (Lecture) (link, 6EC, [Essay])\n\n1st Year, 3rd Period\nIn total 12EC\n\nStructuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project), (12EC)\nResearch Project in Forcing (6EC)\n\n\nDecision Process\nHere I keep the reasoning I made for getting to the full list of courses I took in my 5th Semester\nDuring my 5th semester I will both need to finish (or continue) my B.Sc. Mathematics (LMU) and begin my M.Sc. Logic (UvA). In this page I lsit the courses I plan to follow for both degrees, since I will live in Amsterdam, my main focus will be on the M.Sc. but I will study some courses for the B.Sc. and give the exams once I get to Munich by the end of the German semester which is far later the end of the Dutch semester. It is also relevant to consider that my average ECTS per semester is far above the recommended or typical one (see Bachelors‚Äô Outline).\nM.Sc. Logic (UvA) 5th-6th Sem. Courses\nFirst I list all options I have and courses I would like to take, I paste the links from the Courses List. There are also courses that will be offered during my 6th Semester.\nVery First Priority\nThese are courses that I would follow even if couldn‚Äôt count as credits. Other than in  Philosophy of Mathematics, I have no basis in Type Theory, Topos Theory,  Proof Theory and Recursion theory though I heard frequently about these fields and need an introduction to those. I also never had a proper course in Philosophy of Mathematics nor in Philosophy of Science.\n\nPhilosophy of Mathematics\nType Theory\nTopos Theory\nRecursion theory\n\n\nPhilosophy of Science\nTopics in Formal Epistemology\nStructure for Semantics\nCategory Theory (see Structure on Models)\nProof Theory\nModel Theory (see Model Theory (Lecture))\n\nFirst Priority\n\nIntroduction to Philosophy of Language (see Horsten, L. I also order the courses for priority in each list and give the number of EC in parenthesis (avoiding double counting). Consider that this is meant to be a maximal list in which I count all courses I am interested in, there will most probably be relevant cuts before the Final Choice of Courses, The full list of courses and EC can be found here: Sheets: M.Sc. Logic Courses Plan under ‚Äòmax. list‚Äô.\n1st Period\n\nPhilosophy of Science (6)\nCategory Theory (see Structure on Models) (8)\nMeaning, Reference and Modality (6)\nIntroduction to Philosophy of Language (see Horsten, L. (2010), Having an Interpretation, The Frequency of Telling Stories) (6)\n\n2nd Period\n\nProof Theory (6)\nCategory Theory (see Structure on Models) (\\uparrow)\nTopics in Modal Logic (6)\nPhilosophical Logic (6)\nOntology: Historical Perspectives (6)\nPhilosophy of Cognition (6)\nPhilosophy of Logic (6)\n\nExemption from Mandatory Courses\nI suppose to be exempted from the two mandatory courses: Introduction to Modal Logic &amp; Mathematical Proof Methods for Logic, here I list the relevant courses I followed in the fields:\nRegarding Introduction to Modal Logic I followed Modal Logic (Lecture), a course of the Master in Philosophy of Science and Logic at the MCMP at the LMU and got 1.3 (1.0 is the best and 4.0 the worst mark).\nReading the Mathematical Proof Methods for Logic content I see all points were either already covered in the very first course in logic (i.e. Logic I at the LMU) or taught the Model Theory (Lecture). Other relevant courses are Philosophy of Logic (see What a Logic Could not Be) and also the Seminar in Mathematical Logic by Prof. Schwichtenberg in which we learned how to use minlog. In particular three points have been presented as the core of the course Completeness &amp; Soundness which I had in the basic logic course for classical logic and have seen for a decent amount of modal logics too in Modal Logic (Lecture); then Mathematical Induction which is given as obvious for any of the mathematical courses I gave in the last year, it has been first presented both in Analysis I and Linear Algebra I; and finally Categoricity &amp; Definability which I have seen in depth in Model Theory (Lecture), also, regarding the characterisation of theories in particular see Structure on Models (or in particular notes on Halvorson, H. (2012), What Scientific Theories Could not Be &amp; Halvorson, H. (2013), The semantic view, if plausible, is syntactic).\nEven though I think to have all rights to be exempted from the two mandatory courses, I am wondering whether it is actually convenient to me to be exempted. In fact, even though it would free up time for other more interesting and advanced courses, taking these two courses will take very little time and, hopefully, guarantee me good marks. It still needs to be clarified whether exemption from these courses gives the respective credits or not.\nFinal Choice of Courses\nIn this section I write the final list of courses I follow in my 5th Semester. The presented solution is in line with the average of EC per semester, see Bachelors‚Äô Outline and Sheet: Academic Performance.\n1st Period\n\nPhilosophy of Science (6)\nCategory Theory (3) {8}\nMeaning, Reference and Modality (6)\nIntroduction to Philosophy of Language (6)\n\n\nMathematical Proof Methods for Logic (6)\nIntroduction to Modal Logic (2) {6}\nFor a total of 29EC, all exams of this period would be philosophical or elementary.\n\n2nd Period\n\nProof Theory (6)\nCategory Theory (see Structure on Models) (5){8}\nTopics in Modal Logic (6)\nPhilosophical Logic (6)\nOntology: Historical Perspectives (6)\n\n\nIntroduction to Modal Logic (4) {6}\nFor a total of 33EC\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/A-Topological-Approach-to-Infinite-Disjunctions":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/A-Topological-Approach-to-Infinite-Disjunctions","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/A Topological Approach to Infinite Disjunctions.md","title":"A Topological Approach to Infinite Disjunctions","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Logic-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Topology,-Logic-and-Learning-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Research-Areas/Philosophy-of-Mathematics-and-Logic","Academia/Active--and--Works/Research-Areas/Formal-Epistemology"],"tags":[],"content":"I wrote this essay during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for the course Philosophy of Logic (Lecture). The essay is made available at Overleaf: A Topological Approach to Infinite Disjunctions. I have been influenced for the topic of this essay by the course Topology, Logic and Learning (Lecture) by Alexandru Baltag. This essay can both be regarded as part of Philosophy of Mathematics and Logic and of Formal Epistemology."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/An-Axiomatic-Approach-to-the-Efficient-Market-Hypothesis":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/An-Axiomatic-Approach-to-the-Efficient-Market-Hypothesis","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/An Axiomatic Approach to the Efficient Market Hypothesis.md","title":"2024-10-18","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/6th-Semester"],"tags":[],"content":"Talking with David K√ºhnenmann, course-mate of the M.Sc. Logic (UvA), I exposed an intention I had some time ago, that is to attempt to formalise the Efficient Market Hypothesis. This may turn out to be my essay for the course in Dynamic Epistemic Logic (during my 5th Semester), I might organise a little research project in that direction too (either at the same time with Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project) or during the 6th Semester). I would though try not to involve fields I have no knowledge of, like game theory or any financial mathematics, I will adopt an axiomatic approach based on some formal system I decide."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Category-Theory-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Category-Theory-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Category Theory (Lecture).md","title":"Category Theory (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Research-Areas/Category-Theory","System/Attachments/Yoneda_Naturality.jpeg"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by, Prof. Benno van den Berg during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA). A full description of the course can be found in the MasterMath website at link. I also collect other works I do in Category Theory.\nAssignments\n\nOverleaf: CatTh, 1\nOverleaf: CatTh, 2\nOverleaf: CatTh, 3\n\nI use q.uiver.app to draw the diagrams.\nLecture Notes\nCategory\n\nA cath. \\mathcal{C} is a tuple of:\n\n\\mathcal{C}_0 collection of objects of \\mathcal{C}\n\\mathcal{C}_1 of morphisms/arrows in \\mathcal{C}\n\nhence, for f \\in Mor(\\mathcal{C}), then dom(f), cod(f) \\in Ob(\\mathcal{C})\nf: A \\to B := f \\in Mor(\\mathcal{C}) \\land dom(f) = A \\in Ob(\\mathcal{C}) \\land cod(f) = B \\in OB(\\mathcal{C})\n\n\n\n\nhence, \\mathcal{C} is a directed-multi-graph\n\n\ns.t. \\forall_{A \\in Ob(\\mathcal{C})} \\exists_{1_A \\in Mor(\\mathcal{C})} 1_A: A \\to A\nif \\exists_{f: A \\to B} \\exists_{g: B \\to C} \\top \\to \\exists_{g \\circ f: A \\to C} \\top\n\ns.t. f \\circ 1_A = f = 1_B \\circ f and h \\circ (g \\circ f) = (h \\circ g ) \\circ f\n\n\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni f: A \\to B\n\nf epi if \\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0}\\forall_{\\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni g, h: B \\to C} gf = hf \\to g = h\nf mono if \\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0}\\forall_{\\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni g, h: C \\to B} fg= fh \\to g = h\n\n\nA category is uniquely defined by:\n\nOb(C) a class\nMor(\\mathcal{C}) a class of the form \\{(A_1, B_1), ...\\} for A_i \\in Ob(\\mathcal{C})\n\\circ: Mor(\\mathcal{C}) \\times Mor(\\mathcal{C}) \\to Mor(\\mathcal{C})\n\nby ex.1 specifying what is the identity of each object, is not necessary, since they‚Äôre unique\n\n\n\n\n\\mathcal{C} is loc.small if ZFC \\models \\forall_{A, B \\in Ob(\\mathcal{C})}\\exists_{x} x = Mor(A, B)\n\\mathcal{C} is small if Ob(\\mathcal{C}) and Mor(\\mathcal{C}) are sets.\na Monoid is a one-obj. loc.small category\na small category without parallel arrows is a preorder\n\nwrite A \\le B if \\exists_{f: A \\to B} \\top.\nby def. of cat. given above, &quot;\\le&quot; is trans. and refl.\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{C} cat., f: A \\to B is iso. if ex. g: B \\to A s.t. g \\circ f = 1_A \\land f \\circ g = 1_B\n\ng is unique and called the inverse of f\n\n\nHom_{\\mathcal{C}}(A, B) all arrows from A to B, (homset)\nf : A \\to B is split.epi if ex g: B \\to A s.t. fg = 1_B\n\n(g is called a section of f, and f a retraction of g)\n\n\nfor P \\in \\mathcal{C}_0, P proj., if \\forall_{X, Y \\in \\mathcal{C}_0}\\forall_{\\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni f: P \\to X, g: Y \\to X} \\text{epi.}(g) \\to \\exists_{\\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni h: P \\to X} g\\circ h = f\n\nFunctor\n\nA functor F, is F_0: \\mathcal{C}_0 \\to \\mathcal{D}_0 and F_1: \\mathcal{C}_1 \\to \\mathcal{D}_1 s.t.:\n\n\\forall_{f: X \\to Y} F_1(f) : F_0(X) \\to F_0(Y)\n\\forall_{f, g \\in \\mathcal{C}_1}((X \\to^f Y \\to^g Z) \\to F_1(gf) = F_1(g) F_1(f))\n\\forall_{X \\in \\mathcal{C}_0}F_1(1_X) = 1_{F_0(X)}\n\n\nFunctors preserve isomorphisms, 2.3\nA Functor preserves a property P if \\forall_{x \\in \\mathcal{C}_0 \\cup \\mathcal{C}_1} P(F(x)) \\to P(x), 2.4\nfor F let \\forall_{A, B \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} F_{A, B}: \\mathcal{C}(A, B) \\to \\mathcal{D}(F(A), F(B)):\n\nif surj. F is full\nif inj. F if faithful\n\nif F faithful, then F reflects epsi and monos. 2.6\n\n\nif bij. F is fully faithful\n\n\nProduct Category: \\mathcal{C} \\times \\mathcal{D}\n\nOb(\\mathcal{C} \\times \\mathcal{D}) := \\{(C_0, D_0): C_0 \\in Ob(\\mathcal{C}) \\land D_0 \\in \\mathcal{D}\\}\nHom_{\\mathcal{C}\\times \\mathcal{D}}((C_0, D_0),(C_1, D_1)) := Hom_\\mathcal{C}(C_0, C_1) \\times Hom_\\mathcal{D}(D_0, D_1))\n(g_0, g_1) \\circ (f_0, f_1) := (g_0 \\circ f_0, g_1 \\circ f_1)\n\n\nOpposite Category: \\mathcal{C}^{op}\n\nOb(\\mathcal{C}^{op}) := Ob(\\mathcal{C})\nHom_{\\mathcal{C}^{op}}(A, B) := Hom_{\\mathcal{C}}(B, A)\ng \\circ_{\\mathcal{C}^{op}} f := f \\circ_{\\mathcal{C}} g\n\n\nDuality principle: of any definition, I can always find a dual (co-)\n\ninitial / terminal object\n\nTerminal objects are unique up to unique isomorphism\n\n\nf: A \\to B is a mono iff. fg = fh \\to g = h\n\nmono are ‚Äúoften‚Äù inj.func\n\nproved for \\textbf{Set}\nin \\textbf{Cat}: F mono iff. F inj.on.obj. and faithful, ex.1\n\n\n\n\nf: A \\to B is epi iff. gf = hf \\to g = h\n\nepi are ‚Äúoften‚Äù surj.func\n\nproved for \\textbf{Set}\nin \\textbf{Cat}: F surj.onobj. and full \\Rightarrow F full., ex.1\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFunctorial Structures\n\nExample: R a ring, M_2(R) the 2 \\times 2 matrixes with components in R,\n\nis M_2: \\textbf{Ring} \\to \\textbf{Ring}, f: R \\to S, M_2(f) : M_2(R) \\to M_2(S), M_s(f) \\left(\\begin{smallmatrix} a,\\; b\\\\ c, \\; d \\end{smallmatrix}\\right) =  \\left(\\begin{smallmatrix} f(a), f(b)\\\\ f(c), f(d) \\end{smallmatrix}\\right)\n\n\nF: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D}, if \\alpha \\in \\mathcal{C}_1 iso, then F(\\alpha) iso.\n\n\n\nNatural Transformation\n\nfor \\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D} ex. [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}] cat. s.t. [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}]_0 = Hom_{\\textbf{Cat}}(\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}), [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}]_1 are natural transformations\n\nfor F, G: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} a nat.tr. \\sigma : F \\Rightarrow G is a fam. of morph. \\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0}\\sigma_C : F(C) \\to G(C) s.t.\n\nfor \\forall_{C, C&#039; \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} \\exists_{\\alpha \\in Hom_\\mathcal{C}(C, C&#039;)} Diag.Comm., (Naturality Condition)\n\nDiag: F(C) \\to^{F(\\alpha)}FC&#039; \\to^{\\sigma_{C&#039;}} G(C&#039;) and F(C) \\to^{\\sigma_C} G(C) \\to^{G(\\alpha)} G(C&#039;)\n\n\n\n\nif \\sigma: F \\Rightarrow G in [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}] is iso. iff \\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} iso.(\\sigma_C)\n\\circ: [\\mathcal{D}, \\mathcal{E}] \\times [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}] \\to [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{E}], functor composition is the object part of a functor (see diag), 3.3\n\n\n\nEquivalence of Categories\n\n\\mathcal{C} \\simeq \\mathcal{D} if there are functors F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D}, G: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} s.t.\n\nG \\circ F \\cong 1_\\mathcal{C} \\in [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{C}]_0\nF \\circ G \\cong 1_\\mathcal{D} \\in [\\mathcal{D}, \\mathcal{D}]_0\n\n\nit is called equivalence and G is the pseudo-inverse\nalso \\cong is natural isomorphism of categories\n\n\nEquivalence preserves and reflects terminal objects (and most other properties)\nF: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} is an equivalence iff:, 3.6\n\nF is essentially surjective and‚Ä¶\n\nthat is: \\forall_{D \\in \\mathcal{D}_0} \\exists_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} F_0(C) \\cong D\n\n\n‚Ä¶ F is fully faithful\n\nF is full and faithful\n\n\n\n\n\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}, \\mathcal{E} sm.cat., \\mathcal{D} \\simeq \\mathcal{E} \\to [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}] \\simeq [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{E}], ex.2.2\n\nLimits\n\nfor F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} , a cone is (D, \\mu) s.t.  D \\in \\mathcal{D}_0, nat.tr. \\mu: \\Delta_D \\Rightarrow F (cone), s.t.\n\n(\\mu_C: D \\to F(C): C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0) with nat.req.,  4.1\n\n\n\\Delta_D : \\mathcal{C}\\ \\to \\mathcal{D}, if \\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} (\\Delta_D)_0(C) = D and \\forall_{f \\in \\mathcal{C}_1}(\\Delta_D)_0 = 1_D\nfor D \\in \\mathcal{D}_0, \\Delta_g: \\Delta_D \\to \\Delta_{D&#039;} s.t. (\\Delta_g)_C = g\n\nhence \\Delta: \\mathcal{D} \\to [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}]\n\n\n\n\n(D, \\mu) \\to (D&#039;, \\mu&#039;), is a map g: D \\to D&#039; s.t. \\mu&#039; \\circ \\Delta_g = \\mu (map of cones), 4.1\na lim.cone for F is term.obj of Cone(F) (limiting cone). 4.2\na lim.con for !: \\textbf{0} \\to \\mathcal{D} is term.obj. in \\mathcal{D}\n\nCone(!) \\cong \\mathcal{D}\n\n\nProduct Category 4.1.2\n\nlet F: \\mathbf{2} \\to \\mathcal{D}, a product is the vertex of the limiting cone, called (A \\times B, \\pi).\n\\mathbf{2} only has elements A, B and only reflexive arrows.\n\n\nEqualizer 4.1.3\n\nfor F: \\mathbf{\\hat{2}} \\to \\mathcal{D} let (D, \\mu) be a cone, if it is limiting \\mu_A is an equalizer.\n\nD \\to^{\\mu_A} A \\to^{f, g} B.\n\n\n\\mathbf{\\hat{2}} is A \\to^{f, g} b\n\n\nPullbacks: 4.1.4\n\nfor F: J \\to \\mathcal{D}, a let (W, p) be the lim.cone, its diagram is the pullback diagram\nJ has x, y, z as objects and arrows y \\to^b z and x \\to^a z.\n\n\n\\mathcal{C} has lim.of.sh. \\mathcal{I} if \\forall_{F: \\mathcal{I} \\to \\mathcal{C}} \\exists_{(D,\\mu \\in Cone(F))} \\text{lim.cone.}(D, \\mu), 4.3\nif \\mathcal{C} is s.t. \\forall_{\\text{sm.cat}(\\mathcal{I})} \\mathcal{C} \\text{ lim.of.sh}(\\mathcal{I}) it is said complete.\n\nif only on all \\mathcal{I} s.t. |\\mathcal{I}_0| &lt; \\aleph_0 it is fin.compl.\n\nfin.compl.cat are also called lex, left exact or cartesian.\n\n\n\\mathcal{C} has ‚Ä¶\n\nprod. if complete on all F: \\mathbf{2} \\to \\mathcal{C}\nequal. if complete on all F: \\mathbf{\\hat{2}} \\to \\mathcal{C}\npullb. if complete on all F: J \\to \\mathcal{C}\n\n\nfor M: \\mathcal{I} \\to \\mathcal{C}, and (C, \\mu)_M lim.cone, say it preserved by F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} if (F(C), F\\mu) lim.con, 4.4\n\nF\\mu := \\{F(\\mu_I): I \\in \\mathcal{I}_0\\}\nF pres.lim.of.shape.\\mathcal{I} if it preserves every lim.cone of G: \\mathcal{I} \\to \\mathcal{C}\n\nit preserves small/finite limits if it preserves limits of shape \\mathcal{I} for each \\mathcal{I} small/finite.\n\n\n\n\n\n\ncomplete categories:\n\nsets, top, grps, ring, ab.gr, vs. over a fixed field, cat. (fields are not!)\n\n\nColimits 4.2\na colimiting cocone for F is a limiting cone for F^{op}.\n\n(\\nu, D)_F s.t. \\nu: F \\Rightarrow \\Delta_D init.obj. in Cocone(F).\na colimiting cocone for F: \\mathbf{2} \\to \\mathcal{C}, denoted A + B or A \\sqcup B\n\\mathcal{C} is cocomplete if all \\mathcal{I} small have colimits of for diagrams \\mathcal{I} \\to C.\n\n\ncoprod. of proj. is proj., ex.3.1.b\n\nComplete Categories\n\nif \\mathcal{C} has small products and equalizers, then \\mathcal{C} is complete, 5.1\n\nalso for &lt; k for k a cardinal\nalso co- version\n\n\nif \\mathcal{C} has term.obj and pullb. it has binary prod. and equal, 5.3\ntfae: 5.4\n\n\\mathcal{C} fin.compl.\n\\mathcal{C} has fin.prod. and equil.\n\\mathcal{C} has pullb. and a term.obj.\n\n\n\\mathcal{D} has lim.of.sh.\\mathcal{I}, then so does any [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}], 5.5\n\n\\forall_{\\mathcal{C}}\\text{compl.}(\\mathcal{D})\\to\\text{compl.}([\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}])\n\n\nfor F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} an equiv. and \\mathcal{I} a cat., F preserves and reflects limits of \\mathcal{I}, 5.6\nif \\mathcal{D} complete has lim.of.sh.\\mathcal{I}, does \\mathcal{C}\n\n\\text{compl.}(\\mathcal{D}) \\land \\text{equiv.}(F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D}) \\to \\text{compl.}(\\mathcal{C}\n\n\nif \\text{small.}(\\mathcal{C}) \\land \\text{compl.}(\\mathcal{C}), then \\mathcal{C} is a preorder\n\nCartesian Closed Categories\n\nin \\mathbf{Set}, for \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni f: X \\to Y mono:\n\nX, Y \\in \\mathcal{C}_0 are iso. if \\exists_{f, g \\in \\mathcal{C}_1} f: X \\to Y \\land g: Y \\to X \\land \\text{mono.}(f) \\land \\text{mono.}(g)\nfor f: X \\to Y, there is a coproduct diagram with f and g: Z \\to Y\ngiven the AC, every epi is split.\n\n\nExponentials: for \\mathcal{C} and X, Y \\in \\mathcal{C}_0, X \\times Y and 1_X are distinguished\n\nX^Y \\in \\mathcal{C}_0, \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni ev: X^Y \\times Y \\to X s.t. \\forall_{A \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} \\forall_{\\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni h: A \\times Y \\to X} \\exists!_{ \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni H : A \\to X^Y} ev \\circ (H \\times 1_Y) = h, 6.1\n\nequivalently \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C}(A, X^Y) \\to \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C}(A \\times Y , X) : H \\mapsto ev \\circ( H \\times 1_y) is a bij.\n\n\n\\mathcal{C} is ccc if it has fin.prod. and every X^Y exists.\nin \\mathbf{Cat} ccc holds with \\mathcal{D}^\\mathcal{C} := [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}], ev_0(F, C) = F(C), ev_1(\\sigma, f) = \\sigma_C(f)\n\n(note, nat.tr. are precisely such \\sigma)\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{C} with fin.prod., is called exponentiable if all exponentials exists\n6.6?\n\n\nNatural Numbers Object\n\nin \\mathcal{C} with term.obj. 1, a nat.num.obj. is (0, N, S) \\in \\mathcal{C}_1 \\times \\mathcal{C}_0 \\times \\mathcal{C}_1 s.t.:\n\n1 \\to^0 N, N \\to^S N\n\\forall_{1 \\to^x X \\to^f X} \\exists!_{\\varphi: N \\to X}\\text{diag.comm.}\n\n\nin \\mathcal{C} with ccc and nat.num.obj. (0, N, S) call f: N^k \\to N a num.th.fun. corresponding to F: \\mathbb{N}^k \\to \\mathbb{N} if \\forall_{(n_1, ..., n_k) \\in \\mathbb{N}^k}f \\circ \\langle S^{n_1}, ..., S^{n_k} \\rangle = S^{F(n_1, ..., n_k)}\n\nPA can be done within this frame\n\n\n\n\n\nPresheaves\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{C} sm.cat., the presh.\\mathcal{C} is \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}:=[\\mathcal{C}^{op}, \\mathbf{Set}], 7.1\n\n\\hat{\\mathcal{C}} is complete and cocomplete, limits calculated pointwise\nfor \\mathcal{D} with pullb., \\sigma \\in [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}]_0 is mono iff \\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} \\text{mono.}(\\sigma_C), 7.3\n\nfor \\mathcal{D} with pusho., \\sigma \\in [\\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D}]_0 is epi iff \\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0}\\text{epi.}(\\sigma_C)\n\n\n\n\n\nYoneda Lemma: 7.2\n\nfor \\mathcal{C} loc.sm.cat, \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C}: \\mathcal{C}^{op} \\times \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathbf{Set}, hence \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C}(A, B) \\in \\mathbf{Set}\nalso, for (\\mathcal{C}^{op} \\times \\mathcal{C})_1 \\ni (f, g): (A, B) \\to (A&#039;, B&#039;), \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C}(A, B) \\to \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C}(A&#039;, B&#039;) s.t. (h: A \\to B) \\mapsto g \\circ h \\circ f: A&#039; \\to B&#039;.\nsince \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}} is an exp.cat., \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C} corresponds to y: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}}\n\nsince y: \\mathcal{C} \\to [\\mathcal{C}^{op}, \\mathbf{Set}], first take C \\in \\mathcal{C}, then D \\in \\mathcal{C}^{op}.\nso, for C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0, we have (y_C)(D) := (y(C))(D) = \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{C}(D, C)\nand, for \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni f: D \\to D&#039;, get (y_C)(D&#039;) \\to (y_C)(D), comp.w. f\nand, for \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni g: C \\to C&#039;, get \\mathcal{C}_2 \\ni y_g: y_C \\to y_{C&#039;} s.t. (y_g)_D: (y_C)(D) \\to (y_{C&#039;})(D), com.w. g\n\n\n\\forall_{F \\in [\\mathcal{C}^{op}, \\mathbf{Set}]_0}\\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} \\text{bij.}(\\alpha_{C, F}: \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}}(y_C, F) \\to F(C)), (\\sigma: y_C\\to F) \\to (\\sigma_C)(1_C) s.t. (Yoneda)\n\nfor \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni g: C&#039; \\to C, \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}} \\ni \\mu F \\Rightarrow F, diag.com. Yoneda_Naturality.jpeg (Naturality)\n\\mathcal{C}(C, C&#039;):= \\{f \\in \\mathcal{C}_1: f: C \\to C&#039;\\}, 7.4\n\n\nhence, \\alpha os a nat.iso. s.t. (\\mathcal{C}^{op} \\times \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}} \\to^{ev} \\mathbf{Set}) \\cong^\\alpha \\mathcal{C}^{op} \\times \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}} \\to^{y \\times 1}(\\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}})^{op} \\times \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}} \\to^{\\text{Hom}} \\mathbf{Set}\nX \\in \\hat{\\mathcal{C}} is repr. if \\exists_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}} X \\cong y_C, 7.5\nfor X \\in \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}, y \\downarrow X is a comm.cat. if\n\n(y \\downarrow X)_0 := \\{(C, \\mu): C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0 \\land \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}_1 \\ni \\mu: y_C \\to X\\}\n(y \\downarrow X)_1 := \\{(C,\\mu) \\to (C&#039;, \\nu) |f: c \\to C&#039; \\land \\nu \\circ y_f = \\mu\\}\n\n\nU_X: y\\downarrow X\\to\\mathcal{C}, (C, \\mu) \\mapsto C, f \\mapsto f\ny\\circ U_X: y \\downarrow X \\to \\mathbf{Set}^{\\mathcal{C}^{op}}, recall \\Delta_X: y \\downarrow X \\to \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}\n\\rho_X: y \\circ U_X \\to \\Delta_X\n(X, \\rho_X) is colimiting cocone in \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}, 7.6\n\nevery presheaf is a colimit of representables\n\n\n\\hat{F}:=F \\circ U_X, so \\hat{F}: y \\downarrow X \\to \\mathcal{D}\ny is inj. and fully faithful, 7.7\n\n\n\\hat{\\mathcal{C}} is ccc\n\nas an example of limit, take the exponentials\n\nfor C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0, Y^X(C) := \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}(y_C \\times X, Y)\nfor \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni f: C \\to C&#039;, Y^X(f): Y^X(C) \\to Y^ X(C&#039;) ?\n\n\n\n\n\\forall_{X \\in \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}_0} \\exists_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} X \\cong y_C \\to \\text{proj.}(X), ex.3.1.c\na presh is proj. iff it is a retract of a copr. of repres.\n\n\n\nPresheaves as a Topos\n\na topos is a ccc.w.fin.lim with a subobject classifier\nfor \\mathcal{E} cat.fin.lim. a subo.cl. is a t: T \\to \\Omega s.t.:\n\nt is mono\n\\forall_{m \\in \\mathcal{E}_1} \\text{mono.}(m) \\to \\exists!_{\\mathcal{E} \\ni \\phi:¬†B \\to \\Omega} t \\circ \\psi = \\phi \\circ m\n\n\\phi is classifies m, or the subobject represented by m\nsince t is mono, there is a unique such \\psi too.\n\n\n\n\nhence, T is terminal, 8.3\ncall t: T \\to \\Omega subo.cl. or also just \\Omega\n\n\nfor X \\in \\mathcal{E}_0, def. \\{\\mathcal{E}_1 \\ni f: A \\to X | A \\in \\mathcal{E}_0 \\land \\text{mono.}(f)\\} and order\n\n(m: A \\to X) \\le (n: B \\to X):= \\exists_{\\mathcal{E}_1 \\ni k: A \\to B}n \\circ k = m\n\nk is then unique and mono, 8.4\n\n\n\n\nfor k iso, we get eq.classes which we call subo., write \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(X)\n\nif \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(X) is a set, call \\mathcal{E} well-powered, this we assume for \\mathcal{E}.\n\n\nin \\mathbf{Set}, if m: A \\to X inj., A \\cong Im(m) \\subseteq X\nfor \\mathcal{E}_1 \\ni f: Y \\to X, f^*: \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(X) \\to \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(Y)\n\nf^* \\in \\mathbf{Cat}_1 and monotone\nif \\mathcal{E} small, \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}: \\mathcal{E}^{op} \\to \\mathbf{Set}\nhaving a subo.cl. is eq. to saying that \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E} is repr.\nhence, \\text{Sub}(-): \\mathcal{E}^{op} \\to \\mathbf{Set}, A \\mapsto \\text{Sub}(A), f \\mapsto f^* lec.10.1.5:36\n\\mathcal{E} has subo.cl. if \\text{Sub}(-) is representable lec.10.1.6:19\n\nex. \\Omega \\in \\mathcal{E}_0 s.t. \\mathcal{E}(-, \\Omega) \\cong \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(-) nat.iso.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nfor A \\in \\mathcal{E}_0, A is pow.obj. of X \\in \\mathcal{E}_0 if \\mathcal{E}(Y, A) \\cong \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(X \\times Y) s.t.\n\n\\mathcal{E}_1 \\ni f: Y \\to A, g: Z \\to Y and f corr. to the subo. U of X \\times Y, then fg: Z \\to A corr. to the subo. (id_X \\times g)^*(U) of X \\times Z.\n\ncorrespondence is given by the subo.cl.,\n\n\n\n\nnote \\mathcal{E}(Y, A), \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(X \\times Y) \\in \\mathbf{Set}_0, hence &quot;\\cong&quot; only requires a bij.\npow.obj. are unique up to iso., usually denoted with \\mathcal{P}(X)\n\n\nSubobject Classifiers in Presheaves\nif X \\in \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}_0, a subpresh Y of X is s.t.:\n\n\\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0} Y(C) \\subseteq X(C)\n\\forall_{f \\in \\mathcal{C}_1} Y(f) = X(f)|_{Y(cod(f))}\n\n\nlet \\text{SubPSh}_\\mathcal{C}(X) be the set of all supresh. on \\mathcal{C} of X\n\n\n\\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{C} (X) \\cong \\text{SubPSh}_\\mathcal{C}(X)\nlet \\Omega s.t. \\Omega(C) \\in \\text{SubPSh}_{\\hat{\\mathcal{C}}}(y_C), \\Omega(f) is defined by pulling back along y_f\n\nif R is a sieve on C, then R \\ni f: C&#039; \\to C \\to \\forall_{g: C&#039;&#039; \\to C&#039;} fg = y_C(g)(f) \\in R\nR\\leftrightsquigarrow \\Omega(C) \\in \\text{SubPSh}_{\\hat{\\mathcal{C}}}(y_C)\nfor R\\ni f: C&#039; \\to C, f^*(R) = \\{g: D \\to C&#039; | fg \\in R_C\\}\nhence \\Omega = \\{R : \\text{sieve.on.}C(R) \\}, \\Omega(f)(R) = f^*(R)\nt: 1 \\to \\Omega, 1(C) \\mapsto \\text{max.sieve.on.}C\n\n\\text{max.sieve.on.}C is the unique one containing id_C\n\n\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{E} a topos, we have \\text{Hom}_{\\mathcal{E}}(Y, \\Omega^X) \\cong \\text{Hom}_\\mathcal{E}(X \\times Y, \\Omega) \\cong \\text{Sub}_\\mathcal{E}(C, \\times Y) natuarally in \\mathcal{E}.\n\nAdjunctions\n\n\\mathbf{Cat}_1¬†\\ni F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D}, G: \\mathcal{D} \\to \\mathcal{C}, an adj. is a nat.bij m or F \\dashv G s.t.:\n\n\\forall_{C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0}\\forall_{D \\in \\mathcal{D}_0} m_{C, D} :\\mathcal{D}(FC, D) \\to \\mathcal{C}(C, GD)\n\nhence maps \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni f: FD \\to C, \\mathcal{D}_1 \\ni g: D \\to GC are called transposes of each others\nwrite \\overline{f} := m(f) = g, note \\overline{\\overline{f}} = \\overline{g} = f.\n\n\n\\forall_{\\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni f : C \\to C&#039;}\\forall_{\\mathcal{D}_1 \\ni g: D \\to D&#039;}\\forall_{\\mathcal{D}_1 \\ni \\alpha:FC \\to D} Gg \\circ \\overline{\\alpha} \\circ f = \\overline{g \\circ \\alpha \\circ F f} (Naturality)\n\nthis is eq. to f =1, g = 1 s.t. Gg \\circ \\overline{\\alpha} = \\overline{g \\circ \\alpha} and \\overline{\\alpha} \\circ f = \\overline{\\alpha \\circ F f}.\n\n\n\n\nfor adj. as above, fix D \\in \\mathcal{C}_0, by nat. \\mathcal{C}^{op} \\to \\mathbf{Set}: C \\mapsto \\mathcal{D}(FC, D) is repr. by GD.\n\nby Yon. \\mathcal{D}_1 \\ni \\varepsilon_D = m^{-1}_{GD, D}: FGD \\to D, s.t. m^{-1}_{C, D}(\\beta) = \\varepsilon_D \\circ F \\beta\ndually: for C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0, \\eta_C = m_{C, FC}(1_{FC}: C \\to GFC) s.t. m_{C, D}(\\alpha) = G\\alpha \\circ \\eta_C\n\n\n\\{\\eta_C: C \\in \\mathcal{C}_0\\} \\rightsquigarrow (1_C \\Rightarrow GF) and \\{\\varepsilon_D : D \\in \\mathcal{D}_0\\} \\rightsquigarrow (FG \\Rightarrow 1_D), 9.2\n\ncall \\eta the unit and \\varepsilon the\nif m_{C,D} is inv. of m_{C, D}^{-1} iff G \\Rightarrow^{\\eta \\star G} GFG \\Rightarrow^{G \\circ \\varepsilon} G = 1_G and F \\Rightarrow^{F \\circ \\eta} FGF \\Rightarrow^{\\varepsilon \\star F} F = 1_F\n\n\\eta \\star G := \\{\\eta_{GD} | D \\in \\mathcal{D}_0\\} and G \\circ \\varepsilon := \\{G(\\varepsilon_D) | D \\in \\mathcal{D}_0\\}\n\n\n\n\nfor \\mathbf{Cat}_1¬†\\ni F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D}, G: \\mathcal{D} \\to \\mathcal{C}, \\eta: 1_\\mathcal{C} \\Rightarrow GF and \\varepsilon: FG \\Rightarrow 1_\\mathcal{D} s.t.\n\n(G \\circ \\varepsilon) \\cdot (\\eta \\star G) = 1_G\n(\\varepsilon \\star F) \\cdot ( F \\circ \\eta) = 1_F\n\n\nthen: F \\dashv G with \\eta unit and \\varepsilon counit, 9.3\n\n\nF: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} eq.cat. with G ps.inv, for \\mu: 1_\\mathcal{C} \\Rightarrow GF, \\nu: FG \\Rightarrow 1_\\mathcal{D}, then F \\dashv G with unit \\mu and one with counit \\nu (not nec. at the same time), 9.4\nif F \\dashv G then F pres.colim., G pres.lim.\n\nF pres. init.obj.\nif F has right.adj., let M: \\mathcal{E} \\to \\mathcal{C}, then \\hat{F}: \\text{Cocone}(M) \\to \\text{Cocone}(FM) has right.adj. too, 9.7\n\n\n\nMonads and Algebras\n\nfor F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} and F \\dashv G, let T = GF: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{C},\n\nnote nat.tr. \\eta: 1_\\mathcal{C} \\Rightarrow T\nalso \\mu: T^2 \\Rightarrow T, for \\mu_C = T^2(C) = GFGFC \\to^{G_{(\\varepsilon_{FC})}} GFC = T(C)\nsee diag. 10.1\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{C} cat, a monad is (T, \\eta, \\mu) s.t.:\n\nT: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{C}\n\\eta: 1_\\mathcal{C} \\Rightarrow T nat.tr.\n\\mu: T^2 \\Rightarrow T\nand s.t. 10.1 holds\n\n\nnote that it is in fact a monoid ?\n\n\nfor (T, \\eta, \\mu) on a cat. \\mathcal{C}, the cat. T-Alg is:\n\n(\\mathbf{Alg}_{\\mathcal{C}, T})_0:= \\{(X, h) | X \\in \\mathcal{C}_0 \\land \\mathcal{C}_1 \\ni h: (T(C) \\to X \\land T^2(C) \\to^{T(h)} T(X) \\to^h X = T^2(X) \\to^{\\mu_X} T(X) \\to^h X \\land X \\to^{\\eta_X} T(X) \\to^h X = 1_X\\}\n(\\mathbf{Alg}_{\\mathcal{C}, T})_1 := \\{(X, h) \\to (Y, k) | f: X \\to Y \\land f \\circ h = k \\circ T(f)\\}\n\n\nthere is an adj. F \\dashv G between \\mathcal{C} and \\mathbf{Alg}_{\\mathcal{C}, T} and it is ge. by T = GF., 10.4\nfor F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} and F \\dashv G, let K: \\mathcal{D} \\to \\mathbf{Alg}_{\\mathcal{C}, T} s.t.\n\nK_0(D) = (GFG(D) \\to^{G(\\varepsilon_D)} G(D))\nK_1(f: D \\to D&#039;) = G_1(f)\n\n\nnat. of \\varepsilon proves well-definability.\ncall G:\\mathcal{D} \\to \\mathcal{C} monadic (or that \\mathcal{D} over \\mathcal{C} is) if K is an equiv.\n\n\n\nPresheaves Revisited\n\nfor \\mathcal{C} sm.cat, let X \\in \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}_0 recall \\int_\\mathcal{C} X:= y \\downarrow X, call it category of elements.\nx: (y_C \\to X) \\leftrightsquigarrow x \\in X(C), we can then think of (C, x) \\in (\\int_\\mathcal{C} X)_0 with x \\in X(C)\nfor U: y\\downarrow X \\to \\mathcal{C} forg.fun., def. y \\circ U : y \\downarrow X \\to \\text{Psh}(\\mathcal{C})\n\n(X, \\rho) is a lim.cocone on y \\circ U, 11.2\n\\forall_{(C, x) \\in (y \\downarrow X)_0} \\exists_{(y \\downarrow X)_1 \\ni yU(C, x)} yU(C, x) = y_C \\to X = x\nevery presheaf is a colimit of representables\n\n\nKan Extensions\n\nfor \\mathcal{C} sm.cat., y: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\text{PSh}(\\mathcal{C}) is s.t.\n\n\\forall_{\\mathcal{E} \\in \\mathbf{Cat}_0}\\text{loc.sm.cat}(\\mathcal{E}) \\land \\text{cocom.}(\\mathcal{E})\\to \\forall_{\\mathbf{Cat}_1 \\ni F: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{E}} \\exists_{\\mathbf{Cat}_1 \\ni F_!: \\text{PSh}(\\mathcal{C}) \\to \\mathcal{E}} F_! \\circ y \\cong F, 11.3\n\n\ncall F_! the left Kan extension\n\n\nfor f: \\mathcal{C} \\to \\mathcal{D} for \\mathcal{C}, \\mathcal{D} sm.cat., the prec.fun. f^*: \\hat{\\mathcal{D}} \\to \\hat{\\mathcal{C}}, f^*(Q)(C) = Q(fC), has both adj., 11.5\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Closure-Theory":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Closure-Theory","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Closure Theory.md","title":"Closure Theory","links":["System/Contacts/Contacts","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Closure-Theory"],"tags":[],"content":"This page is about a field of mathematics which should exist but which I did not hear about yet, if anyone reading this page has ever heard about literature in a field that has even some similarities with this, please contact me, Contacts.\nFor now I limit myself to write no more than The Intuition in the hope that I will encounter literature directly facing these issues soon; if that will turn out not to be the case, I will then provide some formalisms to the intuition.\nThe Intuition\nA closure is a function that takes as input a structure and an operation on a subset of the underlying set of the structure and outputs what is commonly known as the closure of that structure under the given operation.\nExamples of such closures are numerous in mathematical practice, very often one is explicitly required to close graphs and algebraic structures under some given operations. Often this turns out to be trivial but many cases, especially in those involving more closures in a row, this may get tricky.\nIn particular, there are some operations and classes of structures that always admit a closure, like transitivity and graphs. There are some closures which open the set under other operations, for instance, if we take a graph and close it first under transitivity and then close it under symmetry, we may have opened it again under the transitivity operation. This shows that sometimes the order in which one closes a structure could make a difference and that, sometimes, only repetitions allow for an actual closure under multiple operations. It is admissible, that there are some operations whose closure is incompatible, i.e. there is no order nor (finite?) repetitions of closures such that the underlying set is closed under all operations.\nFrom this handful of imprecise observations, the reader should only share with me the feeling that if some mysterious dynamics in history of mathematics prevented this field to see the light, then it certainly should now!\nSome Definitions\nBefore getting to the definition of a Closure, I need to have some structures. I conceive in fact the to be a function on structures. There may be technique to generalise a closure to broader classes of structures, for now, I take some specific kinds of structures.\nA closable structure \\mathfrak{C} = (C, \\circ) is tuple of C a set and \\circ an operation.\nList of Potentially Related Fields\n\nMagma Algebra\nFixed Points\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/De-Re-Knowledge-of-Arbitrary-Objects":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/De-Re-Knowledge-of-Arbitrary-Objects","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/De Re Knowledge of Arbitrary Objects.md","title":"De Re Knowledge of Arbitrary Objects","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-in-the-US","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-in-the-EU--and--UK","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Others/Cohen,-M.,-Tang,-W.,-Wang,-Y.-(2021),-De-Re-Updates","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Others/Wang,-Y.,-Wei,-Y.,-Seligman,-J.-(2022),-Quantifier-free-epistemic-term-modal-logic-with-assignment-operator","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Leon-Horsten/Horsten,-L.-(2019),-The-Metaphysics-and-Mathematics-of-Arbitrary-Objects","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Alexandru-Baltag/Baltag,-A.-(2016),-To-Know-is-to-Know-the-Value-of-a-Variable"],"tags":[],"content":"The current state of the project can be found here: Overleaf.\n\nIf I will be particularly satisfied with the outcome of the paper I will consider submitting it to the Dynamic Logic Conference (or ECSQARU 2025, unict) by the 31st January 2025. If I will decide to do so, I will need to update my PhD Applications in the US  &amp; PhD Applications in the EU &amp; UK.\nLiterature\nBefore writing down any of the claims I have on the topic, I find a list of papers I want to read to have a clear and concrete idea of the current developments in the field.\n\nCohen, M., Tang, W., Wang, Y. (2021), De Re Updates\nWang, Y., Wei, Y., Seligman, J. (2022), Quantifier-free epistemic term-modal logic with assignment operator\nHorsten, L. (2019), The Metaphysics and Mathematics of Arbitrary Objects\nBaltag, A. (2016), To Know is to Know the Value of a Variable\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Dynamic-Epistemic-Logic-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Dynamic-Epistemic-Logic-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Dynamic Epistemic Logic (Lecture).md","title":"Dynamic Epistemic Logic (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/De-Re-Knowledge-of-Arbitrary-Objects"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by, Prof. Baltag during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA). A full description of the course can be found here. My solutions to the assignments are available at: Overleaf: DEL. Logic (UvA) held by Yurii Khomskii. Here you can find the main page of the project and the three resources we used (note on notation):\n\nKunen, K. Logic (UvA). I covered most of the material already in Modal Logic (Lecture). The notes are from the book: Modal Logic by P. Blackburn, M. de Rijke, Y. Venema, (2010), Cambridge University Press.\nAs general material I produced or used while following the course, I leave here some incomplete Lecture Notes, I give here also the links to the Assignments and to Final Exam‚Äôs Solutions.\nAssignments\n\nOverleaf: IML, 1\nOverleaf: IML, 2\nOverleaf: IML, 3\nOverleaf: IML, 4\nOverleaf: IML, 5\n\nLecture Notes\n\nBisimilarity &amp; Invariance Lemma, as in: 3. Expressive Power and Invariance.\n\nconverse of invariance lemma holds with n-bisimilarity for n \\in \\mathbb{N}. (see 2.24)\n\\mathcal{M} = (M, R, V) is image finite if \\forall_{x \\in M} |R[x]| &lt; \\aleph_0\n\nR[x] := \\{y \\in M : x R y\\}\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{M}, \\mathcal{M}&#039; image finite, \\forall_{x \\in M}\\forall_{x&#039; \\in M&#039;} \\mathcal{M}, x \\equiv \\mathcal{M}&#039;, x&#039; \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M}, x \\underline{\\leftrightarrow}\\mathcal{M}&#039;, x&#039; (Hennessy - Milner)\n\n\\equiv often written as \\leftrightsquigarrow\n\\mathcal{M}, x \\equiv \\mathcal{M}&#039;, x&#039; \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M}, x \\underline{\\leftrightarrow}\\mathcal{M}&#039;, x&#039; often written as x \\equiv x&#039; \\Rightarrow x \\underline{\\leftrightarrow} x&#039;.\n\n\n[for k \\in ON the maximal complexity of a formula in \\mathcal{L}^k_{ML}, a k-inductively defined modal logic, then \\forall_{x \\in M}\\forall_{x&#039; \\in M&#039;} \\mathcal{M}, x \\equiv \\mathcal{M}&#039;, x&#039; \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M}, x \\underline{\\leftrightarrow}^k \\mathcal{M}&#039;, x&#039; for \\underline{\\leftrightarrow}^k the k-bisimulation, as defined in: Overleaf: IML, 1]\n\n\n\nTypes (from the Book)\n\n\\tau = (O, \\rho) is a modal similarity type for O \\not = \\emptyset, \\rho: O \\to \\mathbb{N}, 1.11\n\nelements of O are modal operators\n\nuse \\triangle_0, \\triangle_1, ... to denote its elements.\n\nfor i \\in \\mathbb{N}, \\triangledown_i(\\varphi_1, ..., \\varphi_n) := \\lnot \\triangle_i (\\lnot \\varphi_1, ..., \\lnot \\varphi_n)\n\n\n\n\n\\rho assigns to each operator \\triangle a finite arity.\n\n\nML(\\tau, \\Phi) is a modal language for \\tau = (O, \\rho) and a set of prop.lett \\Phi, 1.12\n\nForm(\\tau, \\Phi) is given by \\langle p | \\bot | \\lnot \\varphi | \\varphi_1 \\land \\varphi_2 | \\triangle (\\varphi_1, ..., \\varphi_{\\rho(\\triangle)}) \\rangle\n\n\n\\tau-type at w is \\{\\varphi : \\mathcal{M}, w \\models\\varphi\\}, 2.1\n\ntwo \\tau-types at w and w&#039;, for w \\in M, w&#039; \\in M&#039;, s.t. \\mathcal{M}, \\mathcal{M}&#039; have same mod.sim.type \\tau, write w \\leftrightsquigarrow w&#039; if \\tau-type.w is \\tau-type.w&#039;.\n\\mathcal{M} \\leftrightsquigarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039; iff \\bigcap_{w \\in M} \\{\\varphi : \\mathcal{M}, w \\models\\varphi\\} = \\bigcap_{w&#039; \\in M&#039;} \\{\\varphi : \\mathcal{M}&#039;, w&#039; \\models\\varphi\\}\n\\mathcal{M} \\bigsqcup \\mathcal{N} preserves all information.\n\n\nfor \\tau mod.sim.type, \\mathcal{M}_i \\tau-models, then \\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{\\tau-ML}}\\forall_{i \\in I} \\forall_{w \\in M_i} \\mathcal{M}_i, w \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\bigcup_{i \\in I}\\mathcal{M}_i, w \\models \\varphi, 2.3\n\n17.09, Filtrations\n\nA (generated) submodel \\mathcal{M}&#039; of \\mathcal{M} is a model s.t.\n\nW&#039; \\subseteq W\nR&#039; = R \\cap (W&#039; \\times W&#039;)\nV&#039;(p) = V(p) \\cap W&#039;\n(4.) \\forall_{w \\in M&#039;} wRv \\to v \\in W&#039;\n\n\n\\mathcal{M&#039;} is gen.sub, of \\mathcal{M}, x \\in W&#039;, then \\mathcal{M}, x \\underline{\\leftrightarrow} \\mathcal{M}&#039;, x\n\n\n\\mathcal{M} is rooted if exists w \\in M, a root, that generates the whole model, 2.5\nMorphisms\n\nHomo- for \\mathcal{M}, \\mathcal{M}&#039; \\tau-models, f: \\mathcal{M} \\to \\mathcal{M}&#039; hom., if: , 2.7\n\n\\forall_{p \\in \\text{Prop}} \\forall_{w \\in W} w \\in V(p) \\to f(w) \\in V&#039;(p)\n\\forall_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}_0} \\forall_{\\triangle \\in \\tau} \\rho(\\triangle = n \\to \\forall_{W \\subseteq M} |W| = n +1 \\to W = (w_0, ..., w_n) \\in R_\\triangle \\to (f(w_0), ..., f(w_n)) \\in R_\\triangle&#039;\n\n\nModal formulas are not invariant under homomorphism, structure of the domain (source) is reflected in the image (target), not the riverse.\n\\forall_{w \\in M}\\forall_{w&#039; \\in M&#039;}\\exists_{f: \\mathcal{M} \\to \\mathcal{M}&#039;} f(w) = w&#039; \\Rightarrow (\\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML}} \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039;, w&#039; \\models \\varphi), 2.9\n\\mathcal{M} \\cong \\mathcal{M}&#039; \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M} \\leftrightsquigarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039;, 2.9\n\n\nBounded: if\n\n\\forall_{w \\in M} \\forall_{p \\in \\text{Prop}} \\mathcal{M}, w \\models p \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039;, f(w) \\models p\nf is homom. to R\n\\forall_{w \\in M} \\forall_{v&#039; \\in M&#039;} f(w) R v&#039; \\to \\exists_{v \\in M} wRv \\land f(v) = v&#039;\n\n\nlet f: \\mathcal{M} \\to \\mathcal{M}&#039; bound.morph., then \\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML}} \\forall_{w \\in M} \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039;, f(w) \\models \\varphi\n\nfor \\mathcal{M}, \\mathcal{M}&#039; models, f: W \\to W&#039; a bound.morph., then \\mathcal{M}, x \\underline{\\leftrightarrow} \\mathcal{M}&#039;, f(x)\n\n\n\n\nfor \\{\\mathcal{M}_i\\}_{i \\in I} for \\mathcal{M}_i model, the disj.union (On Disjoint Union) is a model \\mathcal{M} s.t.\n\nW := \\bigsqcup_{i \\in I} W_i, R = \\bigcup_{i \\in I} R_i, V(p) = \\bigcup_{i \\in I} V_i(p)\n\n\n\n\n5. Finite Model Property:\n\nModal Depth:\\is deg defined as follows:\n\n(i) deg(p) = 0, (ii) deg(\\bot) = 0, (iii) deg(\\lnot \\phi) = deg(\\phi), (iv) deg(\\phi \\land \\psi) = \\max\\{deg(\\phi), deg(\\psi)\\}\n(v) deg(\\triangle (\\phi_1, ..., \\phi_n)) = 1 + max\\{deg(\\phi_1), ..., deg(\\phi)_n\\}\n\n\nw \\underline{\\leftrightarrow}_n w&#039; i.e. bisimulate up to depth n.\n\nif, for \\text{Prop} \\subsetneq \\mathcal{L}_{ML}, |\\text{Prop}| &lt; \\aleph_0, then (\\forall_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\mathcal{M}, w \\underline{\\leftrightarrow}_n \\mathcal{M}&#039;, w&#039;) \\Leftrightarrow (\\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML}} \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039;, w&#039; \\models \\varphi), 2.30-1\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{M} rooted model in w, define:, 2.32\n\n\\forall_{w&#039; \\in M}ht(w&#039;) = 0 \\to w&#039; = w\n\\forall{w&#039; \\in M} ht(w&#039;) = n + 1 \\to \\exists_{w&#039;&#039; \\in M}ht(w&#039;&#039;) = n \\land w&#039;&#039; R w&#039;\n\n\nht(\\mathcal{M}) = \\max\\{ht(w&#039;) : w&#039; \\in M\\}\n\\mathcal{M}|_k = (M|_k, R|_k, V|_k)\n\nM|_k = \\{w&#039; \\in M : ht(w&#039;) \\le k\\}, R|_k = R|_{M|_k} and V|_k = V|_{M|_k}.\n\n\n\n\nif \\tau has only diamonds, \\phi is sat. iff sat. on a finite mode, 2.34\nFiltrations from 2.25\n\nfor \\Sigma \\subseteq \\mathcal{L}_{ML} cl.under subformulae, 2.36\nW_\\Sigma := \\{[x]: x \\in W\\}\n\n[x]_{(\\Sigma)} := \\{y \\in W : x \\leftrightsquigarrow_\\Sigma y\\}\n\nx \\leftrightsquigarrow_\\Sigma y := \\forall_{\\varphi\\in \\Sigma}(\\mathcal{M}, x \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}, y \\models \\varphi)\n\n\n\n\nthe filtration model \\mathcal{M}^f, 2.36\n\nW^f = W_\\Sigma\n\\forall_{x, y \\in M} xRy \\Rightarrow [x] R^f [y]\n\\forall_{x, y \\in M} ([x]R^f[y] \\Rightarrow \\forall_{\\lozenge \\varphi \\in \\Sigma}(\\mathcal{M}, y \\models \\varphi \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M}, x \\models \\lozenge \\varphi))\nV^f(p) = \\{[x]: \\mathcal{M}, x \\models p\\}\n\n\n\\forall_{\\Sigma \\subseteq \\mathcal{L}_{ML}} |\\Sigma| &lt; \\aleph_0 \\to\\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\Sigma}  \\forall_{x \\in W} \\mathcal{M}, x \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}^f, [x] \\models \\varphi, 2.39\n\n\\forall_{\\Sigma \\subseteq \\mathcal{L}_{ML}} |\\Sigma| &lt; \\aleph_0 \\to |M^f| \\le 2^{|\\Sigma|}, 2.38\nevery formula that is satisfiable, is satisfiable in a finite model, 2.41\n\nfor \\Sigma_\\phi the subformula-closure of \\{\\phi\\}.\n\n\n\n\nOne can always define filtration through:, 2.39\n\n[w] R^s [v] \\Leftrightarrow \\exists_{w&#039; \\in [w]} \\exists_{v&#039; \\in [v]} w&#039; R v&#039; (smallest)\n[w] R^l [v] \\Leftrightarrow (\\forall_{\\Diamond \\phi \\in \\Sigma} \\mathcal{M},v \\models \\phi \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M},w \\models \\Diamond \\phi) (largest)\n\n\nR^s \\subseteq R^f \\subseteq R^l\n[w] R^t [v] \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{\\Diamond \\phi \\in \\Sigma}(( \\mathcal{M}, v \\models \\phi \\land \\Diamond \\phi) \\to \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\Diamond \\phi)\n\nR trans. \\Rightarrow R^t trans.\nfor R trans., define C \\subseteq M, (C, R|_C, V|_C) (cluster), 2.43\n\na cluser is simple, if C = \\{c\\} s.t. cRc and proper if |C| \\ge 2.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n24.09, IV. Trees\n\na tree (T,S) is a frame s.t.\n\nT is rooted (i.e. \\forall_{t \\in T}\\exists!_{r \\in T} rS^*t)\n\nfor S^* the refl.trans.cl. of S\n\n\n\\forall_{t \\in T} t \\not = r \\to \\exists!_{t&#039; \\in T} t&#039; S t\n\\forall_{t \\in T} \\lnot t S^+ t\n\nfor S^+ the trans.cl. of S\n\n\n\n\nfor \\mathcal{M} = (W, R, V), ex. \\mathcal{T} = (T, S, V) s.t. f: T \\to V surj. bounded morphism.\na path in \\mathcal{M} is a seq. (r, u_1, ..., u_n) s.t. u_i R u_{i + 1}\n\nStandard Translation\n01.10, V. Frame Definability\n\na class of frames C is definable if there is a modal formula \\varphi s.t. \\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{F} \\in \\mathcal{C}.\nrecall bounded functions from 17.09, Filtrations.\n\nfor f bounded morphism, s.t. dom(f) = F, f(F)= G, then \\forall_{\\varphi \\in\\mathcal{L}_{ML}} \\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{G} \\models \\varphi.\n\n‚Äúmodally definable classes are closed under bounded morphisms.‚Äù\n\n\n\n\nrecall disjoint union from 17.09, Filtrations. We define it now for frames.\n\nfor C a definable class of frames: \\forall_{\\mathcal{F}, \\mathcal{G} \\in C} \\mathcal{F} \\bigsqcup \\mathcal{G} \\in C\n\n\nfor C FO.def.class of frames, then C is mod.def. iff. C is cl. under bounded morphic images, hgenerated subframes, disjoint unions and reflects untrafitler extensions (Goldlatt - Thomson Theorem)\n\nsee Model Theory (Lecture) for ultrafilters, but also First Bachelor Thesis Concept.\n\n\nL√∂b formula: \\square ( \\square p \\to p) \\to \\square p\n\nfor p = \\bot, \\square ( \\square \\bot \\to \\bot) \\to \\bot \\Leftrightarrow \\square \\lnot \\square \\bot \\to \\square \\bot, if you prove smth consistent, it is false (G√∂del)\n\n\nG√∂del Logic (GL)\n\n\\mathcal{F} is conversely well-founded if there is no ascending infinite chain\n\n(it is not FO-def.)\n\n\n\\mathcal{F} not trans., \\mathcal{F} not conv.well.foud. then \\mathcal{F} \\not \\models \\square ( \\square p \\to p) \\to \\square p.\n\\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{p} \\forall_x ST_x (\\varphi) ?\n\n\n\n08.10, VI. Correspondence\n\n(\\mathcal{F}, V) \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow (\\mathcal{F}, V) \\models \\forall_x ST_x(\\varphi), this is the general form of correspondence\n\n\\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi(p_1, ..., p_n) \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{F} \\forall_{p_1, ..., p_n} \\forall_x ST_x (\\varphi), with a second order quantification\nfor some, second order is not needed: \\mathcal{F} \\models p \\to \\Diamond p \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{F} \\models \\forall_x xR x\n\nwhich is: \\forall_{p} \\forall_x ST_x (p \\to \\Diamond p)\n\n\n\n\n\\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML}} \\exists_{\\alpha(x) \\in \\mathcal{L}_{FOL}} \\forall_{\\mathcal{F} = (M, R)} \\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{F} \\models \\forall_x \\alpha(x), call &quot;\\forall_x \\alpha(x)&quot; is a FO-correspondent of \\varphi.\n\nexample: \\mathcal{F} \\models \\Diamond \\top \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{p_1, ..., p_n} \\forall_x \\exists_y (x R y \\land y = y) \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{F} \\models \\forall_{x}\\exists_y x R y\n\n\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML} is closed if \\forall_{p \\in \\text{Prop}}\\dot p \\not \\in \\varphi\nif \\varphi is closed, it has a FO-corr., which is effectively computable form \\varphi.\n\n\n\n\nmore clearly than in the book: Sahlqvist.pdf\nfor \\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML}, write occurrences as \\dot p \\in \\varphi, call it positive if p is under an even number of negations in \\varphi\n\nI write \\dot p \\in_+ \\varphi. occurrences are either positive or negative (&quot;\\in_-&quot;)\n\n\n\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML} is positive if \\forall_{p \\in \\text{Prop}} \\dot p \\in_+ \\varphi\n\nformulae are positive, negative or either of the two.\nclearly, \\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML}}pos.(\\varphi) \\Leftrightarrow neg.(\\lnot \\varphi)\n\n\nfor \\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{ML}, p \\in \\text{Prop} s.t. \\dot p \\in_+ \\varphi, let V a val. on \\mathcal{F}, and V&#039; a val. s.t. \\forall_{q \\not = p}V&#039;(q) = V(q) and V(p) \\subseteq V&#039;(p), then (\\mathcal{F}, V), w \\models \\varphi \\models \\varphi \\Rightarrow (\\mathcal{F}, V&#039;), w \\models \\varphi.\n\n\\Leftarrow for \\lnot p.\n\n\nthere always is a minimal valuation that makes the formula false\n\n12.11, General Frames &amp; Incomplete Logics\n\n(W, R, A) is a general frame if (W, R) is a kripke frame and A \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X) s.t.\n\nW, \\emptyset \\in A\n\\forall_{U, V \\in A} U \\cup V \\in A\n\\forall_{U, V \\in A} U \\setminus V \\in A\n\\forall_{U \\in A} \\{x \\in W: \\exists_{y \\in U} x R y\\}  \\in A\n\n\\Diamond_R U := \\{x \\in W: \\exists_{y \\in U} x R y\\}\n\n\n\n\nfor (W, R, A) a gen.fr. then:\n\n\\forall_{U, V \\in A} U \\cap V \\in A\n\\forall_{U \\in A} \\{x \\in W: R[x] \\subseteq U\\}  \\in A\n\nR[x] := \\{y : x R y\\}\n\n\n\\square_R U := \\{x \\in W: R[x] \\subseteq U\\}\n\n\n\n\n(W,R,A, V) is a gen.mod. for (W, R, A) a gen.fr and V: \\text{Prop} \\to A.\n\n[\\![\\varphi]\\!]:= \\{x \\in W : \\mathcal{M}, x \\models \\varphi \\land \\varphi \\in A\\}\n\n\nF = (W, R, A) gen.fr and Log(F) := \\{\\varphi : F \\models \\varphi\\} is a consistent normal modal logic.\nDefine K_t Tho (M)\n\n\\Diamond_F p \\land \\Diamond_F q \\to \\Diamond_F(p \\land \\Diamond_Fq) \\lor \\Diamond_F(p \\land q) \\lor \\Diamond_F(\\Diamond_F p \\lor q)\n\\Diamond_F \\top\n\\Box_P( \\Box_P q\\to q) \\to \\Box_P q\n\n\n(M) \\Box_F \\Diamond_F p \\to \\Diamond_F \\Box_F p\n\n\nK_t ThoM is an consistent and complete logic\n\n26.10 Completeness of PDL\nDefinition (Atom) let \\Sigma be a set of formulae, A is an Atom if A \\subs \\lnot FL(\\Sigma) is consistent A \\not \\vdash_{\\PDL} \\bot and A subsetneq B \\subset \\lnot \\FL(\\Sigma), then B \\vdahs_{\\PDL} \\bot$\nAlso define At(\\Sigma). = \\{A | A is an atom in $\\lnot FL(\\Sigma)}\nLemma let A \\in At(\\Sigma), then:\n\n\\varphi \\in \\lnot FL(\\Sigma): exatly one \\varphi \\in A or \\lnot \\varphi \\in A\n‚Ä¶ (sry missed those, but simple equivalence following the definitions of the ways combining programs given in \\FL).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLemma At(\\Sigma) = {\\Gamma \\cap \\lnot FL(\\Sigma) : for some MCS \\Gamma}\nProof \\Gamma \\cap \\lnot FL(\\Sigma) is consistent \\not \\vdash \\bot as \\Gamma \\not \\vdash \\bot\nsuppose \\Gamma \\cap \\lnot \\FL(\\Sigma) \\subsetneq B \\subseteq \\lnot \\FL(\\Sigma), then there is a \\varphi \\in B but \\varpgu \\not \\in \\Gamma \\cap \\lnot FL(\\Sigma), so \\varphi \\not \\in \\Gamma. We then. conclide \\lnot \\varphi \\in \\Gamma, so‚Ä¶\nFor the other direction, simple application of the Lindenbaum lemma.\n$A \\subseteq \\Gamma \\ca \\lnto FL(\\Sigma) \\Rightarrow A = \\Gamma \\cap \\lnot FL(\\Sigma) as both are atoms.\nConsider that all proof swe are doing are constructive by finiteness of \\Sigma and hence of \\FL(\\Sigma)\nLemma if \\varphi \\in \\lnot \\FL(\\Sigma) and \\{\\varphi\\} is consistent, \\varphi \\not \\vdash \\bot then there is aa A \\in At(\\Sigma)$ s.t. \\varphi \\in A.\nProof by Lindenbaum\nDefinition (finite canonical model over \\Sigma) ‚Äútemporary definition‚Äù.\nLet \\Sigma be a finite set of formulas, the finite canonical model over \\Sigma is made by (At(\\Sigma), \\{S_\\pi\\}_{\\pi \\in \\Pi}, V^{\\Sigma}) where V^\\Sigma(p) = \\{A \\in At(\\Sigma) : p \\in A\\}. We then define A S^\\Sijgma_\\pi B \\Leftrightarrow \\hat A \\land \\langle \\pi \\rangle \\hat B., where \\hat A := \\bigwedge \\{\\varphi : \\varphi \\in A\\}.\nNote now: S_{\\pi_1 \\cup \\pi_2} \\not = S_{pi_1} \\cup S_{\\pi_2} and S_{\\pi^*} \\not = (S_{\\pi})^* and we dont like it! We massage the canonical model in order to prove this but still prove the Truths Lemma.\nLemma let A \\in At(\\Sigma) and $\\langle \\pi \\rangle"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Isomorphism-Classes-of-Total-Orders":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Isomorphism-Classes-of-Total-Orders","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Isomorphism Classes of Total Orders.md","title":"Isomorphism Classes of Total Orders","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Model-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Ontic-Structuralism-of-Concepts"],"tags":[],"content":"Why is this not true? (So they say in mathoverflow).\n\\begin{Proposition}[Completeness Results]\n\\label{Completenes Results}\n    Let $T_\\preceq$ be the set of formulae (i) - (iv) defining Total Orders \\ref{Total Order} and consider the classes of structures of $T_\\preceq$, $(X, \\preceq)$ in the first order signature $\\langle \\preceq \\rangle$ such that $|X| = k$, then note that $T_\\preceq \\cup \\{\\vf\\}$ there are at maximum eight isomorphism classes such that precisely those three formulae are either theorems or their negation is:\n    \\begin{itemize}\n        \\item[($d$)] $\\forall_{x, y} \\exists_z x \\preceq z \\preceq y$\n        \\item[($b^*$)] $\\exists_x \\forall_y y \\preceq x$\n        \\item[($b_*$)] $\\exists_x \\forall_y x \\preceq y$\n    \\end{itemize}\n\\end{Proposition}\nI believe that what I wrote is correct but that what they claim is different. What they claim is for a signature \\langle N, \\preceq \\rangle where N is a name for each of the objects in the domain (i.e. |N| = k), which is certainly not the case what I am arguing for.\nI work for a prove of this result whose validity I seem to remember from Model Theory (Lecture) in the project Ontic Structuralism of Concepts. The Proposition is in fact almost true, see StackExchange, the result for DLO is also widely known. The proposition is completely true for Elementary Equivalence instead of Isomorphsm, for instance take (\\mathbb{Z}, \\leq) \\not \\simeq (\\mathbb{Z},  \\leq), or is it?"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Knowledge,-Representation-and-Reasoning-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Knowledge,-Representation-and-Reasoning-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Knowledge, Representation and Reasoning (Lecture).md","title":"Knowledge, Representation and Reasoning (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by, Prof. Ronald de Haan during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA).\nAssignments\n\nOverleaf: KRR, 1\nOverleaf: KRR, 2\nOverleaf: KRR, 3\n\nLecture Notes\nHere I summarise the material and, in particular, write in a very schematic manner, all that is needed for passing the exam.\n09.09, III. DPLL &amp; CDCL\n\nSAT is NP-complete\na CNF formula, is a conjunction of clauses, which are disjunctions of possibly negated literals (at.form.)\n\nevery \\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{PL} is logically equivalent to a CNF-formula\n\nTseytin transformation solves the problem in P-time.\n\n\nfor \\varphi \\in CNF, for \\mathcal{l} literal, then \\varphi|_\\mathcal{l} is \\varphi given \\mathcal{l}\n\n\nBacktracking search: is a brute force algorithm on truth-assignments\n\nit can easily represented through a tree-graph\nPropagation:\n\nUnit Propagation: if \\varphi contains a unit clause, satisfy it (DPLL)\n\nrepeat until there is no unit clause\nunit clauses are those whose all literals other than one have already been set false [s.15]\n\n\nConflict Analysis: (CDCL) [lec., 1:12]\n\nBuild the conflict graph\n\narrows from literals to literals that indicate what forced propagation\n\n\nDraw cuts, each corresponds to a clause\n\nthe clause is the negation of provenience of the cut arrows\n\n\nTheorem: if you add these clauses to the formula, the result does not change\n\nto avoid this situation again, you can add these clauses\nthese clauses are logically entailed in the initial formula\n\n\nAdding all makes the algorithm slower, take the 1UIP [1:24]\n\n1UIP is the rightmost asserting clause [1:27]\n\na clause is asserting if it contains (the neg. of) exac. one literal of the maximal decision level\n\nthe decision level of a literal is when it got chosen, if it derived from propagation, take the highest literal that forced propagation.\n\n\nprecise method: once drawn the graph, proceed by define the cut (L, R),\n\nall p with not max.dec.lev. in L\nl_d is the dec.lit. of max.dec.lev.\nl_1 is lit. closest to \\bot s.t. lies on all path l_d \\rightsquigarrow \\bot\nput the path l_d \\rightsquigarrow l_1 in L, &amp; all lit. with max.dec.lev.\nthe rest (and \\bot) in R\n1UIP is the disj. of the neg. of the antecedents of the arrows crossing\n\n\n\n\n\n\nJump back the second highest decision level of the 1UIP and use it to propagation\n\n\nif a literal appears and never its negation, assume it (PL) [1:46]\npick the literal that satisfies as many clauses as possible\na random restart makes the algorithm sometimes quicker\nGive each literal a score, at each conflict decrease the score of all literals involved, always chose the one with the least score (VSIDS)\n\n\n\n\n\n13.09, IV. ASP\n\nSimilar to Prolog (idk)\nIntroduction to Syntax\n\nrules: `a :- b, c, d, ‚Ä¶, z\n\nmeaning (b \\land c \\land d \\land ... \\land z) \\to a\n\n\nfacts: formula that are true\n\na meaning \\vdash a\n\n\n\n\nExamples:\n\nUniversally quantifiers:\n\n\n\n\n\nrainy(amsterdam).\nrainy(vienna).\nwet(X) :- rainy(X).\n\nSemantic Rules:\n\nDomain Closure: the objects mentioned are the only objects\nUnique-names Assumption: objects with different names are different objects\nClosed-world Assumption: what is not proved true is false\n\n\nHerbrand Interpretation: ? [S. 10]\nMinimal Model is a model s.t. any subset of it is not a model\n\nfor positive programs there is one unique minimal model.\n\n\nSupported Model: for each a \\in M, there is a rule a \\leftarrow \\beta in P s.t. M makes \\beta true\n\n\nNormal Logic Programs (NLP)\n\nnot means \\lnot\na :- b_1, ..., b_n, not c_1, ..., not c_n is allowed\nwe lose the unique-minimal-model property\n\n\nSimpler: Stratified Negation\n\ndraw the dependency graph [S. 16]\ncheck that there is no cycle of negative arrows\n\n\n\n16.09, V. ASP &amp; VI.\n\nFor a NLP P and an interpretation M, then P^M s.t.\n\nremove rules with not a in the body if a \\in M\nremove literals not b from all rules if b \\not \\in M\n\n\nAn Answer Set (AS) of P is a minimal model of P^M\nLego Approach: learn some pieces that improve ASP vocabulary\n\nnum(1)\nleft(X) :- not right(X), num(X)\nright(X) :- not left(X), num(X)\nhas as a AS the binary combinations of 1 to right and left, can be expanded by adding num(2).\nYou can add then left(1) or right(1) then you can narrow the AS.\n\nif a command starts with a # is a meta-command\n\n#show left/1 only show the predicates you are interested in (e.g. hide num())\n\n#show predicate/arity\n\n\n\n\n\n#const k = 2 %generate a constant\nnum(a;b) %all letters in between\nnum(1..2) %all nums in between\n\nGiven a formula \\varphi in CNF, then:\n\ntake var(1..n) for n number of prop.var.\nset true(X) :- not false(X), var(X) and false(X) :- not true(X), var(X)\nset to false (no head) the formulae that falsify each clause of \\varphi\n\n\nChoice rule { a; b } (as a fact or as a head of a rule)\n\nCardinality constrain: 1 { a; b; c } 2 (take only solutions with at least 1 true variables and maximally 2).\n\n\ns :- p(X) : q(X) stands for s :- p(1), p(2) [V. S. 32]\none-to-one mappings [V. S. 33]\n\n23.09, VI. Games with ASP\n\nwe use T = #sum {C, X, Y, Z : P(X), P(Y)} sums only Cs but allows the sum of two equal Cs if the X, Y, Z are different.\nD = #count { M : edge(N, M, C)} workds similarly, or also #max\n\n18.10, Summary\n\nSyntax\n\nnormal logic programs\n\ncontaining only rules of the form: a :- g, c, d, not e, not f\n\n\nextensions:\n\ninclude variables `X, Y\nchoice rules (with cardinality constrains)\naggregates (#sum, #count)\n\n\n\n\nSemantic\n\nInterpretations M \\subseteq Atom(P)\nModels M are interpretations that make all rules of the program true\nSupported Models M are models where each atom a \\in M is supported\nAnswer Sets M are minimal models of the riduct P^M\n\n\nMore Theory\n\n==Clark Completion==: translate the program\n\nExam: not going to make us write the clark completion of a program down\n\n\n==Unfounded Sets==:\n\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Logic,-Language-and-Computation-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Logic,-Language-and-Computation-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Logic, Language and Computation (Lecture).md","title":"Logic, Language and Computation (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc.
