I take no lecture notes, as long as the assignments seem to be easy enough, I am already familiar with most of the material.\nAssignments\nHere I list my solutions for the assignments in the respective Overleaf files:\n\nOverleaf: MPML, 1 \nOverleaf: MPML, 2\nOverleaf: MPML, 3\nOverleaf: MPML, TH-1\nOverleaf: MPML, 4\nOverleaf: MPML, 5\nOverleaf: MPML, TH-2\nOverleaf: MPML, 6\nOverleaf: MPML, 7\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Meaning,-Reference-and-Modality-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Meaning,-Reference-and-Modality-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Meaning, Reference and Modality (Lecture).md","title":"Meaning, Reference and Modality (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/Index-of-Bachelor-Works","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/1st-Semester/Philosophy/Essays/The-Frequency-of-Telling-Stories","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/The-Silent-Assumption-in-Tarskian-Semantics","System/Attachments/MRM-Slides-A.pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Modal-Logic-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Introduction-to-Modal-Logic-(Lecture)","System/Attachments/MRM-Slides-B.pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Meaning,-Reference-and-Modality-(Lecture)","System/Attachments/Some_Results_MPL.jpeg"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by, Prof. Dekker during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA).\nRelevant courses in Philosophy of Language I took are just the one on Kripke (see: The Frequency of Telling Stories, on Kripkean reference of the indexical ‚ÄúI‚Äù) and in Philosophy of Logic (see: The Silent Assumption in Tarskian Semantics).\nTake-Home Exams\n\nOverleaf: MRM, 1\nOverleaf: MRM, 2\nOverleaf: MRM, 3\n\nLecture Notes\n10.09, I. Introduction\nMRM Slides A.pdf\n\nFormal Semantics\n\nIn order to do any formal semantics, one should assume:\n\nThere is structure in the world\nThere is meaning in the world\nThere is structure in meaning\n\ndoubtable. Compositionality, entailment, aprioricity\n\n\n\n\n\n\nExtensional Semantics: meaning is reference\n\neinen Satz verstehen, hei√üt, wissen was der Fall ist, wenn er wahr ist. (L. Wittgenstein)\nM, g \\models \\phi; M \\models \\phi; \\models \\phi; \\Gamma \\models \\phi\n\n(satisfaction, truth, validity, entailment)\n\n\n‚ÄúFido‚Äù\\mapsto Fido\n\n‚ÄúFido is a boy‚Äù\\mapsto 0 iff Fido \\not \\in Boys\n‚ÄúAll boys swim‚Äù\\mapsto 1 iff Boys \\subseteq Swimmers\n\n\nExtensionality Principles:\n\nt = t&#039; \\models \\varphi \\leftrightarrow [t&#039;/t]\\varphi\n\\forall_{x}(A(x) \\leftrightarrow A&#039;(x)) \\models \\varphi \\leftrightarrow [A&#039;/A]\\varphi\n\\psi = \\psi&#039; \\models \\varphi \\leftrightarrow [\\psi&#039;/\\psi]\\varphi\nsame reference \\leftrightarrow same meaning\n\n\nProblems:\n\nIdentity: Lois doesn‚Äôt know that Leningrad is Saint Petersburg\n\nequivalent to: Lois doesn‚Äôt know that SP is itself\n\n\nExistence: Rumpelstiltskin does not exist\n\nyou cannot use the word without reference\n\n\nSubstitution: it is necessary that 9 is 9, planets are 9, hence nec. there are 9 planets\n\n\npossibility of a sentence is given by:\n\nthe atomic propositions that are true there\n\ndetermined by the valuation function V_w(p) \\in \\{0, 1\\}\n\n\nwhat is its space of possibilities\n\ndetermined by R\n\n\n\n\n\n\nintensional semantics: meaning is determination of reference\n\nmeaning as information (J. Hintikka)\nM, w , g \\models \\phi; M, w \\models \\phi; (F) \\models \\phi; \\Gamma \\models \\phi\n\n\ndynamic semantics: meaning is potential to update information\n\nM, \\langle g , h \\rangle \\models \\phi; M, g \\models \\phi; \\models \\phi; \\vec{\\gamma} \\models \\phi\n\n\n\n13.09, II. Frege &amp; Basics in Modal Logic\n\nBasic Modal Logic: already seen material\n\nModal Logic (Lecture)\n\n13. Epistemic Logic\n\n\nIntroduction to Modal Logic (Lecture)\n\n\nFrege: Gedanke are neither things from the external world, not Vorstellungen. A third realm has to be acknowledged.\nEach word (Syntax) is mapped to a Bedeutung (World) and a Sinn (3rd Realm)\nIf a = b then S(a) = S(b) (Compositionality)\n\nClar Kent works for the Local Herald \\not = Superman works for te Daily Planet\n\nSame Bedeutung (compositionality on Bedeutung applied)\nDifferent Sinn, no compositionality on Sinn has been applied\n\nHence Gedanke is not Bedeutung.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSinn as Mode of Presentation\na thought (G.) is what is true or false\n\nExamples\n\na^2 + b^2 = c^2\nVenus follows an elliptic orbit around the sun\nCirce has drugged Odysseus‚Äô men\n\n\nnot a picture, not a sentence, that thing that is true or false\n\nThought and truth cannot be better defined.\n\n\nunchangeable, not psychological but ‚Äúmetaphysical‚Äù\n\nvery close to modern Platonism\n\nthoughts are metaphysical and hyperuranical entities\n\nreal, with determinate truth values and consequences relations, timeless and without location.\n\n\n\n\neverything that is content dependent must be encoded in the thought so that the thought iscontext-indipendent.\n(this can, for instance, not happen with the representation of yourself, see The Frequency of Telling Stories)\n\n\nLeibniz: Eadum sunt, quae sibi mutuo substitui posunt, salva veritate.\n\nQuotations:\n\ndirect: expressions refer to themselves\nindirect: expressions refer to their ordinary sense\n\nthe Sinn is the Bedeutung of that sentence in indirect use.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n17.09, III. Worlds\n\nQuine: \\square \\varphi \\equiv &quot;\\varphi&quot; is analythic\nExtremes:\n\nLeibniz: all worlds certainly exist\nQuine: nihilist, there are none.\n\n\nLewis: Modal Realism\n\n‚Äúthings could have been different‚Äù \\Rightarrow ‚Äúthere are ways things could have been‚Äù\nStalnaker: modal realism is just ‚Äúsome ordinary beliefs by another name‚Äù\nActuality is Indexical: our world is one among others.\n\nNot a particular property of our world.\nWe just believe to more things just like the actual world, nothing more.\nOnly a systematic thinking about the possibilities we already know.\n\n\nStalnaker: possible worlds are ‚Äúsome ordinary beliefs by another name‚Äù.\nLewis on Ordinary Beliefs:\n\nBelief in possible worlds is a natural belief\nThere is no sensible alternative to this belief\nThere is nothing wrong with the belief\n\n\nStalnaker answers Lewis as:\n\nPossible worlds exist.\nThey are of the same sort of the actual world.\n\nAgainst:  b \\rightsquigarrow \\bigwedge \\{P : P(b)\\}(b) is ok, not b = \\bigwedge \\{P : P(b)\\}\n\nthe way the world is, is not the same thing as the world that is that way.\n\n\n\n\nActuality is an indexical.\n\nAgainst: but real\n\nThe objective, absolute point of view is the view from within the actual world, and it is part of the concept of actuality that this should be so.\nSolopsism: deny most things, presentist the future and past, actualist is inclusive\n\n\n\n\nPossible worlds are irreducible.\n\n\n\n\nInstrumentalist: ‚ÄúPossible worlds are convenient fictions which help to make a workable and perspicuous theory‚Äù\nFrames: as done in Introduction to Modal Logic (Lecture) &amp;\n\nFrom: Modal Logic (Lecture)\n\n\\square \\varphi \\to \\varphi corr. to refl.\n\\varphi \\to \\square \\lozenge \\varphi corr. to sym.\n\\square \\varphi \\to \\square \\square \\varphi corr. to trans.\n\\square \\varphi \\to \\lozenge \\varphi corr. to seriality\n\\lozenge \\varphi \\to \\square \\lozenge \\varphi corr. to euclideaness (\\forall_{u, v, w \\in M}u R v \\land u R w \\to w R v)\n\n\nin S5: \\Diamond \\square \\phi \\Leftrightarrow \\square \\phi \\Leftrightarrow \\square \\square \\phi and \\Diamond \\Diamond \\phi \\Leftrightarrow \\Diamond \\phi \\Leftrightarrow \\square \\Diamond \\phi, R is refl., trans., eucl.\n\n\n\n20.09, IV. A. Prior\n\nHe gave foundations of temporal logic as a modal logic\nPrior: Wheresoever then is whatsoever is, it is only as present (mentioning S. Augustine)\nSome Rules\n\nS \\Leftrightarrow S present\nS future \\Leftrightarrow (S present) future\nS future \\Leftrightarrow (S future) present\n\n\nTenses as Temporal Operators:\n\nF ex. in fut., G alw. in the fut.\nP ex. in past, H alw. in the past.\n\n\nTemporal Logic (as in 9. Temporal Logic)\n\n\\models G \\phi \\leftrightarrow \\lnot F \\lnot \\phi and \\models H \\phi \\leftrightarrow \\lnot P \\lnot \\phi (Dualities)\n\\models (p \\to GPp), in the fut., pres. is past, \\models (p \\to HFp), pres. is fut. of past. (Interaction Principles)\nLimits: irrefl. and univ. cannot be characterised. That is though intuitive.\n\nTime is possibly circular, and this is not here. Can we exclude parallel times?\n\n\n\n\n\n24.09, V. Kripke &amp; Modal Predicate Logic\nMRM Slides B.pdf\n\nLecture based on Naming and Necessity, seen mostly in The Frequency of Telling Stories.\na priori \\not \\Leftrightarrow necessary\n\nGoldenbach conjecture is nec. true or nec. false, it does not imply anything epistemic\n\n\nAfter Frege:\n\nRussel: Sinn can be captured in a Description\nSearl: we need to have a cluster of description of the same designator in different modalities\nKripke: names are rigid designators, definite descriptions must not be\n\nrigid designator: ‚Äúif in every possible world it designates the same object‚Äù (NN, p.48)\n\nwe need to make sense of ‚Äúcriteria of transworld identity‚Äù\nPossible Worlds themselves are stipulated because we can rigidly refer to objects\n\n‚Äúif Biden didn‚Äôt win elections‚Äù, such a description of a possible world is possible because we can rigidly refer to Biden. (NN, p.49)\nQ: if Biden rigidly refers to Biden, then Biden is necessarily named ‚ÄúBiden‚Äù\n\nA: Biden is nec. Biden, but Biden is not nec. named ‚ÄúBiden‚Äù. Two different languages, we can use our-own for practical purposes, must not be the same used in other worlds. ‚ÄúThe person called Biden‚Äù is not a rigid designator.\n{Q: should we develop a meta-language or just use the one true in @?}\n\n\nQ: Sinn and Bedeutung of rigid names?\n\nA: Bedeutung makes no sense, different domains, Sinn is not the proper way to think about it, (against Lewis) possible worlds are not already there, they are stipulated after we use names rigidly, that is what refers necessarily to objects in other worlds.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPredicate Modal Logic[I use here \\Vdash for \\backmodels or sledom which are not in Markdown.]\n\nD: W \\to  \\{D_{w_0}, D_{w_1}, ...\\}, w \\mapsto D_w, D_w is the domain of individuals (Domain Function)\n\nhence existence is contigent\n\n\nI interpretations are rigid, same in every world.\nValuations are partial, i.e. \\mathcal{M}, w, V \\models \\varphi or \\mathcal{M}, w, V \\Vdash \\varphi or neither\n\nsee Alternative Semantics to Modal Predicate Logic\n\n\nWe use Weak Kleene Truth tables\n\nif there is an undefined, then undefined.\n\n\nSemantics\n\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models R(t_1, ..., t_n) iff [t_1]_{M, g} \\in D_w and \\langle [t_1]_{M, g}, ..., [t_n]_{M, g} \\rangle \\in I_w(R)\n‚Äúsame as above‚Äù \\Vdash ‚Äúsame as above‚Äù \\not \\in ‚Äúsame as above‚Äù\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models t_i = t_j iff [t_i]_{M, g} \\in D_w and [t_i]_{M, g} = [t_j]_{M, g}, similarly for \\not =\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models (\\phi \\land \\psi) - classical and defined [only?]\n\\mathcal{M},w \\models \\forall_x \\phi iff \\forall_{d \\in D_w} \\mathcal{M}, w, V[x/ d] \\models \\phi\n‚Äúsame‚Äù \\Vdash ‚Äúsame‚Äù \\Vdash \\phi, and for \\exists\n\\square as usual.\n\n\nHard and Friendly Modality\n\nHard Modality: \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\square_h \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{w&#039; \\in W} w R w&#039; \\to \\mathcal{M}, w&#039; \\models \\varphi\n\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\Vdash \\square_h \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{w&#039; \\in W} w R w&#039; \\to \\mathcal{M}, w&#039; \\Vdash \\varphi\n\\not \\models_h \\square (a = a)\n\\not \\models \\square_h (Fa \\to Fa)\n\n\nFriendly Modality: \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\square_f \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{w&#039; \\in W} (w R w&#039; \\land def.(\\varphi)) \\to \\mathcal{M}, w&#039; \\models \\varphi\n\nDistribution of \\square_f is not valid.\nwe could have \\square F(a) but \\Diamond \\lnot \\exists_x F(x)\n\n\n\n\nString &amp; Tolerant Modality\n\n\\Gamma \\models_s \\psi iff in all models \\forall_{w \\in W}\\forall_{\\gamma \\in \\Gamma} (\\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\gamma )\\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\phi\n\nformulae with individual terms are never valid\nF(a) \\models_s F(a) but \\not \\models_s (F(a)\\to F(a))\n\n\n\\Gamma \\models_p \\psi iff \\psi is defined and in all models \\lnot \\exists_{w \\in W}\\forall_{\\gamma \\in \\Gamma} (\\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\gamma )\\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M}, w \\Vdash \\phi\nSome Results: Some_Results_MPL.jpeg\n\n\nBarcan Formulae &amp;co\n\n\\forall_x \\Diamond F(x) \\to \\Diamond \\forall_xF(x), no.\n\\square \\exists_x F(x) \\to \\exists_x \\square F(x), no.\n\\Diamond \\forall_x F(x) \\\\to \\forall_x \\Diamond F(x), increasing domains\n\ninc.dom., i.e. \\forall_{w, w&#039;} w R w&#039; \\to D_w \\subseteq D_{w&#039;}\nalw. valid with &quot;\\square_h&quot; and &quot;\\models_t&quot;\n\n\n\\exists_x \\square F(x) \\to \\square \\exists_x F(x)\n\nalw. valid with &quot;\\square_h&quot; and &quot;\\models_t&quot;\nonly of objects with necessary existence.\n\n\n\\square \\forall_x F(x) \\to \\forall_x \\square F(x)\n\nvalid with &quot;\\square_h&quot; and inc.dom.\nalw. valid with &quot;\\square_f&quot;\n\n\n\\exists_x \\Diamond F(x) \\to \\Diamond \\exists_x F(x)\n\nnot valid with &quot;\\models_s&quot; and &quot;\\square_h&quot;\n\n\n\\exists_x \\Diamond_h F(x) \\models_s \\Diamond_h \\exists_xF(x)\n\\square_h \\forall_x F(x) \\not \\models_s \\forall_x \\square_h F(x)\n\\forall_x \\square F(x) \\to \\square \\forall_x F(x) decreasing domains (Barcan Formula)\n\ndec.dom., i.e. \\forall_{w, w&#039;} w R w&#039; \\to D_w \\supseteq D_{w&#039;}\nnot valid with str.inc.dom.\n\n\n\\Diamond \\exists F(x) \\to \\exists_x \\Diamond F(x)\n\nQuine: nonsense\nothers: if we can refer to smth, it must be there\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n01.10, VI. Real, Possible and Impossible Objects\n\nRussel on Definite Descriptions: THE(A)(B) := \\exists_x(\\forall_y(A(y) \\leftrightarrow x = y) \\land B(x))\nKripke &amp; Stalnaker: there is nothing of which you can say that it does not exist.\nQuine: On What There Is:\n\n‚ÄúThis is the Platonic riddle of nonbeing. Nonbeing must in some sense be, otherwise what is that there is not?‚Äù\nTake, for instance, the possible fat man in that doorway; and, again, the possible bald man in that doorway. Are they the same possible man? How do we decide?\nSo we note:\n\nPossibly Pegasus lives and flies\nHence the sentence ‚ÄúPegasus lives and flies‚Äù is consistent\nConclude: ‚Äúthere is something such that it lives and flies‚Äù is consistent\n\n\nTo be assumed as an entity is, purely and simply, to be reckoned as the value of a variable.\n[A] theory is committed to those and only those entities to which the bound variables of the theory must be capable of referring in order that the affirmations made in the theory be true [p. 13]\nUsing Russell‚Äôs definite descriptions: there is an attribute of being pegasus that is:\n\nunanalysable, irreducible. That is not a description, not a list of predicates.\n\n\n\n\nA Formal Understanding, [S. 73]\n\n‚Ä¶\n\n\n\n08.10, VII. Dynamic Semantics\n\nthe order syntactical natural sentences are said, makes a difference (pronouns, temporal/causal order‚Ä¶)\nTruism, three versions\n\nStalnaker: ‚Äúacts of assertion affect [‚Ä¶] the context, in particular the attitudes of the participants in the situation.‚Äù\nKamp: ‚Äúthe interaction between context and utterance is reciprocal.‚Äù\nVeltman: ‚Äúyou know the meaning of a sentence if you know the change it brings about in the information of state of anyone who accepts the news conveyed by it.‚Äù\n\n\nDynamic Predicate Logic: DPL\n\nin DPL: \\exists_x (\\varphi) \\land \\psi \\Leftrightarrow^! \\exists_x(\\varphi \\land \\psi) (Egli‚Äôs Theorem), S.3.10\n\n==S.3.11, connection with wRv \\to \\forall_x(xRw \\to x = v), i.e. unique predecessor?==\n(\\exists_x \\phi \\to \\psi) \\Leftrightarrow^! \\forall_x(\\phi \\to \\psi), S.3.12\n\n\nSyntax: the signature is the same as the one of \\mathcal{L}_{ML}\n\na model \\mathcal{M} = \\langle \\mathcal{D}, \\mathcal{I} \\rangle, s.t. for every relation \\mathcal{I}(R) \\subseteq D^n\n\nvariable assignments are functions V \\to \\mathcal{D}\n\n\nif you use \\exists_x you introduced x, further appearances of x are pronouns referring to it.\n\nformally: the variable assignment g gets updated to h after the formula \\phi, write g [ \\![ \\phi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h\n\n\n\n\nSemantics\n\nM, g \\models \\phi iff \\exists_h g [ \\![ \\phi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h\n\ng [ \\![ R(x_1, ..., x_n)]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h iff g = h \\land \\langle g(x_1), ..., g(x_n) \\rangle \\in \\mathcal{I}_\\mathcal{M}(R)\ng [ \\![ \\lnot \\phi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h iff g = h \\land \\lnot \\exists_h g [ \\![ \\phi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h\ng [ \\![ \\phi \\land \\psi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h iff \\exists_k g [ \\![ \\phi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} k [ \\![ \\psi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h\ng [ \\![\\exists_x \\phi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h iff \\exists_k g [x] k [ \\![ \\phi]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h\n\ng[x]k says that g|_{V \\setminus \\{x\\}} = k|_{V \\setminus \\{x\\}}\n\n\n\n\n\\phi_1, ..., \\phi_n \\models \\psi iff \\forall_{\\mathcal{M}}\\forall_{g, h} g [ \\![ \\phi_1, ..., \\phi_n]\\!]_\\mathcal{M} h \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M}, h \\models \\psi\n\n\nNothing New: define (\\cdot)^\\clubsuit: \\mathcal{L}_{DPL} \\to \\mathcal{L}_{FOL} s.t. \\mathcal{M}, g \\models_{DPL} \\phi^\\clubsuit iff \\mathcal{M}, g \\models_{FOL} \\phi^\\clubsuit\n\ng [\\![ \\phi^\\clubsuit]\\!] h iff g [\\![ \\phi]\\!] h (signature is the same, hence it makes sense)\nDefine \\phi^\\clubsuit recursively:\n\n(\\cdot)^\\clubsuit|_{\\text{Atom}\\cup \\mathcal{L}_{PL}} = id\n(\\exists_x \\phi \\land \\psi) = (\\exists(\\phi \\land \\psi))^\\clubsuit\n\n\nHence: DPL = FOL + Egli‚Äôs Theorem\n\n\nFurther Features\n\n\\lnot in front of an existential, eliminates the binding power\n\nsimilarly \\forall_x \\phi, \\chi \\to \\psi, \\chi \\lor \\psi\n\n==not trivial cases right? \\psi = \\chi or \\phi(x) = \\phi.\n\\phi \\not \\Leftrightarrow \\lnot \\lnot \\phi\n\\exists_x \\phi \\not \\Leftrightarrow \\lnot \\forall_x \\phi\n(\\phi \\land \\psi) \\not \\Leftrightarrow \\lnot(\\phi \\to \\lnot \\psi)\n\n\n&quot;\\lnot&quot;, &quot;\\land&quot;, &quot;\\exists&quot; are enough to define everything\n\nbut not other combinations\n\n\n\n\nAlso:\n\nS.3.28\n(\\exists_x F x \\land Gx) \\not \\Leftrightarrow (\\exists_y F y \\land G x) (\\alpha-conversion)\nEntailment is horrible\n\nnon-monotone\n\n(Fx \\land \\exists_x Gx) \\not \\Leftrightarrow (\\exists_x Gx \\land Fx)\n\\exists_x Fx \\models Fx\n\\exists_x Fx, \\exists_x \\lnot Fx \\not \\models Fx\n\\exists_x \\lnot F x, \\exists_x Fx \\models Fx\n\n\nnon-reflexive\n\n\\phi \\not \\models \\phi\n\nervik is first and now Verldkamp takes the lead. So Ervik...(?)\n\n\n\n\nnon-transitive\n\n\\lnot \\lnot \\exists_x Px \\models \\exists_x Px \\models Px\n\\lnot \\lnot \\exists_x Px \\not \\models Px\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nUpdate Semantics:\n\ns[\\![ p]\\!] = \\{i \\in s : i(p)=1\\}\n\nG[\\![ R(x_1, ..., x_n) \\!]] = \\{ g \\in G : \\langle g(x_1), ..., g(x_n) \\rangle \\in I(R) ]\\!]\n\n\ns[\\![ \\neg \\varphi]\\!] = s \\setminus s[\\![ \\varphi]\\!]\n\nG[\\![ \\neg \\phi ]\\!] = \\{ g \\in G : G[\\![ \\phi ]\\!] = \\emptyset ]\\!]\n\n\ns[\\![ \\varphi \\land \\psi]\\!] = s[\\![ \\varphi]\\![\\![ \\psi]\\!]\n\nisn&#039;t this the intuition of implication? Given phi then psi\nG[\\![ \\phi \\wedge \\psi ]\\!] = G[\\![ \\phi ]\\!][\\![ \\psi ]\\!]\n\n\ns[\\![ \\varphi \\to \\psi ]\\!] = \\{i \\in s : \\text{if } i \\in s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!] \\text{ then } i \\in s[\\![ \\psi ]\\!]\\}\ns[\\![ \\Diamond \\varphi]\\!] = \\{i \\in s : s[\\![ \\varphi]\\!] \\neq \\emptyset\\}\ns[\\![ \\Box \\varphi ]\\!] = \\{i \\in s : s \\subseteq s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!]\\}\nG[\\![ \\exists_x \\phi \\!]] = \\bigcup_{d \\in D} G[x/d][\\![\\phi \\!]] ]\\!]\nUnfriendly Entailment Again\n\nnon-reflecive\n\n(\\Diamond p \\land \\lnot p) \\not \\models (\\diamond p \\land \\lnot p)\n\n\nnon-monotone\n\n\\Diamond p \\models \\Diamond p but \\Diamond p, \\lnot p \\not \\models \\Diamond p\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCoreference and Modality\n\nReferent Systems\n\ndom(r) = X \\subseteq V,\nran(r) = n = \\{m: m &lt; n\\} Notation!!\n\n\nAssignment: g is an assignment for r if:\n\ndom(g) = ran(r) \\land ran(g) \\subseteq D Notation!!! S. 39\n\n\nExtension of a referent system, S.3.40\nPossibility triple \\langle r, g, w\\rangle\n\nr a ref.sys., g an ass.func.r and w an interpretation function\n\n\nInterpretation in Possibility\n\nThe interpretation i(t) of a term t in possibility i = \\langle r, g, w \\rangle:\n\ni(c) = w(c) for constants c\ni(x) = g(r(x)) for variables x\ni(d) = d for demonstratives d\n\n\n\n\nUpdate of an Information State\n\nThe update s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!] of an information state s by formula \\varphi:\n\ns[\\![ Rt_1, ..., t_n ]\\!] = \\{ i \\in s \\mid \\langle i(t_1), ..., i(t_n) \\rangle \\in i(R) \\}\ns[\\![ \\neg \\varphi ]\\!] = \\{ i \\in s \\mid \\neg \\rightarrow i&#039;: i \\leq i&#039; \\land i&#039; \\in s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!] \\}\ns[\\![ \\varphi \\land \\psi ]\\!] = s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!][\\![ \\psi ]\\!]\ns[\\![ \\Diamond \\varphi ]\\!] = \\{ i \\in s \\mid s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!] \\neq \\emptyset \\}\ns[\\![ \\forall x \\varphi ]\\!] = \\bigcap_{d \\in D}(s[x/d][\\![ \\varphi ]\\!]), where s[x/d] = \\{ i[x/d] \\mid i \\in s \\}\n\n\nNot: s[\\![ \\forall x \\varphi ]\\!] = \\left( \\bigcap_{d \\in D} s[x/d] \\right)[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!]. (Long Story!)\n\n\nSome Metalinguistic Properties\n\nConsistency: if s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!] = \\emptyset for some s (in some model M)\n\nSo \\varphi is acceptable.\n(\\Diamond p \\land \\lnot p) is consistent\n(\\lnot p \\land \\Diamond p) is not consistent\n((\\Diamond p \\land \\lnot p) \\land (\\Diamond p \\land \\lnot p)) is not consistent\n\\Diamond (t_1 = t_2) \\land \\Diamond \\lnot(t_1 = t_2))\n\nis consistent if t_1 or t_2 is a constant or free variable\nis inconsistent if t_1 and t_2 are demonstratives or bound variables\n\n\n\n\nSupport: if s \\models \\varphi, then \\forall i \\in s \\rightarrow i&#039; \\in s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!] : i \\leq i&#039; (in model M)\n\nNo elimination of possibilities; but possibilities may grow.\n\n\nEntailment: if s[\\![ \\varphi ]\\!] \\models \\psi for all s (in all models M)\n\nNever elimination of any possibilities; always licensed to grow.\ne.g. s [\\![ \\Diamond (d_1 = a); \\Diamond (d_2 = a)]\\!] \\models \\forall_z \\Diamond (z = a)\n\n\nCoherence: if s \\models \\varphi for some s = \\emptyset (in some model M)\n\nSo \\varphi is supportable\n(\\Diamond p \\land \\lnot p) is not coherent\n\\Diamond P(t) \\land \\Diamond \\lnot P(t) is always coherent\nNote: Coherence implies consistency.\n\n\n\n\nSome Lost Properties\n\nAssociativity: (\\varphi \\land (\\psi \\land \\chi)) \\equiv ((\\varphi \\land \\psi) \\land \\chi)\nIdempotence: \\varphi \\not\\equiv (\\varphi \\land \\varphi) (for certain \\varphi)\nCommutativity: (\\varphi \\land \\psi) \\not\\equiv (\\psi \\land \\varphi) (for certain \\varphi and \\psi)\n\n\nExistential Generalisation\n\n\\forall_x \\phi \\models^? [t/x] \\phi\n\nTrue if t is a demonstrative or is bound\nFalse if f is a free variable or an individual constant\n\nEverybody can not be Dr. Livingstone, but he needs to be himself\n\n\\forall_x \\Diamond( x \\not = L) \\not \\models \\Diamond ( L \\not = L)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n[t/x] \\phi \\models^? \\exists_x \\phi\n\nTrue if t is a demonstrative or a bound variable\nFalse if t is a free variable or name\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nQuestions\nAlternative Semantics to Modal Predicate Logic\nWe have defined in 24.09, V. Kripke &amp; Modal Predicate Logic the semantic that answers to the very natural question of how one can introduce first order logic in modal logic. Here I present a semantics that I claim to be equivalent to the presented one but that is simpler in two ways: (i) it does not require the introduction of three valued Weak Kleene Logic and (ii) it does not require the introduction of the reversed semantic consequence symbol.\nIdea: To see the intuition, recall that for theories, instead of models, we already have an integrated way of having three truth values: that is (i) T \\models \\varphi, or (ii) T \\models \\lnot \\varphi or (iii) T \\not \\models \\varphi and T \\not \\models \\lnot \\varphi. This though cannot be directly applied to pointed modal models. That is, because models are complete and therefore the case (iii) is excluded.^[1]\nConsider this slight edit (that is sometimes already implicitly used in mathematical praxis) where for a sequence of symbols that are not in the language, call it \\delta, we have T \\not \\models \\delta. (alternatively, one may say that the whole formula T \\models \\delta is not defined, I want it now to be defined and false).\nNow, for each world construct a first order language whose terms are variables and the associated domain D_w (the same defined in class), call such a language \\mathcal{L}^w (in the construction I currently give, these languages solely differ in the constants accepted in the domain, one might consider other differences though) . That is when we write &quot;\\mathcal{M}, w \\models_w \\varphi&quot; we use &quot;\\models_w&quot; which is the consequence relation^[2] of the language \\mathcal{L}^w.\nTo see that Week Kleene Logic is applied, is fairly easy: for \\delta \\notin \\mathcal{L}^w and \\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}^w, we derive \\delta \\circ \\varphi \\notin \\mathcal{L}^w for any connective \\circ, similarly for negation. For instance, \\mathcal{M}, w \\not \\models \\varphi \\land \\delta. Examples of such \\delta would be those formula that would be well formed but contain names of objects that are not in the domain of the world. In general we can state \\forall_{d \\in \\bigcup_{v \\in W} D_v}(d \\not \\in D_w \\land d \\in \\delta )\\to \\mathcal{M}, w \\not \\models \\delta.^[3]\nAlso note that, for a \\not \\in \\bigcap_{w \\in W}D_w, I have \\not \\models (a = a) since for a \\not \\in D_w, then \\mathcal{M}, w \\not \\models a = a. Though I always have \\models \\forall_{x} x = x (since it is equivalent to \\forall_{w \\in W} \\models_w \\forall_{x \\in D_w} x = x) and hence also \\models \\square \\forall_{x = x} since D_w \\not = \\emptyset.\nQuestions\n\nDo you agree that this semantics is completely equivalent with the one seen in class?\nDo you agree on the better simplicity in defining the semantics in this way?\nDo you see any philosophical / foundational concern that one should take care of and which may make this semantics differ to the one presented in class?\n\n[1]: this point already may not be 100% coherent with the way Kripke sees possible worlds, but that is another matter \n[2]: it may now be better to consider the syntactic relation rather than the semantic one, since it is essentially language-dependent and generally would feel more appropriate.\n[3]: here I write d \\in \\delta because I consider \\delta to be an ordered set of symbols, hence I mean d to be a symbol within the sentence \\delta.\nRe: by Soeren Knudstorp.\nIf I‚Äôve understood your suggestion correctly, your proposed semantics wouldn‚Äôt be equivalent. For instance, since you have only one constant for each element of a given domain, you wouldn‚Äôt be able to express statements like h=p (‚ÄòHesperus is Phosphorus‚Äô), but only express v=v (‚ÄòVenus is Venus‚Äô).\nMy Reply:\nI first try to make to make clear to myself how statements like h = p are possible in the predicate modal logic seen in class, and then note that, to my understanding, there is no difference in forming such statements in ‚Äúmine‚Äù or in the given semantics. \nTo begin, in order to construct the statement ‚ÄòHesperus is Phosphorus‚Äô we wish to have variables h, p that denote the same object. Since we have taken names to refer rigidly, we have the general principle that each name, that is a constant d \\in \\bigcup_{w \\in W}D_w, always refers to the same object when interpreted in the different worlds. More precisely, that is for constants h, p \\in \\bigcup_{w \\in W} D_w we have that for every Kripke model \\mathcal{M},  \\forall_{w \\in W} h, p \\in D_w \\to (\\mathcal{M}, w \\models h = p). Now, such a construction is similarly valid in the semantics I have given without any difference that I can see.\nA crucial difference is that the semantic I described gives the hard modality since \\varphi \\not \\in \\mathcal{L}^w \\to \\square \\varphi \\not \\in \\mathcal{L}^w and also strict validity since for every Kripke model \\mathcal{M} I have \\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\bigcup_{w \\in W}\\mathcal{L}^w} \\forall_{w \\in W} \\varphi \\not \\in \\mathcal{L}^w \\to (\\mathcal{M}, w \\not \\models \\varphi). In fact, I do not prove results like &quot;\\models a = a&quot;, since for a \\not \\in D_w it would not hold.\nDefining tolerant modality is easily doable by changing again the semantics of &quot;\\models&quot;, one can in fact set it so that when the consequent is not defined the whole formula containing &quot;\\models&quot; is true.\nDefining friendly modality is though way less natural, since for any formula \\varphi \\not \\in \\mathcal{L}^w \\to \\square \\varphi \\not \\in \\mathcal{L}^w and this can only be avoided by changing again the semantics of &quot;\\models&quot; but buy setting more intricate syntactic rules."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/On-Disjoint-Union":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/On-Disjoint-Union","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/On Disjoint Union.md","title":"On Disjoint Union","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/Bachelor-Thesis"],"tags":[],"content":"The notation (/definition) of disjoint union seems always to create some confusion in mathematical praxis, here I present briefly the understanding I have of it.\nFor &quot;\\sqcup&quot; the symbol of disjoint union, I define the following:[^1] c = a \\sqcup b := c = a \\cup b \\land a \\cap b = \\emptysetwhich is a well-defined formula in language of set theory (given the usual notations for &quot;\\cap&quot;, &quot;\\cup&quot; and &quot;\\emptyset&quot;). This seems to me not to be that controversial, surprising nor distant from mathematical praxis.\nThe problems arise when one wishes to talk about a \\sqcup b without making a formula with it. Then the claim would be that a \\sqcup b is a well defined. I formally understand this, given the context of my Bachelor Thesis, that a \\sqcup b has a Complete Description, i.e. \\exists_{\\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon} (ZFC \\vdash \\varphi(a \\sqcup b) \\land \\forall_{x} \\varphi(x) \\to x = a \\sqcup b). Now, take the instance where a = \\{\\emptyset, \\{\\emptyset\\}\\} and b = \\{\\emptyset, \\{\\{\\emptyset\\}\\}\\}; there \\varphi(a \\sqcup b), depending on the definition we wish to have on \\varphi, would admittedly not hold and the term a \\sqcup b, which is hence not defined.\n[1]: Recall that &quot;:=&quot;, being a metalinguistic symbol, has the maximal scope."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/On-Infinitary-Paths":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/On-Infinitary-Paths","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/On Infinitary Paths.md","title":"On Infinitary Paths","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"I give a definition of infinitary path and sketch some results motivating why this is a path in here Overleaf: Infinitary Paths."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Ontic-Structuralism-of-Concepts":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Ontic-Structuralism-of-Concepts","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Ontic Structuralism of Concepts.md","title":"Ontic Structuralism of Concepts","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Cognition-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Ontic-Structuralism-Feedback"],"tags":[],"content":"For the course in Philosophy of Cognition (Lecture) by Dr. Sbardolini that I followed during my 5th Semester for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA) during my 5th Semester. The work I am doing for the Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project) influenced me greatly in the approach I had to the material of the course, in particular after realising that there is a debate on the application of a structuralist ontology to concepts as briefly mentioned in the SEP entry on Concepts and criticised in the first questions listed in the assignment below. I collected some of the assignments in Overleaf: PhiCogn.\nI then presented a general approach one can have to apply structuralist ontology to concepts to the class: Overleaf: PhiCogn Presentation.\nIn order to complete the course I write this essay: Ontic Structuralism of Concepts."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Logic-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Logic-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Philosophy of Logic (Lecture).md","title":"Philosophy of Logic (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/What-a-Logic-Could-not-Be","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/A-Topological-Approach-to-Infinite-Disjunctions"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by, Dr. Thomas Schiller during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA). A full description of the course can be found here. I already followed a course in Philosophy of Logic for which I wrote What a Logic Could not Be connected to the ideas I am writing about in Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project).\nFor completion of the course I write an essay that I make available here: A Topological Approach to Infinite Disjunctions."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Science-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Science-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Philosophy of Science (Lecture).md","title":"Philosophy of Science (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Halvorson,-H.-(2012),-What-Scientific-Theories-Could-not-Be","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Halvorson,-H.-(2013),-The-semantic-view,-if-plausible,-is-syntactic","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Questions--and--Other-Works/First-Thesis-Concept/Philosophy-First-Thesis-Concept/Structuralism","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/W.-V.-Quine/Quine,-V.W.-(1951),-Two-Dogmas"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by, Dr. Sebastian de Haro Oll√© during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA).\nAssignments\n\nOverleaf: PhiSci, 1, mark: 10\nOverleaf: PhiSci, 2, mark: 9\nOverleaf: PhiSci, 3\nOverleaf: PhiSci Presentation\n\nLecture Notes\nHere I summarise the content of the lecture and state brief remarks on the papers read during the course.\n02.09, I. Logical Empiricism\n\nFrege, Russel, Wittgenstein: Logic has a tautological nature\n\nRussel: ‚Äúmath is the only science in which you don‚Äôt know what you are talking about‚Äù\n\ncontent does not matter\n\n\n\n\nVienna Circle: every principle is either empirically verifiable or logically necessary\nCarnap:\n\nEarly Carnap: philosophy as linguistic analysis\n\nsyntactic, analysis of the form of reasoning\nsemantic, is part of psychology\nof a word tfae: (i) dedicubility, (ii) conditions of truth, (iii) verifiability, (iv) meaning\n\nwhy? given the following theory\n\n\nscientific theory := set of sentences\nsentences that are not observational (i.e. theoretical) shall be divisible into observational\nstrong position against metaphysics\n\n\n\n\nSyntactic view\n\nAxioms make a theory\nTheorems (sentences) can be derived\nCorrespondences Rules bond the theorems to the observations\n\n\nChange in Theory\n\nPositivists Periodisation: you do observations given a theory in the background\nKuhn: a change in the theory, changes the observation\nGalisons: experiments and instruments shall change, accordingly to theories\n\nthere can be dialogue between sciences,\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSemantic view\n\ntheories are sets of models\n\nnot all theories can be axiomatised\nno language dependence\n\n\nsee Halvorson, H. (2012), What Scientific Theories Could not Be, Halvorson, H. (2013), The semantic view, if plausible, is syntactic, in general Structuralism.\n\n\n\n5.09, II. Popper\n\nFalsifiability: empirically provably false\n\nnecessary statements are not fansifiable\n\nwhat is necessary, might be a metaphysical matter\nmathematical statements\n\n\n\n\nobservations rely on the theory\nLakatos: falsifiability should be reviewed\n\nno guidelines on what to do in response to an anomaly\nNew Criteria\n\nNaive falsificationist: falsifiable \\to acceptable (early Popper)\nSofisticated falsificationist: falsifiable, (i) progressive, (ii) heuristic value\n\nbroader view: one should look at research programs, not theories\n\n\n\n\nParts of a theory\n\nHard Core: real essence of the theory\nProtectvie Belt: what can change insignificantly\n\n\n\n\n\n09.09, III. Kuhn\n\nParadigm: a framework for practicing science shared by the scientists in a particular discipline\n\nscience is a social enterprise\ntheoretical principles &amp; assumptions, methods, tools,\n\n\nscience is conservative and seemingly dogmatic:\n\nPopper is on the opposite side\n\nKuhn is not normative, he describes how sciences are\n\n\n\n\nobservation is theory-laden, it cannot be completely detached from paradigms\n\nsemantic incommensurability: words get different menaing\nmethodological incommensurability: standards of measure and method change\n\n\nCritiques to Kuhn:\n\nKuhn‚Äôs paradigms compete and do not comunicate, that‚Äôs not true\n‚Äúparadigm‚Äù is not a precisely described enough word\nLakatos: there are far less emotions involved than Kuhn claims, it‚Äôs not politics\n\n\na good sci.th. is: (i) accuracy, (ii) consistency, (iii) broad scope, (iv) simplicity, (v) fruitfulness\n\nit is not an algorithmic choice, different previous experience gives different valuations\n\n\nMax Weber: values influence scientists‚Äô actions, but (social) science is objective\n\nchoice of topic is value-laden, research is value-free, application of results is value-laden again\n\n\nLongino: objective knowledge can result at community level\n\nCriteria for objectivity:\n\nrecognised avenues for criticism (peer review)\nshared standards\ncommunity is responsive\nequality of intellectual authority\n\n\n\n\n\n16.09, IV. Quine\n\nDuhem: there is no crucial experiment, it cannot be the experiment that falsifies the theory\n\n‚Äúhypotheses can only be tested in combination with auxiliary assumptions‚Äù\neven if you believe to have falsified the theory, there could always be an unconceived alternative which saves the theory and of which nobody thought of.\n\n\nQuinde: Quine, V.W. (1951), Two Dogmas\n\nReductionism: scientific statements are logically equivalent to statements in empiricist language\n\nsubj.lang. of immediate experience / obj.lang. of physical things\n\n\nAnalytic / Synthetic Distinction: difference between conceptual schemes and facts is of degree only\n\nat a certain point, while defining an analytic statement, one will use some experience.\n\n\n\n\nin the end, the two dogmas are equiv.\n\n\nCritique:\n\nProf: all started with skepticism on meaning, if we have a theory of meaning, problem solved\n\nintention of a sentence is in possible worlds semantics\n\nmax.set s.t. S holds\n\n\n\n\n\n\nUnder-determination:\n\nEmpirically equivalent: same observational sentences\nTheoretically inequivalent: different theoretical sentences\n\n\nhence theory is under-determined by the empirical data.\n\n\n\n23.09, V. Scientific Explanation &amp; Understanding\n\nbefore ‚Äò48: explanation is not a philosophical topic for logical empiricists.\nC. Hempel, 1948: covering law model, epistemic explanation\n\ndeductive argument: conditions &amp; general laws explain (deductively prove) the phenomenon.\n\nonly general laws prove only general things\n\n\nConditions of adequacy\n\nlogical consequence {can you actually formalise the conditions? perhaps the general laws}\ngeneral law, to guarantee necessity {trivially take spatio-temporally bounded general laws?}\nexplanans must have empirical content\ntrue metaphysically {empirically accessible?}\n\n\nNo need of causation, this is more general\nProblems:\n\nIt is not clear what explains what, one can change arguments and have symmetries\nOne get to correlations rather than explenations\n\n\nAlternatives\n\ncausation is needed to explain\n\nHume: deletes cause\n\nHume, counterfactual: if no A, then no B, hence A causes B\nHume, regularity theory: usually the sun rises.\n\n\nDe Regt: causation is one way, not the only one\n\n\nunification of how phenomena fit in a broader pattern\n\n{this could be deductive, general law give the frame, conditions the instance\n-: not really, not as formal and you can already assume E to have happened}\n\n\npragmatic, basically contextualism\nscientific explanation requires understanding\n\n\n\n\nUnderstanding:\n\nHempel‚Äôs Eliminativism: understanding is matter of the subject, it is psychological.\nKhalifa‚Äôs Reductvism: having an explanation could be enough\n\nLipton: need to know the cause\nDe Regt: have an oracle who, you know, tells you the truth, you have still no understanding\n\n\nCarnap: in order to have understanding one should\n\ncapability of use for the description of facts\nmetaphysical understanding (refused)\nknowing semantic truth conditions\n\n\nvan Fraassen:\n\nexplanation &amp; understanding are part of the pragmatic, subjective.\nexplanation is irreducible and special to each subject.\nexplanation is not a relation between theory and fact, it is a three term, with also context.\n\n\nDe Regt: Pragmatic use of Understanding\n\nmacro-level: science as a whole\nmeso-level: scientific community\nmicro-level: individuals\n\n\n\n\n\n17.10\n\nPutnam &amp; Oppenheim, Unity of Science as a Working Hypothesis\n\nOne only discipline: Science\n\nSame law, same laws, and coherent laws\n\n\nReducibility of a theory: T_1 reduces T_2 iff\n\nvocabulary in T_2 contains terms not in the vocabulary of T_1\n\n\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Proof-Theory-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Proof-Theory-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Proof Theory (Lecture).md","title":"Proof Theory (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by, Dr. Marianna Girlando during my 5th Semester at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc. Logic (UvA). A full description of the course can be found here.\nAssignments\n\nOverleaf: PT, 1\nOverleaf: PT, 2\nOverleaf: PT, 3\nOverleaf: PT, 4\nOverleaf: PT, 5\nOverleaf: PT, 6\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/3rd-Semester":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/3rd-Semester","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/3rd Semester.md","title":"3rd Semester","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/Index-of-Bachelor-Works"],"tags":[],"content":"See 3rd Semester."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/6th-Semester":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/6th-Semester","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/6th Semester/6th Semester.md","title":"6th Semester","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Assume-I-finish-the-MoL-in-one-year,-what-then","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Master-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Track-of-the-MSc.-Logic","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Rudiments-in-Set-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Model-Theory,-ILLC-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Structures-for-Semantics-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Mathematics-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Type-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Recursion-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Topology,-Logic-and-Learning-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Logic-and-Probability-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/6th-Semester-Courses-Choice"],"tags":[],"content":"During the second and final semester (see Assume I finish the MoL in one year, what then) of the M.Sc. Logic (UvA). The courses I will list, counting the Master Thesis amount to a total of 18 + 27 + 30 = 75 EC.\nI plan to take the following mandatory courses to complete the tracks I am pursuing (see Track of the MSc. Logic):\n\nRudiments in Set Theory (Lecture)\nModel Theory, ILLC (Lecture)\nStructures for Semantics (Lecture)\n\nAdditionally, I plan to attend the following courses:\n\nPhilosophy of Mathematics (Lecture)\nType Theory (Lecture)\nRecursion Theory (Lecture)\nTopology, Logic and Learning (Lecture)\nLogic and Probability (Lecture)\n\nThe reasoning behind these choices is detailed in 6th Semester Courses Choice."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Applications-and-Limitations-of-Interpretations-in-Ontology":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Applications-and-Limitations-of-Interpretations-in-Ontology","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/6th Semester/Applications and Limitations of Interpretations in Ontology.md","title":"Applications and Limitations of Interpretations in Ontology","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Mathematics-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"For the Philosophy of Mathematics (Lecture) I wrote the following essay.\n\\include{name}\n\\title{Applications and Limitations of Interpretations in Ontology}\n \n\\begin{document}\n \n\\maketitle\n \n\\begin{abstract}\n    In this essay we focus on the ontological implications of the set theoretic result that adding urelements to pure set theory does not increase its expressibility. Two main elements are necessary for the argumentation: first, we introduce the concept of interpretation and, in particular, the result that \\(ZF\\) is definitionally equivalent to \\(ZFU\\); secondly, we show how a typical form of ontological argumentation relies on such interpretations. The core goal of the essay is to demonstrate, via examples and a review of broader ontological literature, the limitations of using interpretations in ontological debates.\n\\end{abstract}\n \n\\subsection*{Introduction}\nTo achieve the goal of this essay‚Äînamely, to present crucial limitations to the applicability of paraphrasing arguments in ontological debates‚Äîwe begin by introducing the reader to set theory and the concept of urelements, emphasizing the natural emergence of urelements in the initial conception of sets. In order to reach the primary line of argumentation, we then introduce the definition of interpretation and of definitional equivalence as presented by \\cite{visser}. With these definitions in hand, we present the result by \\cite{lowe} on the similarity of pure set theory and set theory with urelements.\n \nThe second main element of the essay concerns the applicability of such set-theoretic results‚Äîwhich focus solely on the linguistic side of formal systems‚Äîto ontological debates. This is achieved by presenting parts of \\cite{warren}, where a form of argumentation is set forth that can be very precisely defined. In this argument, a paraphrase (which is closely related to the concept of a relative interpretation as presented by \\cite{visser}) is used to show how the existence of those elements that do not increase the expressive power of the language can be disregarded by committing only to the \\q{smaller} language. We focus particularly on the limitations of this reasoning: as Warren himself notes, sets, by being abstract objects, cannot ontologically replace physical entities. We examine the reasons for this limitation further and address the question of exactly where the boundaries lie for this approach. We then present additional examples involving properties, considering a class of well-behaved properties that appear to best match sets, and question whether the paraphrasing succeeds in such a favourable environment. Finally, we discuss how, in general, there are two possible answers: either ontology is divided into distinct classes in which successful paraphrases can occur only within each class, or the boundaries between these classes are fuzzy, so that the composability of interpretations fails‚Äîthereby preventing the formation of a proper category as envisioned in \\cite{visser}.\n \n\\section{Philosophy of Set Theory with and Without Urelements}\nIn this section, we provide a brief introduction to the philosophical significance of incorporating urelements into set theory. First, we explain how the role of urelements appears to be crucial for the most basic philosophical intuition of what a set is. Next, we discuss why urelements have recently come to be considered superfluous in contemporary mathematics, by briefly presenting the relevant mathematical results as outlined in \\cite{lowe}. Finally, returning to the philosophical considerations, we discuss the rationale for including them in our philosophical frameworks. In particular, we outline the specific role that urelements play in ontological debates, and demonstrate how set theory can be employed‚Äîsee \\cite{warren}‚Äîto derive important conclusions in broader ontological discussions. We begin by considering urelements as introduced in \\cite{yao}:\n \n\\begin{quote}\n    Urelements are members of sets that are not themselves sets. \n\\end{quote}\n \n\\subsection{The Intuition of Set}\nFor both mathematicians and philosophers, the idea of recasting all of mathematics in the language of set theory has always been highly appealing. This allure comes not only from set theory‚Äôs standing as a uniquely formal and well-structured framework ‚Äì with its most popular version, $ZFC$, being remarkably simple ‚Äì but also from the fact that sets are naturally intuitive and straightforward. The notion that complex results across algebra, analysis, and number theory can all be derived from the basic idea of a set is, without a doubt, very attractive.\n \nYet, within this vision two distinct ideas are often mixed up: the everyday, intuitive notion of a set and the rigorous mathematical construction of sets. For example, one could argue that the way we develop our understanding of arithmetic numbers ‚Äì at least the finite ones, as discussed in \\cite{carey} ‚Äì closely mirrors the formal structure given by arithmetic axioms (like those in $PA$), so that the numbers we learn to count eventually resemble those defined by formal systems. Even this simple arithmetic case, however, encounters difficulties when the formalisation yields models that do not necessarily capture the \\textit{intended} interpretation, such as the occurrence of non-standard models.\n \nWhen we shift our focus back to set theory and compare our intuitive grasp of sets with the formal structures we ultimately construct, there are significant challenges to overcome before we can achieve a correspondence akin to that in arithmetic ‚Äì and even then, with some limitations. First, when we think of sets as collections of objects in the physical world, this notion seems to arise in a much more instinctive manner and much earlier in our development compared with arithmetic. For instance, we naturally form the idea of a set when grouping items that share a common property, such as objects of the same colour. Nevertheless, this basic notion is still quite different from the formal concept of a set used in set theory. Moreover, a common initial confusion is that these everyday sets, as collections of objects, often include elements that are not themselves sets. In fact, the very first intuitive idea of a set that people use in daily life contains what we call urelements‚Äîobjects that are not sets.\n \nIn the upcoming subsection, we introduce some mathematical results showing that it is possible to rephrase all those urelements in terms of sets while preserving the full meaning of our expressions. Initially, this should be regarded purely as a linguistic transformation‚Äîa rephrasing of our language into one that does not explicitly include urelements, yet conveys exactly the same ideas. The following subsection then explores how one can justify this transformation from an ontological perspective, ultimately reducing urelements to a smaller collection until only sets remain.\n \n\\subsection{Interpretations of Theories}\nAs we have seen, one primary goal of set theory, ever since it gained popularity in mathematical discourse, has been to recast mathematics in set‚Äêtheoretic terms. This approach offers the significant advantage that the language of set theory is remarkably simple, and once fully developed, the theory that defines sets turns out to be, in most of its axioms, straightforward. Conversely, if we were to choose between set theory with urelements and set theory without them, it is clearly more convenient to adopt the version without urelements. Urelements introduce additional complications in the language and require extra considerations when formulating the axioms, thereby making the overall system somewhat more complex.\n \nThis naturally raises the question: if we are to recast mathematics in set‚Äêtheoretic language, should urelements be included, and if so, which ones? A compelling argument against including urelements is to demonstrate that they are redundant. One way to do this is to prove that adding urelements to the language‚Äîand adopting the corresponding theory that reformulates the $ZF$ axioms so they retain an analogous meaning when quantifiers range over a larger domain that includes urelements‚Äîdoes not actually extend the expressive power of the language but instead leaves it unchanged.\n \nPhrasing this claim in precise mathematical terms is challenging, as many details must be rigorously defined. To formalise the notion of redundancy in the expressive power of the language, we introduce two key concepts as presented in \\cite{visser}. A \\textit{relative translation} is a syntactic mapping between the language of set theory with urelements and that of pure set theory; it consists of a formula defining the domain of the translation together with a mapping that assigns to each predicate symbol a corresponding formula in the target language. A \\textit{relative interpretation} is a relative translation that further preserves the logical structure of a theory‚Äînamely, it ensures that if a sentence is provable in the original theory, then its translation is provable in the target theory. In this way, by constructing a relative translation (and hence a relative interpretation) between the urelement theory and the pure set theory, we can rigorously demonstrate that adding urelements does not enrich the expressive power of the language. We see in more detail how this works in the upcoming subsection.\n \n\\subsubsection{Similarity of $ZF$ and $ZFU$}\nFollowing \\cite{visser}, we first present the formal definition of an interpretation and then introduce four conditions that can be used to consider two interpretations as identical. Understanding the identity criteria of an object is crucial because it provides us with the proper ontology of that object and allows us to understand its true nature. We begin by defining a relative translation as a tuple \n\\[\n\\langle \\delta, F \\rangle,\n\\]\nwhere \\(\\delta\\) is a formula in the target language that determines the domain of the translation‚Äîthat is, it specifies which elements of the target structure correspond to the elements in the source language‚Äîand \\(F\\) is a mapping that assigns to each predicate symbol \\(R\\) (of arity \\(n\\)) in the source language a corresponding formula \\(F(R)\\) in the target language with free variables among \\(v_0,\\dots,v_{n-1}\\). A relative interpretation is then defined as a triple \n\\[\n\\langle U, \\tau, V \\rangle,\n\\]\nwhere \\(U\\) is a theory in the source language, \\(V\\) is a theory in the target language, and \\(\\tau = \\langle \\delta, F \\rangle\\) is a relative translation from the language of \\(U\\) to that of \\(V\\) such that for every sentence \\(A\\) of \\(U\\), if \\(U \\vdash A\\) then \\(V \\vdash A^\\tau\\) (with \\(A^\\tau\\) denoting the translation of \\(A\\) under \\(\\tau\\)).\n \nThe framework presented in \\cite{visser} distinguishes several levels of sameness between interpretations; however, here we focus on the strongest level, namely, \\textit{synonymity} or \\textit{definitional equivalence}. In our notation, the variables \\(K, L, \\dots\\) always range over triples of the form \\(\\langle U, \\tau, V \\rangle\\). The following are the detailed conditions that must be satisfied for two relative interpretations \n\\(K = \\langle U, \\tau, V \\rangle\\) and \\(K&#039; = \\langle U, \\tau&#039;, V \\rangle\\) to be considered definitionally equivalent (i.e. equal$_0$ or =$_0$):\n \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item[(a)] \\textit{Equivalence of Domain Formulas:} The domain formulas used in the translations must be provably equivalent in the target theory \\(V\\); that is,\n    \\[\n    V \\vdash \\delta_\\tau \\leftrightarrow \\delta_{\\tau&#039;},\n    \\]\n    ensuring that both translations choose the same subset of \\(V\\) as the universe corresponding to the source theory.\n    \n    \\item[(b)] \\textit{Equivalence of Predicate Translations:} For every predicate symbol \\(R\\) in the source language, the formulas assigned by \\(F_\\tau\\) and \\(F_{\\tau&#039;}\\) must be provably equivalent in \\(V\\):\n    \\[\n    V \\vdash F_\\tau(R) \\leftrightarrow F_{\\tau&#039;}(R).\n    \\]\n    This guarantees that the relational structure is identically preserved by both translations.\n    \n    \\item \\textit{Equivalence on Formulas:} Consequently, for every sentence \\(A\\) in the source language, the translations \\(A^\\tau\\) and \\(A^{\\tau&#039;}\\) must be provably equivalent in \\(V\\). This condition ensures that the entire deductive content of the source theory \\(U\\) is captured in the same manner by both interpretations.\n\\end{itemize}\n \nWhat is the result of our main interest for this purpose is that $ZF$ and $ZFU$ are proved to be \\textit{similar} or \\textit{definitionally equivalent} in \\cite{lowe}. This is a result that is achieved by constructing explicit translations between the two theories. In his proof, L√∂we first defines a translation from $ZF$ to $ZFU$ by identifying each pure set in a model of $ZF$ with a corresponding set in a model of $ZFU$, effectively disregarding the urelements. Conversely, he shows that every model of $ZFU$ contains a canonical inner model of pure sets‚Äîits \\textit{kernel}‚Äîwhich satisfies the axioms of $ZF$. By recursively translating sets in a $ZFU$ model into pure sets, one can demonstrate that the additional axioms governing urelements do not alter the structure of the pure sets. Consequently, every theorem concerning pure sets in $ZF$ remains valid in $ZFU$, and vice versa. Thus, L√∂we&#039;s construction establishes that $ZFU$ is merely a conservative extension of $ZF$, showing that the expressive power of the language is unchanged even when urelements are present.\n \nBefore turning to the main claim of the essay, we examine the ontological consequences arising from this debate. In particular, we are interested in understanding how translations serve to diminish the role of urelements in our considerations, thereby providing a basis for more effective arguments in ontology. By showing that the addition of urelements does not extend the expressive power of our set‚Äêtheoretic language we are led to question whether urelements are ontologically indispensable.\n \n\\subsection{Urelements in Ontological Debates}\nWhen one first realises that sets are tools that allow us to express all of the mathematics we discuss, a mathematical realist might then question whether it remains appropriate to assert that entities such as numbers or vector spaces exist independently, or whether it is more parsimonious to simply acknowledge the existence of sets‚Äîsince all those other terms can be paraphrased in set-theoretic language. This straightforward yet informal argument implicitly bridges two distinct domains of philosophy. On one hand, we have results that are essentially linguistic, such as translations between different languages that speak of various objects; on the other hand, we derive conclusions about the ontology of the objects being discussed. Without a deeper explanation of this connection, however, the argument appears potentially fallacious‚Äîas, for instance, most would agree that the ontology of a \\textit{chair} does not depend on the language used to describe it.\n \nOn this note, \\cite{warren} argues that in ontological debates there is a frequently employed line of argumentation that uses interpretations\\fn{the relation between paraphrases and interpretations is mentioned in \\cite{warren}, p. 1245}:\n \n\\begin{quote}\n    Adding ontological resources usually buys us some expressive power. This added expressive power is often offered as a reason for accepting the new ontology. But if a paraphrase is available, then the additional expressive power can be had without going in for the new ontology.\n\\end{quote}\n \nThe case of interest for applying the similarity between $ZF$ and $ZFU$ is one in which the resources accepted in the debate encompass the entirety of set theory, while some or every other object is disputed. In this scenario, we can successfully argue by considering $ZF$ as the nihilist theory‚Äîthat is, a theory which accepts the resources provided by set theory but denies the existence of any other objects‚Äîwhile the anti-nihilist side supports some form of $ZFU$. In \\cite{warren}, the author contends that the applicability of this ontological step depends on the subtleties of the specific debate in question and that this method has clear weaknesses when applied to a general claim such as this one.\n \nIn the upcoming section we aim to present one particular difficulty that arises both on the formal and informal level when working with translation in the attempt to conclude ontological claims. This issue has been only partially mentioned in \\cite{warren}, and we show how the conclusions might be more dramatic for the argumentative line presented than they are regarded in that paper.\n \n\\section{Urelements and the Metalanguage}\nIn \\cite{warren} before having the relative interpretations formally presented, we have the following concern: \n\\begin{quote}\n    The big picture point of interest is simple. When our RESOURCES are the resources of set theory, then OBJECTS + RESOURCES can be paraphrased using RESOURCES. Section 2&#039;s discussion took place in the informal language of set theory, in which we proved results about class models of $ZFU$. As we noted there, it simplified things to assume in the informal metalanguage that the disputed objects exist. But this is not an assumption that the anti-existence side in an ontological dispute can make. They deny the existence of the disputed objects. This is what the entire dispute is about! According to the anti-existence side, the supposed universe $V_{\\text{Disp} \\cup \\text{Undisp}}$ simply is $V_{\\text{Undisp}}$ - \\q{$\\text{Disp}(x)$} is empty, according to them.\n\\end{quote}\nThis fundamental issue is then resolved by constructing the relative interpretation in a language that takes as urelements only those objects on which both parties agree‚Äîthe \\(\\text{Undisp}\\)‚Äîit follows that such a result must be intelligible to both sides, and even the existence side will need to agree that all they can affirm about the disputed objects can be stated without assuming their existence.\n \nWhat we argue for here is that an analogous problem arises even when we choose the smaller language. On one hand, anti-existence advocates reject any argument formulated in a metalanguage that includes the disputed objects; on the other, proponents of the existence of the disputed objects would object to restricting the language solely to a smaller subset comprising only the undisputed objects.\n \nTo simplify the context, we now consider the anti-existence side to claim that there are no urelements (i.e. \\(\\text{Undisp} = \\emptyset\\)), while the existence side asserts the existence of some finite set of urelements, \\(\\text{Disp} = \\{u_1, u_2, ..., u_n\\}\\) denoting some physical objects. In order for the construction of the translation to be intelligible to the anti-existence side, the metalanguage in which it is developed must not include the disputed urelements; for the reasons Warren states above, this metalanguage would then be that of pure set theory. Such an argument would be entirely acceptable to the anti-existence side. What we question now, is whether the existence side would agree with the restriction of the metalanguage to a mathematical language that does not include physical entities.\n \nOn this point, Warren makes a straightforward note:\n\\begin{quote}\n    Of course, the language of the pro-existence side (\\(L_{\\text{Disp} \\cup \\text{Undisp}}\\)) can include these symbols, but nobody ever doubted that the \\q{bigger} ontological language could paraphrase the \\q{smaller} ontological language. They can do so quite simply by restricting quantifiers to exclude the disputed objects.\n\\end{quote}\n \nIn our simple example, this is equivalent to saying that the language of pure set theory is clearly intelligible also to someone whose language ranges over physical objects. What remains unclear‚Äîand precisely the passage that we claim to be failing‚Äîis whether the mere intelligibility of the language of pure set theory, for someone who claims the existence of urelements, implies that they would agree to limit the expressibility of their metalanguage to that fragment. Even though the construction of the relative interpretation is intelligible to the existence side, proponents of the existence of physical objects would object to the idea that such objects can be reduced to mere sets. The reason simply being that physical objects belong to another class of entities while sets are abstract objects and no collection of abstract objects makes up a physical one. This point partially also remarked by Warren, as he implicitly underlines some similar limitations, either considering debates that only concern abstract objects or by using the argument to reduce sets of physical entities to smaller sets of urelements that still contain physical entities (see \\cite{warren}, p. 1246).\n \n\\subsection{Crossing an Ontological Class}\n \nThe question now arises whether this argument can be extended to certain classes of abstract objects that cannot be easily coded with sets. A notorious example is that of properties. The traditional comparison considers sets with physical objects as urelements, but a similar discussion applies when comparing properties and pure sets. The standard argument is that properties cannot be viewed purely extensionally because there exist distinct properties with the same extension‚Äîfor example, the property of collecting entities with a heart versus those with a kidney, which may have the same extension yet are clearly different properties.\n \nWhen we apply the previous discussion here, we are engaging in something more general than merely proposing an extensional treatment of properties. For instance, a mapping from a language that includes properties to a language of sets with urelements might fail in the given example by identifying two properties that are actually distinct. To facilitate the process, let us restrict our attention to well-behaved properties‚Äîthat is, those whose extensions are sets, thereby excluding those whose extension we cannot prove to be a set. Now, suppose we were to establish a relative interpretation between the language of well-behaved properties and that of \\(ZFU\\), where the urelements are precisely the entities to which the properties apply. This could be achieved by, for example, distinguishing all properties with the same extension by indexing them by an ordinal.\n \nOnce we have demonstrated that this mapping is indeed a valid relative interpretation, the question remains: would this allow us to conclude that including properties in our ontology is unnecessary, as everything can be captured by the resources of sets? Similarly to the earlier debate in which physical objects were argued to belong to a different ontological branch, one might then claim that properties are fundamentally different from sets and that even these well-behaved properties cannot be fully rephrased in \\(ZFU\\)‚Äîand hence, by composition, in \\(ZF\\). This is traditionally done by claiming that the intensionality of properties cannot be well captured by set theoretic constructions. A similar discussion can also be done for possible worlds, where modally realists metaphysical frameworks would certainly disagree with their reduction to mere sets.\n \nAt first, it was clear that the gap between sets and physical objects was too wide to bridge; one could not convincingly argue that physical objects should be ontologically reduced to sets. A similar argument can be made with properties or possible worlds, since properties possess something fundamentally distinct from sets, and any rephrasing of them in set-theoretic terms would be merely a linguistic maneuver rather than an ontological reduction. The open question then is: what are the limits of these branches? In other words, which objects can we satisfactorily rephrase in terms of sets so that we might argue that an ontological commitment to those objects is unnecessary?\n \nThis question can be approached in two ways: in a fuzzy manner or in a determined manner. If answered in a determined way, ontologies would be split into distinct classes in which interpretations can be made, and within each of these classes an expressive language would exist that can phrase every term appropriately. For instance, one might have sets for mathematical entities and atomic particles for physical objects. However, what seems more plausible in a philosophical debate is that these classes have fuzzy boundaries. That is, there may be cases where some entities are close enough to be interpreted in a second class, and that second class is close enough to a third class for an interpretation to be established between them, yet we would not agree that the first class can be interpreted in the third one. This failure of composability of interpretation undermines the formation of a well-behaved category, as required by the framework presented in \\cite{visser}.\n \n\\subsection*{Conclusion}\nWe have first seen that the argumentation presented by \\cite{warren} is accompanied by certain difficulties, as he himself acknowledged, and that incorporating these issues into ontological debates raises questions that are not easily answered. In ontology, it is crucial that the objects whose existence is posited are organized into distinct classes. This classification emerges naturally from philosophical inquiry, and any attempt at generalization necessarily entails adopting a firm stance in various debates. Consequently, we are left with two alternatives, neither of which we definitively endorse, but both of which expose significant limitations. This concludes that the boundaries of the ontological classes in which successful paraphrases may be applied must be thoroughly examined before any paraphrase-based argumentation can be properly considered.\n \n \n\\newpage\n\\begin{thebibliography}{12}\n \n\\bibitem[Carey 2010]{carey} Carey, J. (2010). \\textit{Foundations of Set Theory}. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. \n \n\\bibitem[L√∂we 2006]{lowe} L√∂we, B. (2006). Set Theory with and without Urelements and Categories of Interpretations. \\textit{Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic}, 47(1), 83--91.\n \n\\bibitem[Visser 2004]{visser} Visser, A. (2004). Categories of Interpretations in Logic. \\textit{Journal of Symbolic Logic}, 69(2), 295--319.\n \n\\bibitem[Warren 2021]{warren} Warren, J. (2021). Ontology, Set Theory, and the Paraphrase Challenge. \\textit{Journal of Philosophical Logic}, 50(6), 1231--1248.\n \n\\bibitem[Yao 2023]{yao} Yao, B. (2023). Set Theory with Urelements (Doctoral dissertation). University of Notre Dame.\n \n\\end{thebibliography}\n \n \n \n \n \n\\end{document}"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Forcing-on-Urelements-(Research-Project)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Forcing-on-Urelements-(Research-Project)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/6th Semester/Forcing on Urelements (Research Project).md","title":"Forcing on Urelements (Research Project)","links":[],"tags":[],"content":""},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Logic-and-Probability-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Logic-and-Probability-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/6th Semester/Logic and Probability (Lecture).md","title":"Logic and Probability (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/6th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Others/Cameron,-J.,-(1997),-The-Random-Graph"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course by Prof. van Balder at the ILLC Amsterdam for my M.Sc.
