Dettaglia gli obblighi sanitari, burocratici e strutturali imposti dalla normativa Nazionale Italiana e dalla Regione Liguria. La conformit√† a queste regole √® mandatoria per l‚Äôaccettazione di equini nella struttura. Ogni proprietario di cavalli deve inoltre prendere visione e firmare lo specifico Contract for Horses.\n\n\n\nNormativa Italiana e Regionale (Liguria)\nLa detenzione di equidi (cavalli, asini, muli) in Italia non √® un‚Äôattivit√† libera, ma √® strettamente regolamentata per garantire la sanit√† pubblica e il benessere animale. Di seguito sono elencati i requisiti fondamentali che ColivingLiguria e il proprietario dei cavalli devono soddisfare.\n1. Registrazione e Burocrazia (Anagrafe Equina)\nPer ospitare legalmente dei cavalli sui nostri terreni (in particolare Terreni oltre Torrente), √® necessario formalizzare la presenza degli animali presso l‚ÄôASL competente (ASL 2 Savonese).\n\nCodice Aziendale (Codice Stalla):\n\nNormativa: D.P.R. 317/1996 e D.M. 29 dicembre 2009.\nObbligo: Anche per la detenzione non a fini di lucro, il terreno dove risiedono i cavalli deve essere registrato presso i Servizi Veterinari dell‚ÄôASL per ottenere un Codice Aziendale (Codice Stalla). Questo codice identifica il luogo fisico di detenzione.\nResponsabilit√†: ColivingLiguria (come proprietario del fondo o detentore) deve richiedere l‚Äôapertura del codice.\n\n\nPassaporto e Microchip:\n\nNormativa: Regolamento UE 2015/262 e D.M. 26 settembre 2011.\nObbligo: Ogni cavallo deve essere identificato tramite microchip e possedere il Passaporto Equino (Documento di Identificazione).\n\n\nRegistro di Carico e Scarico:\n\nNormativa: D.P.R. 320/1954 (Regolamento di Polizia Veterinaria).\nObbligo: La struttura deve tenere un registro aggiornato con gli ingressi e le uscite degli animali, vidimato dall‚ÄôASL.\n\n\n\n2. Requisiti Sanitari\n\nTest di Coggins (Anemia Infettiva Equina - AIE):\n\nNormativa: Ordinanza Ministeriale vigente e Piano Nazionale di Sorveglianza AIE.\nObbligo: √à obbligatorio per tutti i cavalli che vengono movimentati o che partecipano a concentramenti avere un test sierologico negativo per l‚ÄôAIE in corso di validit√† (generalmente annuale o biennale a seconda della zona di rischio).\n\n\nVaccinazioni:\n\nSebbene non tutte siano obbligatorie per legge per cavalli ‚Äúda compagnia‚Äù stanziali, l‚ÄôAntinfluenzale e l‚ÄôAntitetanica sono fortemente raccomandate e spesso richieste dai regolamenti interni di scuderia per la sicurezza comune.\n\n\n\n3. Benessere Animale e Requisiti Strutturali per il Codice Stalla\nLa Legge Regionale Liguria n. 23 del 22 marzo 2000 (‚ÄúTutela degli animali di affezione e prevenzione del randagismo‚Äù) e il Codice per la Tutela e la Gestione degli Equidi (Ministero della Salute) stabiliscono i parametri minimi.\nPer ottenere l‚Äôapertura del Codice Aziendale (Codice Stalla) presso l‚ÄôASL 2 Savonese, il terreno non deve solo rispettare il benessere animale, ma soddisfare specifici requisiti burocratico-strutturali:\n\nTitolo di Possesso (Requisito ASL):\n\nPer registrare il terreno, √® obbligatorio presentare l‚Äôatto di propriet√† o un contratto di affitto/comodato registrato all‚ÄôAgenzia delle Entrate. Un semplice accordo verbale o una scrittura privata non registrata non sono validi per l‚Äôottenimento del codice.\n\n\nGestione Deiezioni (Concimaia):\n\nAnche per cavalli al pascolo, l‚ÄôASL richiede un piano di gestione del letame. √à necessaria un‚Äôarea di stoccaggio (concimaia) impermeabilizzata a norma, oppure un piano di spandimento agronomico approvato, per evitare l‚Äôinquinamento delle falde acquifere.\n\n\nArmadietto Farmaci:\n\nIn loco deve essere presente un armadietto o un contenitore chiuso a chiave (identificato con apposita segnaletica) destinato alla custodia di eventuali farmaci veterinari, anche se al momento vuoto.\n\n\nDimensioni del Paddock:\n\nIl terreno (Terreni oltre Torrente, 1.240 m¬≤) rispetta i requisiti minimi di movimento. La normativa impone che l‚Äôanimale abbia la possibilit√† di ‚Äúmovimento libero‚Äù quotidiano.\n\n\n\n\nIl Rifugio (Tettoia/Box):\n\nNormativa: D.Lgs 146/2001 (Attuazione Direttiva 98/58/CE) e Codice per la Tutela e la Gestione degli Equidi.\nObbligo: I cavalli tenuti all‚Äôaperto devono avere accesso a un riparo naturale o artificiale che li protegga dalle intemperie (sole eccessivo, pioggia, vento) e dai predatori.\nCondizioni di Idoneit√†: Affinch√© la struttura sia legalmente valida come rifugio/box, deve rispettare tassativamente questi parametri:\n\nSalubrit√† del Fondo: Deve garantire una superficie di riposo permanentemente asciutta e pulita. √à vietato far stazionare gli animali nel fango; se il terreno naturale non drena, √® obbligatorio un fondo artificiale (es. massetto, ghiaia drenante o tappeti in gomma).\nAltezza di Sicurezza: Il soffitto deve essere sufficientemente alto da permettere al cavallo di tenere la testa in posizione naturale di allerta senza toccare la copertura (altezza minima consigliata al punto pi√π basso: 2,50m - 2,70m).\nVentilazione e Luce: La struttura non deve essere cieca o insalubre (come cantine o garage chiusi); deve garantire un ricircolo d‚Äôaria costante senza correnti dirette nocive e l‚Äôingresso di luce naturale.\nSpazio Vitale: Deve offrire una superficie calpestabile adeguata a permettere a tutti i cavalli presenti di coricarsi contemporaneamente (standard indicativo min. 9-12 m¬≤ per capo).\n\n\nNota: La struttura definitiva che costruiremo (vedi Horse Shelter) √® progettata per eccedere questi standard minimi.\n\n\n\n\nRecinzioni:\n\n√à vietato l‚Äôuso del filo spinato (filo spinato) per la recinzione dei paddock equini, in quanto causa frequente di gravi lesioni. Si deve utilizzare nastro elettrico, legno o materiali idonei anti-infortunio.\n\n\n\n4. Alimentazione e Acqua\n\nAcqua:\n\nNormativa: D.Lgs 146/2001.\nRequisito: L‚Äôacqua deve essere potabile o comunque idonea all‚Äôabbeverata (priva di contaminanti chimici o batteriologici nocivi) e disponibile ad libitum (sempre).\nVincolo per Codice Stalla: Se l‚Äôacqua viene prelevata dal torrente (e non dall‚Äôacquedotto comunale), per aprire il codice stalla √® obbligatorio allegare un certificato di analisi chimico-batteriologica recente che ne attesti la potabilit√†/idoneit√† zootecnica.\n\n\nCibo:\n\nDevono essere somministrati foraggi di buona qualit√†, privi di muffe e polveri (per evitare la bolsaggine). Lo stoccaggio del fieno deve avvenire in luogo asciutto (previsto nella struttura).\n\n\n\n5. Responsabilit√† Civile\n\nDanni a Terzi:\n\nNormativa: Articolo 2052 del Codice Civile.\nPrincipio: ‚ÄúIl proprietario di un animale o chi se ne serve per il tempo in cui lo ha in uso, √® responsabile dei danni cagionati dall‚Äôanimale, sia che fosse sotto la sua custodia, sia che fosse smarrito o fuggito‚Äù.\nPolicy: √à richiesta un‚Äôassicurazione RCT (Responsabilit√† Civile Terzi) specifica per i cavalli. Tutti i dettagli sulla manleva e le responsabilit√† sono definiti nel Contract for Horses.\n\n\n\n\nHorse Keeping Regulations\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nThis page acts as a legal and regulatory compendium for keeping horses at ColivingLiguria. It details the sanitary, bureaucratic, and structural obligations imposed by Italian National Regulations and the Liguria Region. Compliance with these rules is mandatory for the acceptance of equines into the facility. Every horse owner must also review and sign the specific Contract for Horses.\n\n\n\nItalian and Regional Regulations (Liguria)\nThe keeping of equines (horses, donkeys, mules) in Italy is not an unregulated activity, but is strictly regulated to guarantee public health and animal welfare. Listed below are the fundamental requirements that ColivingLiguria and the horse owner must meet.\n1. Registration and Bureaucracy (Equine Registry)\nTo legally host horses on our land (specifically Terreni oltre Torrente), it is necessary to formalise the presence of the animals with the competent Local Health Authority (ASL 2 Savonese).\n\nCompany Code (Codice Aziendale / Codice Stalla):\n\nRegulations: D.P.R. 317/1996 and D.M. 29 December 2009.\nObligation: Even for non-profit keeping, the land where the horses reside must be registered with the ASL Veterinary Services to obtain a Company Code (Codice Aziendale). This code identifies the physical location of keeping.\nResponsibility: ColivingLiguria (as the land owner or holder) must request the opening of the code.\n\n\nPassport and Microchip:\n\nRegulations: EU Regulation 2015/262 and D.M. 26 September 2011.\nObligation: Every horse must be identified via microchip and possess an Equine Passport (Identification Document).\n\n\nLoading and Unloading Register:\n\nRegulations: D.P.R. 320/1954 (Veterinary Police Regulation).\nObligation: The facility must keep an updated register of animal entries and exits, endorsed (vidimato) by the ASL.\n\n\n\n2. Health Requirements\n\nCoggins Test (Equine Infectious Anaemia - EIA):\n\nRegulations: Current Ministerial Ordinance and National EIA Surveillance Plan.\nObligation: It is mandatory for all horses being moved or participating in gatherings to have a valid negative serological test for EIA (generally annual or biennial depending on the risk zone).\n\n\nVaccinations:\n\nAlthough not all are legally mandatory for stationary ‚Äúcompanion‚Äù horses, Influenza and Tetanus are strongly recommended and often required by internal stable regulations for common safety.\n\n\n\n3. Animal Welfare and Structural Requirements for the Stable Code\nThe Liguria Regional Law No. 23 of 22 March 2000 (‚ÄúProtection of pets and prevention of straying‚Äù) and the Code for the Protection and Management of Equines (Ministry of Health) establish minimum standards.\nTo obtain the opening of the Company Code (Codice Stalla) at the ASL 2 Savonese, the land must not only respect animal welfare but also satisfy specific bureaucratic-structural requirements:\n\nTitle of Possession (ASL Requirement):\n\nTo register the land, it is mandatory to present the property deed or a lease/loan for use contract (comodato) registered with the Revenue Agency (Agenzia delle Entrate). A simple verbal agreement or an unregistered private deed are not valid for obtaining the code.\n\n\nManure Management (Manure Heap):\n\nEven for horses at pasture, the ASL requires a manure management plan. A storage area (concimaia) waterproofed to standard is required, or an approved agronomic spreading plan, to avoid pollution of aquifers.\n\n\nMedicine Cabinet:\n\nA lockable cabinet or container (identified with appropriate signage) designated for the custody of any veterinary medicines must be present on-site, even if currently empty.\n\n\nPaddock Dimensions:\n\nThe land (Terreni oltre Torrente, 1,240 m¬≤) meets the minimum requirements for movement. Regulations mandate that the animal must have the possibility of daily ‚Äúfree movement‚Äù.\n\n\nThe Shelter (Canopy/Box):\n\nRegulations: Legislative Decree 146/2001 (Implementation of Directive 98/58/EC) and Code for the Protection and Management of Equines.\nObligation: Horses kept outdoors must have access to a natural or artificial shelter that protects them from adverse weather (excessive sun, rain, wind) and predators.\nConditions of Suitability: For the structure to be legally valid as a shelter/box, it must strictly respect these parameters:\n\nHealthiness of the Ground: It must guarantee a permanently dry and clean resting surface. It is forbidden to keep animals standing in mud; if the natural ground does not drain, an artificial base (e.g., screed, draining gravel, or rubber mats) is mandatory.\nSafety Height: The ceiling must be sufficiently high to allow the horse to hold its head in a natural alert position without touching the roof (minimum recommended height at the lowest point: 2.50m - 2.70m).\nVentilation and Light: The structure must not be blind or unhealthy (like cellars or closed garages); it must guarantee constant air recirculation without harmful direct draughts and the entry of natural light.\nVital Space: It must offer adequate walkable surface area to allow all horses present to lie down simultaneously (indicative standard min. 9-12 m¬≤ per head).\n\n\nNote: The definitive structure we will build (see Horse Shelter) is designed to exceed these minimum standards.\n\n\nFences:\n\nThe use of barbed wire (filo spinato) for equine paddock fencing is forbidden, as it is a frequent cause of serious injury. Electric tape, wood, or suitable injury-proof materials must be used.\n\n\n\n4. Nutrition and Water\n\nWater:\n\nRegulations: Legislative Decree 146/2001.\nRequirement: Water must be potable or otherwise suitable for drinking (free from harmful chemical or bacteriological contaminants) and available ad libitum (always).\nConstraint for Stable Code: If water is drawn from the stream (and not from the municipal aqueduct), to open the stable code it is mandatory to attach a recent chemical-bacteriological analysis certificate attesting to its potability/zootechnical suitability.\n\n\nFood:\n\nHigh-quality forage, free from mould and dust (to avoid heaves/bolsaggine), must be provided. Hay storage must take place in a dry location (provided for in the structure).\n\n\n\n5. Civil Liability\n\nDamage to Third Parties:\n\nRegulations: Article 2052 of the Civil Code.\nPrinciple: ‚ÄúThe owner of an animal, or the person who uses it for the time being, is liable for damage caused by the animal, whether it was in their custody or had strayed or escaped.‚Äù\nPolicy: Specific Third-Party Liability Insurance (RCT) for horses is required. All details regarding indemnification and responsibilities are defined in the Contract for Horses.\n\n\n"},"ColivingLiguria/System/Archive/MicroSturtupHub/ColivingLiguria-for-Startups-and-Cofounders":{"slug":"ColivingLiguria/System/Archive/MicroSturtupHub/ColivingLiguria-for-Startups-and-Cofounders","filePath":"ColivingLiguria/System/Archive/MicroSturtupHub/ColivingLiguria for Startups and Cofounders.md","title":"ColivingLiguria for Startups and Cofounders","links":["ColivingLiguria/People/Simone-Testino","ColivingLiguria","Luna","ColivingLiguria/Financials/Public-Financial-Aid/FESR-Azione-1.3.3.-EU-Grant","ColivingLiguria/Financials/Business-Consultancy","ColivingLiguria/Financials/Business-Segments/Supplementary-Projects/Supplementary-Projects"],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nI‚Äôm Simone Testino, and I‚Äôm currently developing two main projects: ColivingLiguria, which transforms traditional villas into vibrant hubs for remote workers and creatives, and Luna, a startup focused on innovative event and industrial lighting. Coliving Liguria is designed as an ecosystem to foster new ventures. We offer space and support for co-founders for our startups, dedicated contributors, and entrepreneurs who want to develop their own projects within our environment. We provide financial and bureaucratic guidance, access to machinery and workshop space, and marketing support. As a resident, you‚Äôll also enjoy all community benefits, including access to courses and supplementary activities.\n\n\n\nAs the founder, I am actively working on building an environment that serves as a launchpad for like-minded entrepreneurs. We offer a unique opportunity to live and work in Liguria while benefiting from a structured support system. We welcome collaborators in three primary ways:\n\nJoin an existing in-house startup (like Luna).\nContribute directly to the core ColivingLiguria project.\nLaunch your own independent project with our support.\n\n1. Join Our In-House Startup: Luna\nWe are actively seeking co-founders and collaborators for our flagship technical startup, Luna, which has received funding through the FESR Azione 1.3.3. EU Grant. For individuals who wish to dedicate significant skills to this project, we offer highly advantageous terms, including potentially free accommodation at Coliving Liguria.\nWhat is Luna?\nLuna, through recently patented technologies, solves the inefficiencies of traditional light towers used on construction sites and at events. It is a large, spherical, helium-filled aerostatic balloon containing powerful LEDs. Held stable by tethers, it provides wide, diffuse, and energy-efficient illumination from a high vantage point (10-25 metres). The primary target market is high-end event lighting, with secondary applications in industry.\nWe are looking for individuals with skills in engineering, electronics, and business development.\n2. Launch Your Own Startup From Here\nIf you have your own business idea, Coliving Liguria provides the ideal environment and support structure to help you bring it to life.\nWhat We Offer\n\nFinancial &amp; Bureaucracy Assistance: I provide guidance on navigating Italian bureaucracy, company formation, and structuring financials for new startups in Italy. This draws from my direct experience securing European funds for ColivingLiguria. For in-depth support, see my Business Consultancy services.\nSpace &amp; Resources: We provide office space, workshops, and accommodation. For independent projects, this operates on a model where you rent resources from Coliving Liguria.\nPrototyping Equipment: You will have access to high-level industrial tools, including a 3D printer, available on-site for the development of Luna.\nMarketing Support: Leverage our network, including professional photographers and social media managers, to help promote your product or service. This aligns with our collaborative advertising model where promoting supplementary projects enhances the entire ecosystem.\nInvestment &amp; Partnership: For promising ideas that become official Coliving Liguria projects, we can discuss formal collaboration agreements that may include remuneration through profit sharing or other forms of equity participation in the new venture.\n\n3. Community and Lifestyle Benefits\nAll entrepreneurs and collaborators residing at Coliving Liguria benefit from the full community experience. This includes access to all planned activities and Supplementary Projects, such as language courses or sports activities, creating a balanced environment for work and life.\n\nHow to Get Started\nThe best way to begin is with a direct conversation with me, Simone Testino. I invite you to get in touch to gather more information on our current projects, discuss how you could contribute, share your impressions, or propose your own ideas.\nFor an initial, informal contact, the preferred channels are WhatsApp or Instagram. L‚Äôobiettivo era coprire in modo completo e approfondito tutti gli argomenti di Logica, Matematica e Fisica previsti dal bando di ammissione, alternando lezioni teoriche a esercitazioni pratiche mirate.\nIn questo corso ho svolto le seguenti attivit√†:\n\nSviluppo Autonomo del Materiale: Ho creato da zero tutto il materiale didattico, incluse slide teoriche, raccolte di esercizi e simulazioni per le lezioni.\nInsegnamento Online: Ho condotto l‚Äôintero corso in modalit√† online, gestendo una classe virtuale e utilizzando strumenti di didattica a distanza per massimizzare l‚Äôinterazione e l‚Äôefficacia dell‚Äôapprendimento.\n"},"Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Abstract-and-Spacial-Logic-Quizzes":{"slug":"Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Abstract-and-Spacial-Logic-Quizzes","filePath":"Personal Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura Abstract and Spacial Logic Quizzes.md","title":"Futura Abstract and Spacial Logic Quizzes","links":["Personal-Finance/Financial-Diary/2024/Futura-Logic-Quizzes","Manim-Code-for-Futura-Abstract-and-Spacial-Logic-Quizzes","Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Abstract-and-Spacial-Logic-Quizzes","System/Attachments/LogicQuizExample.jpeg"],"tags":[],"content":"Following the Futura Logic Quizzes, I outline here the main components needed to develop the code that generates the figures. I will use the Manim Community library.\nThe first step consists in building the general framework, which I implemented in Grid. This provides the basic structure into which the various figures will be inserted. In this framework, cells can be obscured, and one cell can be marked as the asked cell‚Äîthat is, the missing element that the student must replace by selecting from among the option cells. To complete this part, I also implemented a function capable of drawing figures in any cell of the grid or in any of the option cells.\nThe second part of the programme, detailed in Automation of Concepts, focuses on automating quiz generation. This component requires the concepts defined in Concepts, and aims to automatically produce quizzes that adhere to the logic of those concepts. The result of each run is saved locally in a folder. Concretely, this process consists of a simple for loop that iterates over all variables left free by each concept, generating a large collection of distinct quizzes.\nConcepts\nTo take some inspiration I first consult some similar examples given by manual of IQ tests that I previously collected. In particular I made the Gird taking inspiration from the LogicQuizExample.jpeg. From a similar pattern I draw the first example."},"Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Math-Didactic-Document":{"slug":"Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Math-Didactic-Document","filePath":"Personal Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura Math Didactic Document.md","title":"Futura Math Didactic Document","links":["Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura","Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Manuale-Aereonautica-Marzo","Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Manuale-Esercito-Marzo"],"tags":[],"content":"Between the 07.03.2025 and 12.03.2025 I have worked on a document commissioned by Futura for the training of students preparing for the oral exam. I save the code comprehending all material in Futura Manuale Aereonautica Marzo, which is kept private due to the agreement signed with Futura.\nRight after, I have then been assigned a second job Futura Manuale Esercito Marzo, of the same form of the former and with similar retribution which I did between the 13.03.2025 and the 19.03.2025.\nIn total for the first job I wrote 114 pages and for the second 122 new pages, in the second one I used some parts from the previous job. I saved all data on the documents in Spreadsheet: Futura Document Data. The retribution was of 10‚Ç¨ per page, totalling 2360‚Ç¨ in about 8 days of part time work, while still doing most of the assignment for university, quite a satisfaction."},"Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Military":{"slug":"Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura-Military","filePath":"Personal Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura Military.md","title":"Futura Military","links":["Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/Futura","Personal-Finance/Jobs/Teaching/Futura/ADT-Forze-Armate","System/Attachments/slide1.jpeg","System/Attachments/slide2.jpeg","System/Attachments/lastslide.jpeg"],"tags":[],"content":"On this page, I provide both the lesson materials I have produced and briefly present my work with Futura regarding preparation for public concourses. Misura\n\n\\LaTeX Code\nI suggest to compile this code using Overleaf, the following passages are crucial for the proper compilation of the code:\n\nDownload these images, and upload them (left column)\n\nslide1.jpeg\nslide2.jpeg\nlastslide.jpeg\n\n\nSet LuaTeX instead of LaTeXpdf compiler from the menu.\n\n\t% Compilare con XeLaTeX o LuaLaTeX\n \n\\documentclass{beamer}\n\\usepackage[absolute,overlay]{textpos}\n% Pacchetti necessari per il font Open Sans e la gestione dei colori\n\\usepackage{fontspec}   % Funziona con XeLaTeX o LuaLaTeX\n\\usepackage{xcolor}     % Per definire colori personalizzati\n\\usepackage{graphicx}   % Per includere immagini\n\\usepackage{enumitem}   % Per personalizzare gli elementi delle liste\n\\usepackage{adjustbox}  % Per adattare dimensioni di immagini e altri elementi\n\\usepackage{amsmath}    % Per le equazioni matematiche\n\\usepackage{pgfplots}   % Per i grafici\n \n% Impostare il font Open Sans (√® necessario avere Open Sans installato sul sistema)\n\\setsansfont{Open Sans}\n \n% Definire i colori personalizzati ADT\n\\definecolor{ADTBlue}{RGB}{26, 46, 73}   % Colore blu (#1A2E49)\n\\definecolor{ADTRed}{RGB}{235, 77, 61}   % Colore rosso (#EB4D3D)\n \n% Impostare il tema Beamer su default e modificare le impostazioni di colore\n\\setbeamercolor{normal This might provide a potential answer to the question I posed in Is it the Begin of a Motivational Decline: one of the main concerns I had there was finding a proper methodology or criteria to identify a field captivating enough to dedicate most of the upcoming years to. Some of these criteria will likely depend on the PhD Applications Results, while others are independent of them and might be relevant if I get into one of the PhD Applications in the US, as they impose no constraints on a specific programme.\nRegarding Finite Model Theory, I see several aspects that I find particularly attractive, and I will try to list them here while keeping in mind that I currently have no precise knowledge of what the field entails.\nFirst, I was deeply interested in Model Theory (Lecture) when I took the course at the University of Constance and will have a similar lecture again at the ILLC Amsterdam, namely Model Theory, ILLC (Lecture). I have also recently applied some notions from it in Ontic Structuralism of Concepts. This confirms that I am very much engaged in model theory and consider it one of the most intriguing fields in mathematical logic.\nSecondly, one major advantage of Finite Model Theory is its strong applicability in Computer Science, making it a particularly versatile area within mathematical logic. Keeping career paths open in directions similar to Balder‚Äôs (see LinkedIn) could provide some diversity in my future studies, allowing for a mix between academia and industry.\nLastly, Finite Model Theory‚Äîlikely as much as Model Theory‚Äîmay have interesting developments in neighbouring fields that I am highly interested in, ranging from Philosophy and Model Theory (2018) to its connections with Translation Theory, other areas of mathematical logic (but also Algebra, Graph Theory, Modal Logic), and its applications in computer science. It might therefore play a central role in several disciplines I am drawn to."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Five-Reasons-Why-I-Should-Slow-My-Pace":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Five-Reasons-Why-I-Should-Slow-My-Pace","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/Diary/Five Reasons Why I Should Slow My Pace.md","title":"Five Reasons Why I Should Slow My Pace","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2023/Bachelors'-Outline","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Master's-Outline","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications","Academia/Active--and--Works/Research-Areas/Research-Areas","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-in-the-US","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Is-it-the-Begin-of-a-Motivational-Decline"],"tags":[],"content":"I have been moving at full speed in my academic pursuits these past years (see Bachelors‚Äô Outline &amp; Master‚Äôs Outline) and now that I am about to finish the M.Sc. Logic (UvA) in record time, I am wondering whether this approach has been the right one or not. Thinking about whether this has been the right approach in the past is perhaps not the best question to ask, since I cannot change that anyway, and in the end, I am proud of my results, which both on paper and in terms of competence acquired, given the time span, are very satisfactory. The question I want to think about today is whether it makes sense to maintain a similar pace during my PhD, no matter where it will take me (see PhD Applications). Here I find some arguments in favour of changing the pace and then describe the struggles I had when keeping it in the past years.\nThe first key point is that what I did up to now allowed me to get a good introduction to different Research Areas but not get very deep into a single one. I have developed competence in a variety of fields in mathematical logic and analytical philosophy, but there is no single field in which I feel ready to publish. This is not a problem during my master‚Äôs but needs to change when getting started with the PhD programme. This non-specialisation is not directly a consequence of the quick pace I kept in these years, but it is certainly connected since I could never just follow my curiosity and take the time to read several papers on one topic and give accurate answers to all questions that came up, as I had too many things to do in too little time. As a consequence, I couldn‚Äôt get deep enough into a single field.\nSecondly, during a PhD, the activity I need to maximise the outcome is not really just to push to finish it quickly to do a Postdoc but instead to get good papers published in my field. This does not necessarily mean having a slower pace, but at least that I should not finish before the contract ends. Though perhaps the aim of getting two PhD degrees, like in math and philosophy, could be an aim to bear in mind.\nFourthly, on a more practical note, I will be paid for 5 years (if in PhD Applications in the US), and should therefore not take much less than 5 years. Finding funding is always a struggle, and losing money by finishing a contract before its due might not be the best strategy.\nLast but not least, it is getting stressful. I recently wrote about Is it the Begin of a Motivational Decline and I find that the current pace is not something I can keep in the long run. Three years have been a good amount of time to get a solid background in my field, and now I need to take the time to get really deep into one single field without spending too much time tasting different fields."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Is-it-the-Begin-of-a-Motivational-Decline":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Is-it-the-Begin-of-a-Motivational-Decline","filePath":"Academia/Active follows is a continuation of the Assume I finish the MoL in one year, what then given my past PhD Applications.\nThe high uncertainty of the future and the accompanying stress, compounded by the intense pressure of the Masters (see Master‚Äôs Outline), is causing me to question the pace at which I have conducted (see Bachelors‚Äô Outline) and am still conducting my studies. I will begin by presenting the current scenarios that lie ahead given the PhD Applications, followed by some general uncertainties about which Research Areas I actually see myself working in the future.\nUpcoming Scenarios\nI feel tense about the PhD Applications, particularly the respective Regrets. Two scenarios lie ahead of me: either I get good PhD Applications Results or bad ones.\nIf I were to receive a good outcome, i.e., getting into at least one of the PhD Applications in the US (it seriously wouldn‚Äôt matter which one, as they are all excellent), it would make me very happy and motivated. Finally achieving such a good result after all the effort during my Bachelor‚Äôs (see Bachelors‚Äô Outline) and Master‚Äôs (see Master‚Äôs Outline) would be incredibly rewarding. Being admitted to any of the universities I applied to in the USA would undoubtedly place me among the top 100 philosophers of my birth year, serving as a great motivator. Depending on the university faculty and the developments of my Master Thesis (which might depend on where I get admitted), I will decide on my area of specialisation. Currently, I am unsure of my precise path, as my Fields_of_Competence_and_Research_13.12.24.pdf outlines several different Research Areas I am interested in, without a clear favourite. My PhD Applications Results would primarily guide me in selecting a specific field, where I would then immerse myself while maintaining a broad perspective whenever possible.\nThe second scenario involves not being accepted by any of the PhD Applications in the US or Oxford and Cambridge in PhD Applications in the EU &amp; UK. If this happens, I have three options.\nOption one is to expand my PhD Applications in the EU &amp; UK, applying to more departments where I could pursue a project that continues my Master Thesis. Staying at ILLC Amsterdam or returning to LMU Munich would certainly be excellent options, along with other potential places like Vienna. If accepted, I would happily pursue a PhD at any of these institutions. If not, I would have to consider the next two options.\nOption two is to accept one of the less optimal offers from the PhD Applications in the EU &amp; UK. Each of these would need careful consideration, factoring in both living standards (which are excellent in places like Lund University or Denmark) and the academic career opportunities they would provide.\nOption three is to remain enrolled in the M.Sc. Logic (UvA), staying at ILLC Amsterdam, an excellent environment, to conduct more research projects aimed at leading to successful publications. This research year at ILLC Amsterdam would significantly enhance my chances for successful PhD Applications in the US the following year. This option should be weighed against the MA Philosophy at Simon Fraser University, where I would receive a small salary but possibly be in a less stimulating environment. Financially, this option would be feasible (see Personal Finance (old)) with guaranteed support from my parents.\nWhat Will I Do?\nI have always been very certain about what I wanted to study, but now, for the first time, I find myself unsure of my career prospects when faced with the choice of many Research Areas that excite me, despite all being closely related to my broader field of Theoretical Analytical Mathematical Philosophy and Mathematical Logic. Currently, given the scenarios presented above, I think that the department of the PhD programme I will end up in will be the one determining the main Research Areas I will specialise in.\nThis uncertainty adds complexity to the Master Thesis, which currently has the topic on Translation Theory, a subject I am genuinely interested in and find fruitful for many theoretical results in areas I am intrigued by. In conclusion, I am confident that I will find a field where I can excel and specialise, but I do not know what it is yet, and I feel like I have no clear means to determine it. The tools I used to determine my current focus were straightforward: I enjoy rational and abstract reasoning, so I pursued the most abstract and rational field available. Now, having discovered the diversity of abstract and rational fields, I am not equipped with the means to choose the one I want to dedicate the next several years to."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Strategic-Thesis-Proposal---AlphaProof--and--Proof-Theory":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Strategic-Thesis-Proposal---AlphaProof--and--Proof-Theory","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/Diary/Strategic Thesis Proposal - AlphaProof & Proof Theory.md","title":"Strategic Thesis Proposal - AlphaProof & Proof Theory","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"\n\n                  \n                  AI-Generated Proposal \n                  \n                \n\n\nResearch Note: This proposal was autonomously generated by AI Gemini 3 Pro on November 22, 2025, based on an analysis of current trends in AI-driven mathematics and the user‚Äôs academic background.\nAction Item: Review this suggestion to evaluate if a pivot towards a technical Proof Theory thesis could strategically position you for roles in elite AI research labs like Google DeepMind (AlphaProof team).\n\n\n\nThe Opportunity: AlphaProof\nAlphaProof is a reinforcement learning-based system from Google DeepMind designed for formal mathematical reasoning. It recently achieved silver-medal performance at the International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO).\n\nCore Technology: Combines a pre-trained language model with the AlphaZero reinforcement learning algorithm.\nFormal Language: Uses Lean (a theorem prover based on Dependent Type Theory) to formally verify proofs.\nRelevance: This represents the cutting edge of Neuro-Symbolic AI‚Äîthe intersection of neural networks and formal logic.\n\nWhy Proof Theory?\nTo work on systems like AlphaProof, deep expertise in Proof Theory is a massive differentiator. Unlike general ML engineers, a researcher who understands the structural properties of proofs (normalization, cut-elimination, consistency) can contribute to:\n\nProof Search Algorithms: Optimizing how the AI explores the space of possible proofs.\nFormal Verification: Designing better feedback loops between the theorem prover (Lean/Isabelle) and the neural network.\nSynthetic Data Generation: Creating high-quality formal proofs to train the models.\n\nProposed Thesis Direction\nInstead of a purely philosophical or historical thesis, consider a technical thesis in Proof Theory with a view towards automated reasoning.\nPotential Topics:\n\nProof Mining in Lean: Extracting constructive content from non-constructive proofs using automated tools.\nNeural Proof Search: Analyzing the proof-theoretic properties of traces generated by LLMs.\nStructural Proof Theory for Automated Reasoning: Investigating how sequent calculus variants (e.g., G3ip) can improve automated proof search efficiency.\n\nStrategic Value for CV\nA thesis in this area signals to HR and Research Leads at DeepMind/OpenAI/Anthropic that:\n\nYou have rigorous mathematical maturity (Logic/Proof Theory).\nYou are aligned with the ‚ÄúFormal Mathematics‚Äù agenda (Lean/Coq).\nYou bridge the gap between symbolic logic and modern AI.\n\nKey References\n\nAlphaProof Announcement: Google DeepMind Blog - AlphaProof\nLean Community: Lean Prover\nRelevant Papers:\n\nHyperTree Proof Search for Neural Theorem Proving (Reynolds et al.)\nGenerative Language Modeling for Automated Theorem Proving (Polu &amp; Sutskever)\n\n\n\n\nThis note is a placeholder for further personal research."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-Regrets":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-Regrets","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/PhD Applications/PhD Applications Regrets.md","title":"PhD Applications Regrets","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-in-the-US","System/Attachments/Writing_Sample.pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/Bachelor-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.A.-Philosophy-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.Sc.-Mathematics-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Assume-I-finish-the-MoL-in-one-year,-what-then","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Master's-Outline","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-Results","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Is-it-the-Begin-of-a-Motivational-Decline","Academia/Active--and--Works/Research-Areas/Research-Areas"],"tags":[],"content":"I began working on the applications in early November and completed most of the attachments by early December to be ready for the first submission to Princeton. In hindsight, I regret not spending enough time on the Writing_Sample.pdf, which was part of my Bachelor Thesis. The quality of this work was subpar, receiving a 2.7 for the B.A. Philosophy Thesis and a 2.0 for the B.Sc. Mathematics Thesis, grades that are unlikely to be competitive for Ivy League schools.\nBeyond the writing sample, I am not confident about the recommendation letters. The recommenders were either not well-acquainted with my work or did not have a strong belief in it, which diminishes my confidence in their letters.\nAdditionally, I believe I did not devote sufficient effort to crafting the statements of purpose. I did not upload them here because I tailored each one to specific universities, highlighting the professors and research groups of interest. However, these statements were never thoroughly revised or polished.\nFurthermore, I regret not considering a broader range of universities in the process. Logic (UvA) within a year (see Assume I finish the MoL in one year, what then), and the overall Master‚Äôs Outline.\nI remain uncertain whether putting in more effort would have altered the PhD Applications Results. [22.02.2025] I got in fact rejected.\n[22.02.2025] Another thing I regret is applying only to PhD programmes in Philosophy. In particular, I underlined how the ranking by philosophicalgourmet.com has been of practical use for picking the universities I wanted to apply to.\nGeneral Remarks\nFor each of the positions I want to apply to, I will need to focus on the writing sample they ask for, which will supposedly be the same for all applications and come from Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project). I will also pay attention to the deadlines and check if any particular documents are required, I list all of these either here or in Attachments to PhD Applications. For each university, I not only verify the details of the application process but also identify which professors in particular may be key for my studies at that institution, those names are listed here and more details are given in the specific motivational letters in Attachments to PhD Applications.\nI also list PhD Applications in the EU &amp; UK, divided by different deadlines (Oxford belongs to this list and Bristol to the other one, only because of different deadlines). To manage the process efficiently, I created separate pages for the two regions:\n\nPhD Applications in the US\nPhD Applications in the EU &amp; UK\n\nThese pages primarily serve as organisational tools to help me track everything during the application process. Therefore, I want to analyse what I would need to do in less optimal scenarios‚Äînamely, if I get rejected from all the best options.\nI can briefly outline what these best options are, though I do not wish to rank all the universities I applied to, as it is realistic that I will not be admitted to most of these programmes. Instead, I want to categorise them into two groups: on one hand, the programmes I would definitely accept if admitted; on the other, those I would not be entirely satisfied with, either due to a lack of academic excellence or because they do not align with my primary research interests.\nOptimal Universities\nThe universities in the first group‚Äîthe optimal options‚Äîare all PhD Applications in the US except for Toronto, which lacks a particular focus on logic and mathematical philosophy, and Simon Fraser University which only offers a master degree. This group also includes Oxford and Cambridge, but no other universities. All other programmes in PhD Applications then belong to the second group of suboptimal options.\nSuboptimal Universities\nAmong the suboptimal programmes, some do not align with my interests, such as Saint Andrews &amp; Bonn, while others lack particular academic excellence, like Czech Academy of Science. However, the best option within this group is certainly Czech Academy of Science, as I am particularly interested in the project at the intersection of algebra and proof theory, which I find highly compelling.\nAssuming I am only admitted to suboptimal programmes, several options remain open.\nFirst, I would apply to more universities. There are still optimal options, such as LMU Munich, ILLC Amsterdam, and Bristol, to which I have yet to apply. I would definitely consider contacting professors at these universities to explore potential opportunities. I would also look into other European universities, such as those in Vienna or other major cities. Additionally, I could consider self-funding a PhD in Germany, as this seems feasible, and my family could support me financially for up to two years.\nTo continue this reasoning, let‚Äôs assume that by the end of the academic year, in August, I have no optimal offer but only some suboptimal ones. In that case, I could accept the most appealing suboptimal offer, spend a year there, and then decide whether to complete the PhD and later pursue a postdoc, or to interrupt the PhD after the first year and reapply to the same (and more) optimal programmes, ensuring I have fewer PhD Applications Regrets.\nAlternatively, I could decide to stay at ILLC Amsterdam, not officially terminate my M.Sc. Logic (UvA), and instead spend more time conducting research there for a year before reapplying to optimal PhD programmes. Among the plans I considered three months ago in Assume I finish the MoL in one year, what then, these currently seem to be the only options I am open to pursuing."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/6th-Semester-Courses-Choice":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/6th-Semester-Courses-Choice","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/Master of Logic/6th Semester Courses Choice.md","title":"6th Semester Courses Choice","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Assume-I-finish-the-MoL-in-one-year,-what-then","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Rudiments-in-Set-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Advanced-Set-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Model-Theory,-ILLC-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Model-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Mathematics-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"In this page I give a rough projection of the courses I may take in the second semester. Logic (UvA), I asked some questions to the secretary of the programme, I paste here the email I sent and the answers. These questions have to do with what discussed in particular in Track of the MSc. Logic.\nEmail Sent\n\nDear Tuƒüba,\n\nI have¬†some questions on the Academic Plan which I need to complete before the 1st of March, since I plan on graduating this summer. I will be in the university today, so feel free to let me know in case you prefer me to come to your office.\n\n\nFirstly, I would like to ask how to select my research projects within the academic plan, as they are not currently visible. In particular, I intend to undertake an additional research project in the upcoming semester for which I have not yet planned or registered. How can I ensure that the credits for this project are included in the overall total?\n\n\nSpecifically, I have agreed with Enrico Cinti‚Äîthe supervisor of the research project on Categorical Foundations of Structuralism‚Äîto add an extra 6EC to the original project,¬†by initiating a new one. This would allow additional time to explore further research questions that have arisen during the current one. One requirement states:\n\n\n‚ÄúIf more than one third of a curriculum is comprised of exemptions or components marked with a ‚Äòpass‚Äô, the qualification of cum laude will not be awarded.‚Äù source\n\n\nAm I correct in assuming that the thesis is excluded from the curriculum calculation, and that the limit for ‚Äòpass‚Äô components is therefore 30EC? In my case, I would have 24EC from research projects, 3EC from the Seminar in Mathematical Logic, and 3EC from LoLaCo, totalling 30EC.\n\n\nSecondly, regarding the requirement that every component must be marked with at least a 7 (2.a), it applies solely to courses registered in the academic plan as main courses, and not to those considered extracurricular, right?\n\n\nFinally, concerning the track selection: based on my current course choices, I satisfy the requirements for both the Mathematics track (in which I am currently enrolled) and the Linguistics track. As far as I understand, depending on the marks received after the 1st of March, it should be possible to adjust the course selection so that the more favourable marks count towards the main requirements (within the respective limits), with the lower marks allocated to the extracurricular component. Could you please advise on how this can be achieved?\n\n\nBest regards, ¬†\nSimone"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/ELLIS-Honours-Programme":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/ELLIS-Honours-Programme","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/Master of Logic/ELLIS Honours Programme.md","title":"ELLIS Honours Programme","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester"],"tags":[],"content":"Close to the conclusion of the 5th Semester, if I manage to have an average above 8.0 and no grade below 7.0, I will consider to apply for the ELLIS Honours program (see ELLIS Homepage). Logic (UvA) within one year and still meet all the requirements I listed in Assume I finish the MoL in one year, what then. On this page, I attempt to bring some order to my thoughts regarding the most important tasks I need to complete before starting and focusing on the thesis. For this reason, this list neglects both the Master Thesis and all courses of the 6th Semester, as my priority is first to ensure that all tasks from the 5th Semester are completed.\nSince my concern is not whether I should complete these tasks, but rather when and with what priority they should be done, I have organised the list by deadlines, noting how flexible they are and which advantages I gain by completing some tasks earlier than others.\n\n\nCategory Theory (Lecture) Exam\n\nDeadline: 20.01\n\n\n\nOntic Structuralism of Concepts\n\nDeadline: 24.01\nI already have a well-formed idea for the essay and just need to write it down. It is not a particularly challenging or technical essay, so I expect to finish it easily before the deadline, if not sooner.\n\n\n\nDe Re Knowledge of Arbitrary Objects\n\nDeadline: 31.01\nThis project is my highest priority‚Äînot because the deadline is strict (as it could potentially be postponed by months), but because I already have a clear plan for how to proceed. I aim to create a submission-worthy project for conferences (though I am not assuming acceptance) and to position it as a potential publication for the PhD Applications.\n\n\n\nForcing (Research Project) Presentation\n\nDeadline: 07.02\nThe date has been fixed. I will handle the introductory part and, as a result, will not need to prepare much additional material.\n\n\n\nA Topological Approach to Infinite Disjunctions\n\nDeadline: 08.02\nI will finalise the idea for this project while working on De Re Knowledge of Arbitrary Objects. My plan is to submit the essay by the first week of February.\n\n\n\nIntroduction to Modal Logic (Lecture) Exam\n\nDeadline: 20.02\nThis exam covers a substantial amount of material and will significantly impact my final average (see Track of the MSc. Logic). Therefore, I will dedicate all my time after the Forcing (Research Project) presentation to its preparation.\n\n\n\nForcing (Research Project) Exercises\n\nDeadline: 25.02\nThere is no strict deadline for these exercises. I will work on them after completing the Introduction to Modal Logic (Lecture) exam.\n\n\n\nStructuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project) Cinti\n\nDeadline: 28.02\nI will complete this project by incorporating parts of previously written essays and submitting the final work.\n\n\n\nMaster Thesis Abstract &amp; Project details submission\n\nDeadline: 01.03\n\n\n\nStructuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project) Benno\n\nDeadline: 10.03\nStarting with the work submitted for the same project under Cinti‚Äôs supervision, I aim to deepen my understanding of Morita equivalence. I will conclude the project by adding a categorical perspective. However, due to time constraints and my desire to focus on writing the Master Thesis by this point, I will not be able to delve as deeply into the categorical details in the literature as I initially planned.\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Last-Steps-to-Finish-the-MoL-in-one-Year":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Last-Steps-to-Finish-the-MoL-in-one-Year","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/Master of Logic/Last Steps to Finish the MoL in one Year.md","title":"Last Steps to Finish the MoL in one Year","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Assume-I-finish-the-MoL-in-one-year,-what-then","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Master-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Category-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Finishing-the-Fifth-Semester,-Deadlines-and-Priorities","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Introduction-to-Modal-Logic-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Forcing-(Research-Project)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/A-Topological-Approach-to-Infinite-Disjunctions","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/De-Re-Knowledge-of-Arbitrary-Objects"],"tags":[],"content":"In the past, I outlined some sufficient conditions that would make it convenient for me to complete the M.Sc. Logic (UvA) in one year instead of two (see Assume I finish the MoL in one year, what then). I largely followed the principles I set out there and submitted PhD Applications under the assumption that I would complete the Master of Logic in one year. However, some bureaucratic concerns now need to be addressed to ensure that there are no issues moving forward.\nOn 28.10.2024, I contacted Maria Aloni regarding the possibility of finishing the Master of Logic in one year and the relevant deadlines for submitting the thesis. Since she oversees the graduation trajectory, I asked for clarification on the requirements, and she provided the following response:\n\nAs for the formal requirement, as you mention in your email, to graduate in the summer of 2025, you need to submit your academic plan and thesis project by March 1st, 2025, and to do so, you must have completed at least 72 EC by that date. This is the only requirement.\n\nThus, before 1st March, I need to accomplish two things: (i) formulate a clear project for my Master Thesis, which is currently lacking, and (ii) complete at least 72 EC. The first point does not seem particularly critical, as I will be able to adjust my thesis trajectory while working on it. However, I do need to identify a supervisor, which will likely be Schindler, as previously discussed.\nRegarding the second point, my recent failure in the Category Theory (Lecture) exam means I will not have the corresponding credits by that date, and I may also face difficulties in completing the more category-theoretic aspects of Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project). Based on my expected total workload for the 5th Semester‚Äî65 EC from the 1st and 2nd periods and 18 EC from research projects in the 3rd period‚ÄîI was originally aiming for 83 EC. However, given the failed exam, I will instead accumulate only 69 EC. This is problematic, as I will be short of 3 EC. Furthermore, this calculation assumes that no further issues or delays arise, which is uncertain given that my plans from Finishing the Fifth Semester, Deadlines and Priorities did not fully materialise.\nTo ensure that I reach the expected 69 EC, the following conditions must be met:\n\nPass the Introduction to Modal Logic (Lecture) exam on the 20th.\nSubmit the exercises for Forcing (Research Project) by 25th February and present on the 14th.\nSubmit the A Topological Approach to Infinite Disjunctions.\nSubmit the De Re Knowledge of Arbitrary Objects paper.\nSubmit Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project) to Enrico Cinti.\n\nAdditionally, I need to find a valid way to obtain the missing 3 EC. The simplest solution would be to extend my research project with Enrico Cinti by 3 EC, so I need to contact him via email to discuss this possibility.  I have now [04.02.2025] done it.\nLastly, I will send another email to Maria Aloni to clarify these details and ensure there are no further bureaucratic obstacles. I have now [04.02.2025] done it."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Master's-Outline":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Master's-Outline","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/Master of Logic/Master's Outline.md","title":"Master's Outline","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2023/Bachelors'-Outline","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/Academic-Diary","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Diary/Assume-I-finish-the-MoL-in-one-year,-what-then","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-Results"],"tags":[],"content":"On this page, I make some general considerations on my M.Sc. Logic (UvA) similarly to how I did for the Bachelors‚Äô Outline. Related pages can also be found in the Academic Diary, such as Assume I finish the MoL in one year, what then.\nOnce completed and upon receiving the PhD Applications Results, I will write here the details of how I planned my master‚Äôs degree, the results I achieved, and the difficulties I encountered."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Track-of-the-MSc.-Logic":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/Master-of-Logic/Track-of-the-MSc.-Logic","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Academic Diary/2024/Master of Logic/Track of the MSc. Logic.md","title":"Track of the MSc. Logic","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Introduction-to-Modal-Logic-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Proof-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Rudiments-in-Set-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Model-Theory,-ILLC-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Meaning,-Reference-and-Modality-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Structures-for-Semantics-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/6th-Semester","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-in-the-US","Academia/Active--and--Works/Academic-Diary/2024/PhD-Applications/PhD-Applications-in-the-EU--and--UK"],"tags":[],"content":"The track that best aligns with my interests in the M.Sc. Logic (UvA) is the Math Track. I plan to take all four compulsory courses during my 5th and 6th semesters:\n\nIntroduction to Modal Logic (Lecture)\nProof Theory (Lecture)\nRudiments in Set Theory (Lecture)\nModel Theory, ILLC (Lecture)\n\nHowever, officially pursuing this track would require counting these courses towards the final curriculum (outlined in the Spreadsheet: MoL Marks), which might not be the most strategic choice. Instead, I plan to also take:\n\nMeaning, Reference and Modality (Lecture)\nStructures for Semantics (Lecture)\n\nSince I already have an 8.5 for the first course and can easily take the second during my 6th Semester, this approach would allow me to officially complete both the Logic &amp; Mathematics track and the Logic &amp; Language track, while giving bureaucratic priority to the latter. This way, I would not be required to include all four math courses in the final transcript.\nThis strategy may not affect my PhD Applications in the US, as I am already applying for them now [01.01.2025], but it might influence my PhD Applications in the EU &amp; UK."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Mathematics/Commutative-Algebra-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Mathematics/Commutative-Algebra-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Mathematics/Commutative Algebra (Lecture).md","title":"Commutative Algebra (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/4th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/LMU-Munich","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.Sc.-Mathematics-(LMU)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Algebra-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Mathematics/Commutative-Algebra-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Linear-Algebra-II-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course during my 4th Semester at the LMU Munich for my B.Sc. Mathematics (LMU).\nFollowing the lecture series on Algebra (Lecture), I proceed taking notes for this course too. The lecture notes begin with a general 1. Introduction, I summarise here the core of the content that is relevant for the final exam.\n2. Rings and Ideals\n\n2.1 def. ring, 2.2 def. ring.hom, 2.3 def. subring\n\nf: A \\to B ring.hom, im(f) subr. of B.\n\n\nA, B rings, B is a A-algebra (with str. map f) if there is an hom. f s.t. f: A \\to B. 2.4\n\nif B&#039; also A but with str.map f&#039;: A \\to B&#039;, a hom. of A-alg. is a func. g: B \\to B&#039; s.t. g \\circ f = f&#039;\n\n\nA ring, f:A \\to B ring.hom., for b_1, ..., b_n \\in B, def. \\tilde{f}: A[X_1, ..., X_n] \\to B, s.t. \\tilde{f}|_A = f, \\forall_{i \\in [0, n]}\\tilde{f}: X_i \\mapsto b_i, i.e. \\tilde{f} \\circ i = f, 2.5\n\nA ring, i: A \\to A[X] incl., if f: A \\to B a ring hom. and b \\in B, then X \\mapsto b defines a unique ring hom. \\tilde{f}: A[X] \\to B, \\sum_{i = 0}^n a_i X^i \\mapsto \\sum^n_{i = 0}f(a_i)b^i, if a const.pol. \\tilde{f}(a) = f(a)b^0 = f(a), hence \\tilde{f}|_A = f, i.e. \\tilde{f} \\circ i = f, hence \\tilde{f} is an hom. of A-alg. (Universal Mapping Property)\nExample: A = k a field, B = k[X, 1/X], X_1 \\mapsto X, X_2 \\mapsto 1/X def. a uniq.surj. hom of k-alg. k[X_1, X_2] \\to k[X, 1/X], 2.5.a\n\n\nideals, 2.7\n\nf ring.hom., ker(f) is id.\nA/\\mathfrak{a} = \\{x + \\mathfrak{a}: x \\in A\\} is a ring, by (x + \\mathfrak{a})(y + \\mathfrak{a}) = xy + \\mathfrak{a}\n\n\nfor A ring, \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., \\pi:A \\to A/\\mathfrak{a} proj., T \\subseteq A s.t. \\overline{T} = \\pi(T) = T + \\mathfrak{a}, then \\pi induces \\{\\mathfrak{b} : \\mathfrak{b} \\subseteq A id. \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{b}\\} \\to^\\cong \\{\\overline{\\mathfrak{b}} : \\overline{\\mathfrak{b}} \\subseteq A/ \\mathfrak{a} id. \\}, 2.8\ntfae: (i) A fi., (ii) only id. are (0) and A, (iii) every ring.hom f: A \\to B is inj (if B \\not = 0). 2.10\n\nin \\mathbb{Z}: (n) \\cap (m) = (lcm(m, n)), (n) + (m) = (gcd(m, n)), (n)(m) = (nm)\n\n\n\\mathfrak{a}, \\mathfrak{b} \\subseteq A are coprime if \\mathfrak{a} + \\mathfrak{b} = A, 2.12\n\nthen \\exists_{x \\in \\mathfrak{a}}\\exists_{y \\in \\mathfrak{b}} x + y = 1\n\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{a}_1, ..., \\mathfrak{a}_n ideals, \\Phi: A \\to \\prod_{i =1}^n A(A/\\mathfrak{a}_i), x \\mapsto (x + \\mathfrak{a}_1, ..., x + \\mathfrak{a}_n) then A:\ni. \\mathfrak{a}_i, \\mathfrak{a}_j are copr. for i \\not = j \\Rightarrow \\prod_{i = 1}^n \\mathfrak{a_i} = \\bigcap^n_{i = 1} \\mathfrak{a}_i \\\nii. \\Phi is surj. \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{a}_i, \\mathfrak{a}_j are copr. for i \\not = j\niii. \\Phi is inj. \\Leftrightarrow \\bigcap_{i =1}^n\\mathfrak{a}_i = \\{0\\}\n(Chinese Reminder Theorem), 2.14\nfor f: A \\to B ring.hom. \\mathfrak{a} id. in A, \\mathfrak{b} id. in B: 2.16\n\n\\mathfrak{b}^c = f^{-1}(\\mathfrak{b}) \\subseteq A is an ideal called contraction or pullback of \\mathfrak{b}\n\\mathfrak{a}^e := \\mathfrak{a}B := \\{\\sum^n_{i = 1} y_i f(x_i) : x_i \\in \\mathfrak{a}, y_i \\in B\\} \\subseteq B is an ideal (generated by f(\\mathfrak{a})), called extension or pushforward of \\mathfrak{a}.\nFurhtermore, it holds: 2.17\n\n\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{a}^{ec}, \\mathfrak{b}^{ce} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{b}\n\\mathfrak{b}^c = \\mathfrak{b}^{cec}, \\mathfrak{a}^e = \\mathfrak{a}^{ece}\nlet C = \\{\\mathfrak{a} : \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A ideal, \\exists_{\\mathfrak{b} \\subseteq B} \\mathfrak{a} = \\mathfrak{b}^c\\} = \\{\\mathfrak{a} : \\mathfrak{a}^{ec}¬†= \\mathfrak{a}\\}, E = \\{\\mathfrak{b} : \\mathfrak{b} \\subseteq B ideal, \\exists_{\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A} \\mathfrak{b} = \\mathfrak{a}^e\\} = \\{\\mathfrak{b} : \\mathfrak{b}^{ce} = b\\}, set of ideals in A that are contractions and extensions respectively, then \\mathfrak{a} \\mapsto \\mathfrak{a}^e induces a bij. C \\to^\\tilde E with inverse \\mathfrak{b} \\mapsto \\mathfrak{b}^c\n\n\nf: A \\to B ring.hom.: 2.18\n\n(\\mathfrak{a}_1 + \\mathfrak{a}_{2})^e = \\mathfrak{a}^{e}_1 + \\mathfrak{a}_1^e, (\\mathfrak{b}_1 + \\mathfrak{b}_2)^c \\subseteq \\mathfrak{b}_1^c + \\mathfrak{b}_2^c\n(\\mathfrak{a}_1 \\cap \\mathfrak{a}_{2})^e \\subseteq \\mathfrak{a}^{e}_1 \\cap \\mathfrak{a}_1^e, (\\mathfrak{b}_1 \\cap \\mathfrak{b}_2)^c = \\mathfrak{b}_1^c \\cap \\mathfrak{b}_2^c\n(\\mathfrak{a}_1\\mathfrak{a}_{2})^e = \\mathfrak{a}^{e}_1\\mathfrak{a}_1^e, (\\mathfrak{b}_1\\mathfrak{b}_2)^c \\subseteq \\mathfrak{b}_1^c\\mathfrak{b}_2^c\n\n\n\n\n\n3. Prime Ideals\n\n3.1 pr.id., max.id.\n\n(i) A/\\mathfrak{p} ID \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{p} pr.id., (ii) A / \\mathfrak{m} \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{m} is max.id., (iii) max.id. \\Rightarrow pr.id.\n\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq A, then A/ \\mathfrak{p} \\cong (A / \\mathfrak{a})/(\\mathfrak{p}/ \\mathfrak{a}) and (\\mathfrak{p} is pr.id. \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{p} / \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A / \\mathfrak{a} is pr.id.)\n\\mathfrak{p} pr.id. \\Leftrightarrow (for any id. \\mathfrak{a}, \\mathfrak{b} then \\mathfrak{ab} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p} \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{a} \\in \\mathfrak{p} \\lor \\mathfrak{b} \\in \\mathfrak{p}), exe.2.1.a\n\\{\\mathfrak{p_i}\\}_{ i \\in [1, n]} all but max. 2 pr.id., \\mathfrak{a} id.: \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\bigcup_{i = 1}^n \\mathfrak{p}_i \\Rightarrow \\exists_{i \\in [1, n]} \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}_i, exe.2.1.b  (Prime Avoidance)\nevery ideal lies in a max.id. 3.3\n\\mathfrak{p} \\subsetneq A pr.id. \\mathfrak{ab} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p} \\to (\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p} \\lor \\mathfrak{b \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}}) e.2.1.a\n\n\n3.4 def. PID\n\n(k[X] PID \\Leftrightarrow k fi.) but n \\ge 2 \\Rightarrow k[X_1, ..., X_n] not PID\n\n\nA loc.ring if \\exists!_{\\mathfrak{m} \\subsetneq A}max.id(\\mathfrak{m}), 3.6\n\n\\kappa := A / \\mathfrak{m} (residue field)\n\nA fin.gen.k-alg, \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A), then res.fi. of \\mathfrak{p} is k(\\mathfrak{p}) := quot(A/\\mathfrak{p}), and tfae: exe.5.2\n\n\\mathfrak{p} cl.point in spec(A)\nk \\subseteq k(\\mathfrak{p}) is a fin.fi.ext.\nk\\subseteq k(\\mathfrak{p}) is an alg.fi.ext.\n\n\n\n\ntfae: (i) A loc.ring, (ii) \\exists_{\\mathfrak{a} \\subsetneq A}( id.(\\mathfrak{a}) \\land \\forall_{x \\in A \\setminus A^\\times} x \\in \\mathfrak{a}), (iii) A \\setminus A^\\times is id.\n\nexample: \\mathbb{F}_{p^k} is loc.ring with \\mathbb{F}_{p^{k-1}} max.id., \\mathbb{F}_p res.fi.\n\n\n\n\nA ring, X = spec(A) := \\{\\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq A : \\mathfrak{p} prime ideal\\}, called the spectrum of A, 3.9\nT \\subseteq A subset, then V(T) := \\{\\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A) : T \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}\\}\n\nif \\mathfrak{a} = (T) id. then V(T) = V(\\mathfrak{a})\nV(0) = X, V(1) = V(A) = \\emptyset\nS \\subseteq T \\subseteq A \\Rightarrow V(T) \\subseteq V(S)\nV(\\bigcup_i a_i) = V(\\sum_i a_i) = \\bigcap_i V(a_i)\nV(a \\cap a&#039;) = V(a a&#039;) = V(a) \\cup V(a&#039;)\nX = spec(A), \\mathfrak{p} \\in X \\Rightarrow [\\mathfrak{p}] = V(p)\n\n\n\\mathfrak{p} \\in X is not a closed point ( [\\mathfrak{p}] \\subsetneq \\overline{[\\mathfrak{p}]}) \\Leftrightarrow [p] \\subsetneq V(p) \\Leftrightarrow p \\subsetneq A \\land \\mathfrak{p} is not max.\nA ring, X = spec(A), zar.top.X is s.t. cl.sets are \\{V(\\mathfrak{a}): \\mathfrak{a} id.\\}, 3.12\n\n\\{irr. and cl. subs. in X\\} correspond to \\{max ideals in A\\} correspond to \\{closed points in X\\}\nx \\in X is cl. if \\{x\\} \\subseteq X is cl., i.e. if \\overline{\\{x\\}} = \\{x\\}, 3.12\n\n\\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A), V(\\mathfrak{p}) = \\overline{\\{\\mathfrak{p}\\}} = \\bigcap \\{V(\\mathfrak{a}) : \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}\\}\n\\mathfrak{p} pr.max.id. \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{p} cl.point in X top.sp.\n\n\n\n\nX top.sp. \\emptyset \\not = T \\subseteq X subs., T is red. if T = T_1 \\cap T_2 and T_i \\subsetneq T closed.\n\nT irr. \\Leftrightarrow for any \\emptyset \\not = U \\subseteq T then T = \\overline{U} \\cup (T \\setminus U)\n\n\\emptyset is not irr.\n\\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A), then \\{\\mathfrak{p}\\} is irr.\n\nV(\\mathfrak{p}) is irr.cl.subs.\n\n\n\n\nX = spec(A), since [\\mathfrak{p}] \\subseteq x is irred. (bc it‚Äôs a singleton); [\\mathfrak{p}] = V(\\mathfrak{p}) is irr.\nT \\subseteq X irr. \\Rightarrow \\overline{T} \\subseteq X is irr.\n\\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq A pr.id. \\Leftrightarrow V(\\mathfrak{p}) \\subseteq X is irr. and cl.\n\n\nA ring: A has one pr.id. \\Leftrightarrow any a \\in A is nilp. or a \\in A^\\times, exe.4.1\nA ring: spec(A) irr. \\Leftrightarrow \\sqrt{(0)} pr.id. \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{N}_A pr.id., link\nexamples, 3.13\n\nk fi., then spec(k) = \\{(0)\\}\np \\in \\mathbb{Z} pr.num., \\mathfrak{p} = (p), spec(\\mathbb{Z}_\\mathfrak{p}) = \\{(0), \\mathfrak{p}^e\\}\n\nV(\\mathfrak{p}^e) = \\{\\mathfrak{p}^e\\}, hence it‚Äôs cl.point\n\\mathbb{Z}_\\mathfrak{p} := \\{p / q : p, q \\in \\mathbb{Z} \\land q \\not \\in \\mathfrak{p}\\}, 3.8.e\n\n\\mathbb{Z}_\\mathfrak{p} is loc.ring., \\mathfrak{p}^e := \\{a/s : a \\in \\mathfrak{p} \\land s \\not \\in \\mathfrak{p}\\} uniq.max.id.\n\n\n\n\nspec(\\mathbb{Z}) = \\{(p) : p pr.num.\\} \\cup \\{(0)\\}, generally:\n\nA ID \\Rightarrow spec(A) = \\{pr.id.\\} \\cup \\{(0)\\} and \\{pr.id.\\} are the cl.points.\n\ncl.subsets are finite\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMoving from A ring. to spec(A) top.sp. with V(- ) yields the following correspondences:\n\nprime ideals in A \\leftrightarrow irreducible closed subsets of spec(A)\nmaximal ideals in A \\leftrightarrow closed points of spec(A)\n\n\n\n4. Noetherian Rings\n\nA ring, is a Noetherian ring if every ideal \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A is finally generated, 4.1\n\n(a) A is PID \\Rightarrow A is noeth.\n\nfields, \\mathbb{Z}, \\mathbb{Z}[i] and k[X] are noeth. rings\n\n\n(b) f: A \\to B ring.hom., A noeth. then im(f) \\le B is noeth.\n\nhence quotients of noeth. are noeth.\nif \\overline{\\mathfrak{a}} \\subseteq f(A) ideal, there is fin.gen.id. \\mathfrak{a} = (x_1, ..., x_r) s.t. f(\\mathfrak{a}) = \\overline{\\mathfrak{a}}, then \\overline{\\mathfrak{a}} = (f(x_1), ..., f(x_r))\n\n\n(c) A = k[X_1, X_2, ...] pol.ring. with infinite many variables, then \\mathfrak{a}:= (X_1, X_2, ...) \\subseteq A is not fin.gen.\n\nif B = k[X_1, X_2, ...] is quot.field. for A \\to B, f \\mapsto \\frac{f}{1}, so subrings with noeth.rings must not be noeth.\n\n\n\n\nfor A a ring: (\\mathfrak{p} pr.id. \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{p} fin.gen) \\Rightarrow A noeth., exe.2.4.b\nA noeth. then (i) A has fin. many min.pr.id., (ii) every ideal in A contains a min.pr.id., (iii) \\mathcal{N}_A = \\bigcap_{i = 1}^r \\mathfrak{p}_i for \\{\\mathfrak{p}_1, ..., \\mathfrak{p}_r\\} min.pr.id. of A, 8.5\nFor A ring, tfae: 4.3\n\nA noeth\nevery ascending chain of ideals \\mathfrak{a}_1 \\subseteq \\mathfrak{a}_2 \\subseteq ... in A becomes stationary,\n\ni.e. \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\forall_{k \\ge 0} \\mathfrak{a}_n = \\mathfrak{a}_{n + k} (Ascending Chain Condition)\n\n\nany S \\not = \\emptyset set of ideals in A has a max. elem.\n\n(then you can use the [[Linear Algebra II (Lecture)#Recap#12.2 Zorn‚Äôs Lemma]])\n\n\n\n\nA noeth., f: A \\to A surj.ring.hom. \\Rightarrow f is aut.\nA noeth. \\Rightarrow A[X_1, ..., X_n] noeth. (Hilbert‚Äôs Basis Theorem), 4.5\nlet X top.sp., X is noeth. if X has DCC on cl.subsets, 4.6\n\nfor Y_i closed subset of X, X \\supset Y_1 \\supset Y_2 \\supset ... \\Rightarrow \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}\\forall_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} Y_n = Y_{n + k} (DCC)\nX top.sp. tfae: 4.7\n\nX is noeth.top.sp.\nevery non empty fam. of cl.subsets has a minimal element\nX satisfies ACC for open subsets\nevery non empty fam. of open subsets has a max.elem.\n\n\nexample 4.8:\n\n\\mathbb{R} and \\mathbb{C} in usual top. are not noeth.top.sp.\nA noeth.ring. \\Rightarrow X = spec(A) noeth.top.sp.\nyou can have A not noeth. but spec(A) noeth.top.sp.\n\n\n\n\nT \\subseteq X irr.subs. iff T cannot be written as T = Y_1 \\cup Y_2 for Y_1, Y_2 \\subsetneq T top.sp.\n\nlet X top.sp. Z \\subseteq X is irr.comp. if Z maximally irr.subset.\n\n\\{min.pr.ideals\\} correspond to \\{irr.comp (i.e. max.ir.cl.subset\\}\nevery irr.comp. is cl. (i.e. T \\subseteq X cl. \\Rightarrow \\overline{T} \\subseteq X cl.) exe.3.3.b\nevery irr.subset is contained in an irr.comp.\nA ID \\Rightarrow spec(A) irr., tut.12.4.i\nA red.ring, spec(A) irr. \\Rightarrow A ID tut.,12.4.i\nspec(A) irr., \\Rightarrow spec(A) has a uniq.min.irr.comp \\Rightarrow A has a uniq.min.pr.id. tut.12.4.i\n\n\n\n\nX noeth.top.sp. \\emptyset \\not = Y \\subseteq X cl., then there are irr.cl.subsets Y_1, ..., Y_r \\subseteq Y s.t. (i) Y = \\bigcup_{i = 1}^r Y_i, (ii) for i \\not = j then Y_i \\not \\subseteq Y_j, then (Y_i)_{i \\in [1, .r]} are the irr.comp. of  Y 4.9\n\nX noeth.top.sp. \\Rightarrow finitely many irr.comp.\nA noeth.ring., fin.min.pr.id, 4.10\n\nA noeth.ring., X = spec(A) noeth.top.sp. \\Rightarrow X has fin. many irr.comp \\Rightarrow A has fin. many min. pr.ideals.\nCompute irr.comp. for A noeth.ring, X = spec(A), find all min.pr.ideals\n\n\n\n\nfor f: A \\to B, B is of finite type over A if ex. surj.map A[X_1, ..., X_n] \\to B, tut.3.1.a\n\nA neoth, B fin.typ.ov.A \\Rightarrow B noeth.\n\n\n\n5. Radicals\n\nlet A ring, x \\in A is nilp. if \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} x^n = 0\n\n\\mathcal{N}_A = \\{x \\in A : \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} x^ n = 0\\} = \\cap \\{\\mathfrak{p}: \\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq A is pr.id\\} = \\sqrt{(0)} ideal in A\nA is red. if \\mathcal{N}_A = \\{0\\}\n\nA ID \\Rightarrow A red.\nA red.ring, spec(A) irr. \\Rightarrow A ID tut.,12.4.i\n\n\n0 \\not = x \\in A nilp. \\Rightarrow x zerodiv.\nA has one! pr.id \\Leftrightarrow any a \\in A is nilp. or a \\in A^\\times \\Leftrightarrow A/\\mathcal{N}_A fi., exe.4.1\nID \\Leftrightarrow (0) pr.id. wiki\n\n\nlet A a ring. A_{red} := A / \\mathcal{N} contains no non-triv. nilp.elem., 5.3\nfor A ring, \\mathfrak{a} id.: \\mathfrak{r}(\\mathfrak{a}) := \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{a}} := \\{x \\in A : \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}x^n \\in \\mathfrak{a}\\} = \\bigcap_{\\mathfrak{p} \\in V(\\mathfrak{a})} \\mathfrak{p} id. in A, 5.4\n\n\\pi: A \\to A/\\mathfrak{a} quot.map., \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{a}} = \\pi^{-1}(\\mathcal{N}_{A/\\mathfrak{a}})\n\n\\mathfrak{a} = \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{a}} \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{a} = \\pi^{-1}(\\mathcal{N*_{A / \\mathfrak{a}}}) \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{N}_{A / \\mathfrak{a}} = \\{0\\}, i.e. \\mathfrak{a} is rad.id. iff A /\\mathfrak{a} red, 5.4\n\n\n\\mathfrak{a} pr.id. \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{a} rad.id.\n\\mathfrak{a, a&#039;} rad. \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{a \\cap a&#039;} rad., tut.\n\n\nFor \\mathfrak{a}, \\mathfrak{a}&#039; \\subseteq A ideals:, 5.5\n\n\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{r(a)}\n\\mathfrak{r(r(a)) = r(a)}\n\\mathfrak{r(aa&#039;) = r(a \\cap a&#039;) = r(a) \\cap r(a&#039;)}\n\\mathfrak{r(a) = (}1\\mathfrak{) \\Leftrightarrow a} = A\n\\mathfrak{r(a + a&#039;) = r(r(a) + r(a&#039;))}\n\\mathfrak{r(a), r(a&#039;)} coprime \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{a, a&#039;} coprime\n\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{a}&#039; Affine Algebraic Geometry\n\nfor \\iota: A \\to B A-alg., then B&#039; is A-subalg. if B&#039; \\subseteq B subr. s.t. \\iota(A) \\subseteq V&#039;, 6.1\n\nfor T \\subseteq B subset, A[T] A-subalg. gen. by T, A[T] := \\bigcap\\{B&#039; : B&#039; A-subgalg. of B \\land T \\subseteq B&#039;\\}\n\nA[T] is the smallest A-subalg. of B containing T\nA[t_1, ..., t_n] := A[T] = \\{\\sum_{i_1, ..., i_n \\in \\mathbb{N}} a_{i_1, ..., i_n}t^{i_1}_1 \\cdot ... \\cdot t_n^{i_n} : a_{i_1, ..., i_n} \\in A \\land t_i \\in T alm. alla_{i_1, ..., i_n} = 0 \\} (see Answers A. 1)\n\n\n\n\nB is a fin.gen. A-alg. \\Leftrightarrow \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}A [X_1, ..., X_n]/a \\cong B, 6.3\n\nevery ring A is fin.gen. to id_A, since A[X]/(X) \\cong A\n\n\nfor k fi., A\\not = 0 a k-alg, then a \\in A alg. is alg.over.k if ex. 0 \\not = f \\in k[X] s.t. f(a) = 0, 6.4\n\nif each a \\in A is alg.over.k, then A is alg.over.k.\nif L/k is a fi.ext., then L alg.over.k iff ring L alg.over.k.\n\n\nexists f: A \\to B ring.hom. \\Leftrightarrow B is a A-alg.\nk field, k \\to A is k-alg., then: 6.5\n\nif A ID and alg. over k \\Rightarrow A is a field\nA is a field and ex. Modules\n\nA ring., a A-mod. is a ab.gr. on + and a scal.mult. A \\times M \\to M, (a,m) \\mapsto am s.t., 7.1\n\na(m + m&#039;) = am + am&#039;\n(a + a&#039;) m = am + a&#039;m\n(aa&#039;) m = a(a&#039; m)\n1m = m\n\n\nfor M A-mod., N A-submod. of M  if N\\subseteq M subgr. s.t. \\forall_{a \\in A}\\forall_{n \\in N}an \\in N, 7.1\nexamples, 7.2:\n\n(i) (\\mathfrak{a}, \\cdot_A) with scalar mult., (ii) A fi., mod. are exactly vec.sp., (iii) \\mathbb{Z}-mod. are exactly ab.gr. (iv) (A^n, +_A) with comp.wise mult.\n\n\n\n\nfor M, N A-mod, A morph./lin.map. is f : M \\to N s.t., 7.3\n\n\\forall_{m, m&#039; \\in M}f(m + m&#039;) = f(m) + f(m&#039;)\n\\forall_{a \\in A}\\forall_{m \\in M} f(am) = af(m)\n\n\n(Hom(M, N), +_f)is A-mod. for (f+ g)(m) = f(m) + g(m), (af)(m) = af(m)\n\nHom_A(M, N) := \\{f : M \\to N : f is A-lin.\\}\n\nM an A-mod., M \\cong Hom_A(A, M), exe.6.2.a\n\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., Hom_A(A/\\mathfrak{a}) \\cong M[\\mathfrak{a}] :=\\{m \\in M : \\forall_{a \\in \\mathfrak{a}} am = 0\\}, exe.6.2.b\nm, n \\in \\mathbb{N}, then Hom_\\mathbb{Z}(\\mathbb{Z}/m, \\mathbb{Z}/n) \\cong \\mathbb{Z}/gcd(m, n) as A-mod., exe.6.2.c\n\n\n(f +_f g)(m) := f(m) +_N g(m) and (a\\cdot_f f)(m) = a \\cdot_N f(m)\n\n\nfor f \\in Hom_A(M, N), then ker(f) \\subseteq M and im(f) \\subseteq N are A-submod.\nif M is A-mod, N \\subseteq M A-submod., then M / N is A mod. with scal.mult. a(m + N) = am + N.\n\n\\pi : M \\to M / N, m \\mapsto m + N is surj.A-lin.map\nHomomorphism Theorem holds too\n\n\n(i) \\bigcap_{i \\in I}M_i, (ii) \\bigoplus_{i \\in I} M_i, (iii) \\prod_{i \\in I} M_i,  are A-mod., (v) M_1 \\cup M_2 is not.\n\n\\bigoplus_{i \\in I} M_i := \\{\\{m_i\\}_I \\in \\prod_{i \\in I} M_i : |\\{i \\in I : m_i \\not = 0 \\}| &lt;
