M \\otimes_A N = 0, then M = 0 \\lor N = 0, exe.9.2\nfor F, F&#039;, with bases \\{e_i\\}_I, \\{e_j\\}_J, then F \\otimes_A F&#039; has basis \\{e_i \\otimes e_j : i \\in I, j \\in J\\}, 7.20.a\n\nA^m \\otimes_A A^n \\cong A^{mn} (see fin.gen.free.A-mod., 7.5.3)\nM A-mod. and F free.A-mod. with basis \\{e_i\\}_I, then \\forall_{m \\otimes f \\in M \\otimes_A F} \\exists!_{\\{m_i\\}_I \\subseteq M}m \\otimes f = \\sum_{i = 1}^n m_i \\otimes e_i\n\n\nfor k alg.cl.fi. A-mod. and A-lin.fun.:, 7.27\n\nis exact at M_i, if im(f_{i -1}) = ker(f_i).\nis exact if it is in every module.\n0 \\to M&#039; \\to^f M is exact \\Leftrightarrow f inj\nM \\to^g M&#039;&#039; \\to 0 is exact \\Leftrightarrow g surj.\n0 \\to M&#039; Dimensions\n\nfor \\emptyset \\not = X top.sp., then dim(X) = \\sup\\{n : X_0 \\subsetneq X_1 \\subsetneq ... \\subsetneq X_n \\subseteq X irr.cl.\\}, 8.1\n\nfor A ring, dim(A) := dim(spec(A))\n\nequivalently: dim(A) = \\sup\\{n : \\mathfrak{p}_0 \\subsetneq ... \\subsetneq \\mathfrak{p}_n \\land \\forall_{i \\in [1, n]} \\mathfrak{p}_i \\subseteq A pr.id\\}\n\n\nfor T \\subseteq \\mathbb{A}_k^n, T = \\bigcup_{i = 1}^r T_i, then dim(T) = \\max \\{dim(T_i) : i \\in [1, r]\\}\n\nboth dim(T) and dim(T_i) are defined as subspaces with irr.cl.subsets.\n\n\nfor V \\subseteq \\mathbb{A}_k^n aff.var.ov.k for k alg.cl.fi., then dim(V) = dim(A(V))\nexamples: 8.2\n\nA PID and not a field, dim(A) = 1\n\ndim(k) = 0\nA noeth.ring \\Rightarrow dim(A[X_1, ..., X_n]) = dim(A) +n, 8.5\n\n\ndim(k[X_1, ..., X_\\omega]) = \\infty\nA noeth.loc.ring \\Rightarrow dim(A) &lt; \\infty, 9.15\nA noeth., dim(A) \\ge 2 \\Rightarrow |spec(A)| = \\infty, exe.14.2\n\n\n\n\n\\{a_1, ..., a_n\\} \\subseteq A alg.ind. if \\forall_{0 \\not = f \\in k[X_1, ..., X_n]}f(a_1, ..., a_n) =0\n\nequivalently: \\forall_{0 \\not = f \\in k[X_1, ..., X_n]} k[X_1, ..., X_n] \\to A, f \\mapsto f{a_1, ..., a_n} is inj.ring.hom.\n\n\nk fi. A k-alg., then tr(A) := \\sup\\{|T| : T \\subseteq A finite alg.ind.subset\\} (transcendence degree), 8.3\n\nif A = 0, then tr(A) = -1\nif A = k[X_1, ..., X_n], then tr(A) = n\n\nif A = k[X], then \\{X\\} \\subseteq A is max. fin. alg.ind.subset and tr(A) = 1.\n\n\n\n\nk fi., A a k-alg., S \\subseteq A subset s.t. it gen. A as a k-alg., then dim(A) \\le \\sup \\{|T| : T \\subseteq S f.alg.ind.subset\\}\n\nhence dim(K[S]) \\le tr(S), 8.4\n\nS = A \\Rightarrow dim(A) \\le tr(A)\n\n\nexample: 8.5\n\nA noeth. then (i) A has fin. many min.pr.id., (ii) every ideal in A contains a min.pr.id., (iii) \\mathcal{N}_A = \\bigcap_{i = 1}^r \\mathfrak{p}_i for \\{\\mathfrak{p}_1, ..., \\mathfrak{p}_r\\} min.pr.if. of A, 8.5\n\n\n\n\nk fi., A fin.gen.k-alg., then dim(A) = tr(A), 8.6\nM is an art.A-mod. if for A-submod. any chain M \\subseteq ... \\subseteqq M_n \\subseteq ... is stat., 8.7\n\nevery non-empty set of A-submod. of M has a min.el., 8.7\nA is art.ring if A is an art.A-mod., 8.7\n\n\nfin.A-mod. \\Rightarrow art.A-mod., 8.8.a\nV k-mod., dim_k(V)&lt;\\aleph_0 \\Rightarrow V is art.k-mod., 8.8.b\n\\mathbb{Z} is not art.ring. (since \\{(n^k) : k \\ge 1\\} has no min.el.), 8.8.c\n\n\nA \\not = 0 ring, s.t. 0 = \\mathfrak{m}_1\\cdot ... \\cdot \\mathfrak{m}_k for \\mathfrak{m}_i \\subseteq A max.id., then A is art.ring \\Leftrightarrow A is noeth., 8.9\nA art.ring, then: 8.10\n\npr.id. \\Leftrightarrow max.id.\n\ndim(A) = 0\n\n\nfin.many max.id. in A\n\n\nart.ring \\Leftrightarrow noeth. and dim(A) = 0, 8.10\n\nart.ID \\Leftrightarrow fi.\n\n\nM art.A-mod., f \\in End_A(M), f inj. \\Rightarrow f surj., tut.10.2\nk fi., A fin.gen.k-alg., tfae: 8.11\n\ndim(A) =. 0\nA alg.ov.k\ndim_k(A) &lt; \\infty (as a vec.sp.)\nA is art.ring\n|spec_{max}(A)| &lt; \\aleph_0\n\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A), then ht(\\mathfrak{p}) = \\sup \\{m : \\mathfrak{p}_0 \\subsetneq ... \\subsetneq \\mathfrak{p}_m = \\mathfrak{p} \\land \\forall_{i \\in [0, m]} \\mathfrak{p}_i \\in spec(A)\\}, 8.12\n\nif \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., then ht(\\mathfrak{a}) = \\inf \\{ht(\\mathfrak{p}) : \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A) \\land \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}\\}\nht(A) = dim(A) + 1\nht(\\mathfrak{p}) + dim(A/\\mathfrak{p}) \\le dim(A) (often equal)\nA fact.ring, \\mathfrak{p} \\in spac(A) s.t. ht(\\mathfrak{p}) \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{p} princ.id., 8.13\n\n\nk fi., \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq k[X_1, ..., X_n] id., then tfae:, 8.14\n\nk[X_1, ..., X_n]/\\mathfrak{a} has pure dim n-1\n\nevery irr.comp. T of X has dim(T) = n-1\n\n\nht(\\mathfrak{a}) = 1 (in particular \\mathfrak{a} \\subsetneq k[X_1, ..., X_n])\n\\sqrt{\\mathfrak{a}} princ.id.\n\n\nX \\subseteq \\mathbb{A}^m_k, Y \\subseteq \\mathbb{A}^n_k aff.var. for k alg.cl.fi., then dim(X \\times Y ) = dim(X) + dim(Y), 8.16\n\n9. Localization\n\nA ring, S \\subseteq A mult.cl. if S^{-1}A in which the element of S have a multiplicative inverse.\n\nA ID, S = A \\setminus \\{0\\} \\Rightarrow S^{-1}A = Quot(A)\nA ring, S = A \\setminus \\mathfrak{p} \\Rightarrow S^{-1} =: A_\\mathfrak{p} loc.ring.\nA ring, S = \\{f^k : k \\ge 0\\} \\Rightarrow S^{-1}A = A_f for some f \\in A.\nThere is a ring.hom. f: A \\to S^{-1}A, a \\mapsto a/1 (always)\n\nif A ID, then f inj., f: A \\to Quot(A)\nS \\subseteq A, (a, s) \\sim (a&#039;, s&#039;) := \\exists_{t \\in S}(t(as&#039; - a&#039;s) = 0)\n\nnote consequences of t = 0 \\in S, every tuple is similar.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nS^{-1}A fin.gen.A-alg. \\Leftrightarrow \\exists_{f \\in A} S^{-1}A = A_f, tut.11.1.a\nA ring., \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., S^{-1}\\sqrt{\\mathfrak{a}} = \\sqrt{S^{-1}\\mathfrak{a}}, tut.11.2.a\n\\overline{S} is im. of S in A / \\mathfrak{a}, then\nA ring., S \\subseteq A, mult.cl. f: A \\to S^{-1} A, g: A \\to B ring.hom. s.t. \\forall_{s \\in S} g(s) \\in B^\\times then: ex! ring.hom h: S^{-1}A \\to B s.t. g= h \\circ f (Universal Property), 9.4\n\nP proj. A-mod., S mult.cl.subs., then S^{-1}P is proj.S^{-1}A-mod., tut.12.4.xi\n\n\nS^{-1}A int.ov.A \\Rightarrow S^{-1}A = A, exe.14.3\nfor S^{-1} A and f: A \\to S^{-1}A, 9.4\n\ns \\in S \\Rightarrow f(s) \\in (S^{-1} A)^\\times\n\\exists_{s \\in S} (f(a) = 0 \\rightarrow as = 0)\n\\forall_{x \\in S^{-1}A} \\exists_{a \\in A} \\exists_{s \\in S} x = f(a) f(s)^{-1}\n\n\nFor f: A \\to S^{-1}A, a \\mapsto \\frac{a}{1}, 9.5\n\n\\mathfrak{a}\\subseteq A id. \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{a}^e = \\{a/s : a \\in \\mathfrak{a}\\} \\subseteq S^{-1}A\n\n\\mathfrak{a} \\cap S \\not = \\emptyset \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{a}^e = S^{-1}A\n\n\nif \\mathfrak{b}\\subseteq S^{-1}A is id., then \\mathfrak{b}^{ce} = \\mathfrak{b}\next. and contr. give bijections: \\{pr.id. of S^{-1}A\\}\\leftrightarrow^\\cong \\{pr.id.\\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq A s.t. \\mathfrak{p} \\cap S = \\emptyset\\}\n\n\nexample (Localisation as a Functor): 9.6\n\nfor A ring, \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A), define A_\\mathfrak{p} loc. with \\mathfrak{p} as uniq.max.id.:\nM A-mod., \\exists_{t \\in S} (m, s) \\sim (m&#039;, s&#039;) \\Leftrightarrow t(sm&#039; - s&#039;m) =0\nm/s + m&#039;/s&#039; = (s&#039;m + sm&#039;) / ss&#039; and a/s \\cdot m/s&#039; = am/ss&#039;\nf: M \\to N A-lin.map., S^{-1}f : S^{-1}M \\to S^{-1}N, m/s \\mapsto f(m)/s is S^{-1}A-lin.\n\nS^{-1}(f) \\circ S^{-1}(g) = S^{-1}(f \\circ g)\n\n\nHence localisation defines a functor S^{-1}: \\mathcal{Mod}_A \\to \\mathcal{Mod}_{S^{-1}A}\n\nM \\mapsto S^{-1}M,\n(f: M \\to N) \\mapsto (S^{-1}f: S^{-1}M \\to S^{-1}N)\n\n\n\n\nthe functor S^{-1}- is exact (Exact Localisation), 9.7\n\nif M&#039; \\to^f M \\to^g M&#039;&#039; exa, then S^{-1}M&#039; \\to^{S^{-1}f} S^{-1}M \\to^{S^{-1}g} S^{-1}M&#039;&#039; is exact.\n\n\nN, P \\subseteq M A-mod., then, 9.8\n\nS^{-1}(N + P) = S^{-1}N + S^{-1}P\nS^{-1}(N \\cap P) = S^{-1}N \\cap S^{-1}P\nS^{-1}(M /N) \\cong S^{-1}M/S^{-1}N\n\n\nf: S^{-1}A \\otimes_A M \\to S^{-1}M, a/s \\otimes m \\mapsto am/s is the unique S^{-1}A-lin.isom., 9.9\n\nconsider the two functors S^{-1}( - ) and S^{-1}A \\otimes_A ( - ): M \\mapsto S^{-1}A \\otimes_A M, f \\mapsto 1 \\otimes f_*\n\n9.9 implies S^{-1}M \\cong S^{-1}A\\otimes_A M, also the mapping of functions is equivalent.\nhence the two distinct functors are isomorphic.\n\n\n\n\nf: S^{-1}M \\otimes_{S^{-1}A} S^{-1}N \\to S^{-1}(M \\otimes_A N), (m/s) \\otimes (n/s&#039;) \\mapsto (m \\otimes n)/ss&#039; is S^{-1}A-lin.isom. 9.10\n\nfor S = A \\setminus \\mathfrak{p}, M_\\mathfrak{p} \\otimes_{A_\\mathfrak{p}} N_\\mathfrak{p} \\cong (M \\otimes_A N)_\\mathfrak{p}\n\n\na property \\mathcal{P} of rings (or mod.) is loc. if \\mathcal{P}(A) \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{\\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A)} \\mathcal{P}(A_\\mathfrak{p}) (Local Property), 9.11\n&quot;M = 0&quot; is a local property, 9.12\n\nA ring, M A-mod., tfae: (i) M = 0, (ii) \\forall_{\\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A)} M_\\mathfrak{p} = 0, (iii) \\forall_{\\mathfrak{m} \\text{ max.id.}} M_\\mathfrak{m} = 0, 9.12\n\n\n‚Äùf: M \\to N is ink. Primary Decomposition\n\nA ring., \\mathfrak{q} \\subsetneq A primary.id. iff \\forall_{x, y \\in A} \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}xy \\in \\mathfrak{q} \\to x \\in \\mathfrak{q} \\lor y^n \\in \\mathfrak{q}, 10.1\n\nequivalently, A/\\mathfrak{q} \\not = 0, and every zero.div. in A/\\mathfrak{q} is nilpot.\n\ni.e. \\bar y \\in A/\\mathfrak{q} zero.div. \\bar x \\cdot \\bar y = 0 for \\bar x \\not = 0 \\Rightarrow \\bar y^n = 0 for n \\ge 1\n\n\nfor \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{q} \\subsetneq A, then: \\mathfrak{q} primary.id. \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{q} /\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A / \\mathfrak{q} primary.id.\nprime.id. \\Rightarrow primary.id.\n\\{(p^n) : p \\in \\mathbb{P} \\land n \\in \\mathbb{N}\\} are primary.id. in \\mathbb{Z}\n\n\n\\mathfrak{q} \\subsetneq A primary id. \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{p} = \\mathfrak{\\sqrt{q}} \\subsetneq A prime.id. (say \\mathfrak{q} is \\mathfrak{p}-primary) 10.3-4\n\n\\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}} is smallest s.t. \\mathfrak{q} \\subseteq \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}}\n\n\n\\mathfrak{m} \\subseteq A max.id., \\mathfrak{q} \\subsetneq A id., if \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}} = \\mathfrak{m} or if \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\mathfrak{m}^n \\subseteq \\mathfrak{q} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{m}, then q is \\mathfrak{m}-primary, 10.5\n\n\\mathfrak{m}^n is \\mathfrak{m}-primary, but not all primary ideals are a power of max.id.\npowers of prime ideals are not necessarily primary ideals 10.6\n\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., a PD of \\mathfrak{a} is a fin.set of primary.id. \\mathfrak{q}_1, ..., \\mathfrak{q}_r s.t. \\mathfrak{a} = \\mathfrak{q}_1 \\cap ... \\cap \\mathfrak{q}_r, 10.7\nA noeth.ring., \\mathfrak{a} \\subsetneq A id., \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{a} has a (min.)PD. 10.8(.12)\n\nA PID, \\mathfrak{a} = (p_1^{n_1}, ..., p^{n_r}_r), then \\mathfrak{a} = (p_1^{n_1}) \\cap ... \\cap (p_r^{n_r})\n\n\n\\mathfrak{q}_1, ..., \\mathfrak{q}_r are \\mathfrak{p}-primary \\Rightarrow \\bigcap_{i = 1}^r \\mathfrak{q}_i is \\mathfrak{p}-primary, 10.10\nA PD is a min.PD if \\forall_{i \\in [1, r]} (\\bigcap_{j \\not = i} \\mathfrak{q}_j) \\not \\subseteq \\mathfrak{q}_i and \\forall_{i \\not = j}\\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}_i} \\not = \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}_j}, 10.11\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., a \\in A, then (\\mathfrak{a}: a) := \\{x \\in A : xa \\in \\mathfrak{a}\\} \\subseteq A id.\n\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A), \\mathfrak{q} a \\mathfrak{p}-prim.id., then: 10.14\n\n\\sqrt{(\\mathfrak{q}:a)} = A if a \\in \\mathfrak{q}\n\\sqrt{(\\mathfrak{q}:a)} = \\mathfrak{p} if a \\not \\in \\mathfrak{q}\n\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{a} \\subsetneq A id, then \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A) is ass.to.\\mathfrak{a} if \\exists_{a \\in A}\\sqrt{(\\mathfrak{a}:a)} = \\mathfrak{p}, 10.15\n\ndefine AP(\\mathfrak{a}) = \\{\\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A) : \\mathfrak{p} ass.to.\\mathfrak{a}\\}\nx \\in AP(\\mathfrak{a}) is an isolated.prime. if it is min_\\subseteq. in AP(\\mathfrak{a})\n\nnot isolated elements are embedded\n\n\n\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{a} \\subsetneq A id., \\mathfrak{a} = \\mathfrak{q}_1 \\cap ... \\cap \\mathfrak{q}_r min.PD, then AP(\\mathfrak{a}) = \\{\\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}_1}, ..., \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}_r}\\} (Uniqueness I), 10.16\n\nr and \\mathfrak{p}_1, ..., \\mathfrak{p}_r depend only on \\mathfrak{a}.\nisol.pr.id. of \\mathfrak{a} are exactly the min.pr.id.ov.\\mathfrak{a}, 10.17\n\n\nA ring, \\mathfrak{a} \\subsetneq A id., \\mathfrak{a} = \\mathfrak{q}_1 \\cap... \\cap \\mathfrak{q}_r min.PD, \\mathfrak{p} = \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{q}_i}, if \\mathfrak{p}_i isol.pr.(/min.pr.id.ov.\\mathfrak{a}) and A \\to A_{\\mathfrak{p}_i} loc.map., then \\mathfrak{q}_i =(\\mathfrak{a}^e)^c (Uniq. II), 10.19\n\nalso, pr.comp. corresponding isol.pr.id. in a min.PD do not depend on the PD.\n\n\n\n11. Integral Ring Extensions\n\nMotivation\n\nrecall from Algebra (Lecture): L/K fi.ext.: fin.gen &amp; alg. \\leftrightarrow finite\nhere: R/A ring.ext.: fin.gen &amp; int. \\leftrightarrow finite\n\n\nA \\subseteq B subring.,  b \\in B is int.ov.A if \\exists_{f \\in A[X]} f \\text{ mon. }\\land f(b) = 0, 11.1\n\ni.e. \\exists_{a_1, ..., a_n \\in A} b^n + a_1b^{n-1} + ... + a_n = 0\nB (or B/A) is int. if any b \\in B is int.ov.A\n\n\nS^{-1}A int.ov.A \\Rightarrow S^{-1}A = A, exe.14.3\nA ring, \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A, M fin.gen.A-mod., if \\Phi:M \\to M A-lin. s.t. \\Phi(M) \\subseteq \\mathfrak{a}M, then ex. f \\in \\mathfrak{a}[X] mon. s.t. f(\\Phi) = 0 \\in End_A(M) (Caley Hamilton, see 17.4 Cayley-Hamilton), 11.3\n\nfor \\mathfrak{a} = A = k fi., M a fin.dim.vex.sp., then pick a basis \\{b_1, .., b_n\\} and let \\Phi have a matrix, then f is the usual characteristic polynomial.\n\n\nA ring.ext. A \\subseteq B is fin., if B is a fin.gen A-mod., 11.4\nA \\subseteq B ring.ext., then A \\subseteq B fin. \\leftrightarrow A \\subseteq B int. \\land fin.gen, 11.5\n\ni.e. ex. b_1, ..., b_n \\in B int.ov.A s.t. B = A[b_1, ..., b_n]\n\n\nA \\subseteq B ring.ext., then C := \\{b \\in B : b int.ov.A\\}\\subseteq B  subring. (of A too), (Integral Closure) 11.6-7\n\nif C = A, then A is Integrally Closed, if C = B, B is integral over A\n\n\nA \\subseteq B, B \\subseteq D ring.ext., then: 11.9\n\nA \\subseteq B, B \\subseteq D int. \\Rightarrow A \\subseteq D int.\nC int.cl. of A in B \\Rightarrow C is max.int.cl. of A in B\nA \\subseteq B, \\mathfrak{b} \\subseteq b, \\mathfrak{a} = f^{-1}(\\mathfrak{b}) \\subseteq A id. \\Rightarrow A/\\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq B/ \\mathfrak{b} int.\nA \\subseteq B int., S \\subseteq A mult.cl. \\Rightarrow S^{-1}A \\subseteq S^{-1}B int.\n\nif also C int.cl. of A in B \\Rightarrow S^{-1}C int.cl. of S^{-1}A in S^{-1}B\n\n\n\n\nA ID, then the norm.cl. A^\\nu of A in Quot(A) is the int.cl of A in Quot(A), 11.10\n\nhence: A \\subseteq A^\\nu \\subseteq Quot(A)\nif A = A^\\nu, then A is norm.\n\n\n‚Äúbeing normal‚Äù is a local property, 11.11\n\ntfae: (i) A norm. (ii) \\forall_{\\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A)} A_\\mathfrak{p} norm., (iii) \\forall_{\\mathfrak{m} \\in spec_{max}(A)} A_\\mathfrak{m} norm.\nfact.ring \\Rightarrow norm.\n\n\nA\\subseteq B int.ring.ext., B ID, then: A fi. \\Leftrightarrow B fi., 11.13\n\nA \\subseteq B int.ring.ext., then: 11.14\n\n\\mathfrak{q} \\in spec(B), \\mathfrak{p} =\\mathfrak{q} \\cap A \\in spec(A), then: \\mathfrak{p} max.id. \\Leftrightarrow \\mathfrak{q} max.id.\n\\mathfrak{q}_1, \\mathfrak{q}_2 \\in spec(B) s.t. \\mathfrak{q}_1 \\subseteq \\mathfrak{q}_2, \\mathfrak{p} = \\mathfrak{q}_1 \\cap A = \\mathfrak{q}_2 \\cap A \\in spec(A), then \\mathfrak{q}_1 = \\mathfrak{q}_2\n\n\\mathfrak{q}_1 \\subsetneq \\mathfrak{q}_2 \\Rightarrow \\mathfrak{q}_1 \\cap A \\subsetneq \\mathfrak{q}_2 \\cap A\n\n\n\n\n\n\nA \\subseteq B int.ring.ext.: \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A) \\Rightarrow \\exists_{\\mathfrak{q} \\in spec(B)} \\mathfrak{p} = \\mathfrak{q} \\cap A (Lying-Over), 11.15\n\nover every prime ideal of A lies a prime ideal of B\n\n\nA \\subseteq B int.ring.ext., \\mathfrak{p}_1 \\subseteq ... \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}_m \\subseteq ... \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}_n pr.id. in A, \\mathfrak{q}_1 \\subseteq... \\subseteq \\mathfrak{q}_m  pr.id. in B s.t. \\forall_{ i \\in [1, m]} \\mathfrak{p}_i = \\mathfrak{q}_i \\cap A, then: \\{\\mathfrak{q}_i\\}_{[1, m]} can be extended to \\{\\mathfrak{q}_i\\}_{[1, n]} by \\forall_{ i \\in [1, n]} \\mathfrak{p}_i = \\mathfrak{q}_i \\cap A (Going-Up), 11.16\nA \\subseteq B int.ring.ext, \\Rightarrow dim(A) = dim(B), 11.17\nA \\subseteq B int.ring.ext. A norm., B ID, \\mathfrak{p}_n \\subseteq ... \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}_m \\subseteq ... \\subseteq \\mathfrak{p}_1 pr.id. in A, \\mathfrak{q}_m \\subseteq ... \\subseteq \\mathfrak{q}_1 pr.id. in B s.t. \\forall_{i \\in [1, m]} \\mathfrak{p}_i = \\mathfrak{q}_i \\cap A, then: \\{\\mathfrak{q}_i\\}_{[1, m]} can be ext. to \\{\\mathfrak{q}_i\\}_{[1, n]} by \\forall_{ i \\in [1, n]} \\mathfrak{p}_i = \\mathfrak{q}_i \\cap A (Going-Down), 11.16\n\nf: A \\to B ring.hom has going.up. prop. if f(A) \\subseteq B satisfies the conditions above\nC(\\mathfrak{a}) : = \\{n \\in B : b int.ov.\\mathfrak{a}\\}\n\n\nA \\subseteq B ring.ext., \\mathfrak{a} id. in A, C int.cl. of A in B, then C(\\mathfrak{a}) = \\sqrt{C \\cdot \\mathfrak{a}}\n\nC \\cdot \\mathfrak{a} = a^e for A \\to C\nhence C(\\mathfrak{a}) id. in A\nA = C \\Rightarrow C(\\mathfrak{a}) = \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{a}}\n\n\nA \\subseteq B ring.ext., B ID, A norm., \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., b \\in B int.ov.\\mathfrak{a}. then: b alg.ov.Quot(A), 11.20\n\nthe min.pol. of f has the form: m+b = X^n + a_1 X^{n-1} + ... + a_{n -1}X + a_n s.t. \\forall_{i \\in [1, n]} a_i \\in \\sqrt{\\mathfrak{a}}\n\n\nk fi., A fg.k-alg.: ex. \\{c_1, .., c_n\\} \\in A alg.ind. s.t. k[X_1, ..., X_n] \\cong k[c_1, ..., c_n], C \\subseteq A int.ext., 11.21\n\n|k| \\ge \\aleph_0, \\{a_1, ..., a_n\\} \\subseteq k, s.t. A = k[a_1, ..., a_n], then for \\gamma_{ij} \\in k, c_i = a_i + \\sum^m_{j = n +1} \\gamma_{ij} \\cdot a_j\n\n\nfor A a ring, \\mathfrak{p}_0 \\subsetneq ... \\subsetneq \\mathfrak{p}_n \\subsetneq A is max. if it can‚Äôt be extended.\nk fi., A fin.gen k-alg., \\mathfrak{p}_0 \\subsetneq ... \\subsetneq \\mathfrak{p}_n \\subsetneq A is max.ch.pr.id., then dim(A/\\mathfrak{p}_0)= n, 11.23\n\nalso, A has pure.dim. n\n\ni.e. every irr.comp. of spec(A) has dim. n\n\n\nevery max.ch.pr.id. in A has len. n.\nif \\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq \\mathfrak{q} pr.id. in A, then all max.ch.pr.id. between \\mathfrak{p} and \\mathfrak{q} have same lenght\n\ni.e. a finitely generated k-algebra A is a catenary ring\n\n\n\n\nA fin.gen.k-alg., of pure dim., if \\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq A pr.id. then dim(A) = ht(\\mathfrak{p}) + dim(A / \\mathfrak{p}), 12.24\n\nhence for \\mathfrak{a} \\subseteq A id., dim(A) = ht(\\mathfrak{a}) + dim(\\mathfrak{a} / A)\n\n\n\n\nAppendix\nIntroduction\n\nCommutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry\n\nExample:\n\nV := \\{(a,a^2): a \\in \\mathbb{C}\\}, complex parabola Y = X^2\nA(V) := \\mathbb{C}[X, Y]/(Y-X^2), i.e. functions V \\to \\mathbb{C}\nI(V):= \\{h \\in \\mathbb{C}[X, Y]: \\forall_{P \\in V}h(P) = 0\\}, i.e. the eq.class of polynomial of V, in the ex. (Y-X^2).\n\n\na ring, like A(V) is:\n\nfinitely generated, if it is a quotient of \\mathbb{C}[X, Y], call it \\mathbb{C}-algebra.\nreduced, if it contains nilpotent elements, call it affine \\mathbb{C}-algebra.\n\n\nfor varieties V, W define:\n\n\\psi: V \\to W, (a, a^2) \\mapsto f(a) for f \\in \\mathbb{C}[X].\n\\phi: W \\to V s.t. \\phi(a) = (f(a), g(a)) \\in V (i.e. g(a) = f(a)^2 in the ex.) for f,g \\in \\mathbb{C}[X].\n\n\nBack to the example with W = \\mathbb{C}, \\phi: W \\to V, a \\mapsto (a, a^2), \\psi: V \\to W, (a, a^2) \\mapsto a\n\n\\phi \\circ \\psi = id_V, \\psi \\circ \\psi = id_W i.e. V \\cong W (as affine varieties).\n\n\neach such \\psi induces the def. of \\psi^* : A(W) \\to A(V).\n\nin the ex. we get A(W) = \\mathbb{C}[X] \\cong \\mathbb{C}[X, Y]/(Y - X^2) = A(V)\n\n\non p.3 there is an example of non-isom. varieties.\n\n\nCommutative Algebra and Algebraic Number Theory\n\nQuestion: Which ID are factorial? Look at Ring extensions\nA \\le B a ring.ext., say b \\in B int. over A if there is a monic pol. f \\in A[X] s.t. f(b) = 0.\nC:= \\{b \\in B : b int. over A\\} is a ring s.t. A \\le C \\le B, call it the integral closure.\nThere are further remarks in the introduction.\n\n\n\nQuestions\nHere I collect the questions I ask to the tutor concerning the lecture material, I expressively make reference to the script file.\n\nIn the definition of \\mathfrak{b}^c, 2.16, I cannot understand the notion of \\mathfrak{b} \\cap A since the function f is an arbitrary ring homomorphism and can therefore have a domain completely different from its codomain. Intuitively f^{-1}(\\mathfrak{b}) is a notion that must differ from \\mathfrak{b} \\cap A, since the latter is empty in many more cases, than the former (take f: A \\to B and f&#039;: A&#039; \\to B for \\Phi: A \\to A&#039; an isomorphism, \\mathfrak{b} \\cap A \\not = \\emptyset but \\mathfrak{b} \\cap A&#039; = \\emptyset, hence f&#039;^{-1}(\\mathfrak{b}) =\\emptyset but \\emptyset \\not = \\Phi(f^{-1}(\\mathfrak{b})) = f&#039;^{-1}(\\mathfrak{b})). Searching online I often found the preimage of the ideal to be the correct definition of \\mathfrak{b}^c and couldn‚Äôt clarify what exactly \\mathfrak{b} \\cap A means (other than the proper set theoretic meaning that does not convince me due to the reason exposed above).\nIn the definition 6.1, I cannot understand what ‚Äúalmost all a_{i_1, ..., i_n} = 0‚Äù exactly means. Considering that that sequence is clearly meant to be finite (i.e. for n \\in \\mathbb{N}), I don‚Äôt see how the notion of ‚Äúalmost all‚Äù can be defined. On this, I found from wikipedia that: ‚ÄúThe meaning of ‚Äúnegligible‚Äù depends on the mathematical context; for instance, it can mean¬†finite,¬†countable, or¬†null.‚Äù Given this finte context, I suppose the only plausible meaning is that it applies to all elements (i.e. negligible is null), but then why not just write &quot;\\forall_{j \\in [1, n]}a_{i_j} = 0&quot;?\nA similar issue presents itself in 7.3, where the index can be infinite, in that case I suppose that ‚Äúalmost all‚Äù means ‚Äúall but finitely many‚Äù, hence: the definition of direct sum results as the following: \\bigoplus_{i \\in I} M_i := \\{\\{m_i\\}_I \\in \\prod_{i \\in I} M_i : |\\{i \\in I : m_i \\not = 0 \\}| &lt; \\aleph_0\\}; is this definition correct?\nOn the definition 7.5.c of an A-basis, I wanted to ask whether the understanding I have of it is correct: for A a ring, M an A-module, \\{m_i\\}_{i \\in I} \\subseteq M is a basis if \\forall_{m \\in M} \\exists!_{\\{a_i\\}_I \\subseteq A} m = \\sum_{i = 1}^n a_i m_i, here I use the symbol &quot;\\exists!&quot; defined as follows: \\exists !_x \\varphi(x) := \\exists_x \\varphi(x) \\land \\forall_y \\varphi(y) \\to x = y.\nOn the lemma 7.9.b it is assumed that ‚Äùh: P \\to N is an arbitrary A-linear map‚Äù, I wanted therefore to ask whether the notion of ‚Äúbeing arbitrary‚Äù could be clarified and whether it has been previously defined or more clearly stated.\nIn the solution of Exercise Sheet 14, Exercise 1 c, it is stated that there is a map Spec(S^{‚àí1}A) ‚Üí Spec(A) that is injective and inclusion preserving. In the lecture we have seen the map f: A \\to S^{-1}A, a \\to \\frac{a}{1} though I cannot see how that induces the map claimed in the solution or where that could otherwise come from. Could you either show me how the mapping of the function Spec(S^{‚àí1}A) ‚Üí Spec(A) works or where it compares in the script? Also, I suppose that the map f would not induce directly any mapping between the two spectra, since for \\mathfrak{p} \\in spec(A), then \\{f(p) : p \\in \\mathfrak{p}\\} \\subseteq S^{-1}A would not be a prime ideal.\n\nAnswers\n\nHere, \\mathfrak{b}\\cap A is just a notation to emphasize to which ring you contract the ideal \\mathfrak{b}. Hence, in 2.16, you have to interpret the equality \\mathfrak{b}\\cap A = f^{-1}(\\mathfrak{b}) as a definition of the left hand side. As you write, this equality does usually not make sense set-theoretically.\nHere, ‚Äúalmost all‚Äù refers to the set\nI:=\\{ (i_t)_{t \\in T&#039;} \\mid T&#039;\\subseteq T \\text{ finite}, i_t \\in \\mathbb{N} \\}.\nThe notation in 6.1 means that the sum is taken over the index set I. In particular, for each i = (i_t)_{t \\in T&#039;} \\in I, you have an element a_i\\in A (written as a_i=a_{i_1,\\dots,i_n} if T&#039;=\\{t_1,\\dots,t_n\\}) and we demand that a_i=0 for all but finitely many i.\nThis is correct.\nYour definition is almost correct. However, you have to additionally demand that a_i=0 for all but finitely many i. Also, you should write m=\\sum_{i \\in I} a_im_i (and not \\sum_{i=1}^n).\nHere, ‚Äúarbitrary‚Äù is just there to emphasize that while g is surjective, h need not be surjective. You can replace ‚Äúan arbitrary‚Äù by ‚Äúany‚Äù.\nin general, if f: A \\to B is a ring homomorphism, then f induces a continuous map\nSpec(f): Spec(B) \\to Spec(A), \\mathfrak{p} \\mapsto f^{-1}(\\mathfrak{p})\n(see e.g. exercise sheet 2, exercise 3). Here, we just have the special case B=S^{-1}A.\n\nContinuations\nI may continue to study related fields such as Algebraic Geometry (yt) and (Algebraic) Number Theory. In particular this source by Columbia University may be interesting: Stack Project and builds up on the already familiar material.\nExam Review\nHere I list the remarks and questions I have regarding the correction of the exam by following the order of the exercises:\n1a) Where I state \\bigcap A = max.elem. of A \\Rightarrow |A| = 1, I used a confusing notation, I mean tin fact that this holds in general (as I state before) that when the minimal and maximal element of a partial order coincide, then the cardinality of the underlying set must be one. So A as stated in that proposition is a general set and not A that is used in the exercise. Since what I wrote about A in that proposition holds for spec(A) (here referring to the ring A), then I can conclude |spec(A)| = 1. If I got 5/6 in that exercise because of this misleading notation, one could reconsider it by reading this explanation and underlying that ‚Äúin general‚Äù.\nSecondly, it is remarked that I did not prove taht A \\not = 0, this though immediately follows from the fact that‚Ä¶?"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.A.-Philosophy-Thesis":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.A.-Philosophy-Thesis","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Thesis/B.A. Philosophy Thesis.md","title":"B.A. Philosophy Thesis","links":[],"tags":[],"content":""},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.Sc.-Mathematics-Thesis":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.Sc.-Mathematics-Thesis","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Thesis/B.Sc. Springer, 1985.\nRelevant Sections:\n\nChapter 1: Generalized Quantifiers and Elementary Logic: Discusses the syntactical extension of first-order logic.\nChapter 3: Infinitary Languages: Focuses on the syntactical properties of infinitary logics.\n\nGoogle Search: Barwise &amp; Feferman, ‚ÄúModel-Theoretic Logics‚Äù\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/Bachelor-Thesis":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/Bachelor-Thesis","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Thesis/Bachelor Thesis.md","title":"Bachelor Thesis","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.A.-Philosophy-(LMU)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.Sc.-Mathematics-(LMU)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.A.-Philosophy-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.Sc.-Mathematics-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/4th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/LMU-Munich","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/ILLC-Amsterdam","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/6th-Semester/Master-Thesis"],"tags":[],"content":"I wrote my bachelor thesis with the title A Formal Approach to Syntactic Structures: Language Theory as a Field in Mathematical Logic. The full version of the thesis can be found at Overelaf: B.A. Thesis, this work syntheses both version officially submitted, for the B.A. Philosophy (LMU) and for the B.Sc. Mathematics (LMU), these are respectively to be found at B.A. Philosophy Thesis and B.Sc. Mathematics Thesis.\nI wrote this work during my 4th Semester, from April to July 2023, at the LMU Munich under supervision of Dr. Dougherty from the MCMP first and then by Prof. Merkl (department of Mathematics of the LMU Munich) and Prof. Schuster from the University of Verona (former lecturer at the LMU Munich).\nAfter the presentation by Prof. van Bentham at the ILLC Amsterdam on Translation Theory on the 21st November 2024, I decided to invest my research of the Master Thesis on his literature I was unaware of while writing the bachelor thesis."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Axiomatic-Metaphysics-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Axiomatic-Metaphysics-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Philosophy/Axiomatic Metaphysics (Lecture).md","title":"Axiomatic Metaphysics (Lecture)","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"This course takes place at the LMU in my fourth semester and is held by Prof. Zalta from Standford.\nLecture Notes\nEssay deadline: 02.08.2024\nSlides Links\n\n1st Lecture\n2nd Lecture\n3nd Lecture\n4th Lecture\n5th Lecture\n6th Lecture\n7th Lecture\n8th Lecture\n9th lecture\n\nFrege\n\n\n10th Lecture\n11th Lecture\n12th Lecture\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Ethics-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Ethics-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Philosophy/Ethics (Lecture).md","title":"Ethics (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Political-Philosophy-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"\nMoral Agents &amp; Moral Objects:\n\nChildren: objects but not agents (yet)\nFuture generations: unsure, definitely objects, perhaps agents\nAI: not objects, perhaps agents\nClimate: may be objects (why exactly?), no agent\nThere are border lines, adults are both subjects and object, children are only objects (you can do harm to them but shall have no responsibility, AI might be considered a subject but not an object. A stone is none of these.)\n\n\nAxiologic/Evaluative terms (good, bad) vs Deontic/Normative terms (should, right, wrong)\n\nRawls: utilitarianism begin with axiological, Kant with Deontic\n\n\nDescriptive (just describe a situation) or Normative (describe and judge)\nThree Macrotheories\n\nVirtue Ethic (on subj.) {Aristotle}\nDeontology (rules, way to conduct) {Kant}\nConsequentialism (cons. of actions) {Utilitarianism}\n\nConfusions: Mill: Aristotle is utilitarinanist, Kant is virtue ethics\n\n\n\n\nNeed to pick one? No, you might go for the ‚Äúcommon sense morality‚Äù\nThree Levels of Research: {on the trolley problem}\n\nMetaethics: Semantical, Metaphysical and Epistemic questions\n\nMetaphysical:\n\nare moral properties metaphysical properties?\n\n\nEpistemical:\n\nis there moral knowledge? How do we get it?\n\n\nPsychological questions are sometimes also metaethical questions\n\nwhat roles do emotions play? (cf. Hume)\n\n\n{where do intuitions come from? Can we justify them rationally?}\nis metaethics relevant for Normative/Applied Ethics?\nKantian Theory is in the middle of meta and normative\n\nwhat is a duty?\n\n\n\n\nNormative Ethics: what does utilitarianism/kantianism/aristotelism say on this?\n\ncompare ethical systems and derive actions\n\n\nApplied Ethics:\n\nClima\nAnimals (Bentham/Mill)\nAI\nBioethics\n\n\n\n\n\nConsequentialism\n\nConsequentialism (Anscombe): morally judged are nothing but consequences of actions\n\nvalue monism / value pluralism\nThree most popular options:\n\nHedonistic theories: pleasure (Bentham, \\simMill), monist\nPreference Utilitarianism: (D. Parfit, Reasons and Persons),\n\nactual preferences? well informed ones? only the moral ones?\n\n\nList Theory: pluralist\n\nthere is a list things one should consider, e.g. friendship, love‚Ä¶\n\n\n\n\nUtilitarianism: maximise utility/happyness (value monist)\n\nAction-utilitarianism (judge actions) / Rules-utilitarnianism (judge rules)\n\neach case is compatible with each of the following cases.\n\n\nPeople yet to exist must be considered\nBentham\n\nBentham Principle of Utility: maximise utility\n\nUtility is absence of pain\n\n\nBentham Subjective Hedonistic Utility\n\nAlternatives: (i) objective theory of pleasure, (ii) satisfy wishes\n\n\nBentham Animal‚Äôs Utility is as valuable\n\n\nPreference Utilitarianism: the utility is to satisfy wishes (D. Parfit, Reasons and Persons)\n\nactual preferences? well informed ones? only the moral ones?\n\n\nArguments: Pro utilitarianism\n\nBentham: we have both the intuition to do good for ourselves and for the community, we therefore need to find an objective criterion that quantifies that. Utilitarianism is a starting point, an intuition.\n\n\nC: people have different intuitions, hence it is not evident that there is a unique measure of common utility.\n\n\nBentham critiques to his time:\n\nAnimal rights, slaves, gender equality, jails, homosexuality\n\n\nAgainst Bentham\n\nPhilosophy of Swine: utility cannot be just pleasure\n\n\n\n\nMill‚Äôs Solution: different qualities of happiness (Kartoffeln essen &lt;&lt; Art)\n\nPlato: different levels, no amount of potatos makes a poem.\nMill: animals‚Äô pleasure is at a lower quality than humans‚Äô, still mor.obj.\nHow to distinguish? Look at the educated class\n\nstill: utility is absence of pain\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArguments: Contra utilitarianism\n\nUtilitarianism is unpractical, how shall I compute it?\n\nMill: no harm principle: ‚Äúyou are free until you harm someone else‚Äù.\n\n\nFreedom is good just bc it enables higher utility (for Kant it must be a first principle)\nThe demandingness objection: utilitarianism requires us to be constantly active\n\nMill: no harm principle: not harming is ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù.\nSidgwicks: just follow the common sense\n\n\nAxiological Argument: there‚Äôs more than just pleasure to be maximised\n\nswitch to value pluralism consequentialism\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArguments: Contra consequentialism\n\nmoral saint (Wolfs): it‚Äôs good to spend the life helping, would you marry someone like that?\nDeontic argument: other than utilities, there are rights and duties to respect.\n\nBentham; natural rights are nonsense (a true English man)\nIf one could, should one destroy the plane on 9/11?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nKantian Deontology\n\nit is a subset of all Deontology theories, one might argue against this though.\nthree reasons to behave: (i) personal advantage {bad}, (ii) bc its just funny {bad}, (iii) from duty {yay}\n\nmoral law comes from pure practical reason, every subject with reason has it.\ncf. Hume: morality arises from emotions\n\n\nimperatives: hypothetical (if that then) and categorical (no matters what, do that)\nevery creature with reason has one principle in mind:\n\n(i) ‚Äúhandle nur nach derjenigen Maxime, durch die du zugleich wollen kannst, dass sie ein allgemeines Gesetz werde.‚Äù\n(ii) ‚Äúhandle so, als ob die Maxime deiner Handlung durch deinen Willen zum allgemeinen Naturgesetze werden sollte‚Äù\nFour classes of duties:\n\non yourself &amp; absolute (/positive): preserve your life\non yourself &amp; not absolute (/negative): develop your talents\non others &amp; absolute (/positive): do not make false promises\non others &amp; not absolute (/negative): make others happy\n\n\nPeople shall be no means\n\n(iii) ‚Äúder Mensch und √ºberhaupt jedes vern√ºnftige Wesen existiert als Zweck an sich selbst, nicht blo√ü als Mittel zum beliebigen Gebrauche f√ºr diesen oder jenen Wille‚Äù\n\nMoral objects are rational creatures (not animals, perhaps aliens)\nKant: (iii) \\leftrightarrow (ii) \\leftrightarrow (i)\n\n\n\n\nWill is free (cf. Descartes)\n\npositive free will is a good will, i.e. one that choses general principles to respect\nsollen \\to k√∂nnen: I dont wanna do X, if I had to do X, then I know I am able to do X, despite not wanting to do X\n\n\nReich der Zwecke: dream world where people are all treated as ends.\nHegel: leerer Formalismus, Mill: counterexamples, Schiller: where are emotions?\n\n\n\nVirtue Ethic\n\nVirtue:\n\nKant: some moral fatigue\nHume: features of personality\n\nis a virtue if it gives pleasure (or is useful) to me or others\n\n\n\n\nGreece: Socrates is the idol for all\n\nEpicurus: happiness, and virtue as a way to the piece of the soul\nStoics: pure virtue, control just because its right\nSceptics: look for ataraxia, dont give a shit\nCynics: independency from convention to get control on the life\n\n\nAristotle: we need to start from pure knowledge\n\nall that exists has a function, our is to reach Œµ·ΩêŒ¥Œ±ŒπŒºŒøŒΩŒØŒ±\n\nmen as political, rational and social creatures\nprefectionism: we shall get the perfect state of our nature\n\n\nerstens all activities have a streben nach good a right ends\nzweitens eudaimonia is the highest end, the happiness\nHappiness: Œµ·ΩêŒ¥Œ±ŒπŒºŒøŒΩŒØŒ±, Mill: that is the only utility, Aristotle is utilitarianist\n\n‚Äúactivity of the soul in accordance with the [best] virtue [‚Ä¶] and the most complete goal‚Äù\ncount the whole life, not a day. Only after death you can tell.\n\nif kids die after our death, that also bad for us.\n\n\nnot only absence of pain but happiness in doing human activities\nwithout friends no one is happy, social virtues are impoerant too\nnot essential:\n\nLust &amp; Freuden\n\n\n\n\nVirtue: ·ºÄœÅŒµœÑŒÆ\n\n‚Äúabitude of a good-working person‚Äù but also ‚Äúfeature that we admire in others‚Äù\nrequire training (no enjoyment at the beginning)\ngood education is necessary\nin media stat virtus\nnot all in our power, must be lucky\n\n\n\n\nCritiques:\n\nPsychologically realistic? Cultural relativism? Egoism?\n\n\n\nOther Theories\n\nRawls (see Political Philosophy (Lecture)): Reflective Equilibrium\n\na meta-method, it requires some other methods like conceptual engineering, Aristotelian teleology\nhow can I get a balance between the rational results from the method and the intuitions?\n\n(i) general ethical values, (ii) mid-level principles, (iii) judgments on specific situations\n\n\nTwo Truth Theories\n\nMoral Realist: two incoherent set of moral rules, one must be wrong (D. Parfit)\nCoherentism: as long as the theory is coherent, then it‚Äôs fine.\n\n\nSidgwick, moral theories as methods\nBioethical Principles: (i) autonomy, (ii) care of the patient, (iii) avoid damage, (iv) social justice\nOther Theories: Constractualism, Feminism, (Confucianism, Ubuntu ethics)\n\n\n\nResponsibility\n\nShoemaker: Faces of responsability: (i) attributibility, (ii) answeability, (iii) accountability\nKant: Freedom is necessary or no behaviour shall be judged\n\nCompatibilism: we are free, the world may be determinist or not (Strawson, Hume)\nIncompatibilism: we are free \\to world is indeterminated (\\simKant)\n\n\nFrankfurt: you are free when you are free to act on your wishes.\n\nyou have responsibility only if you could have done otherwise (Frankfurt)\n\n\nStrawson: responsibility is a human, not metaphysical matter; who cares about determinism\n\nparticipant stance: treat other as responsible adults\n-¬†objective stance: treat them as children that are not responsible\n\n\nDistinctions:\n\nnegative / positive and retrospective / prospective\n\nprosp. pos, like dad and son (need to actively do stuff and for the future)\nprosp. neg. you need to avoid some bad behaviour\n\nsimilar things for those people that don‚Äôt exist (yet) are harder to state\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCriteria: control, foreseeability, understanding of the event, under these circumstances one is resp.\n\nWilliams: we are almost always responsible\n\n\nPraise &amp; Blame distinction\n\nan active component is necessary for praise but not in blame\n\nif you avoid to be good, you‚Äôre blameworthy\npraise shall not entail self-interest\nblame can come with self-interest (and often does)\n\n\n\n\nCEO example: moral evaluations influence perceptions of intentionality, (Joshua Knobe)\n\npeople are more likely to judge harmful actions as intentional than beneficial ones\nPolicies help/harm the environment, CEO knows it, he didn‚Äôt/did it intentionally\n\n\nNon-identity Problem: (iii) we cannot change the future of ppl in bad scenarios (we‚Äôd change ppl)\n\n(i) bad choices \\to sad future ppl, (ii) no bad choices \\to not those ppl\n\n\n\nMetaethics\n\nMoral Realism: (i) there r moral facts (metap.), (ii) those r true or false (sem.), (iii) we can know (epi.)\n\nNon-naturalism: moral facts are not psych., phys. or in any way natural. Those they‚Äôre out there\nQuietism: need of a moral language/category, not reducible to truths of other sort\nNaturalism\n\nAnalytical Naturalism: analytical (non natural), true beliefs\n\nopen question argument which analytical principle shall we take? who knows?\ne.g. x is right := x maximalises utility\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMotivational Internalism{ext.}: the motivation is {not} part of the moral belief (non-cogn.) {cogn.}\nDirection of fit: is the one of mor.jud. like the one of belief (\\tonon-cogn) or of desires (\\tocogn) or both?\nAnti Realism:\n\nCognitivism: moral judgements are beliefs\n\n‚ÄúError Theory‚Äù: moral beliefs are imagination of mor.truths, which actually don‚Äôt exist (Joyce)\n(Judgement Dependent Theories: those are true human opinions (Wright))\n(Cornell Realism: those are true &amp; more than human &amp; natural &amp; not nat.red. (Sturgeon))\n(Standard Moral Reductionism: true&amp; notjust.hum &amp; nat. &amp; not nat.red.)\n\n\nnon-Cognitivism: moral judgements are not beliefs, i.e. not true nor false\n\nQuasi-Realism: there are moral truths, we just feel them but cannot phrase them (Blackburn)\n\n(Blackburn): hence not subjective\n(Ayer): non-cogn \\to mor.judg. depend on the subject\n\n\n\n\n\n\nArguments Forms (Street):\\\n\nvindicating: explain the reason of moral judg., get justified belief\ndebunking: explain the reason of moral judg., and show it to be wrong\n\n\n\nClima Ethics\n\nDoes nature have a value on itself?\nBeautiful is well-formed, Sublime is power to compel and destroy\nLeopold: love, care, amazement are necessary for a good relationship with land\n\nA behaviour is right if it protects integrity, stability and beauty of the biotical society\nEcofascism? individuals must not be meaningless, or just kill half of the population\n\nCalicott: Clima ethics is just an extension\n\n\n\n\nRolston: brang the issue in academia first\n\npractically: protect the nature\ntheoretically: a theory of values must be developed\n\n\nParfit: how can we satisfy our duties for future generations?\n\nsame/different people choices and sam/different number choices ?\naverage utilitarianism / sum utilitarianism\n\nrepugnant conclusion: large and poor poulation\n\n\nagain: non identity problem\n\n\nScheffer:\n\nagainst the principle of well-behaviour\nif we were the last generation of mankind, how should we feel? is it important? yes bc:\n\nInterest rule: it gives meaning and importance\nLove rule: we love mankind\nValue rule: value and meaning comes from future\nReciprocity rule: we use existence of future people, bc it makes our life meaningful\nHence: future generations are even more important that our own!\n\n\n\n\nBroom: Divisions\n\nPublic Morality (duties of countries) vs Private Morality (duties of individuals)\nDuties of Charity vs Duties of Justice\n\nCharity: nobody has the claim on our charity unless we have a special relation with them\nJustice: toward those people that have the right not to be wronged.\n\n\nPrivate Morality on Climate Change the Duties of Justice are more improtant\nPublic Morality on Climate Change the Duties of Charity are more important\nWhy our emissions are not right:\n\nThe harm inflicted on future generations depends on the actions we take.\nThe harm we cause is not trivial, but severe.\nThe harm we cause is not accidental; we know we are causing it.\nWe do not compensate the victims we harm.\nMost of our actions that harm future generations are for our own benefit.\nThe harm caused by our emissions is not reciprocated.\nWe could reduce our greenhouse gas emissions.\n\n\nhence we should stop emittig or compensate\n\n\n\nAI Ethics\n\nBlack Box, we know nothing of what happens between input e output\n\nexplainable AI tries to find out\n\n\nIs AI a Moral Agent? is it a Moral Object?\nThree branches of the discussion:\n\nalready present questions\nquestions caused by misunderstandings by people\non near and far future\n\n\nAristoteles: AI and techne is cool!\nTuring: Turing test says that they can imitate\nMcCarthy: same\nRussel: machines can perceive and behave\nReal Trolley Problem with AI, how should it solve it?\nMoral Machine: can it solve moral issues for us?\n\nCoeckelbergh: no agents must have emotions\nVeliz: no, moral agent must have coscience\ncouldn‚Äôt AI have emotions and coscience?\n\n\nMachines and Power:\n\nTuring: they‚Äôll overcome us\nWiener: the purpose in the machine must be the one we definitely desire\nSolutions:\n\nLimit the capacity (sad tho)\nAI value Alignment\n\n\n\n\nAre we enslaving AI? if they get more developed?\nAI and Responsibility\n\npeople take responsibility freely\nPerhaps we should welcome responsibility gaps\nAI may take responsibility instead of us\nPeople-Machines teamwork\n\n\nInteraction with people\n\nTuring: we want it to be man-like, it may show us how we think\n\n\ncan robots have ethical features?\ncan they imitate them?\ncan they represent them?\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Logic-II-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Logic-II-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Philosophy/Logic II (Lecture).md","title":"Logic II (Lecture)","links":[],"tags":[],"content":""},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Mathematical-Philosophical-Colloquium":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Philosophy/Mathematical-Philosophical-Colloquium","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Philosophy/Mathematical Philosophical Colloquium.md","title":"Mathematical Philosophical Colloquium","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Thesis/B.A.-Philosophy-Thesis","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.A.-Philosophy-(LMU)","System/Documents"],"tags":[],"content":"In this course I present my B.A. Philosophy Thesis and submit a protocol on the persentation of two other students. This corresponds to the module P10 in the B.A. Philosophy (LMU), the certificate can be found in the Documents under Ludwig Maximilian Universit√§t M√ºnchen.\n\nOverleaf: Protocol\nOverleaf: Presentation of the Thesis\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Questions--and--Other-Works/Axiom-of-Strong-Negation-of-Undefinable-Choice":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Questions--and--Other-Works/Axiom-of-Strong-Negation-of-Undefinable-Choice","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/4th Semester/Questions & Other Works/Axiom of Strong Negation of Undefinable Choice.md","title":"Axiom of Strong Negation of Undefinable Choice","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"The questions on this topic have been first exposed in: Overleaf: Axiom of Strong Negation of Undefinable Choice.\nZF \\vdash Finite Choice\nIn this section I resemble the proof of Finite Choice from the axioms of ZF by following the Discussion.\nHere I recap Andreas Blass‚Äôs answer:\nWe are given the existential statement, ‚ÄúThere is an element in¬†x.‚Äù What should be noticed in addition is that what we want to prove is also an existential statement, ‚ÄúThere is a choice function.‚Äù We have an¬†explicit construction, which I‚Äôll call¬†C, that will convert any element of¬†x¬†into a choice function, namely sending any¬†y¬†to¬†\\{(x,y)\\}. If we can‚Äôt explicitly define any particular¬†y, then we won‚Äôt be able to define any particular choice function either, but the problem doesn‚Äôt require us to explicitly define a choice function; we need only prove that one exists. And that follows, thanks to¬†C, from the existence of elements in¬†x.\nThen, I shall distinguish two axioms: Axiom of  Finite Choice (AFC) and Axiom of Finite Definable Choice (AFDC), and from the answer above I note ZF \\vdash AFC. Now, meanwhile AFC can clearly be written within the object language \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon, it might not be the case with AFDC, in fact this axiom should entail the predicate ‚Äúbeing \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon-definable‚Äù which cannot clearly be written in the same language since it depends on it.\nQuestion: Is there a way to express AFDC in \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon?\nA candidate but possibly way to complex method would be to change the logic behind the existential quantifier &quot;\\exists_x \\varphi(x)&quot; might be true only if you can present an x s.t. \\varphi(x), this would be a more radical version of intuitionistic mathematics (here I mean the one excluding AC and not necessarily A \\lor \\lnot A). In fact one would, in such a logic, not admit any proof of existence that cannot present a definable example, this can clearly be stated in the semantical definition of the quantifiers of a classical (or intuitionistic, in the sense that rejects A \\lor \\lnot A) logic.\nOtherwise, one might simply add a predicate \\delta to \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon, call it \\mathcal{L}_{\\epsilon, \\delta}, s.t. \\delta(x) iff. there is a formula \\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon s.t. \\forall_{y} \\varphi(y) \\leftrightarrow \\varphi(x). Since there is an existential on formulae, this is a metalinguistic definition, which is not a problem since all syntax is traditionally defined metalinguistically (i.e. a \\land b iff a and b). Note that the definition of \\delta is not recursive because it runs over formulae in the language without \\delta itself.\nIn \\mathcal{L}_{\\epsilon, \\delta} we can write AFDC and consider both ZF + AFDC and ZF + \\lnot AFDC which will both probably be consistent, since ZF is written in \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon only. One might proceed by adding axioms to ZF s.t. they result consistent with SNUC as expressed in the \\LaTeX file above.\nQuestion: Could we have an axiom X in \\mathcal{L}_{\\epsilon, \\delta} s.t. ZF + X \\vdash ADC, i.e. the Axiom of Definable Choice? Is X needed?\nThat is an axiom that allows to pick definable elements. Perhaps this axiom might not even be needed if we are in \\mathcal{L}_{\\epsilon, \\delta}.\nQuestion: Can we finally prove $con(ZF) \\Rightarrow con(ZF + AFDC)"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Research Project/Structuralism & Categories (Research Project).md","title":"Categorical Foundations of Structuralism","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/5th-Semester","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/M.Sc.-Logic-(UvA)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Category-Theory-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Supervisor's-Page)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hannes-Leitgeb/Leitgeb,-H.,-Ladyman,-J.-(2007),-Criteria-of-Identity-and-Structuralist-Ontology","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Leon-Horsten/Horsten,-L.-(2010),-Having-an-Interpretation","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Halvorson,-H.-(2012),-What-Scientific-Theories-Could-not-Be","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Halvorson,-H.-(2013),-The-semantic-view,-if-plausible,-is-syntactic","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Halvorson,-H.,-Barrett,-T.-(2015),-Glymour-and-Quine-on-Theoretical-Equivalence","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Halvorson,-H.,-Tsementzis,-D.-(2015),-Categories-of-Scientific-Theories","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Halvorson,-H.-(2015),-Morita-Equivalence"],"tags":[],"content":"During my 1st Year, 3rd Period of my M.Sc. Logic (UvA), I did a research project I want to pursue in the thin, though currently wider than ever, intersection between Philosophy of Science and Category Theory. I proposed this research project to both Dr. Enrico Cinti (researcher in Philosophy of Science at the ILLC and University of Geneva) and Prof. Benno van den Berg (lecturer of Category Theory (Lecture)), more on the bureaucratic state of the project can be found on the Structuralism &amp; Categories (Supervisor‚Äôs Page), I will here mainly focus on its content and relation with my past work.\nThe current updated version of the project can be found here: Overleaf: S&amp;C Main.\nIn this page I present the general procedure that led me to the writing of the project, I start by presenting the Main Literature References, and by outlining the Calendar I follow for the reading and writing phases.\nMain Literature References\nI organise the reading so that there will be an open dialogue with a little group of other students of the M.Sc. Logic (UvA) who are planning to do research in this field.\n\nStructuralism:\n\nSEP: Structural Realism, Ladyman\n\nAdditional: SEP: Structuralism in Physics\nAdditional for Mathematicians: Leitgeb, H., Ladyman, J. (2007), Criteria of Identity and Structuralist Ontology\nAdditional: Horsten, L. (2010), Having an Interpretation\n\n\n\n\nSyntactic &amp; Semantic View on theories:\n\nHalvorson, H. (2012), What Scientific Theories Could not Be\n\n\nTheoretical Equivalence:\n\nHalvorson, H. (2013), The semantic view, if plausible, is syntactic\nHalvorson, H., Barrett, T. (2015), Glymour and Quine on Theoretical Equivalence\n\n\nCategorical Structuralism &amp; Morita Equivalence:\n\nHalvorson, H., Tsementzis, D. (2015), Categories of Scientific Theories\nHalvorson, H. (2015), Morita Equivalence\n\nAdditional for Mathematicians: nLab Morita Equivalence\nSEP: Category-Theoretic Structuralism in Philosophy of Mathematics\n\n\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Supervisor's-Page)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Supervisor's-Page)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Master/5th Semester/Research Project/Structuralism & Categories (Supervisor's Page).md","title":"Supervisor's Page","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Research-Project)","Structuralism--and--Categories-(Tracks--and--Roles)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Research-Project/Structuralism--and--Categories-(Supervisor's-Page)"],"tags":[],"content":"In revision.\n\nThis is a subpage of the Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project).\nIn this page all material that will be relevant to the supervisors for the project Structuralism &amp; Categories (Research Project) is uploaded and revised.\nInvolvement of the Supervisors\nDuring the project, we will first work together as a united group to ensure that each student has the necessary background to fully understand the basic literature on structuralism and issues related to theoretical equivalence (for the list of papers, see Literature to Explore). This phase will only require the supervisors to answer some of our questions as we go through the reading material.\nIn the second phase of the project, some of us will develop original ideas that we decide to write about (see Claim Tracks). Before moving into the actual writing, we may ask for a meeting where the group member presents their idea and seeks feedback.\nFinally, the supervisors will receive a document encompassing the entire project, which will be broken down into each student‚Äôs individual contributions to meet the requirements of Bureaucracy.\nBureaucracy\nWhile the content and the proper output of the project will be one single organic work involving multiple tracks (Claim Tracks &amp; Background Tracks) written by each one of the group‚Äôs members, the bureaucracy to get a recognisable research project out of it requires some further steps. Though, the current bureaucratic form of the project, should not confine in any way the intensions of the projects (see Project Structure &amp; Goals).\nUnder a solely bureaucratic perspective, the project will be structured as follows: there will be two independent projects and each one of the students participating to each of the projects will be submitting their own document:\n\nThe first project will be supervised by both Prof. van den Berg &amp; Dr. Cinti, each one of the students submitting the sufficient amount of work will receive 6EC (with passed / not passed)\nThe second project will be supervised by Dr. Cinti [1] only and will give 6EC (with passed / not passed) depending on the contributions; the submission for this project clearly must have empty intersection with what submitted for the first project.\n\n[1]: that is, if Dr. Cinti is allowed to supervise a project by himself; this question will be answered within the end of the week."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Algebra-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Algebra-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Mathematics/Algebra (Lecture).md","title":"Algebra (Lecture)","links":["tags/3rd_Semester","tags/LMU","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Linear-Algebra-II-(Lecture)","System/Attachments/groups_hom.png","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Algebra-(Lecture)","tags/jokes"],"tags":["3rd_Semester","LMU","jokes"],"content":"I collect here some of the notes of the lecture on Algebra I followed in the 3rd_Semester at the LMU held by A. Rosenschon.\nRecap\nElementary Group Theory\nMost of theorems of this section were present already in Linear Algebra II (Lecture).\n\nNormal Divisor\n\nfor H \\subseteq G subgr., aH := \\{ah : h \\in H\\}, Ha:= \\{ha : h \\in H\\}\n\n|aH| = |bH|\nG =\\bigsqcup_{a \\in R \\subseteq G} aH\naH = bH \\Leftrightarrow aH \\cap bH = \\emptyset \\Leftrightarrow a \\in bH \\Leftrightarrow b^{-1}a \\in H\n\n\nG/H := \\{aH : a \\in G\\}, H \\setminus G := \\{Ha : a \\in G\\}, |G:H|:= |G/H|, |G/H| = H \\setminus G\n|G| = |G:H|\\cdot |H| (Lagrange)\nfor H \\subseteq G subgr., H \\trianglelefteq G : \\forall_{a \\in G} aH = Ha\nWays to prove U \\trianglelefteq G:\n\nfor \\varphi: G \\to G&#039;, ker(\\varphi)\\trianglelefteq G\n|G : H| = 2 \\Rightarrow H \\trianglelefteq G, link.\n\n\nG \\to G, x \\mapsto gxg^{-1} is a gr.autom.\n\n\nHomomorphism and Isomorphism Theorems 1.12\n\nfor (i) \\varphi: G \\to G&#039; hom., (ii) N \\trianglelefteq G s.t. N \\subseteq ker(\\varphi), (iii) \\pi: H \\to G/N, a \\mapsto aH then:\nex. uniq. \\overline{\\varphi}: G/N \\to G&#039; s.t. G \\to^\\pi G/N \\to^\\overline{\\varphi} G&#039;, G \\to^\\varphi G&#039; groups_hom.png\n\n\\varphi surj, then \\overline{\\varphi}: G / ker(\\varphi) \\to G&#039; is isom.\n\n\nH \\subseteq G subgr. N \\trianglelefteq G, then (i) HN \\subseteq G subgr., (ii) N \\trianglelefteq HN, (iii) H \\cap N \\trianglelefteq H, (iv) H/H \\cap N \\cong HN/N (1st Isomorphism Theorem)\n\nHN := \\{hn | h \\in H \\land n \\in N\\}\n\n\nfor N, H \\trianglelefteq G, N \\subseteq H \\subseteq G, then (i) N \\trianglelefteq H, (ii) H/N \\trianglelefteq G/N, (iii) (G/N)(H/N)\\cong G/H (2nd)\n\n\nGrothendieck\nCyclical Groups\n\n...\n\n\n\nRings and Polynomials\nMost of these theorems are present in Linear Algebra II (Lecture) already, though I list some of them here again:\n\nfor \\varphi hom, \\varphi inj. \\Leftrightarrow \\varphi surj. No, find the right version\n\nfor |R| &lt; \\aleph_0 comm, \\forall_{a \\in R} a | 0 \\lor a \\in R^\\times (B.9.1.a)\n\n\nRings and Polynomial Rings in one Variable\n\ndef. of Ring: for a group (R, +) with e = 0 and a monoid (R, \\cdot) with e = 1 it holds (a + b)c = ac + ab and c(a + b) = ca + cb. It is comm. if ab = ba.\n\nif 0 = 1, then R = \\{0\\}\n\n\nR^\\times = \\{a \\in R | \\exists_{b \\in R} ab = ba = 1\\}, (R^\\times, \\cdot_{R}) is a group.\nFor (R_i)_{i \\in I} a family of rings, \\prod_{i \\in I} R_i is ring with component-wise + and \\cdot.\nR[X] \\simeq (R^{(\\mathbb{N})}, +_{R^\\omega}, \\cdot_{R^\\omega})\n\nR^{(\\mathbb{N})} = \\{(a_i)_{i \\in I} : \\forall_{i \\in I}a_i \\in R \\land |\\{a_i \\in (a_i)_{i \\in I} : a_i \\not = 0\\}| &lt; \\aleph_0\\} with + and \\cdot from R^\\omega. 2.2-2.3\n\n\ngrad(f) = max\\{i |: a_i \\not = 0\\}\n\ngrad(f + g) \\le max\\{grad(f), grad(g)\\}, grad(fg) \\le grad(f) + grad(g).\n\n\n\n\nIdeal\n\ndef. ideal I \\subset R s.t. (I, +_R) subgroup of (R, +) and \\forall_{r \\in R} \\forall_{i \\in I}ra = ar \\in I\ndef. generator (a_j)_{j \\in J}, if I = \\sum_{x \\in X} Ra_i, fin.gen. if |(a_j)_{j \\in J}| &lt; \\aleph_0, principle if (a).\n2.14: p prime Ideal if \\forall_{a, b \\in R} ab \\in p \\rightarrow (a \\in p \\lor b \\in p), m max. ideal if all ideals I, \\forall_{I \\subset R} m \\subseteq I \\subseteq R \\rightarrow (I = m \\lor I = R).\n2.15: R comm., I \\subsetneq R prime iff R/ I is ID. I \\subsetneq R max. ideal \\Leftrightarrow R/m is a field.\n\nfor I max., I prime. p \\mathbb{Z} max. \\Leftrightarrow p prime.\n\n\n\n\nRings-homomorphisms and Factor-rings\n\ndef hom. \\varphi: R \\rightarrow S s.t. (i) \\varphi(a +_R b) = \\varphi(a) +_S \\varphi(b), (ii) \\varphi(ab) = \\varphi(a)\\varphi(b), (iii) \\varphi(1_R) = \\varphi(1_S).\n\nker(\\varphi) is an ideal, im(\\varphi) is a subr., \\varphi determines a gr. hom. R^\\times \\rightarrow S^\\times. ker(\\varphi) = \\{0\\} \\Rightarrow \\varphi inj.\n\n\nHomomorphiesatz\nChinese Restsatz\n\n\nPrime Factorisation\n\ndef. let \\delta : R \\setminus \\{0\\} \\rightarrow \\mathbb{N} s.t.  a, b \\in R, b \\not = 0 there is q, r \\in R s.t. a = qb + r where \\delta(r) &gt; \\delta (g) \\lor r = 0, then R is eucl. ring and \\delta a norm. 2.17\nR eucl \\Rightarrow R PID\np \\in R \\setminus R^\\times  irr. if \\forall_{x, y \\in R} p = xy \\rightarrow x \\in R^\\times \\lor y \\in R^\\times\np \\in R \\setminus R^\\times prime if \\forall_{x, y \\in R} p|xy \\rightarrow p|x \\lor p|y\n(i) (p) max. \\Rightarrow p prime, (ii) p prime \\Rightarrow p irr. (iii) R PID: p irr. \\Leftrightarrow p prime \\Leftrightarrow (p) max. 2.20\nR PID, 0 \\not = a \\in R \\setminus R^\\times, then a = p_1 \\cdot p_2 \\cdot ... \\cdot p_n. unique up to order and mult. with units. 2.22\ndef Fact. Ring: \\forall_{0 \\not = a \\in R \\setminus R^\\times} if (i) a = p_1 \\cdot p_2 \\cdot ... \\cdot p_n or (ii) a = i_1 \\cdot i_2 \\cdot ... \\cdot i_m irr elem. 2.23\n\nR Fact. Ring p prime \\Leftrightarrow p irr.\nR eucl. \\Rightarrow R PID \\Rightarrow R Fact Ring\nggT(x_1, ..., x_n) = \\prod_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}} p^{min\\{v_p(x_1), ..., v_p(x_n)\\}}\n(x_1, ..., x_n) = (d) \\Rightarrow d = ggT(x_1, ..., x_n), (x_1) \\cap ... \\cap (x_n) = (v) \\Rightarrow v = kgV(x_1, ..., x_n)\n\nin an ID there could be no gcd bc not every ideal is principal. 2.26\n\n\n\n\nfor R is PID, |R| &lt; \\aleph_0 \\Rightarrow R is a field, link.\nR[X] PID \\Rightarrow R is a filed, link.\n\\mathfrak{p} pr. ideal \\Rightarrow R/ \\mathfrak{p} ID (B.9.1.c)\n\\mathfrak{m} max. ideal \\Rightarrow R/\\mathfrak{m} is a field. (B.7.1.a)\n\n\nRoots of Polynomials\n\nK a field grad(f) = n \\ge 0 then f has max. n roots, exactly n if f = \\prod^n_{i = 1}(X- a_i) \\in K[X].\nf \\in K[X], f(\\alpha)= 0, then \\alpha mult. root \\Leftrightarrow f&#039;(\\alpha) = 0 \\Leftrightarrow ggT(f, f&#039;)(\\alpha) = 0.\nM = R \\times R \\setminus \\{0\\} = \\{(a, b) : a, b \\in R \\land b \\not = 0\\}, (a, b) \\sim (a&#039;, b&#039;) \\Leftrightarrow ab&#039; = a&#039;b, with the fraction operation define the the quotient field, called Q(R). 2.28 Also \\frac{a}{b} = \\epsilon \\prod_{p \\in P} p^{v_p(x)}.\nv_p(f) := min \\{v_p(c_i): i \\in \\mathbb{N}\\},  (Gauss-lemma) R fact. Ring v_p(fg ) = v_p(f) + v_p(g).\n(Gauss) R fact. \\Rightarrow R[X] fact.: q \\in R[X] pr. \\Leftrightarrow q \\in R pr. \\lor (q primitive in R[X] \\land prime in Q(R)[X].\n\nR fact. q primitive in R[X]: q irr in R[X] \\Leftrightarrow q irr. in Q(R)[X].\n\n\nfor f, g \\in\\mathbb{Q}[X], cont(fg) = cont(f) \\cdot cont(g), link.\n\ncont(f) is the gcd(a_1, ..., a_n) for all coefficients of f., wiki.\n\n\nIrreducibility Criteria for R fac. ring with quotientfield and f primitive.\n\n(Eisenstein) f = \\sum_{i = 0}^n a_iX^i primitive, grad(f) &gt; 0 and there is p prime in R, s.t. \\lnot p | a_n, \\forall_{0 \\le i &lt; n}p | a_i, \\lnot p^2 | a_0, then f irr. in R[X]. 2.34\n(Red. mod. p) p \\in R, 0 \\not = f = \\sum_{i = 0}^n a_i X^i \\in R[X] s.t. \\lnot p | a_n and \\pi: R[X] \\rightarrow (R/(p))[X], \\sum_{i = 0}^n a_iX^i \\mapsto \\sum^n_{i = 0}\\overline{a_i}X^i for \\overline{a_i}:= a + (p). If \\pi(f) irr. then f irr in Q(R)[X], if f also primitive, then f irr. in R[X]. 2.35\n\n\nMethods (Sol. 9.2): for R fac., f = \\sum_{k = 0}^d a_k X^k \\in R[X], d \\ge 2., check red. of f in Q(R)[X]\n\nEisenstein: check for all p \\in \\mathbb{P} s.t. p | a_0, if it works, it is irr., else continue\nRoots: check poss. roots in Q(R), i.e. \\frac{a}{b} \\in Q(R) s.t. gcd(a, b) = 1, a|a_0, b|a_n, if none, continue\nDegree: if d \\le 3, f has no roots \\Leftrightarrow f irr. (if no roots, conclude)\nReduction: if R = \\mathbb{Z}, \\lnot 2 | a_d, then \\overline{f} \\in \\mathbb{F}_2[X] irr. \\Rightarrow f \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X] irr., try further red.., else continue\n\nrecall irr. pol. of d \\le 4 in \\mathbb{F}_2[X] (link): for d \\le 3, try \\overline{f}(0), \\overline{f}(1), else\n\nx^4 + x^3 + x^2 + x + 1 and x^4 + x^n + 1 for n \\in \\{1, 2, 3\\}\n\n\n\n\nAbsurdum: if d = 4, f norm., no roots, try f = (X^2 +  aX + b) (X^2 + cX + d) get cont., else\nR = \\mathbb{Z}, d \\le 5 with roots \\xi_i \\in \\mathbb{C} \\setminus \\mathbb{Q}, if \\forall_{i , j}\\xi_i \\cdot \\xi_j \\not \\in \\mathbb{Q}, f irr.\nf irr. \\Leftrightarrow f^\\flat irr. (Wiederholungsblatt 6.a, Tut.B.9-10)\n\nf^\\flat is f with the order of the coefficients inverted, this can help to apply Eisenstein.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAlgebraic Field Extensions\n\nCharacteristic\n\ndef. for R ID \\varphi: \\mathbb{Z} \\rightarrow R, n \\mapsto n \\cdot 1_R, for p \\in \\mathbb{N} s.t. (p) = ker(\\varphi) then char(R) = p.\n\nR \\subseteq S subr. \\Rightarrow char(R) = char(S)\n\n\ndef. prime field P=\\bigcap\\{L : L \\subseteq K subfield\\} \\subseteq K, smallest subfield of K.\n\n(i) char(K) = p &gt; 0 \\Leftrightarrow P \\simeq \\mathbb{F}_p, (ii) char(K) = 0 \\Leftrightarrow P \\simeq \\mathbb{Q}.\n\n(iii) any field contains some \\mathbb{F}_p or a \\mathbb{Q} up to isomorphism.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nField-Extentions\n\nL/K ext. if K is a subfield of L. Note that L is a K-VS.\n\n[L:K] = dim_K (L)\n\n[L:K] = [L:E][E:K]\n\n[L: K] \\in \\mathbb{P} \\Rightarrow K = E \\lor E = L\n\n\n\n\n\n\nL/K, \\alpha \\in L algebraic on K if ex. f \\in K[X] s.t. f(\\alpha) = 0. Also \\alpha is primitive to L/K.\nFinite Fields\n\nFor p^n, p \\in \\mathbb{P}, ex. unique up to isom. \\mathbb{F} s.t. |\\mathbb{F}| = p^n.\n\nFor \\mathbb{F}_{p^n} is spli.fi. of X^{p^n}-X \\in \\mathbb{F}_p[X]\n\\mathbb{F}_p \\subseteq \\mathbb{F}_{p^n} \\subseteq \\overline{\\mathbb{F}_p} holds, hence \\mathbb{F}_p \\subseteq \\mathbb{F}_{p^n}  \\subseteq \\mathbb{F}_{p^m} \\subseteq \\overline{\\mathbb{F}_p} \\Leftrightarrow n |m\n\nextensions \\mathbb{F}_{p^n} \\subseteq \\mathbb{F}_{p^m} are the only extensions of finite fields with char. p.\n\n\n\n\n|K| &lt; \\aleph_0 \\Rightarrow \\exists_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}}\\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} K \\cong \\mathbb{F}_{p^k} wiki.\n\n\n\nGalois Theory\nTrue love makes non-Galois couples: not normal or inseparable. And if you claim your lover to be perfect, be aware that they are separable to anyone. jokes\n\nL/K is gal. := L/K norm. and sep., a gal. gr. Gal(L/K) = Aut_K(L), Galois Examples.\n\nL/K normal, then:\n\nrecall: L/K norm. \\Rightarrow Hom_K(L, \\overline{K}) = Aut_K(L) 3.23.c\n|Aut_K(L)| = |Hom_K(L, \\overline{K})| = [L : K]_s \\le [L: K]\n\n\nL/K separable, then:\n\n(\\Leftrightarrow) |Aut_K(L)| = [L : K]\n\n\nL/K gal. \\Leftrightarrow |Gal(L/K)| = [L:K]\nL/K gal. fin. \\Rightarrow L= K(\\alpha_1, ..., \\alpha_n) = K[\\alpha_1, ...,\\alpha_n], for \\sigma \\in Gal(L/K) is uniq. def. by  \\sigma(\\alpha_1), ..., \\sigma(\\alpha_n).\nf \\in K[X], root \\alpha \\in L, \\sigma \\in Gal(L/K) \\Rightarrow f(\\sigma(\\alpha))= 0\n\n0 = f(\\alpha) \\sum^n_{i = 0}a_i \\alpha^i \\in L, 0 = \\sigma(0) = \\sigma(f(\\alpha)) = \\sigma(\\sum^n_{i = 0}a_i \\alpha^i) = \\sum^n_{i = 0}a_i \\sigma(\\alpha^i) = f(\\sigma(\\alpha)).\n\n\nL/K gal., K \\subseteq E \\subseteq L:\n\n(i) L/E gal., Gal(L/E) \\subseteq Gal(L/K) subgr.\n(ii) if E/K gal. \\Rightarrow Gal(L/K) \\rightarrow Gal(E/K), \\sigma \\mapsto \\sigma|_E is surj. hom.\n\n\nL field, G \\subseteq Aut(L), then L^G := \\{a \\in L | \\forall_{\\sigma \\in G}\\sigma(a) = a\\} (fixk√∂. of G): 4.4\n\n(i) |G|&lt; \\aleph_0 \\Rightarrow (L/L^G gal. \\land G = Gal(L/L^G)\n(ii) |G| \\ge \\aleph_0 \\land L/L^G alg. \\Rightarrow  L/L^G gal. \\land G \\subseteq Gal(L/L^G) subgr.\n\n\nL/K norm.: 4.5\n\n(i) L/L^{Aut_K(L)} gal. \\land Gal(L/L^{Aut_K(L)}) = Aut_K(L)\n(ii) if L/K sep. then K = L^{Aut_K(L)}\n\n\nfor \\psi: E \\mapsto Gal(L/E), \\phi: H \\mapsto L^H, then \\phi \\circ \\psi = id\n(Gal.-Cor.) L/K gal., L^H/K norm. (\\Rightarrow gal.) \\Leftrightarrow H \\trianglelefteq G \\Rightarrow H = ker(Gal(L/K) \\rightarrow Gal(L^H/K), \\sigma \\mapsto \\sigma|_{L^H}) 4.6\n\nif L/K fin. sep. then |\\{K&#039;: K \\subseteq K&#039; \\subseteq L\\}| &lt; \\aleph_0\n\nif also N/K norm.cl. then N/K fin. gal. and [N:K] = |Gal(N/K)| &lt; \\aleph_0.\n\n\n\n\nMethod: find Gal(f), L spl.fi. of f in K, and all E s.t. K \\subseteq E \\subseteq L\n\nGalois Ext. L is a spl.fi., hence L/K is norm., prove it to be sep.\n\nchar(K) = 0 \\Rightarrow L/K sep.\nL/K fin., then L/K sep. \\Leftrightarrow L = K(\\alpha_1, ..., \\alpha_n) for \\alpha_1, ..., \\alpha_n \\in L sep. over K \\Leftrightarrow [L:K]_s = [L:K]\nL/K alg., let \\mathcal{A} \\subseteq L s.t. K(\\mathcal{A}) = L, then L/K sep. \\Leftrightarrow any \\alpha \\in \\mathcal{A} sep. over $K\n\n\nDegree: find [L:K], conclude [L:K] = |Gal(f)|\nElements:\n\nlet \\sigma(\\alpha_i) = \\alpha_j\ndetermine \\sigma(\\alpha_j) using that \\sigma is a K-automorphism.\ncombine a fixed \\alpha_i with any \\alpha_j, and check wether they are automorphism\nStop when \\alpha_j are finished or you already got [L:K] many automorphism.\n\n\nIsomorphic Class: check isomorphisms with the groups in the table using the listed methods\nGalois Correspondence: subfields of L correspond to subgroups of Gal(f)\n\nfor \\sigma \\in Gal(f), L^{\\langle \\sigma \\rangle} are exactly the subfields\nto compute L^{\\langle \\sigma \\rangle} consider \\sigma(a_1 \\beta_1 + ... + a_n \\beta_n) for \\beta_1, ..., \\beta_n the basis of L/K and recall L^G := \\{a \\in L | \\forall_{\\sigma \\in G}\\sigma(a) = a\\}, for instance if \\sigma(a + b \\sqrt{2} + c \\sqrt{3} + d \\sqrt{6})$$= a - b\\sqrt{2} + c \\sqrt{3} + d\\sqrt{6}, then L^{\\langle \\sigma \\rangle} = \\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt{3}).\n\n\n\n\n\n\nRoots of the Unit\n\nfor f_n := X^n -1 \\in K[X] for n \\in \\mathbb{N}\\setminus \\{0\\}\n\nU_n := \\{\\alpha \\in \\overline{K}: \\alpha^n = 1\\} subgr. of (\\overline{K}^\\times, \\cdot), U_n cycl. 4.9\n\\lnot char(K) | n \\Rightarrow |U_n| = n \\land (U_n, \\cdot_{\\overline{K}}) \\cong (Z/(n), +).\n\nif \\lnot char(K) | n then X^n -1 \\not = 0 \\land (X^n -1)&#039; = nX^{n-1} \\not = 0 hence f_n sep. and |U_n| = n.\n\\zeta \\in U_n pr. if \\langle \\zeta \\rangle = U_n or equivalently ord(\\zeta) = n.\nfor \\zeta pr. U_n = \\{1,\\zeta, ..., \\zeta^{n-1}\\}, K[\\zeta]/K is spl.fi. of x^n -1\n\n\nif p = char(K) | n, n = p^rm, \\lnot p | m then x^m -1 sep., since x^n -1 = (x^n-1)^{p^r}, x^n-1 and x^m -1 share all roots. From now on assume \\lnot char(K) | n.\na \\in G, ord(a) = n \\in \\mathbb{N} \\Rightarrow \\forall_{m \\in \\mathbb{Z}} ord(a^m) = \\frac{m}{gcd(m, n)}\n\nif G = \\langle a \\rangle then G = \\langle a^m \\rangle \\Leftrightarrow gcd(m, n) = 1\n\n\n\\varphi: \\mathbb{N} \\setminus \\{0\\} \\rightarrow \\mathbb{N}, n \\mapsto |\\{m : 1 \\le m \\le n \\land gcd(m, n) = 1\\}| = |\\{gen., of \\mathbb{Z}/(n)\\}| = |\\mathbb{Z}/(n)^\\times| =  |\\{gen., of U_n\\}| = |\\{\\zeta \\in U_n : \\zeta pr. \\}| (Euler-\\varphi-function)\n\n\\varphi(1) = 1, \\varphi(2) = 1, \\varphi(3) = 2\ngcd(m, n) = 1 \\Rightarrow \\varphi(m \\cdot n) = \\varphi(m) \\cdot \\varphi(n)\nn = p_1^{v_1} \\cdot ... \\cdot p_r^{v_r} for v_i &gt; 0 \\Rightarrow \\varphi(n) = \\prod_{i = 1}^r p_i^{v_1 -1}\nn = \\sum_{d | n \\land d &gt; 0} \\varphi(d)\n\n\nfor \\lnot char(K) | n and (\\zeta_i)_{i \\in [1, ..., \\varphi(n)]} pr. \\phi_n := \\prod_{i = 1}^{\\varphi(n)}(x - \\zeta_i) = \\prod_{d | n} \\phi_d 4.11 (circ. div. pol.)\n\n\\phi_4 = (x -i)(x +i)\nfor all n \\in \\mathbb{N}, \\phi_n \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X] is irr.\n\n\nfor d | n, P_d := \\{\\zeta_d : \\zeta_d pr.\\} \\subseteq U_n, U_n := \\bigsqcup_{d|n}P_d, x^n - 1 = \\prod_{d|n} \\prod_{\\zeta \\in P_d} (x - \\zeta) = \\prod_{d |n} \\phi_d\n\nM_d := \\{g \\in \\mathbb{Z}/(n) : ord(g) = d\\}, \\bigsqcup_{d|n} M_d = \\mathbb{Z}/(n)\n\n\n\\lnot char(K) | n, \\zeta_n pr., then X^n - 1 sep., K(\\zeta_n) spl.fi of X^n - 1, i.e. fin.gal. check note 4.13.\nfor n \\ge 1, \\zeta \\in \\overline{\\mathbb{Q}}, \\zeta pr. then f= \\phi_n, also \\phi_n \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X] irr. 4.15 ?\n\\zeta \\in \\overline{\\mathbb{Q}}, \\zeta = \\sqrt[n]{u} primitive for u \\in \\mathbb{Q}^\\times, then (i) \\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)/\\mathbb{Q} gal., (ii) [\\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)/ \\mathbb{Q}] = \\varphi(n), (iii) Gal(\\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)/\\mathbb{Q}) \\cong \\mathbb{Z}/(n)^\\times.\n\ncall gal. L/K abelian if Gal(L/K) is abelian. [[Algebra (Lecture)#example-with‚Äîzeta|Example with  zeta]].\n\n\n\n\n\n\nRoots Extensions\n\nchar(K) = 0, L/K is rad. if there are K_1 \\subseteq ... \\subseteq K_r = L s.t. K_{i + 1} = K_i(\\sqrt[n_i]{a_i}) 4.18\n\nL/K rad. \\Rightarrow L/K fin.\nchar(K) = 0, L/K rad. then ex. M/K s.t. K \\subseteq L \\subseteq M s.t. M/K rad. gal. 4.20\nL/K gal. rad., char(K) = 0, then Gal(L/K) is quot. of a gr. G s.t. (i). 4.21\n\n(i): exists G_i \\subseteq G subgr. s.t. \\langle e \\rangle = G_r \\trianglelefteq G_{r-1} \\trianglelefteq ... \\trianglelefteq G_0 = G, G_i/G_{i + 1} ab. (G solvable)\n\n\nchar(K)=0, f \\in K[X] is sol. with rad. if ex. M/K rad. with all roots of f. 4.22\n\nf \\in K[X] sol.w.rad. \\Rightarrow Gal(f) quot.gr. of G s.t. (i)\n\nf \\in K[X] solv.w.rad. \\Leftrightarrow Gal(f) is solv. (not proved)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAdvanced Group Theory\n\nX a set, S(X) the set of bij. on X, S(X) is a gr. on \\circ, G operates on X if ex. \\Phi: G \\to S(X) hom.\n\nfor g \\in G, x \\in X write g \\cdot x = \\Phi(g)(x), also \\Phi(1)= id_X = 1 \\cdot x = id_X(x) = x\ng_1, g_2 \\in G, write g_1 g_2 \\cdot x = \\Phi(g_1 g_2)(x) = \\Phi(g_1)(\\Phi(g_2)(x)) = g_1 \\cdot (g_2 \\cdot x).\nWithin these two rules, \\cdot can be freely chosen (similarly to the \\lambda \\cdot v for a VS)\nGal(f) oper. on roots of f.\n\n\nG oper. on X, for x \\in X def:\n\nO_x = \\{g\\cdot x : g \\in G\\} \\subseteq X (orbit of x)\n\nX = \\bigsqcup_{x \\in R \\subseteq X} O_x\n\n\nG_x = \\{g \\in G : \\forall_{x \\in X} g \\cdot x = x\\} \\subseteq G (stabilisator of x)\n\nG_x subgr of G, 5.3\n\n\nfor |G| &lt; \\aleph_0, G oper. on G with g \\cdot x = gxg^{-1} 5.6.a\n\nO_x = \\{gxg^{-1} : g \\in G\\}\nG_x = \\{g \\in G: gx = xg\\}\nZ(G) := \\{g \\in G : \\forall_{x \\in G}g x = x g\\}\n\n(i) Z(X) \\trianglelefteq G, (ii) G ab. \\Leftrightarrow Z(G) = G, (iii) x \\in Z(G) \\Leftrightarrow G_x = G \\Leftrightarrow |O_x| = 1, (iv) |G| = |Z| + \\sum_{|O_x| &gt; 1}|O_x|\n\n\n\n\nG/G_x \\cong O_x (\\Leftrightarrow |G : G_x| = |O_x|), since gG_x \\mapsto g\\cdot x bij. 5.5\n\n|X| = \\sum_{O_x \\text{ disj.}}|O_x| = \\sum_{O_x\\text{ disj.}}|G /G_x|\n|G| = |G_X| + \\sum_{|O_x| &gt; 1} |O_x| Tut.12.1.a\nobv. G_x = G \\Leftrightarrow |O_x| = 1\n|G| =p^k, for p \\in \\mathbb{P}, k \\ge 1 then Z \\not = \\{1\\}\n\n\n\n\n|G| =p^2 \\Rightarrow G abel. 5.6.c\n|G| =p^r \\cdot m, \\lnot p | m, a syl.-p-subgr of G is U \\subseteq G s.t. |U| = p^r, i.e. max. p-subgr.\n|G| = p^r \\cdot m, \\lnot p |m, then for any 1 \\le s \\le r G has a subgr U_s s.t. |U_s| = p^s  (Syl.-I)\n\nfor p \\in \\mathbb{P}, p | |G| \\Rightarrow G has an elem. of order p. (Special Theorem of Cauchy)\n\n\n|G| = p^r \\cdot m, \\lnot p | m, \\forall_{s \\in [1, r]}\\exists_{g \\in G} g U_sg^{-1} \\subseteq U_r (Syl.-II)\n\nfor P, P&#039; syl.-p-subgr. then \\exists_{g \\in G} g P&#039;g^{-1} = P\nP the only syl.-p-subgr \\Leftrightarrow P \\trianglelefteq G, (i.e. \\exists_{g \\in G} gPg^{-1} = P).\n\n\ns_p |m and s_p \\equiv \\overline{1}^p (mod. p) (Syl. III)\n\n|G| =p^r \\cdot m, \\lnot p | m, s_p = |\\{P : syl.-p- subgr. of G\\}|\n\n\nMethod: prove there is no simple group of order n, tut.B.13.1\n\nSylow Subgruops: consider the factorisations of the from |G| =p^r \\cdot m, \\lnot p | m,\nSylow III: for each p, m found above determine possible s_p s.t. s_p |m and s_p \\equiv \\overline{1}^p.\nAbsurdum: assume for each p found in 1., assume s_p \\not =1 and get contradiction\nSylow II: since there is one p s.t. s_p = 1, then use P the only syl.-p-subgr \\Leftrightarrow P \\trianglelefteq G.\n\n\nN \\trianglelefteq G, H \\trianglelefteq N and H syl.subgr. of N, \\Rightarrow H \\trianglelefteq G, tut.B.13.2 (weaker transitivity)\nClassification of Groups of Small Order\n\nAbelian Groups\n\n(a) for A an ab.gr. s.t. |A| = p^k then ex.uniq. a partition l_0, ..., l_s, \\sum_{i = 0}^s l_i = k, 1 \\le l_0 \\le ... \\le l_s \\le k s.t. A \\cong \\mathbb{Z}/p^{l_0} \\mathbb{Z} \\oplus ... \\oplus \\mathbb{Z}/p^{l_s} \\mathbb{Z}.\n(b) for A an ab.gr. s.t. |A| = p \\cdot q, p \\not = q then A \\cong \\mathbb{Z}/p \\mathbb{Z} \\oplus \\mathbb{Z}/q \\mathbb{Z} \\cong \\mathbb{Z}/p\\cdot q \\mathbb{Z}.\n\n\nGroups through Generators and Relations\n\nG = \\langle \\alpha, \\beta | \\alpha^3 = 1 = \\beta^2, \\beta \\alpha = \\alpha^2\\beta \\rangle is the gr. generated by \\alpha, \\beta s.t. \\beta \\alpha = \\alpha^2 \\beta.\n\nQuestions are: (i) is one of the conditions redundant?
