(ii) is it a trivial gr.?\nG \\cong S_3 for \\alpha = (123), \\beta = (12)\n\n\nD_n = \\langle \\alpha, \\beta | \\alpha^n = 1 = \\beta^2, \\beta \\alpha = \\alpha^{-1}\\beta \\rangle (gr. of symm. of an n-sided reg. polygon)\n\nD_3 = \\langle \\alpha, \\beta | \\alpha^3 = 1 = \\beta^2, \\beta \\alpha = \\alpha^{-1}\\beta = \\alpha^2 \\beta \\rangle \\cong S_3\nmax. ord. of the first rotation \\alpha is \\frac{ord(D_n)}{2}\n\nfor ord(G) equal 6 or 10 this is enough, for 8 it might still be \\mathbb{Z}/(2) \\oplus \\mathbb{Z}/(4).\n\n\nthe reflection \\beta has ord. 2.\n\nthis information is not very helpful since there is such a \\beta in each possible group.\n\n\n\\beta \\alpha = \\alpha^{-1} \\beta\n\nthis shall be checked for ord(G) = 8.\nrecall D_n is not abelian\n\n\n\n\nQ = \\langle \\alpha, \\beta | \\alpha^4 = 1 \\beta^4, \\alpha^2 = \\beta^2, \\beta \\alpha = \\alpha^3 \\beta \\rangle, |Q| = 8\n\nQ = \\langle \\begin{smallmatrix} 0 &amp; 1 \\\\ -1 &amp; 0 \\end{smallmatrix}, \\begin{smallmatrix} 0 &amp; i \\\\ i &amp; 0 \\end{smallmatrix}\\rangle \\subseteq GL_2(\\mathbb{C})\nQ = \\{\\pm 1, \\pm i, \\pm j, \\pm k\\}, i^2 = j^2 = k^2 = -1, yt,\n\ni \\rightsquigarrow j \\rightsquigarrow k \\rightsquigarrow i to get + (i.e. ij = k snd inverse for -, i.e. i k = -j)\nfor \\alpha \\in \\{\\pm i , \\pm j, \\pm k\\}, \\langle \\alpha \\rangle = \\{1, \\alpha, -1, - \\alpha\\}.\n\n\n\n\np&gt;2 prime, |G| = 2p \\Rightarrow G \\cong \\mathbb{Z}/2p\\mathbb{Z} or G \\cong D_p. 5.19\nG not ab., |G| = 8 \\Rightarrow G \\cong Q \\lor F \\cong D_4 5.20\n\n\n\n\n\nSolvable Groups\n\nG sol. if ex. (G_i)_{i \\in [0, r]} s.t. (i) G_i \\subseteq G subgr., (ii) \\{e\\} = G_r \\trianglelefteq ... \\trianglelefteq G_1 \\trianglelefteq G_0 = G, (iii) G_i / G_{i + 1} ab.\n\nG ab. \\Rightarrow G sol. (G_0 = \\{e\\}, G_1 = G, G_0/G_1 \\cong G ab.)\n\n\nFor U \\subseteq G subgr., N \\trianglelefteq G, then: 5.23\n\nG sol. \\Rightarrow G/N sol.\nG sol. \\Rightarrow U sol.\nN, N/G sol. \\Rightarrow G sol.\n\n\n|G| = p^k \\cdot q^l \\Rightarrow G sol. (Burnside)\n\nwe only proved: |G| = p^k \\Rightarrow G sol. 5.24\n\n\n|G| = 2n + 1 \\Rightarrow G sol. (Feit-Thompson) (nor proved)\n\n\nSimple Groups\n\nG sim. if G \\not = H \\not = \\{e\\} \\Rightarrow H \\not \\trianglelefteq G  i.e. there‚Äôs no non-trivial norm.div. 5.25\n\n\\mathbb{Z}/p\\mathbb{Z} sim.\n\n\nA_5 sim. 5.26\n\nn \\ge 5 \\Rightarrow S_n not sol\nA_5 is smallest s.t. (i) not ab., (ii) sim.\n\n\n\n\n\nPolynomials with S_n as Galois Group\n\nGal(f) \\cong S_n for n \\ge 5 \\Rightarrow f not sol. with rad.\n\nsince Gal(f) permutes roots of f,  Gal(f) \\subseteq S_n subrgr.\nsince n \\ge 5, S_n not sol.\n\n\nfor n \\ge 2: 6.1\n\n(i) S_n = \\langle (12), (123...n)\\rangle\n(ii) if ex. H s.t. (iia) H \\subseteq S_n trans.subgr. and contains a transp. and (n -1)-cycle, then H = S_n\nfor 1 \\ge i, j \\ge n, i \\not = j ex. \\sigma \\in H s.t. \\sigma(i) = j then H trans subgr.\n\n\np \\in \\mathbb{P}, f \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X] irr. s.t. deg(f) = p and has exactly 2 not-real roots, then Gal(f) \\cong  S_p 6.2\nGal(X^{p^n} - X) = Gal(\\mathbb{F}_{p^n}/\\mathbb{F}_p) cycl.,\n\nif m | |Gal(f)|, ex. an elem. of order m.\n\nfor f \\in \\mathbb{F}_p[X] irr., \\exists_{\\sigma \\in Gal(f)} ord(\\sigma) = n\n\n\n|Gal(\\mathbb{F}_{p^n})| = n, \\mathbb{F}_{p^n} / \\mathbb{F}_p is simple and separable (since \\mathbb{F}_p is finite)\n\n\n\\mathbb{F}_{p^n}/\\mathbb{F}_p fin. sep., if \\mathbb{F}_{p^n} = \\mathbb{F}_p[\\alpha], f \\in \\mathbb{F}_p[X] is min. of \\alpha, so f irr. of deg. n.\n\n\\forall_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}}\\forall_{n \\ge 1} \\exists_{f \\in \\mathbb{F}_p[X]} f irr.\\land deg(f) = n.\n\n\nA fac.ring., \\mathfrak{p} \\subseteq A pr.ideal, \\overline{A} = A/\\mathfrak{p}, K = Q(A), k = Q(\\overline{A}). For f \\in A[X] primitive, let \\overline{f} \\in \\overline{A} be f mod(p), then: (i) \\overline{f} sep \\Rightarrow f sep., (ii) Gal(\\overline{f}) \\subseteq Gal(f) subgr. 6.4 (not proved)\n\\forall_{n \\ge 1} \\exists_{f \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X]} deg(f) = n \\land Gal(f) \\cong S_n\n\nExamples\nFor Galois Theory I decided to write down some of the examples too, I collect them here:\nGalois Examples\n\n(a). L = \\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt{p}), K = \\mathbb{Q}, since f = x^2 -p \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X] hence norm., char(\\mathbb{Q}) = 0 \\Rightarrow L/K sep. Also [L:K] = 2 \\Rightarrow |Gal(L/K)| = 2 \\Rightarrow Gal(L/K) \\cong \\mathbb{Z}_2, elem. in Gal(L/K) premute roots (\\pm \\sqrt{p}) of f, i.e. \\sqrt{p} \\mapsto \\sqrt{p} and \\sqrt{p} \\mapsto -\\sqrt{p} (uniq. def. by \\alphas)\n(b). f = (x^2 -2)(x^2 - 3) \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X] has zer. k√∂. \\mathbb{Q}[\\sqrt{2}, \\sqrt{3}] = L, [L:\\mathbb{Q}] = 4. L/K is gal., \\Rightarrow |Gal(L/\\mathbb{Q})| = [L: \\mathbb{Q}] = 4. Elements perm. roots, (22:33, 2-2:33, 22:3-3, 2-2:3-3), Gal(L/K) = \\{id, \\sigma, \\tau, \\sigma\\tau\\} \\cong \\mathbb{Z}_2 \\times \\mathbb{Z}_2.\n(c) f = x^3 -2 \\in \\mathbb{Q}[X], let \\omega s.t. \\omega^2 + \\omega + 1 = 0, roots of f is \\{\\sqrt[3]{2}, \\sqrt[3]{2}\\omega, \\sqrt[3]{2}\\omega^2\\}, L = \\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt[3]{2}, \\omega) is zer.k√∂. of f, [L: \\mathbb{Q}] = 6, Gal(L/\\mathbb{Q}) prem. the roots, hence Gal(L/\\mathbb{Q}) = S_3 (smallest non-abelian), gal. gr. must not be abelian. The extension between, [\\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt[3]{2}): \\mathbb{Q}] = 3, \\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt[3]{2} \\subset \\mathbb{R}, \\sigma(\\sqrt[3]{2}) \\in \\mathbb{R} hence \\sigma(\\sqrt[3]{2}) = \\sqrt[3]{2}, hence |Gal(\\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt[3]{2}) /\\mathbb{Q})| = 1 \\not = 3 = [\\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt[3]{2}): \\mathbb{Q}], hence it is not a gal. ext.\np \\in \\mathbb{P}, r, n \\in \\mathbb{N}\\setminus \\{0\\}, q = p^r, q\\ = p^{rn}, \\mathbb{F}_p \\subseteq \\mathbb{F}_q \\subseteq \\mathbb{F}_q&#039; \\subseteq \\overline{\\mathbb{F}_p} and \\mathbb{F}_q \\subseteq \\mathbb{F}_{q&#039;} sep. (\\Leftarrow finite), (norm. \\Leftarrow \\mathbb{F}_q&#039; zer.k√∂. for X^q - X \\in \\mathbb{F}_q[X]) \\Rightarrow |Gal(\\mathbb{F}_{q&#039;}/\\mathbb{F}_q)| = n, see script for conclusion.\n\nGalois Correspondence Examples\n\n(a) L = \\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt{2}, \\sqrt{3})/\\mathbb{Q} is gal. and Gal(L/\\mathbb{Q}) = \\{id, \\sigma, \\tau, \\sigma\\tau\\} as in Galois Examples (b). For the other examples, see the script.\n\nExample with \\zeta\n\nn = 12, \\zeta = \\sqrt[12]{u} prim. for u \\in \\mathbb{Q}^\\times, \\varphi(12) = \\varphi(3 \\cdot 2^2) = \\varphi(3)\\varphi(2^2) = 2 \\cdot 2 = 4. \\mathbb{Z}^\\times = \\{1, 5, 7, 11\\}, Gal(\\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)/\\mathbb{Q}) = \\{\\sigma_m : m \\in \\mathbb{Z}^\\times\\} =: G for \\sigma_m: \\zeta \\mapsto \\zeta^m. \\sigma_{11} = \\sigma_3 \\circ \\sigma_7. Also note G \\cong \\mathbb{Z}/(2) \\times \\mathbb{Z}/(2). Also \\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)/\\mathbb{Q} has three non trivial fields in between: \\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)^{\\langle \\sigma_5 \\rangle}, \\zeta^3 \\sqrt[4]{u} = \\pm i, hence \\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)^{\\langle \\sigma_5 \\rangle} = \\mathbb{Q}(i). The second field is: \\mathbb{Q}^{\\langle \\sigma_7 \\rangle}, \\zeta^2 = \\sqrt[6]{u} = \\frac{-1 \\pm \\sqrt{-3}}{2}, then \\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)^{\\langle \\sigma_7 \\rangle} = \\mathbb{\\sqrt{-3}}. \\mathbb{Q}(\\zeta)^{\\langle \\sigma_{11} \\rangle}, similarly \\mathbb{Q}^{\\langle \\sigma_11 \\rangle} = \\mathbb{Q}(\\sqrt{3}).\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Analysis-III-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Analysis-III-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Mathematics/Analysis III (Lecture).md","title":"Analysis III (Lecture)","links":["tags/3rd_Sem","tags/LMU","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Analysis-II-(Lecture)"],"tags":["3rd_Sem","LMU"],"content":"I followed this course by Prof. Leeb during my 3rd_Sem a the LMU. A considerable part of the following notes (and hence of the program of the course) are already present in Analysis II (Lecture), the approach of this lecture was more theoretical (topological).\nI. Measure Theory\nI.1 Measure Problem\nXX\nI.2 Measuring Volume with Finite Divisions\nI.2.1 Set-theoretic Rings and Algebras\n\nDef. a set-ring is \\mathcal{R} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X) s.t. it is an (alg.) sub-ring of (\\mathcal{P}(X), \\Delta, \\cap).\n\nfor A \\Delta B := \\{x \\in X : (x \\in A \\lor x \\in B) \\land \\lnot (x \\in A \\land x \\in B)\\}, \\chi_\\emptyset \\equiv 0 and \\chi_X \\equiv 1.\nfor \\mathcal{R} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(X): \\mathcal{R} is a ring \\Leftrightarrow \\emptyset \\in \\mathcal{R} \\land \\mathcal{R} is \\setminus-stable \\land \\mathcal{R} is \\cup-stable.\n\nA \\Delta B = (A \\setminus B) \\cup (B \\setminus A), A \\cap B = A \\setminus (A \\setminus B)\n\\forall_{A, B \\in \\mathcal{R}}A \\setminus B \\in \\mathcal{R} \\land A \\cap B \\in \\mathcal{R} \\land B \\setminus A \\in \\mathcal{R}\n\n\n\n\nDef. a set-alg. \\mathcal{A} is a set-ring s.t. 1_\\mathcal{A} \\in \\mathcal{A}.\n\n\\mathcal{A} is a set-alg. \\Leftrightarrow \\emptyset \\in \\mathcal{A} \\land \\mathcal{A} is \\cup-stable \\land \\mathcal{A} is \\cdot^C-stable\n\\forall_{A, B \\in \\mathcal{R}}A \\setminus B \\in \\mathcal{R} \\land A \\cap B \\in \\mathcal{R} \\land B \\setminus A \\in \\mathcal{R} \\land (A \\cup B)^C\n\n\nFor \\mathcal{E} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X), def. the set-ring  \\mathcal{R}_\\mathcal{E} = \\bigcap\\{\\mathcal{R} : \\mathcal{E} \\subseteq \\mathcal{R} \\land \\mathcal{R} is a ring\\} on X.\nDefine \\mathcal{F}_0 \\subseteq ... \\subseteq \\mathcal{F}_n \\subseteq ... \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X), for \\mathcal{F}_0:= \\mathcal{E} \\cup \\emptyset, \\mathcal{F}_n := \\{A \\setminus B, A \\cup B : A, B \\in \\mathcal{F}_{n-1}\\} \\supseteq \\mathcal{F}_{n -1};  \\bigcup_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\mathcal{F}_n.\n\n\\mathcal{R}_\\mathcal{E} is the smallest ring containing \\mathcal{E}. Q\n\n\nDef. \\mathcal{H} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X) halfr. if (i) \\emptyset \\in \\mathcal{H}, (ii) \\mathcal{H} is \\mathcal{H}-st., (iii) \\forall_{A, B \\in \\mathcal{H}} \\exists_{C_1, ..., C_n \\in \\mathcal{H}} A \\setminus B = C_1 \\sqcup ... \\sqcup C_n.\n\n\\mathcal{R} is an hafr.\nPrincipal Exampe, (PE) \\mathcal{I} = \\{[a, b) : a \\le b \\land a, b \\in \\mathbb{R}\\} is halfr. on \\mathbb{R}.\n(Simultane Zerlegung) \\forall_{H_1, ..., H_n \\in \\mathcal{H}} \\exists_{H_1&#039;, ..., H_n&#039; \\in \\mathcal{H}} H_i = H_j&#039;, ..., H_{j&#039;}&#039;\n\\mathcal{R}(\\mathcal{H}) def. Q\n\n\nProducts\n\n\\mathcal{F}_1 *...* \\mathcal{F}_n : = \\{M_1 \\times ... \\times M_n: \\forall_{i \\le n} M_i \\in \\mathcal{F}_i\\} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X_1 \\times ... \\times X_n), \\cup-st. cover. for \\mathcal{F}_i \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X),\n\nsquares\n\n\n\\mathcal{F}_1 \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mathcal{F}_n := \\{finite union of subsets of \\mathcal{F}_1 *...*\\mathcal{F}_n\\}\n\nunion of squares\n\n\n\\mathcal{Z}(\\mathcal{F}_1, ..., \\mathcal{F}_n) := \\{\\pi_k^{-1}(M_k) : M_k \\in \\mathcal{F}_k, 1 \\le k \\le n\\} where \\pi_k^{-1}: X_1 \\times ... \\times X_n \\rightarrow X_k is a proj.\n\nCylinder\n\n\n\\mathcal{H}_1 *...* \\mathcal{H}_n is an halfr. on X_1 \\times ... \\times X_n, (prod. of halfr.)\n\\mathcal{H}_1 \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mathcal{H}_n = \\mathcal{R}(\\mathcal{H}_1) \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mathcal{R}(\\mathcal{H}_n)\n(PE) [a, b) : = [a_1, b_1) \\times ... \\times [a_d, b_d) elem. of Q^d = \\mathcal{I} * ....* \\mathcal{I} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(\\mathbb{R}^d) halfr., \\mathcal{R}(Q^d) = \\mathcal{F}^d : = \\mathcal{I} \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mathcal{I} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(\\mathbb{R}^d) (figures).\n\n(Zerl. Lemma) every figure is a disj. union of finitely many squares\nAny finite union of squares is also a figure\n\n\n\n\n\nI.2.2 Content\n\n\\mu: \\mathcal{H} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] s.t. (i) \\mu(\\emptyset) = 0, (ii) \\mu(A_1 \\sqcup ... \\sqcup A_n) = \\mu(A_1) + ...  + \\mu(A_n) \\land A_1 \\sqcup ... \\sqcup A_n \\in \\mathcal{H} (cont.)\n(PE) \\lambda_\\mathcal{I}: Q^1 \\rightarrow [0, \\infty), [a, b) \\mapsto b-a (euclidian lenght)\n\\forall_{A, B \\in \\mathcal{H}} A \\subseteq B \\rightarrow \\mu(A) \\le \\mu(B) (monotony)\n\\forall_{A_1, ..., A_n \\in \\mathcal{H}} \\mu(A_1 \\cup ... \\cup A_n) \\le \\mu(A_1) + ... + \\mu(A_n) (subadditivity)\nFor \\mu: \\mathcal{H} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] ex. uniq. \\overline{\\mu}: \\mathcal{R}(\\mathcal{H}) \\rightarrow [0, \\infty].\n\nHow to extend the content? Q\n\n\n(PE) \\lambda^1_{Q_1}: Q^1 \\longrightarrow [0, \\infty], [a, b) \\mapsto b-a extends to \\lambda^1_{\\mathcal{F}^1}: \\mathcal{F}^1 \\longrightarrow [0, \\infty].\nProducts\n\nIf (\\mu_1 \\times ... \\times \\mu_n)(\\mathcal{H}_1 \\times ... \\times \\mathcal{H}_n) = \\mu_1(H_1) \\cdot ... \\cdot \\mu_n(H_n), \\mu_1 \\times ... \\times \\mu_n cont. \\mathcal{H}_1 * ... * \\mathcal{H}_n\n\nconvention: 0 \\cdot \\infty = 0\n\n\n(PE)  \\lambda^d_{Q^d} := \\lambda^1_{Q^1} \\times ... \\times \\lambda^1_{Q^1} (d-times) on Q^d = Q^1 * ... * Q^1 \\subset \\mathcal{P}(\\mathbb{R}^d)\n\\mu_1 \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mu_n uniq. cont. on \\mathcal{R}_1 \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mathcal{R}_n \\subset \\mathcal{P}(X_1 \\times ... \\times X_n) s.t.:\n\n(\\mu_1 \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mu_n)(M_1 \\times ... \\times M_n) = \\mu_1(M_1) \\cdot ... \\cdot \\mu_n(M_n),\n\nrecall: (M_1 \\times ... \\times M_n) \\in \\mathcal{R}_1 * ... * \\mathcal{R}_n for M_i \\in \\mathcal{R}_i\n\n\n\n\n(PE) \\lambda^d_{\\mathcal{F}^d} is unique\n\n\n\nI.3 Measuring Volume with Countable Divisions\nI.3.1 Pre-measures\n\ndef. Q\nA_n \\nearrow A := \\bigcup_{n = 1}^\\infty A_n = A for (A_i)_{i \\in [1, n]} a \\subseteq-chain (inside approximation), similarly A_n \\swarrow A.\nlet A_n \\nearrow A \\land A&#039;_n \\swarrow A then \\lim_{n \\rightarrow \\infty} \\mu(A_n) \\le \\mu(A) \\le \\lim_{n \\rightarrow \\infty} \\mu(A&#039;_n).\nProducts\n\n\\mu_1 \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mu_n pmeas.\n\n\n\nI.3.2 \\sigma-Algebras\n\n\\mathcal{A} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(X) is \\sigma-al. if: (i) \\emptyset \\in \\mathcal{A}, (ii) (A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{A} \\Rightarrow \\bigcup_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} A_n \\in \\mathcal{A} (\\sigma-\\cup-st.), (iii) \\cdot^C-st.\n\neq. to: (i)* X \\in \\mathcal{A}, (ii)* (A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{A} \\Rightarrow \\bigcap_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} A_n \\in \\mathcal{A} (\\sigma-\\cap-st.), (iii) \\cdot^C-st.\n\n\nBy transf. ind. define \\sigma(\\mathcal{E}):= \\mathcal{E}_{\\omega_1}:\n\nfor A \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X), A^\\vartheta := Q\n\\mathcal{E}_0 := \\mathcal{E} \\cup \\{\\emptyset\\}\n\\mathcal{E}_n := \\mathcal{E}_{n-1}^\\vartheta\n\\mathcal{E}_\\lambda := (\\bigcup_{n &lt; \\lambda} \\mathcal{E}_n)^\\vartheta for \\lambda limit ordinal\n\n\nTopological Origin\n\n\\mathcal{B}(X) := \\sigma(\\mathcal{T}) for (X, \\mathcal{T}) top. sp.\n\n(PE) \\mathcal{B}^d := \\mathcal{B}(\\mathbb{R}^d)\n\n\\mathcal{B}^d = \\sigma(A) for any of the following options\n\nA are open subsets of X, i.e. the topology.\nA are the closed subsets of X.\nA are the compact subsets of X.\nA are the open metrical balls\nA are the closed metrical balls\nA are the open rectangles\nA are the half-open rectangles, i.e. Q^d\n\n\n\\mathcal{B}^d = \\sigma(Q^d)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDynkin Systems\n\n\\mathcal{D} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X) is dyn. if (i) \\emptyset \\in \\mathcal{D}, (ii)(A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{D} \\Rightarrow \\bigsqcup_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} A_n \\in \\mathcal{D}, (iii) is \\cdot^C-st.\n\\mathcal{A} is dyn. and if \\mathcal{D} is \\cap-st. it is \\sigma-al.\n\\forall_{D_1, D_2 \\in \\mathcal{D}} D_1 \\subseteq D_2 \\rightarrow D_2 \\setminus D_1 \\in \\mathcal{D}\n\\mathcal{D}|_D : = \\{M \\subset D |M \\in \\mathcal{D}\\} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(D) (Spur) is dyn on D.\n\\mathcal{D}_D := \\{M \\subset X | M \\cap D \\in \\mathcal{D}\\} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(X) is dyn on X.\n\\mathcal{E} \\cap-st., \\mathcal{D}(\\mathcal{E}) is \\sigma-al.\n\n\nThe Measurable Category\n\nXX\n\n\nProducts\n\n\\mathcal{A}_1 \\otimes ... \\otimes \\mathcal{A}_n = \\sigma(Z(\\mathcal{A}_1, ..., \\mathcal{A}_n)) Q\n\nZ(\\mathcal{A}_1, ..., \\mathcal{A}_n) = \\{\\pi^{-1}_k (M_k) | M_k \\in \\mathcal{A}_k \\land k \\in [1, n]\\}\n\n\n\n\n\nI.3.3 Measures\n\n\\mu: \\mathcal{A} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] is a meas.\n\neq. \\mu: \\mathcal{A} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] a meas. on \\mathcal{A} if (i) \\mu(\\emptyset) = 0, (ii) \\mu(\\bigsqcup_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}A_n) = \\sum_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}\\mu(A_n)\n\n\nExternal Measures\n\n\\mu^*(M) : = inf\\{\\sum^\\infty_{n=1}\\mu(A_n):(A_n)_{n\\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{H} \\land \\bigcup^\\infty_{n=1}A_n \\supseteq M\\} for \\mu cont.\n\nif empty \\mu^*(M) = inf(\\emptyset) = \\infty\nit is enough to look at the p.disj. (A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}.\n\\overline{\\mu^*} = \\mu^*\n\n\n\\mu^*: \\mathcal{P}(X) \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] ext. meas iff\n\n\\mu^*(\\emptyset) = 0\n\\forall_{M, M&#039; \\subseteq X} M \\subseteq M&#039; \\rightarrow \\mu^*(M) \\le \\mu^*(M&#039;) (monotony)\n(M_n)_{n \\in\\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X), \\mu^*(\\bigcup^\\infty_{n = 1} M_n) = \\sum^\\infty_{n = 1} \\mu^*(M_n) (\\sigma-subadditivity)\n\n\nSimilarly define the internal measure, \\mu_*\n\n\nMotivation\n\n\\mu^*(M) -\\mu_*(M) = \\mu^*(M) +\\mu^*(R-M)-\\mu^*(R) \\ge 0, bound. R of a fuzzy shape M (discr.)\ncall M meas. if \\forall_{S \\subset X}\\mu^*(S) = \\mu^*(S \\cap M) + \\mu^*(S \\cap M^C).\n\\mu^*(N) = 0 (nullset)\n\n\nExtensions of Pre-measures to Measures\n\n(Carath√©odory, 1914) \\mathcal{A}^*, \\mu^*|_{\\mathcal{A}^*} are resp. a \\sigma-al. and a meas. Q\n\n\\mathcal{A}^* := \\{M \\subseteq X : M is \\mu^*-meas\\}.\n(i) \\sigma(\\mathcal{R}) \\subseteq \\mathcal{A}^*\n(ii) \\mu^*|_{\\sigma(\\mathcal{R})} is a meas.\n\n(i), (ii) \\Rightarrow \\mu^*|_\\mathcal{R} prem., also \\mu^*|_\\mathcal{R} \\le \\mu (recall dom(\\mu) = \\mathcal{R})\n\n\n\\mathcal{H} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X), \\mu: \\mathcal{H} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] meas., then \\mu is finite if \\mu(X) &lt; \\infty (finite)\n\n\n\\mathcal{H} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X), \\mu: \\mathcal{H} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] meas., it is \\sigma-fin. if ex (H_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} s.t. \\forall_{x \\in X} \\exists_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} x \\in H_n \\land \\mu(H_n) &lt; \\infty\n(Extension Theorem):\n\n(Existence) \\mu: \\mathcal{R} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] a prem., it def. a meas. \\mu^* on \\sigma(\\mathcal{R}).\n(Maximality of  \\mu^*|_\\mathcal{R}) for any meas. \\nu s.t. \\nu|_{\\mathcal{R}} = \\mu, \\nu \\le \\mu^*|_\\mathcal{R}\n(Weak Uniq.) \\mu: \\mathcal{R} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] \\sigma-fin. prem., then there is a uniq. ext to a meas. \\sigma(\\mathcal{R})\n\n(PE) \\lambda^d := (\\lambda^d_{\\mathcal{F}^d})^*\n\n\n\n\n\n\nApproximation of Subsets\n\nM is \\mu^*-meas. \\Leftrightarrow \\mu^*(\\partial M) = 0 \\Leftrightarrow \\mu^*(I) = \\mu^*(A)\n\nI:= M - \\partial M\nA:= \\bigcap^\\infty_{n = 1} A_{\\frac{1}{n}} \\in \\sigma(\\mathcal{R}), for \\forall_{\\epsilon &gt; 0} \\exists_{A_\\epsilon \\in \\sigma(\\mathcal{R})} (M \\subset A_\\epsilon \\land \\mu^*(A_\\epsilon) &lt; \\mu^*(M) + \\epsilon\n\n\n\\mu is \\sigma-fin. \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{A}^* \\subseteq \\{\\alpha : \\alpha = \\beta_1 \\cup ... \\cup \\beta_n \\cup \\gamma_1 \\cup ... \\cup \\gamma_m \\land \\forall_{i \\in [1, max(n, m)]}\\beta_i \\in \\sigma(\\mathcal{R}) \\land \\mu^*(\\gamma_i) = 0\\}.\n\\mu is compl. if all \\mu-nullsets are in \\mathcal{A}.\n\n\\mathcal{N}:= \\{N \\subseteq X : \\exists_{N_\\nu \\in \\mathcal{A}} N \\subseteq N_\\nu \\land \\nu(N_\\nu) = 0\\}\n\n\n\\tilde{\\mathcal{A}} := \\{A \\cup N: A \\in \\mathcal{A} \\land N \\in \\mathcal{N}\\} = \\{\\tilde{A} \\subset X : \\exists_{A&#039; \\in \\mathcal{A}} \\tilde{A} \\Delta A&#039; \\in \\mathcal{N}\\} \\subseteq \\mathcal{A}\n\n\\tilde{\\mathcal{A}} is a \\sigma-al. and ex a uniq. ext \\tilde{\\mu}.\n\n\n\n\nMore on the Measurable Category\n\nPushforward (Wiki): for f: X_1 \\rightarrow X_2 meas., (X_1, \\mathcal{A}_1), (X_2, \\mathcal{A}_2) meas. sp. and \\mu: \\mathcal{A}_1 \\rightarrow [0, \\infty] then the pushf. is the meas f_*(\\mu): \\mathcal{A}_2 \\rightarrow [0, \\infty], A_2 \\mapsto \\mu(f^{-1}(A_2)).\n\n\nProduct Measure\n\nfor (X_i, \\mathcal{A}_i, \\mu_i)_{i \\in [1, n]}, recall \\mathcal{A}_1 \\otimes ... \\otimes \\mathcal{A}_n \\subseteq \\mathcal{A}_1 \\boxtimes ... \\boxtimes \\mathcal{A}_1 \\subseteq \\mathcal{A}_1 * ... * \\mathcal{A}_n \\subseteq Z(\\mathcal{A}_1, ..., \\mathcal{A}_n).\n\n\\mathcal{A}_1 \\otimes ... \\otimes \\mathcal{A}_n is the \\sigma-al., the other are equivalent generators.\n\n\ndef. for (X_i, \\mathcal{A}_i, \\mu_i)_{i \\in [1, n]} \\sigma-fin. then \\mu_1 \\otimes ... \\otimes \\mu_n is the product measure and (X \\times ... \\times X, \\mathcal{A}_1 \\otimes ... \\otimes \\mathcal{A}_n, \\mu_1 \\otimes ... \\otimes \\mu_n)\n\n\n\nI.3.4 Lebesgue Measure\n\nTopological Approximation of Measurable Sets\n\nXX\n\n\nInvariances and Behave under Affine Functions\n\nfor \\phi: \\mathbb{R}^d \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^d aff \\phi^*(\\lambda^d) = |\\frac{1}{det(A)}|\\cdot \\lambda^d\n\n\n\nII. Integration Theory\nII.1 Integration &amp; Numeral Functions\n\na num.f, is f: X \\rightarrow \\overline{\\mathbb{R}} for X a set s.t. (X, \\mathcal{A}) meas.sp. and \\overline{\\mathbb{R}}:= \\{- \\infty, \\infty\\} \\cup \\mathbb{R}.\n\n\\overline{\\mathcal{B}} := \\mathcal{B}(\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}) is a \\sigma-al. generated by:\n\n\\{[-\\infty, a) : a \\in \\mathbb{R}\\}, also for (-\\infty, a],[- \\infty, a]\n\n\nf: X \\rightarrow \\overline{\\mathbb{R}} num is meas. \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{a \\in \\mathbb{R}}\\{f \\le a\\}\n\n\\{f \\le a\\} := f^{-1}([-\\infty, a]) \\in \\mathcal{A}\n\\mathcal{M}_\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}(X, \\mathcal{A}) are the meas.num.f. on (X, \\mathcal{A})\n\nclosed under sup, limsup.\n\n\n\\mathcal{M}_\\mathbb{R}(X, \\mathcal{A}) are the meas.num.f. on (X, \\mathcal{A}) s.t. im(f) = \\mathbb{R}\n\\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}) are the meas.num.f. on (X, \\mathcal{A}) s.t. im(f) =[0, \\infty]\n\n\n\n\nApproximation trough Step Funcitons\n\nfor f step.f. f meas. \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{i \\in I} c_i meas. i.e. each level is meas.\n\n\\Rightarrow \\mathcal{T}_\\mathbb{R} = \\mathcal{T}_{\\mathbb{R}}(X, \\mathcal{A}):= meas.step.f. s.t. im(f) = \\mathbb{R}\n\\Rightarrow \\mathcal{T}_{[0, \\infty]} = \\mathcal{T}_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}):= meas.step.f. s.t. im(f) = {[0, \\infty]}\n\n\nany f \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]} is a monotone limit of t_n \\subseteq \\mathcal{T}_{[0, \\infty]}: t_n \\nearrow f\n\n\nRegions below Graphs\n\nfor f: X \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}, f \\in \\mathcal{M}_\\overline{\\mathbb{R}} \\Leftrightarrow \\{(x, y) \\in X \\times \\mathbb{R}: y \\le f(x)\\} \\in \\mathcal{A} \\otimes \\mathcal{B}^1 (prod.\\sigma-al. of X \\times \\mathbb{R})\nf_1, f_2 \\in \\mathcal{M}_{\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}} \\Rightarrow (f_1, f_2)^{-1}(A_1 \\times A_2) := f_1^{-1}(A_1) \\cap f_2^{-1}(A_2) \\in \\mathcal{A}\n\nf_1 + f_2 (pointwise) is uniq. and meas. (addition)\nQ (moltiplication)\n\n\n\n\n\nII.2 Lebesgue Integral\n\nf: X \\rightarrow \\overline{\\mathbb{R}}, prod.meas. is \\mu \\otimes \\beta^1 = (\\mu \\boxtimes \\mathcal{B}^1)^*|_{\\mathcal{A} \\otimes \\mathcal{B}^1}\n\nII.2.1 Integral for Non-negative Functions\n\nthe Integral I: \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}) \\rightarrow [0, \\infty], f \\mapsto \\int_X f d \\mu := (\\mu \\otimes \\beta^1)(\\{(x, y) \\in X \\times \\mathbb{R}: 0 &lt; y &lt; f(x)\\})\n\nf \\le g \\Rightarrow \\int_X f d\\mu \\le \\int_X g d \\mu (monotony of \\mu \\otimes \\beta^1)\nf_n \\nearrow f \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}) \\Rightarrow \\int_X f_n d \\mu \\nearrow \\int_X f d \\mu (monotone convergence, B. Levi)\n\n\nfor (f_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq M_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}), then \\int \\lim_{n \\rightarrow \\infty}\\inf f_n d\\mu \\le \\lim_{n \\rightarrow \\infty} \\inf \\int_{X}f_n d\\mu (Fatou‚Äôs lemma)\nLinearity &amp; Homogenity\n\n\\int_X \\chi_A d \\mu = \\mu(A)\n\\int_X t d \\mu = \\sum_{i = 1}^n \\mu(A_i)a_i for t = \\sum^n_{i = 1} a_i \\chi_{A_i}, \\forall_{i \\in [1, n]}A_i \\in \\mathcal{A}, also if A_i are not disj.\nany f_+, f_- \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}) can be approximated by some t_{+,n}, t_{-,n}.\nI has monotony, is additive and pos. homogene.\n\n\n\nII.2.2 Integral on Measurable Functions\n\nfor f \\in \\mathcal{M}_\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}(X, \\mathcal{A}), is \\mu-int. \\Leftrightarrow\\int_X |f| d \\mu &lt; \\infty \\Leftrightarrow \\int_x f_\\pm d \\mu &lt; \\infty\n\n|\\int_X f d \\mu| \\le \\int_X |f| d \\mu\n\n\nf=g alm.ever. if \\mu(\\{x: f(x) \\not = g(x)\\}) = 0\n\nf = g alm. ever. \\Rightarrow \\int_X f d \\mu = \\int_X g d \\mu\nf \\in \\mathcal{M}_\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}(X, \\mathcal{A}) is \\mu-int. in A (\\in \\mathcal{A}) if \\chi_A \\cdot f is \\mu-int.\n\n\n\\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{R}^1 \\subsetneq \\mathcal{L}_{\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}}^1 is te VS of meas. func.\n\nf_1, f_2 \\in \\mathcal{L}^1 \\Rightarrow f_1 + f_2 \\in \\mathcal{L}^1 (additivity)\nf_1, f_2 \\in \\mathcal{L}^1 \\land f_1 \\le f_2 \\Rightarrow \\int_X f_1 d \\mu \\le\\int_X f_2 d \\mu (monotony)\n\n\nGemetrical Structure of \\mathcal{L}^1\n\nthe functional || \\cdot ||_1 : \\mathcal{L}^1(X, \\mathcal{A},\\mu) \\rightarrow [0, \\infty), f \\mapsto \\int_X |f| d\\mu is a halfnorm\n|f + g | \\le |f| + |g| \\Rightarrow ||f + g||_1 \\le ||f||_1 + ||g||_1 (triangle inequality)\n|\\int_X f d \\mu \\le ||f||_1\nhence \\mathcal{L}^1 is:\n\n\\mathbb{R}-linear\nmonoton\nLipzisch cont. for || \\cdot ||_1\n\n\nf = g alm.ever. \\Leftrightarrow ||f - g||_1 = 0\n\\{f \\in\\mathcal{L}^1: ||f||_1 = 0\\} is a subVS of \\mathcal{L}^1, because of the triangle-ineq.\n\n\n\nII.2.3 Convergence Theorems\n\nf_n \\rightarrow^{L^1} f \\Leftrightarrow ||f_n - f||_1 \\rightarrow 0\n\nf_n \\rightarrow^{L^1}f \\Leftrightarrow \\int_x |f_n - f| d \\mu \\rightarrow 0 \\Rightarrow \\int_x f _n d \\mu \\rightarrow \\int_X f d \\mu \\Leftrightarrow \\int_X (f_n - f) d \\mu \\rightarrow 0\n\n\n(f_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{M}_{\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}}, f \\in\\mathcal{M}_\\overline{\\mathbb{R}} s.t. f_n \\rightarrow f \\mu-alm.ever., then (i) ex. g \\in \\mathcal{L}^1_{[0, \\infty]} s.t. |f_n| \\le g alm.ever., (ii) f_n, f \\in \\mathcal{L}^1_\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}, (iii) f_n \\rightarrow^{L_1} f, (iv) \\int_X f_n d \\mu \\rightarrow \\int_X f d \\mu (majorant covergence, Lebesgue)\nany Causchy-seq. (f_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{L}^1_{\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}}, f \\in \\mathcal{L}^1 s.t. (f_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\rightarrow^{L_1} f, then ex. a subseq. (f_{n_k})_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} s.t. f_{n_k} \\rightarrow f pointwise \\mu-alm.ever. (inverse direction)\n(\\mathcal{L}^1(X, \\mathcal{A}, \\mu), || \\cdot ||_1) is complete, hence a Banach Space (Riesz-Fischer for L_1) Q\n\nII.2.4 Integration over Products\n\nrecall: (\\mu_1 \\otimes \\mu_2) (A_1 \\times A_2) = \\mu_1(A_1) \\cdot \\mu_2(A_2)\nIf M \\in \\mathcal{A}_1 \\otimes \\mathcal{A}_2, then \\forall_{x_1 \\in X_1}M_{x_1} \\in \\mathcal{A}_2 and the num.f. X_1 \\rightarrow [0, \\infty], x_1 \\mapsto \\mu_2(M_{x_1})] is meas. (i.e. is in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}_1) and (\\mu_1 \\otimes \\mu_2)(M) = \\int_{X_1} \\mu_2(M_{X_1})d\\mu_1(x_1)).\n\n\\{x_1\\} \\times M_{x_1} := M \\cup (\\{x_1\\} \\times X_2)\n\n\nQ (Cavalieri Principle)\nf \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0 , \\infty]}(X_1 \\times X_2, \\mathcal{A}_1 \\otimes \\mathcal{A}_2), then (i) x_1 \\mapsto \\int_{X_2} f(x_1, \\cdot) d \\mu_2 \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(X_1, \\mathcal{A}_1), i.e. is meas., (ii) \\int_{X_1 \\times X_2} f d(\\mu_1 \\otimes \\mu_2) = \\int_{X_1} (\\int_{X_2} f(x_1, \\cdot) d \\mu_2) d\\mu_1(x_1) (Fubini)\nf \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0 , \\infty]}(X_1 \\times X_2, \\mathcal{A}_1 \\otimes \\mathcal{A}_2) \\Leftrightarrow x_1 \\mapsto \\int_{X_2} f(x_1, \\cdot) d \\mu_2 is \\mu_2-int. \\Rightarrow f(x_1, \\cdot) is \\mu_2-int. for x_1 \\in X \\mu_1-alm.ever.\n\nII.2.5 Transformation of Measures and Integrals\n\nTransformation of Integrals under meas. Functions\n\nfor \\varphi: (X, \\mathcal{A}) \\rightarrow (Y, \\mathcal{B}) meas., define \\varphi: (X, \\mathcal{A}) \\rightarrow (Y, \\mathcal{B}) (pullback)\n(\\mathcal{A} \\rightarrow^\\mu [0, \\infty]) \\mapsto (\\varphi_{* \\mu}: \\mathcal{B} \\rightarrow [0, \\infty], M \\mapsto \\mu(\\varphi^{-1}(M)) ( = \\varphi_{* \\mu}(M)) (trans. forward of e meas)\n(Transformation formulae for integrals under meas. functions)\n\n(i) for f \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(Y, \\mathcal{B}) holds \\int_Y f d(\\varphi_{* \\mu}) = \\int_X(f \\circ \\varphi) d \\mu.\n(ii) for f \\in \\mathcal{M}_{\\bar{\\mathbb{R}}}(Y, \\mathcal{B}), then f is \\varphi_* \\mu-int. \\Leftrightarrow f \\circ \\varphi \\mu-int\n\nhence \\int_Y f d(\\varphi_{*} \\mu) = \\int_X(f \\circ \\varphi) d \\mu\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTransformation of the Lebesgue Measure under Diffeomorphims\n\nrecall: for \\varphi_{A, r} aff. \\varphi_{A, r}: \\mathbb{R}^d \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^d, x \\mapsto Ax + r, then (\\varphi_{A, r})_* \\beta^d = |det A|^{-1} \\beta^d\nfor C^1-diffeo. \\varphi: U \\rightarrow V op. subset of \\mathbb{R}^d, holds \\varphi_*(\\beta^d|_U) = |det(d(\\varphi^{-1}))| \\cdot \\beta^d|_V.\nfor \\varphi a C^1-diffeo. \\varphi: U \\rightarrow V op. subset of \\mathbb{R}^d, contain Borel-Nullsets and is Lebesgue-meas. Also \\varphi_*(\\lambda^d|_U) = |det(d(\\varphi^{-1}))| \\cdot \\lambda^d|_V\n\n\nTransformation of Integrals under Diffeomorphisims\n\nfor \\varphi a C^1-diffeo. \\varphi: U \\rightarrow V op. subset of \\mathbb{R}^d: (Transf. for integrals under diffeos)\n\nfor f\\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(V, \\mathcal{B}(V)):\n\n(i) \\int_V f d \\lambda^d = \\int_U (f \\circ \\varphi) \\cdot |det(d(\\varphi))| d \\lambda^d\n\n\nfor f \\in \\mathcal{M}_{\\bar{\\mathbb{R}}}(V, \\mathcal{B}(V)):\n\n(i)\n(ii) f is \\lambda^d-int. \\Leftrightarrow (f \\circ \\varphi) \\cdot det(d(\\varphi))| is \\lambda^d-int.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIII. Manifolds, Differential Forms and Stokes‚Äô Theorem\nMost of the materialis covered by Youtube: Bright Side, I take notes on these topics here: make the link.\nIII.1 Differentiable Manifolds\n\nM \\subseteq \\mathbb{R}^n is m-dim (for m \\le n) \\mathcal{C}^{k}-submnf. \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{p \\in M} \\exists_{\\varphi: U \\rightarrow V} \\varphi(M \\cap U) = (\\mathbb{R}^m \\times \\{0\\}) \\cap V\n\n\\mathbb{R}^m \\times \\{0\\} \\cong\\mathbb{R}^m\n\\varphi is the extr.ch. for M in p, k := \\varphi|_{M \\cap U} is the intr.ch. in p\n\n\nTransfer Chart\n\nextr.ch. \\varphi_2 \\circ \\varphi_1^{-1}: \\varphi_1(U_1 \\cap U_2) \\rightarrow \\varphi_2(U_1 \\cap U_2), \\mathcal{C}^k-diffeo.\nintr.ch. k_2 \\circ k_1^{-1}: k_1(M \\cap U_1 \\cap U_2) \\rightarrow k_2(M \\cap U_1 \\cap U_2), \\mathcal{C}^k-diffeo.\n\nintr.ch \\mathcal{C}^k-compatible if such a mapping ex.: it is possible to der. on M intrisically\n\n\na top.sp. X is m-dim. loc.euc. if locally isom, to \\mathbb{R}^m, i.e. each open ball is hom. to a subset of \\mathbb{R}^m.\n\n\nFurhter Structure\n\nan Atlas for X loc.euc. is \\mathcal{A} \\subseteq map(U_i, k_i)_{i \\in I} s.t. X = \\bigcup_{i \\in I}U_i.\n\n\\mathcal{A} is \\mathcal{C}^k-diff. (or \\mathcal{C}^k-atl.) if its charts are pairw. \\mathcal{C}^k-compatible.\neach \\mathcal{A} \\mathcal{C}^k-atl. has a unique max.\\mathcal{C}^k-atl. \\mathcal{A}&#039; s.t. \\mathcal{A} \\subseteq \\mathcal{A}&#039;.\n\n\nF: X \\to Y cont. is said diff. if for k, k&#039; charts on p, k^{-1} \\circ F \\circ k&#039;: k(X) \\to k&#039;(X) is diff.\na m-top.man. is m-dim. loc.euc. Haus.sp. with count. basis\na m-dim \\mathcal{C}^{k}-diff.man. is a m-dim.top.man. with \\mathcal{C}^k-diff.struct.\n\na \\mathcal{C}^k-diff.struc. on a loc.euc.sp. is a max.\\mathcal{C}^k-atl.\n\n\nfor N^n a \\mathcal{C}^k-mnf, M^m \\subseteq N^n is \\mathcal{C}^k-submnf. of N if for any p \\in M ex. k_p: U \\to V (U \\subseteq N, V\\subseteq \\mathbb{R}^n) s.t. k_p(M \\cap U) = (\\mathbb{R}^m \\times 0) \\cap V an m-dim. \\mathcal{C}^k-submnf. of \\mathbb{R}^m.\n\n\\forall_{p \\in M}\\exists_{k_p \\in ch(U, k_p)}p \\in dom(k_p) \\land k(M \\cap U) =  (\\mathbb{R}^m \\times 0) \\cap V (Bright)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIII.2 Manifolds with Boundaries\n\nM \\subseteq \\Omega man. for \\Omega op., then M has \\mathcal{C}^k-bound. \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{p \\in \\partial \\Omega} \\exists_{k \\in ch(U, k)} K(\\Omega \\cap U) = H^m \\cap k(U) Q\n\nf: U \\to \\mathbb{R}^m \\in \\mathcal{C}^\\infty, U \\subseteq \\mathbb{R}^n  Q (Regular Value Theorem) Bright\n\n\n\nIII.3\nIII.4 1-from and Cotangentbundle\n\nM^m a \\mathcal{C}^k-mnf, def. df|_U = \\sum_{i = 1}^m (\\frac{\\partial(f \\circ x^{-1})}{\\partial x_i} \\circ x) dx_i =: \\sum_{i = 1}^m \\frac{\\partial f}{\\partial x_i}dx_i (func. on U \\subset M)\nT^*_pM := (T_pM)^*, i.e. cotang.sp. is dualsp. of tang.sp.\nT^*U = \\bigsqcup_{p \\in U} T^*_p M, T^*x: T^*U \\to x(U) \\times \\mathbb{R}^m, \\sum^m_{i = 1}a_i(dx_i)_p \\mapsto (x(p), \\sum_{i = 1}^m a_i e_i), a = \\sum_{i = 1}^m a_i e_i\nd \\tilde{x_j} = \\sum_{i = 1}^m (\\frac{\\partial(\\tilde{x_j} \\circ x^{-1})}{\\partial x_i} \\circ x) dx_i =: \\sum_{i = 1}^m \\frac{\\partial\\tilde{x_j}}{\\partial x_i} dx_i (change of basis)\n\\sum^m_{j = 1} \\tilde{a_j} d \\tilde{x_j} = \\sum_{i = 1}^m (\\sum_{j = 1}^m \\tilde{a_j} (\\frac{\\partial \\tilde{x}_j}{\\partial x_i} \\circ x))dx_i,\n\nloc.transf.map. \\tilde{x}(U \\cap \\tilde{U}) \\times \\mathbb{R}^m \\to x(U \\cap \\tilde{U}) \\times \\mathbb{R}^m, (\\tilde{x}, \\tilde{a}) \\mapsto (x(\\tilde{x}), \\sum_{i = 1}^m (\\sum_{j = 1}^m \\tilde{a_j} \\frac{\\partial \\tilde{x_j}}{\\partial x_i}(x(\\tilde{x})))e_i)\nand (x, a) \\mapsto (\\tilde{x}(x), \\sum_{j = 1}^m (\\sum_{i = 1}^m a \\frac{\\partial x_i}{\\partial \\tilde{x_j}}(\\tilde{x}(x)))e_j)\n\n\\tilde{a} = \\sum_{i = 1}^m \\tilde{a_i} e_i and a = \\sum_{i = 1}^m a_i e_i\n\n\n\n\nso T^*M has the inducted strc. 2m-dim. \\mathcal{C}^k-mnf. with boundary.\n1-form \\alpha on M is l \\le k-1 cont.diff.func. \\alpha: M \\to T^*M on U iff. for all coeff. \\alpha|_U = \\sum_{i = 1}^m a_i dx_i\nfor F: M^m \\to N^n diff. dF_p: T_p M \\to T_{F(p)} N, then dF^*_p : T^*_{F(p)}N \\to T^*_pM, \\lambda \\mapsto \\lambda \\circ d F_p (pullback) and for \\alpha 1-from on N, F^* \\alpha 1-from on M for (F^*\\alpha)_p := dF^*_p (\\alpha_{F(p)}) = \\alpha_{F(p)} \\circ dF_p.\nF^* dy_j = \\sum^m_{i = 1} ((F^*dy_j)(\\frac{\\partial}{\\partial x_i}))dx_i =: \\sum^m_{i=1}(dy_j(dF_p \\frac{\\partial}{\\partial x_i})) =: \\sum_{i = 1}^m (d(y_j \\circ F \\circ x^{-1})(e_i))dx_i\nd(y_j \\circ F \\circ x^{-1})(e_i) = \\frac{\\partial y_j}{\\partial x_i} \\circ x (also called y(x)) \\Rightarrow F^* dy_j = \\sum^m_{i = 1} (\\frac{\\partial y_j}{\\partial x_i} \\circ x) dx_i\n\nIII.5 Higher Dfferential Forms and External Derivatives\n\nFor M^m a \\mathcal{C}^l-mnf- with bound., \\Lambda^k TM := \\bigsqcup_{p \\in M} \\Lambda^k T_p M := \\Lambda_k T^*_pM \\cong Alt_k(T_p M) (Vectorspace of the alternating k-multilinearforms on T_pM)\n\n\\Lambda^*T M := \\bigsqcup_{p \\in M} \\Lambda^* T_p M = \\bigoplus_{k =0}^m \\Lambda^k T_p M,\n\\pi_{\\Lambda^k T M}: \\Lambda^k T M \\to M and \\pi_{\\Lambda^* TM} \\Lambda^* TM \\to M\n\\Lambda^0 TM = \\mathbb{R}, \\Lambda^1 TM = T^*M, \\Lambda^m T M is determinant-lines-bundle\n\n\na k-form (or diff.form of deg. k) on M is an inters of the bundels \\pi_{\\Lambda^k TM}, \\alpha_ M \\to \\Lambda^k TM s.t. \\pi_{\\Lambda^k TM} \\circ \\alpha = id_{\\Lambda^k TM} \\Leftrightarrow \\alpha(p) \\in \\Lambda^k T_p M \\Leftrightarrow \\alpha(p) \\in Alt_k (T_p M).\n\na mixed k-form is on M is an inters. of bundles \\pi_{\\Lambda^* TM} s.t. ‚Ä¶ (the same)\nalgebraic operations are pointwise (\\alpha + \\beta)_p = \\alpha_p + \\beta_p, ‚Ä¶\n‚Ä¶ Q\n\n\n$\\alpha|U = \\sum{1 \\le i_1 &lt; ‚Ä¶ &lt; i_k \\le m} a_{i_1, ‚Ä¶, i_k} dx_{} idk\nfor F: M \\to N, dF_p: T_p \\to T_{F(p)} N, then dF^*_p: \\Lambda^k T_{F(p)}N \\to \\Lambda^kT_p M is lin. and \\alpha k-form on N, then (pulled back k-from on M) F^* \\alpha is (F^* \\alpha)(v_1, ..., v_k)  = \\alpha_{F(p)}(dF_p(v_1), ..., dF_p(v_k)) for v_1, ..., v_k \\in T_p M\n\nF^*(\\alpha \\land \\beta) = (F^* \\alpha) \\land (F^* \\beta)\nF^*(dy_{j_1}\\land ... \\land dy_{j_k}) = (F^*dy_{j_1}) \\land ... \\land (F^*dy_{j_k}) = \\sum^m_{i_1 = 1} (\\frac{\\partial y_{j_1}}{\\partial x_{i_1}} \\circ x) dx_{i_1} = \\sum_{\\ \\le i_1, ..., i_k \\le m}(\\prod_{l = 1}^k(\\frac{\\partial y_{j_l}}{\\partial x_{i_l}} \\circ x)) dx_{i_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{i_k} = \\sum_{1 \\le i_1 &lt; ... &lt; i_k \\le m} (det(\\frac{\\partial y_{j_r}}{\\partial x_{i_s}}) \\circ x) dx_{i_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{i_k}\n\nfor k = m = n F^* dy_1 \\land ‚Ä¶ \\land dy_m = det (\\frac{\\partialy_r}{\\partial x_s} \\circ x)$ add substripts\n\n\nsynt. all the same for \\Lambda^* instead of \\Lambda^k.\n\n\nExternal Derivative\n\nthe derivative f \\mapsto df from diff.func. to 1-forms is a diff.operator of first order (ext. der.)\n\nd(fg) = (df) g + f (dg)\nex.uniq. ext. of the total differential on func. to a fam of \\mathbb{R}-ln. operators s.t.\n\nd(\\alpha \\land \\beta) = (d \\alpha) \\land \\beta + (-1)^k\\alpha \\land d \\beta for \\alpha diff.k-form, \\beta diff.l-fom (product rule)\nd^2 = 0 on 2-times diff. forms (if M is \\mathcal{C}^x for x \\ge 2, else on func.) (comp. prop.)\n\n\nfor p \\in U, U \\subseteq M \\Rightarrow ex. \\psi \\in \\mathcal{C}^2 s.t. supp(\\psi) \\subseteq U, supp(\\psi) comp. (supp), \\psi \\equiv 1 cl. to p\n\n\nfor op. d s.t. 1. &amp; 2., \\alpha diff.form on M, p \\in M then \\forall_{U\\subseteq M} p \\in U \\rightarrow \\exists_{\\psi \\in \\mathcal{C}^2(M)} \\psi(U) \\equiv 1, d(\\psi \\alpha) = (d \\psi) \\land \\alpha + \\psi d \\alpha, around p d(\\psi \\alpha) = d \\alpha, i.e. (d\\alpha)_p depends on \\alpha(p) (locality)\n\n(d_U \\alpha_U)_p := (d\\alpha)_p\nfor \\alpha = \\sum_{i_1 &lt; ... &lt; i_k} a _{i_1, ..., i_k} dx_{i_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{i_k} diff. on U then by 1. &amp; 2. we must: d_U(\\sum_{i_1 &lt; ... &lt; i_k} a _{i_1, ..., i_k} dx_{i_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{i_k}) := \\sum_{i_1 &lt; ... &lt; i_k} da _{i_1, ..., i_k} \\land dx_{i_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{i_k}\n\nfor \\alpha = a dx_{i_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{i_k}, \\beta = bdx_{j_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{j_l}, (prod. rule) d_U(\\alpha \\land \\beta) = d_U(ab dx_{i_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{i_k} \\land dx_{j_1} \\land ... \\land dx_{j_l}) = d(ab) \\land dx_{i_1} \\land ... = (da)b + a(db) \\land dx_{i_1} \\land ...\nd^2_U = d_U(df) = d_U (\\sum_{i}\\frac{\\partial f}{\\partial x_i}dx_i) for \\frac{\\partial f}{\\partial x_i} = \\frac{\\partial( f \\circ x^{-1})}{\\partial x_i} \\circ x, then (complex property) = \\sum^m_{i = 1}(d \\frac{\\partial f}{\\partial x_i}) \\land dx_i = \\sum_{i, j} \\frac{\\partial^2 f}{\\partial x_j \\partial x_i} dx_j \\land dx_i = \\sum_{j &lt; i}(\\frac{\\partial^2 f}{\\partial x_j \\partial x_i} - \\frac{\\partial^2 f}{\\partial x_i \\partial x_j}) dx_j \\land dx_i =0\n\n\n‚Ä¶\n\n\n\n\nRecap Linear Algebra\n\nV is m-dim. \\mathbb{R}-VS., the basis of V are in V \\times ... \\times V is open and dense ? has two components\n\nyou cannot get from a component to the other without going out of the basis.\nThe two basis are called positive and negative.\nBoh\n\n\n\n\n\nManifolds: by Youtube: Bright Side\n\n1. Introduction and Topology\n\nfor a met.sp. (X, d) we can def. op. sets A \\subseteq X, then:\n(X, \\mathcal{T}) is a top.sp. for \\mathcal{T} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(X) if (i) \\emptyset, x \\in \\mathcal{T}, (ii) A, B \\in \\mathcal{T} \\Rightarrow A \\cap B \\in \\mathcal{T}, (iii) (A_i)_{i \\in I} \\subset \\mathcal{T} \\Rightarrow \\bigcup_{i \\in I} A_i \\in \\mathcal{T}. each elem. in \\mathcal{T} are called open sets.\n\n\n2. Interior, Exterior, Boundary, Closure\n\nAnalysis II (Lecture)\n\n\n3. Hausdorff Spaces\n\n(a_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq X, for a_n \\rightarrow a := \\forall_{U \\in \\mathcal{T}} a \\in U \\rightarrow \\exists_{N \\in \\mathbb{N}}\\forall_{n \\ge N} a_n \\in U\na top.sp. is Hausd. if \\forall_{x, y \\in X} x \\not = y \\rightarrow \\exists_{U_x, U_y \\in \\mathcal{T}} x \\in U_x \\land y \\in U_y \\land U_x \\cap U_y = \\emptyset\n\n\n\n4. Quotient Space\n\n5. Projective Space\n\nS^n := \\{x \\in \\mathbb{R}^{n + 1} : ||x|| = 1\\}\na proj.sp. P^n(\\mathbb{R}) := S^n / \\sim for x \\sim y := x = y \\lor x = - y\n\n\n6. Second-Countable Space\n\ngenerators of \\mathcal{T} is called a basis\n\\mathcal{B} \\subseteq \\mathcal{T} is a basis if: \\forall_{U \\in \\mathcal{T}} \\exists_{(A_i)_{i \\in I} \\subseteq \\mathcal{B}} \\bigcup_{i \\in I} A_i = U\n(X, \\mathcal{T}) is second-countable if there is a basis \\mathcal{B} s.t. |\\mathcal{B}| &lt; \\aleph_0.\n\n\n7. Continuity\n\nf: X \\to Y is cont. if f(U) op. \\Rightarrow U op.\nf homeom. if f: X \\to Y bij. cont. and f^{-1} cont.\nf cont. \\Leftrightarrow for (x_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} s.t. x_n \\rightarrow x then (f(x_n))_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\rightarrow f(x)\n\nthis holds in met.sp. and second-countable spaces.\n\n\n\n\n8. Compactness\n\nAnalysis II (Lecture)\n\n\n9. Locally Euclidean Spaces\n\n(X, \\mathcal{T}) is a mnf. if (i) Hausd., (ii) second-count., (iii) locally euc. of dim. n\n(X, \\mathcal{T}) is loc.euc. if \\forall_{x \\in X}\\exists_{U \\in \\mathcal{T}}\\exists_{U&#039; \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n}\\exists_{h: U \\to U&#039;}h is homeom.\na trans.map.\n\n\n16. Smooth Maps\n\nf: M \\to N for M, N, f diff in p \\Leftrightarrow k \\circ f \\circ h^{-1} diff. in p.\n\n\n19. Tangent Space\n\nFor M \\subseteq \\mathbb{R}^n k-dim. mnf, h: U \\to U&#039;, a param. \\varphi: \\mathbb{R}^k \\cap U&#039; \\to M \\cap U\nT_p^{sub}M:= d\\varphi_{\\tilde{p}}[\\mathbb{R^k}] = \\{J_\\varphi(\\varphi^{-1}(p))x | x \\in \\mathbb{R}^k\\} \\subseteq \\mathbb{R}^n\n\n\\tilde{p}:= \\varphi^{-1}(p)\n\n\nex. for f: \\mathbb{R}^2 \\to \\mathbb{R}, f \\in \\mathcal{C}^1(\\mathbb{R}^2), M = G_f := \\{(\\begin{smallmatrix} x \\\\ y \\\\ f(x, y) \\end{smallmatrix})| (x, y) \\in \\mathbb{R}^2\\}, a param. \\varphi: \\mathbb{R}^2 \\to M, (\\begin{smallmatrix} x \\\\ y \\end{smallmatrix}) \\mapsto (\\begin{smallmatrix} x \\\\ y \\\\ f(x, y) \\end{smallmatrix}), T_p^{sub}M is the span of the columns of J_\\varphi(x, y)\n\n\n20. Tangent Curves\n\n\\gamma: \\mathbb{R} \\to M is a curve\nT_p M = \\{\\gamma&#039;(0) | \\gamma: (-\\varepsilon, \\varepsilon) \\to M diff. \\land \\gamma(0) = p\\}\n\n\n21. Tangent Space (Definition via tangent courves)\n\nHere we don‚Äôt require M \\subseteq \\mathbb{R}^n as did in 19.\nC_p(M):= \\{\\gamma: (- \\varepsilon, \\varepsilon) \\to M | \\gamma diff. \\land \\gamma(0) = p\\}\n\\gamma \\sim \\alpha := (h \\circ \\gamma)&#039;(0) = (h \\circ \\alpha)&#039;(0)\n[\\gamma]_\\sim := \\{\\alpha | \\gamma \\sim \\alpha\\}\nT_p(M) := C_p(M) / \\sim\n\nv + w := h^{-1}_*(h_*(v) + h_*(w)) for h_*: [\\gamma]_\\sim \\mapsto (h \\circ \\gamma)&#039;(0)\n\\lambda \\cdot v := h^{-1}_*(\\lambda \\cdot h_*(v))\n\n\nT_p^{sub}M \\to T_pM, \\gamma&#039;(0) \\mapsto [\\gamma]_\\sim nat. bij.\n\n\n22. Coordinate Basis\n\nU \\subseteq M, h: U \\to U&#039;, \\varphi := h^{-1}, then h_* : T_p M \\to \\mathbb{R}, [\\gamma] \\mapsto (h \\circ \\gamma)&#039;(0) lin. bij. (\\varphi := h_*^{-1})\na coor.bas. on M resp. to h chart, (\\partial_j)_{j \\in [1, ..., n]}:=(\\varphi_*(e_j))_{j \\in [1, ..., n]} is a basis of T_pM\n\n\\partial_j = \\frac{\\partial \\varphi}{\\partial x_j} this is why we use the notation \\partial_j.\n\n\nT_pM \\cong^{\\varphi_*} \\mathbb{R}^n \\cong^{J_\\varphi (\\tilde{p})}T_p^{sub}M\nfor f: M \\to N sm., df_p: T_p M \\to T_p N\n\n\n23. Differential (Definition)\n\na tangent bundle TM:= \\bigsqcup_{p \\in M}T_pM\n\ndim(TM) = 2 \\cdot dim(M)\n\n\nfor f: M \\to N, df_p: T_pM \\to T_{f(p)}N, [\\gamma] \\mapsto [f \\circ \\gamma]\n\ndf: p \\mapsto df_p\n\n\nM, N \\subseteq \\mathbb{R}^n sm. df_p:[\\gamma] \\mapsto [f \\circ \\gamma] = (f \\circ \\gamma)&#039;(0) = J_f(\\gamma(0))\\gamma&#039;(0) i.e. der. of f along [\\gamma] at p.\n\n\n24. Differential in Local Charts\n\n\\tilde{f} := k \\circ f \\circ h^{-1}, f = k^{-1} \\circ \\tilde{f} \\circ h, df = dk^{-1} J_\\tilde{f} dh.\n\ndk_{f(p)}(df_p([\\gamma])) = J_{\\tilde{f}}(h(p)(h \\circ \\gamma)&#039;(0) = J_{\\tilde{f}} [h \\circ \\gamma] = J_{\\tilde{f}} dh([\\gamma])\n\n\n\n\n25. Differential (Example)\n\n\\partial_j = \\varphi_*(e_j) = d_{\\varphi_{h(p)}}(e_j)\nfor f: M \\to \\mathbb{R}, \\partial_j f(p):= df_p(\\partial_j) = \\frac{\\partial(f \\circ \\varphi)}{\\partial x_j}(h(p))\n[f \\circ \\varphi \\circ \\tilde{\\gamma}] = (f \\circ \\varphi \\tilde{\\gamma})&#039;(0) = J_{f \\circ \\varphi}(h(p)) \\tilde{\\gamma}&#039;(0) = \\frac{\\partial(f \\circ \\varphi)}{\\partial x_j}(h(p))\n\n\\tilde{\\gamma}(t) = h(p) + t \\cdot e_j\n\n\n\n\n\nVerschiedenes\n\nDichte (B. 10): for f \\in \\mathcal{M}_{[0, \\infty]}(X, \\mathcal{A}), then f\\mu: \\mathcal{A} \\rightarrow  [0, \\infty], A \\mapsto \\int_A f d \\mu\n\n(Wiki) if X_1 = f^{-1}(X_2), then \\int_{X_2} g d(f_*\\mu) = \\int_{X_1} g \\circ f d\\mu.\nExistence\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Constructive-Analysis-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Constructive-Analysis-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Mathematics/Constructive Analysis (Lecture).md","title":"Constructive Analysis (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Helmut-Schwichtenberg/Helmut-Schwichtenberg","System/Attachments/nat_scm.pdf","System/Attachments/Presentation__nat_scm.pdf"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this seminar by Helmut Schwichtenberg on the use in constructive analysis of Minlog. Here you find my presentation on the implementation of the natural numbers and the relative script I produced. Here you find the Course‚Äôs Website.\n\nnat_scm.pdf\nPresentation__nat_scm.pdf\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Programming-II-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Programming-II-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Mathematics/Programming II (Lecture).md","title":"Programming II (Lecture)","links":[],"tags":[],"content":"This course should have been preceded by Programming I, which I will take the next semester. This was necessary in order to finish the BSc Mathematics in 4 semesters considering the transfer from the University of Constance to the LMU Munich. Here is a brief recap of the topics relevant for the exam, I will need to take the course for 3 ECTS only. The course is on Object Oriented Programming in C++.\nRecap\nThis will mainly be a collection of notes on programs which can most be found on the course website. Here I only presented the first lecture, since the published material was complete and detailed enough and we were allowed only to bring that material to the exam and not the personal notes.\nLecture 1\nclass\nusing namespace std;\n \nclass Complex { \n \nprivate:\n\tdouble re, im;\npublic:\n\tComplex(double=0, double=0); \n\t\n\tdouble real();\n\tdouble imag();\n\t\n\tfriend Complex conj(Complex);\n};\n \nComplex::Complex(double re_, double im_)\n\t: re(re_), im(im_) {}\n \ndouble Complex::real() { return re; }\ndouble Complex::imag() { return im; }\n \nComplex conj(Complex z) {\n\tz.im = -z.im; return z;\n}\n \nThis is a classic example of a class, it is divided in the private and public part, the former contains the informations that constitute a complex number. In the public part there is first the constructor, a function with the same name of the class, its sole job in this program is to set to¬†0 a non specified component in the class. Then I name two methods real and imag which are defined after the class thanks to  the ::, since their output is a familiar type, there is no need to do more. On the other hand, if we want to define a function of the same type, like conj giving the complex conjugate, there is the need to add friend, it is similarly defined after the class but without the need to add ::. Recall that the definition of both methods and friend function must follow the definition of the class.\nthis\nThe command this is the so-called pointer, one could add inside the class the function:\nComplex square() {\n\tdouble re2 = re*re - im*im,\n\t\tim2 = 2*re*im;\n    re = re2; im = im2;\n\treturn *this;\n\t}\n \nint main() {\n\tComplex z{1.0, 2.0};\n\tcout &lt;&lt; &lt;&lt; ‚ÄùRe z = ‚Äù &lt;&lt; z.square()\n\treturn 0;\n}\nWriting the function with z. in front determines the input and the output will be the same value, in fact there is the need to set z to the same values of z2 in the defined function. Also compare the following two defined functions.\ndouble real() { return (*this).re; }\ndouble imag() { return this-&gt;im; }\nThey show two different syntax for the same semantic. Furthermore consider the following function:\ndouble abs() {\n\treturn sqrt( (*this).real()*(*this).real() + (this-&gt;imag())*(this-&gt;imag()) );\n\t}\nprivate/public\nThe components of the class declared in the private section cannot be accessed from the outside of the class, private is also the default option of the class. For instance if we write outside of the class the following line, we will get an error:\ncout &lt;&lt; z.re &lt;&lt; endl;\nConstructors\nIt shows how an attribute should be initialised, it must have the same name of the class and you can also construct the attribute of the class even if some of the inputs are missing.\nclass Complex {\n\tComplex (double x, double y)\n\t    : re(x), im(y) {}\n};\nAnother example is the following:\nclass Polynom { \n\tprivate:\n\t\tvector&lt;double&gt; coeff;\n\tpublic:\n\t\tPolynom() {}\n\t\tPolynom(int n) : coeff(n + 1) { coeff[n] = 1; } Polynom(const vector&lt;double&gt;&amp; v) : coeff(v) {}\nWhat needs to be done in the case where less variables than needed are given is expressed within the (), for instance consider\nComplex(double re_=0, double im_=0) : re(re_), im(im_) {}\nThe constructors that sets at 0the missing variables. Constructors are called standard iff no parameters is required.\nAn interesting example of a constructor is the one of vectors. Those can be initialised by giving its length or with its content\nvector&lt;double&gt; v1(7);\nvector&lt;double&gt; v2{1, 2, 3, 4};\nDestructor\nThe name of the destructor must be of the form ~C, they are normally built in, though one can make an explicit one by using delete operator. An example is the following:\n~Vektor() {\ndelete[] ap;\n}\nSuch destructors are useful only for managing the memory correctly but should have no influence on the theoretical practice of the program."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Stochastic-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Stochastic-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Mathematics/Stochastic (Lecture).md","title":"Stochastic (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/LMU-Munich","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.Sc.-Mathematics-(LMU)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/3rd-Semester","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Mathematics/Analysis-III-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Analysis-II-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"I began following this lecture at the LMU Munich for my B.Sc. Mathematics (LMU) during my 3rd Semester without completing it, I collect here some notes I took during the course.\nLecture Notes\nHere is a recap of all definitions and propositions relevant for the exam and presented in the lectures and published material.\n\n\n\\Omega\n\n\\Omega Raum, \\mathcal{F} is a \\sigma-Al. iff (i) \\Omega \\in \\mathcal{F} (ii) A \\in \\mathcal{F} \\rightarrow A^C \\in \\mathcal{F} (iii) (A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{F} \\Rightarrow \\bigcup_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}A_n \\in \\mathcal{F}\nP is a w-Ma√ü iff (i) P(\\Omega) = 1 (ii) P(\\bigsqcup_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}A_n) = \\sum_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}P(A_n).\nm Farben, mit Reihenfolge, mit Zur√ºcklegen: \\Omega_1^{n,m} : = [m]^{[n]} = \\{\\omega | \\omega : [n] \\rightarrow [m]\\}, |\\Omega_1^{[n, m]}| = m^n\nm Farben, mit Reihenfolge, ohne Z√ºrucklegen: \\Omega_2^{n, m}: = \\{\\omega \\in [m]^{[n]}: \\omega inj.\\}, ==|?|==. L.1\nMultindex Notation: \\alpha \\in \\mathbb{N}^m, |\\alpha| = \\sum_{i = 1}^m \\alpha_i, \\alpha ! = \\alpha_1 !...\\alpha_m!. L.2\nm Farben, mit Reihenfolge innerhalb d. Farbe \\Omega_\\alpha := \\{f:[m]^{|\\alpha|} | \\forall_{k \\in [m]} |f^{-1}(k)| = \\alpha_k\\}, |\\Omega| = |\\alpha|!.\nm Farben, ohne Reihenfolge innerhalb d. Farbe \\tilde{\\Omega}_\\alpha : = \\Omega_\\alpha / \\sim, |\\tilde{\\Omega}_\\alpha| = \\frac{|\\alpha|!}{\\alpha!}.\n\n\n\n\\sigma\n\n\\sigma \\subset \\mathcal{P}(\\Omega) s.t. (i) \\Omega \\in \\sigma, (ii) A \\in \\sigma \\rightarrow A^C \\in \\sigma, (iii) \\bigcup_{n \\le \\omega} A_n \\in \\sigma.\nAlso (iv) \\emptyset \\in \\sigma, (v) \\bigcup_{n \\le \\omega} A_n \\in \\sigma, (vi) A \\cup B, A \\cap B, A \\setminus B, A \\Delta B \\in \\sigma\nFor \\mathcal{A}_1, \\mathcal{A}_2 \\sigma-al., then \\mathcal{A}_1 \\cap \\mathcal{A}_2 is a \\sigma-al.\nFor \\mathcal{E} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(\\Omega), \\sigma_\\Omega(\\mathcal{E}) : = \\bigcap \\{\\mathcal{A} : \\mathcal{A} is a \\sigma-al. \\land \\mathcal{E} \\subset \\mathcal{A}\\}, smallest \\sigma-al. with \\mathcal{E}.\n\\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R} : =  \\sigma_\\mathbb{R}(\\{(a, b) : a &lt; b\\}), and in general \\mathcal{B}_X := \\sigma_X (t) for (X, t) a topological space L.2\n\\Omega discrete \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{F} = 2^\\Omega; else: \\Omega = \\mathbb{R} \\Rightarrow \\mathcal{F} = \\sigma(\\{A \\subset \\mathbb{R}: A open\\}) = \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}.\nNotice: \\sigma ( \\{(a, b) : a &lt; b \\land a, b \\in \\mathbb{R}\\}) = \\sigma(\\{(-\\infty, q): q \\in \\mathbb{Q}\\}) = \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}\n\n\n\n\\mathbb{P}\n\nFor (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}), \\mathbb{P}: \\mathcal{A} \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^+_0 \\cup  \\{+\\infty\\} s.t. (i) \\mathbb{P}(\\emptyset) = 0, (ii) \\mathbb{P}(\\bigsqcup_{n \\le \\omega} A_n = \\sum_{n \\le \\omega} \\mathbb{P}(A_n) L.3\nIf (ii), (iii) \\mathbb{P}(\\Omega) = 1 and \\mathbb{P}: \\mathcal{A} \\rightarrow [0, 1] it is a w-Ma√ü. Consider the set theoretic conseq.\nFor (A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\in \\mathcal{A}^\\mathbb{N}, and if A_1 \\subseteq A_2 \\subseteq... then \\lim_{n \\rightarrow \\infty} \\mathbb{P}(A_n) = \\mathbb{P}(\\bigcup_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}A_n)\n\\lambda_d(Q) = \\prod^d_{i = 1} (b_i - a_i), or also A \\mapsto \\frac{\\lambda_d(A)}{\\lambda_d(\\Omega)} is an equal distribution on a d-dim interval. L.4\n\\phi(\\omega) is \\mathbb{P}-almost sure if \\mathbb{P}(\\{\\omega \\in \\Omega : \\lnot \\phi(\\omega)\\}) = 0.\n\n\n\nTools\n\nOn (\\mathbb{R}, \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}, \\mathbb{P}), D: \\mathbb{R} \\rightarrow [0, 1], x \\mapsto \\mathbb{P}((-\\infty, \\infty ]) 3.1 (Distribution function)\n\n(i) x \\le y \\rightarrow D(x) \\le D(y), (ii) (x_n)_{n  \\le \\omega} mon.f., \\lim_{n \\rightarrow \\infty} x_n = x then \\lim_{n \\rightarrow \\infty} D(x_n) = D(x) (iii) lim_{x \\rightarrow - \\infty} D(x) = 0 \\land lim_{x \\rightarrow \\infty} D(x) = 1. 3.2\n\n\nfor P, Q meas., for the respective distribution function D_P, D_Q, holds D_P = D_Q \\Rightarrow P = Q. 3.3;5\nM \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(\\Omega) is \\cap-st. gen. of (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}), if M is \\cap-st. and \\sigma_\\Omega(M) = \\mathcal{A}\nP, Q meas. that agree on a \\cap-st. gen., then they are equal.\n\n\n\n\\mathcal{D}\n\n(i) \\Omega \\in \\mathcal{D}, (ii) A \\in \\mathcal{D} \\rightarrow A^C \\in \\mathcal{D}, (iii) disj. seq A_i then \\bigsqcup_{i \\le n} A_i \\in \\mathcal{D}.\nfor (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}) and P, Q, D:= \\{A \\in \\mathcal{A}: P(A) = Q(A)\\}\nM \\cap-st. and \\mathcal{D} \\subseteq \\mathcal{P}(\\Omega) a dyn.sy. on \\Omega, then M \\subseteq \\mathcal{D} \\Rightarrow \\sigma_\\Omega(M) \\subseteq \\mathcal{D} (Dynkin Lemma)\n\n\n\nf\n\nf is \\mathcal{A}-\\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}-meas. define for \\forall_{B \\in \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}} f^{-1}(B) \\in \\mathcal{A}.\n\nA cont. funciton is \\mathcal{A}- \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R} - meas., also closed under +, \\frac{\\cdot}{\\cdot}, \\cdot, \\circ, |\\cdot |, \\lim, \\sup.\n\nfrom f \\circ g meas, consider + as a cont. func on func.\n\n\nfor f: \\Omega \\to \\overline{\\mathbb{R}} tfae: (i) f is \\mathcal{A}-\\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}-meas., (ii) \\forall_{a \\in \\mathbb{R}} \\{f \\le a\\}\\in \\mathcal{A}\n\n\\{f \\le a\\} := f^{-1}([-\\infty, a])\nsame holds for &lt;, &gt;, \\ge, or \\{a \\le f &lt;b\\} since they all generate \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}.\n\n\n\n\n\\int_\\Omega f d \\mu : = \\sup \\{\\sum_{k = 1}^n \\alpha_k \\mu(A_k) :  n \\in \\mathbb{N} \\land \\forall_{k}(A_k \\in \\mathcal{A} \\land \\alpha_k \\in [0, \\infty] \\rightarrow \\sum_{k = 1}^n \\alpha_k \\mathbb{1}_{A_k} \\le f)\\}.\nSimply check what I noted in Analysis III (Lecture).\nf_+ just like in Analysis II (Lecture).\n\n\n\nJ, Dichte\n\nfor (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mu), f \\Omega \\to [0, \\infty] meas. s.t. \\int_\\Omega d d \\mu = 1, then J: \\mathcal{A} \\to [0, 1], A \\mapsto \\int_A f d\\mu is a meas.\nExamples:\n\nGleichverteilung: \\zeta: [a, b] \\to [0, \\infty], x \\mapsto \\frac{1}{b-a}, P_{[a, b]}: A \\mapsto \\int_A \\zeta_{[a, b]} d \\lambda = \\frac{\\lambda(A)}{b -a}.\nExponentialverteilung: \\zeta_a: [0, \\infty], x \\mapsto a\\cdot e^{-ax}, P_a(A) = \\int\\zeta_a d \\lambda = \\int_0^\\infty a e^{-ax} dx\nGau√ü Verteilung:  \\zeta_{\\mu, \\sigma}: x \\mapsto \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi \\sigma^2}} \\cdot exp(-\\frac{1}{2}(\\frac{x-\\mu}{\\sigma})^2) for x \\in \\mathbb{R}, then \\forall_{A \\in \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}} P_{\\mu, \\sigma}: A \\mapsto  \\int_A \\zeta_{\\mu, \\sigma} d \\lambda = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty \\zeta_{\\mu, \\sigma} dx.\nDirac measure has no Dichte!\n\n\n\n\n\nQuantil\n\n\\mu prob.meas. on (\\mathbb{R}, \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}) with D dis.f., for y \\in (0, 1), elem in \\{x \\in \\mathbb{R}: lim_{x&#039; \\to x} D(x&#039;) \\le y \\le D(x)\\} are y-quantils on D.\n\nD inj. \\Rightarrow quantil is unique\n\n\na ‚Äúquasi-inverse‚Äù I(y) = sup\\{x \\in \\mathbb{R} : D(x) \\le y\\} a y-quantil of D, hence is I the quantil function.\nfor (\\tilde{\\Omega}, \\tilde{\\mathcal{A}}) and an index set I, \\forall_{i \\in I} x_i : \\Omega \\to \\tilde{\\Omega}, then \\sigma(x_i, i \\in I) := \\sigma \\{x_i^{-1}(\\tilde{A}) : \\tilde{A} \\in \\tilde{\\mathcal{A}} \\land i \\in I\\} is \\sigma-al. on \\Omega. 4.4;9\n\\bigotimes^n_{i = 1} \\mathcal{A_i} =\\sigma(x_i, i \\in [n]) =  \\sigma_\\Omega(\\{\\bigtimes^n_{i = 1} : A_i \\in \\mathcal{A}_i \\land i \\in [n]\\}) 4.5;9 (Product \\sigma-Algebra)\n(existence and uniqueness of the product measure) 4.6;9\n\n\n\n(\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathcal{B}_{\\mathbb{R}^n}, \\mu) and \\rho: \\mathbb{R}^n \\to [0, 1] meas. s.t. \\forall_{A \\in \\mathcal{B}_{\\mathbb{R}^n}} \\mu (A) = \\int_A \\rho d \\lambda_{\\mathbb{R}^n}, then \\mathcal{L}_\\mu(\\pi) has the dichte: J: \\mathbb{R}^m \\to [0, \\infty], x \\mapsto \\int_{\\mathbb{R}^{n-m}} \\rho(x, y) d \\lambda_{\\mathbb{R}^{n-m}}(y).\n\nfor \\pi: \\mathbb{R}^n \\to \\mathbb{R}^m, (x_1, ..., x_m, ..., x_n) \\mapsto (x_1, ..., x_m) the proj. of the first m coord.\nFrom 13.3 Iterierte Integrale (The Italians) recall: Tonelli, Fubini\n\n\n\nLet (i) (\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathcal{B}_{\\mathbb{R}^n}, \\mathbb{P}), (ii) let \\mathbb{P} have a Dichte f respect \\lambda_{\\mathbb{R}^n}, (iii) \\Phi: U \\to V \\mathcal{C}^1-Diffeo on U, V op., then: \\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{R}(\\Phi^{-1}) Dichte, g(y) = (f \\circ \\Phi) (y) \\cdot |det(D \\Phi_y)|.\n\nRecall 13.4 Transformationssatz\n\n\n\nConditional Probabilities\n\nfor (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}), B \\in \\mathcal{A} a Ereignis s.t. \\mathbb{P}(B) &gt; 0 define \\mathbb{P}(A | B) = \\frac{\\mathbb{P}(A \\cap B)}{\\mathbb{P}(B)} 4.10;10\n\n\\mathbb{P}(\\cdot | B) : \\mathcal{A} \\to [0, 1], A \\mapsto \\mathbb{P}(A|B) is a prob.meas. on (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A})\n\n\nfor (A_k)_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} a disj.zer. of \\mathcal{A} s.t. \\forall_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}}\\mathbb{P}(A_k) &gt; 0 then \\forall_{B \\in \\mathcal{A}} \\mathbb{P}(B) = \\sum_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\mathbb{P}(B | A_k) \\mathbb{P}(A_k)\nfor (A_k)_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} a disj.zer. of \\mathcal{A} s.t. \\forall_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}}\\mathbb{P}(A_k) &gt; 0, then \\forall_{B \\in \\mathcal{A}} \\mathbb{P}(B) \\to \\mathbb{P}(A_k | B) = \\frac{\\mathbb{P}(B | A_k)\\mathbb{P}(A_k)}{\\sum_{d \\in I}\\mathbb{P}(B | A_j)\\mathbb{P}(A_j)} 4.12;11 (Bayes)\n\n\n\nStochastic Independence\n\n(A_i)_{i \\in I} \\subseteq \\mathcal{A} sto.ind. for \\mathbb{P} if \\forall_{E \\subseteq I}((|E| &lt; \\infty \\land E \\not = \\emptyset) \\to\\mathbb{P}(\\bigcap_{i \\in E}A_i) = \\prod_{i \\in E} \\mathbb{P}(A_i)) 4.12;11\n(X_i)_{i \\in I} sto.ind. for \\mathbb{P} if: for each X_i: (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}) \\to (\\Omega_i, \\mathcal{A}_i), for all (A_i)_{i \\in I} s.t. A_i \\in \\mathcal{A}_i holds: (\\{X_i \\in A_i\\})_{i \\in I} is sto.ind. for \\mathbb{P}.\n\n(X_i)_{i \\in I} sto.ind. \\Rightarrow (\\sigma(X_i))_{i \\in I} sto.ind.\nfor: X_i: (\\mathbb{R}, \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}) \\to (\\mathbb{R}, \\mathcal{B}_\\mathbb{R}), i \\in [n] and let D: \\mathcal{R} \\to [0, 1] distr. of \\mathbb{P}, then (X_i))_{i \\in I} sto.ind. \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{(y_i)_{i \\in [n]} \\in \\mathbb{R}^n} \\mathbb{P}(x_i \\le y_i, i \\in [n]) = \\prod_{i \\in [n]} D_{X_i}(y_i)\n\nin this case also for \\varphi_k: \\mathbb{R}^k \\to \\mathbb{R} meas, \\varphi^k(x_1, ..., x_k) and (x_l)_{l \\le k} sto.ind.\nfor I_k pair. disj. subsets. of I, s.t. |I_k| &lt; \\infty, and \\varphi_k: \\mathbb{R}^{|I_k|} \\to \\mathbb{R} meas. and for (X_i)_{i \\in I} sto.ind., then (\\varphi_k \\circ (X_i)_{i \\in I})_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} sto.ind.\n\n\n\n\n(\\mathcal{F}_i)_{i \\in I} a fam. of \\cap-st. set.sys. are sto.ind. if for each \\emptyset \\not = \\mathcal{F}_i \\subseteq \\mathcal{A} if for all (A_i)_{i \\in I} s.t. A_i \\in \\mathcal{F}_i holds (A_i)_{i \\in I} is sto.ind. for \\mathbb{P}.\nfor (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}), and B \\in \\mathcal{A} then \\mathcal{D}_B := \\{A \\in \\mathcal{A}: (A, B) sto.ind. for \\mathbb{P}\\} is a dyn.sys.\n\n\n\nTheory and Epirie\n\nfor (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}) prob.sp., (\\tilde{\\Omega}, \\tilde{\\mathcal{A}}) meas.sp. X_i : (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A})\\to (\\tilde{\\Omega}, \\tilde{\\mathcal{A}}) for i \\in I indep. and identically distributed if (X_i)_{i \\in I} independent and \\forall_{i, j \\in I} \\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{P} (X_i) = \\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{P}(X_j) (i.i.d) 5.1;13\n\nNotation: \\llcorner x \\lrcorner = max \\{z \\in \\mathbb{Z} : z \\le x\\}\n\n\nfor X: (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}) \\to (\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}, \\mathcal{B}_{\\overline{\\mathbb{R}}}), \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}X^n := \\int_\\Omega X^n d \\mathbb{P} = \\int_\\Omega x(\\omega)^n d \\mathbb{P}(\\omega), if |X|^n int. write X \\in L^n (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}) and say: X has the nth. moment in \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}X^n.\n\ncheck Bsp. 1. at the end of L. 13\n\n\nL^1 (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}) 5.3;14\n\nis a Linear Space \\forall_{\\alpha, \\beta \\in \\mathbb{R}} \\forall_{x, y \\in L^1 (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P})} \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} [\\alpha x + \\beta y] = \\alpha \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}[x] + \\beta \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}[y].\n\\forall_{x, y L^1 (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P})} x \\le y \\to \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x) \\le \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(y)  (Monotony)\n\\forall_{A \\in \\mathcal{A}} \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} (\\mathbb{1}_A) = \\mathbb{P}(A)\n\\forall_{x, y \\in L^2 (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P})} (\\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}[xy])^2 \\le \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}[x^2] \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}[y^2] (Cauchy-Schwarz)\n\n\nfor x \\in L^2 (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}), 5.4;14\n\nvar_\\mathbb{P}(x) := \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} (x - \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x))^2 (Variance)\n\nvar_\\mathbb{P} (x) = \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x^2) - (\\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x))^2\nvar_\\mathbb{P}(x) \\ge 0\nvar_\\mathbb{P}(ax) = a^2 var_\\mathbb{P}(x)\nvar_\\mathbb{P}(x + a) = var_\\mathbb{P}(x)\n\n\n\\partial_\\mathbb{P}(x) := \\sqrt{var_\\mathbb{P}(x)} (Standardabweichung)\n\n\\partial_\\mathbb{P}(ax) = |a| \\partial_\\mathbb{P}(x)\n\n\ncov_\\mathbb{P}(x, y) := \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x - \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} (x))(y- \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(y)) (Covariance)\n\ncov_\\mathbb{P}(x, x) = var_\\mathbb{P}(x)\ncov_\\mathbb{P}(x, y) = cov_\\mathbb{P}(y, x)\ncov_\\mathbb{P}(x+y, z) = cov_\\mathbb{P}(x, z) + cov_\\mathbb{P}(y, z)\ncov_\\mathbb{P}(\\alpha, y) = \\alpha cov_\\mathbb{P}(x, y)\ncov_\\mathbb{P}(x, y) = \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(xy) - \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x) \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(y)\n\n\ncorr_\\mathbb{P}(x, y):= \\frac{cov_\\mathbb{P}(x, y)}{\\partial_\\mathbb{P} \\cdot \\partial_\\mathbb{P}(y)} \\in [-1, 1] (Correlation)\n\\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} y = 0 then say y is centred\n\n\\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x- \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}x)^n central nth moment of x.\n\n\n\n\nfor x, y \\in L^1 (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}), independent, then: 5.5;14\n\n\\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(xy) = \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x)\\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(y)\ncov_\\mathbb{P}(x, y) = 0 (say those are uncorrelated \\not = independent, only one direction. A fam. is uncorr. if pairw. uncorr.)\n\n\nfor (x_i)_{i \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\in L^1 (\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}), \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(\\sum^n_{i = 1}x_i) = \\sum^n_{i = 1} \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x_i)\n\nfor (x_i)_{i \\in I} uncorr., then var_\\mathbb{P}(\\sum^n_{i = 1}x_i) = \\sum^n_{i = 1} var_\\mathbb{P}(x_i)\n\n\n\n\n\nfor x_i \\in L^2(\\Omega, \\mathcal{A}, \\mathbb{P}) uncorr., and ident.distr. then: \\forall_{\\epsilon &gt;0} \\mathbb{P}(|\\frac{1}{n} \\sum^n_{i = 1} x_i - \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} x_1| \\ge \\epsilon) \\le \\frac{var_\\mathbb{P}(x_1)}{n \\epsilon^2} \\to^{n \\to \\infty} 0 5.6;15 (Weak principle of big numbers)\n\n\\forall_{i \\in [n]} \\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{P}(x_i) = \\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{P}(x_1) (ident.distr.)\n\\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}X_1 = \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}\\frac{1}{n} \\sum^n_{i = 1}x_i\n\\hat{x}_n := \\frac{1}{n} \\sum^n_{i = 1} x_i\n\n\n\nfor A \\in \\mathcal{A}, c \\in \\mathbb{R}_0^+ and x \\ge 0 zufallv. s.t. \\forall_{\\omega \\in A}x(\\omega) \\ge c, then \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}x \\ge c \\mathbb{P}(A) (Tschebyschaff Inequality)\n\n\nx zufallv., m &gt; 0, a &gt; 0 then: \\mathbb{P}(|x| \\ge a) \\le a^{-m} \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} |x|^m\n\n\n(x_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} zufallv. and x \\in \\mathbb{R}, x_n \\longrightarrow^\\mathbb{P}_{n \\to \\infty} x \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{\\epsilon &gt;0} lim_{n \\to \\infty} \\mathbb{P}(|x_n -x| \\ge \\epsilon) = 0 (conv. in prob.)\n\n\nx zufallv., def. L_x: \\mathbb{R}^+_0 \\to \\mathbb{R}, s \\mapsto \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}[e^{sx}]  (Laplace-Transformation/Momenterzwegende Funktion) 5.10;16\n\n\nx zufallv. with real values, \\forall_{a \\in \\mathbb{R}} \\forall_{s \\ge 0} \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(e^{sx}) \\ge e^{sa} \\mathbb{P}(x \\ge a) and \\mathbb{P}(x \\ge a) \\le inf_{s \\ge 0}(e^{-sa} \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(e^sx)) (exp. Tschebyschaff Inequality)\n\n\nfor (A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} ind. s.t. \\forall_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}\\mathbb{P}(A_n) = p then \\frac{1}{n} \\sum^n_{i = 1} \\mathbb{1}_{A_i} \\longrightarrow^\\mathbb{P}_{n \\to \\infty} p\n\n\nfor (x_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} iid zufallv., \\mu \\in \\mathbb{R}, \\partial \\in \\mathbb{R}^+_0 s.t. \\forall_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} x_n = \\mu, var_\\mathbb{P}(x_n) = \\partial^2, then \\frac{1}{n} \\sum^n_{i = 1} x_i =: \\hat{x}_n \\longrightarrow^{\\mathbb{P}-f.s.}_{n \\to \\infty} \\mu (\\mathbb{P}-fast sicher), 5.12;16 (Strong principle of big numbers)\n\n\\mathbb{P}(\\hat(x)_n \\longrightarrow^{n \\to \\infty} \\mu) = \\{\\omega \\in \\Omega : lim_{n \\to \\infty} \\hat{x}_n(\\omega) = \\mu\\}=1\n\n\n\n(A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq \\mathcal{A} and A^*:= limsup_{n \\to \\infty} (A_n), then (i) \\sum_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\mathbb{P}(A_n) &lt; \\infty \\Rightarrow \\mathbb{P}(A^*) = 0, (ii) \\sum_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\mathbb{P}(A_n) = \\infty and (A_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} ind. \\Rightarrow \\mathbb{P}(A^*) = 1 (Borel-Cantelli Lemma)\n\nconsider lim sup and lim inf as in Analysis III (Lecture).\nalso: (x_n \\longrightarrow^{\\mathbb{P}-f.s.}_{n \\to \\infty} x) \\Rightarrow (x_n \\longrightarrow^{\\mathbb{P}}_{n \\to \\infty} x) (see exercise)\n\n\n\n\\tilde{x}_n := \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{n}} \\sum^n_{i = 1} (x_i - \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x_i)) (Skalierung)\n\n\n\\Phi_x : \\mathbb{R} \\to \\mathbb{C}, y \\mapsto L_x(i \\cdot y) = \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}[e^{iyx}] (Characteristical Function)\n\n\\Phi_x(0) = 1\n|\\Phi_x(y)| \\le 1\ny \\mapsto \\Phi_x(y) glm.stet.\n\\Phi_x(y) = \\overline{\\Phi_x(-y)}\nfor x_1, x_2 zufallv. ind.: \\Phi_{x_1 + x_2} (y) = \\Phi_{x_1}(y) \\cdot \\Phi_{x_2}(y)\n(3), (4);18\n\n\n\nfor (x_i)_{i \\in \\mathbb{N}} real zufallv. s.t. \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} x_i = 0 and \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}x^2 &lt; \\infty then \\Phi \\tilde{x}_n(y) \\longrightarrow^{n \\to \\infty} exp(- \\frac{1}{2} y^2 var_\\mathbb{P}(x_1)) 5.15;18\n\n\nfor (x_i)_{i \\in\\mathbb{N}} real zufallv. uniformely distr. and ind., for \\mu \\in \\mathbb{R}, \\sigma \\in \\mathbb{R}^+_0 s.t. \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P} x_i = \\mu and \\sigma = \\sigma_\\mathbb{P}(x_i), then \\forall_{a, b \\in \\mathbb{R}} a \\le b \\rightarrow \\lim_{n \\to \\infty} \\mathbb{P}(\\tilde{x}_n \\in [a, b]) = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2\\pi \\sigma^2}} \\int_a^b e^{- \\frac{1}{2} {(\\frac{x}{\\sigma})^2}} dx  5.16;18 (Zentrale Grenzwertsatz)\n\n\\tilde{x}_n := \\frac{1}{n}\\sum^n_{ i = 1}(x_i - \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x_i))\n\n\n\nx real zufallv. and distr. \\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{P}(x) with Dicht e \\delta(y) = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi \\sigma^2}} exp(- \\frac{1}{2}(\\frac{y-\\mu}{\\sigma})^2), then x \\sim \\mathcal{N}(\\mu, \\sigma) 5.17;18 (Normal Distribution)\n\nStandard Normal Distribution if \\mu = 0 and \\sigma = 1.\nfor \\mu = \\mathbb{E}_\\mathbb{P}(x_i) and \\sigma = \\sigma_\\mathbb{P}(x_i)\n\n\\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{P}(\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{n}} \\sum^n_{i = 1}(x_i - \\mu)) \\longrightarrow^{n \\to \\infty} \\mathcal{N}(0, \\sigma)\n\\mathcal{L}_\\mathbb{P}(\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{n} \\sigma} \\sum^n_{i = 1}(x_i - \\mu)) \\longrightarrow^{n \\to \\infty} \\mathcal{N}(0, 1)\n\\mathbb{P}(\\frac{\\sigma}{\\sqrt{n}}a + \\mu \\le \\frac{1}{n} \\sum^m_{i = 1} x_i \\le \\mu + \\frac{\\sigma}{\\sqrt{n}}b) \\longrightarrow^{n \\to \\infty} \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi}} \\int^b_a e^{-{\\frac{1}{2}x^2}} dx)\n\n\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Choice":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Choice","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Philosophy/Choice.md","title":"Choice","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/What-a-Logic-Could-not-Be","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Model-Theory-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"This writing was a part of What a Logic Could not Be which I decided to cut after changing course to the essay. It gives a decently precise definition of choice, possibly different from the familiar one used in mathematical praxis. The formalisation uses theory presented in Model Theory (Lecture).\n\\section{The \\enquote{Choice}}\nWhat we naturally mean when we say that we have a choice, is that we are given with the to pick one of some options we are given, these choice are supposed to be, on one hand all different, or it wouldn&#039;t be much of a choice, but on the other hand, they should all have some common features for a certain aim we are making the choice for. Similarly, in mathematics a choice is made between options that are, in some respects, equivalent but in some other equivalent: for instance, it often happens to be the choice of an element in some equivalence class.  What is crucial here, is that the chosen element has no distinguished feature, i.e. there is no definable property in the language that is true only for that object. That is to say that all options we have are equivalent, there is nothing that we can say for a distinguished object among our options. In set theory, we say that, if the set of choices we are given is infinite, then we require the Axiom of Choice; in the definition I gave above though, there is no need for it to be infinite.\n \n\\subsubsection*{Formalisation}\nIn order to get to a more precise definition of a choice, I need first to define what a complete type is. The following formalisations are not necessary for a satisfactory understanding of the essay. To have a better grasp of the distinction of object and metalanguage, the reader is suggested to read the first section of \\href{plato.stanford.edu/entries/tarski-truth/#ObjLanMet}{SEP: Tarski&#039;s Truth Definitions}.\n \n\\begin{Definition}[Complete Type]\n    Given a model $\\mathcal{M}$ (with domain $M$) in a language $\\mathcal{L}$ and an object $\\alpha \\in M$, define the complete type $tp^\\mathcal{M}(\\alpha) = \\{\\varphi(\\cdot) \\in \\mathcal{L}: \\mathcal{M} \\models \\varphi(\\alpha)\\}$ where $\\varphi(\\cdot)$ denotes formulae with one free variables.\n\\end{Definition}\n \n\\begin{Definition}[Choice]\n    Given a theory $T$, a set $S$ s.t. for each $\\mathcal{M} \\models T$ it holds $\\forall_{s, s&#039; \\in S} tp^\\mathcal{M}(s) = tp^\\mathcal{M}(s&#039;)$ (definitional equivalence of $S$ with respect to $T$) and a function $f: S \\to \\{0, 1\\}$ s.t. there is a unique element with $f(s) = 1$, then $s$ is called a choice of $f$ in $S$ with respect to $T$.\n\\end{Definition}\n \n\\begin{Remark}\n    Existence of a choice $s$ in a set $S$ with respect to $T$ for $|S|$ infinite requires the axiom of choice in the metatheory.\n\\end{Remark}\n \n\\subsection{\\enquote{Canon} and \\enquote{Abstraction}}\nIn this essay I denote with the term \\enquote{Abstraction} some object previous to a choice, like an equivalence class previous to the choice of a single element; that is, I believe, a more strict denotation of the natural one for abstraction, it is also a more precise one and the one I need in the scope of this essay. Also, with the word \\enquote{Canonical Choice} I denote an object that has some metalinguistic feature that is, indeed, distinguished among the other options, and which allows to bypass the \\emph{definitional equivalence} of all properties. For instance, a Canonical Choice might be one referring to the syntax, i.e. take the object whose name comes first in the alphabetical order, features of this kind, are not accessible within the language and are therefore not definable even though metalinguistically, we can clearly define those.\n \n\\subsubsection*{Formalisation}\n \n\\begin{Definition}[Abstraction]\n    For a choice $s$ in a set $S$, call $S$ (one of) the abstraction(s) of $s$.\n\\end{Definition}\n \n\\begin{Definition}\n    In a set $S$ with a choice $s$ a canon $\\kappa$ is a metalinguistic formula with one free variable s.t. $\\kappa(s)$ and $\\forall_{s&#039; \\in S \\setminus \\{s\\}} \\lnot \\kappa(s&#039;)$.\n\\end{Definition}\n \n\\subsection{The Problem of Choice}\n \nGiven a definitionally equivalent set $S$, the logician is can choose one of the three following paths\n \n\\paragraph{I. Abstract} If the logician refuses to pick an element, they can decide to stick with the set $S$. This allows them to do not loose information but may not allow them to make any considerations or computations that can be made only on elements of $s$ and not on sets of them, some examples are present in the upcoming sections.\n \n\\paragraph{II. Choose} In order to make some of the named computations, the logician may choose one object, this though requires them, if $|S|$ is infinite, to assume the axiom of choice in their metatheory.\n \n\\paragraph{III. Canonical Choice} Some of the named computations may come out easier if one knows already, metalinguistically, what to expect from the choice, therefore one often looks for some form of canonical choice. This option also prevents us to assume metatheoretically the axiom of choice.\n \nThese paths are best understood via examples, I present in the next sections how one can apply this concepts in a complete conception of pluralism."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Correspondence":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Correspondence","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Philosophy/Correspondence.md","title":"Correspondence","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Structure-on-Models","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/What-a-Logic-Could-not-Be","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Logic-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"The essay is available at Overleaf.\nRelated Pages\n\nStructure on Models\nWhat a Logic Could not Be\n\n\nIn Philosophy of Logic (Lecture) we discussed that since domains of models are sets and we don‚Äôt have a set containing all sets, we cannot ground truth on validity of models. Despite this, it is claimed the so-called squeezing argument, completeness still holds but we cannot claim the same for soundness."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Modal-Logic-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Modal-Logic-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Philosophy/Modal Logic (Lecture).md","title":"Modal Logic (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/3rd-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/LMU-Munich","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/B.A.-Philosophy-(LMU)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Model-Theory-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed this course during my 3rd Semester of the Bachelor at the LMU Munich. The course has been held by Dr. Marra at the mcmp. Here I collect the notes from the material available online. I had an oral exam on the 22nd May 2024 and got 1.3; the mark counts in the B.A. Philosophy (LMU).\n1. Intro and Lecture\n\nModal: a mode of truth like: necessity, knowledge, belief, obligation, present\n\nAlethic: \\square \\varphi means ‚Äúit is necessary that \\varphi‚Äú.\n\nCounterfactual: \\varphi \\square \\to \\psi  means ‚Äúif \\varphi were the case, then \\psi would be the case‚Äù.\n\n\nEpistemic: K_\\varphi means ‚Äúthe agent knows \\varphi‚Äù.\n\nK_i \\varphi means ‚Äúagent i knows that \\varphi‚Äù.\nL_i \\varphi means ‚Äúthe agent i cannot rule out that \\varphi‚Äú.\n\n\nDeontic: O_\\varphi means ‚Äúit is obligatory that \\varphi‚Äú.\nTemporal: G \\varphi means ‚Äù it will always be the case that \\varphi‚Äù.\n\nH_\\varphi means ‚Äù it was always the case that \\varphi‚Äù.\n\n\n\n\nwff. are generated by the usual (finitary) recursion with \\lnot, \\land, \\square\n\n\\lozenge \\varphi := \\lnot \\square \\lnot \\varphi\n\n\n\n2.
