Truth\n\nKripke Frames: \\mathcal{F} := (W, R) for W = \\{w_1, w_2, ...\\} non empty, R \\subseteq W \\times W a binary relation on W.\n\nR, the accessibility relation, is interpreted in different ways:\n\nDeontic Logic: Ideality\nTemporal Logic: Immediate Predecessor\n\n\nR can be:\n\nReflective, Symmetric, Transitive\nSerial: \\forall_x \\exists_y xRy\nConversely well-founded: there is no inf. ascending chain x_0 R x_1 \\land x_1 R x_2 \\land x_2 R x_3 ...\nEuclidian: \\forall_{x, y, z}((xRy \\land x R z) \\to y R z)\n\n\n\n\nKripke Models: \\mathcal{M} := (W, R, V) s.t. \\mathcal{F} = (W, R) is K.fr., V: AT \\to \\mathcal{P}(W) for AT the set of atomic sentences mapped to the set of worlds where it holds. Write w \\in V(p) means ‚Äùp is true at w‚Äú.\nKripke Semantics:\n\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models p iff w \\in V(p)\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\lnot \\varphi iff not \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi \\land \\psi iff \\mathcal{M} , w \\models \\varphi and \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\psi\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\square \\varphi iff for all v: if wRv then \\mathcal{M}, v \\models \\varphi\n\nthose are local, only affected by accessible worlds.\nthose are intensional, \\square \\varphi at w depends on other things\n\n\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\lozenge \\varphi iff for some v: w R v and \\mathcal{M}, v \\models \\varphi\nFor convention: V(\\bot) = \\emptyset and V(\\top) = W\nw is an end point if \\lnot \\exists_v v R w\n\n\n\n3. Expressive Power and Invariance\n\nBisimulation: denoted with E, is a relation between W_1 and W_2 of two Kripke Models for fixed w \\in W_1, v \\in W_2, s.t.:\n\n\\forall_{p \\in AT} w E v \\Rightarrow (w \\in V_1 (p) \\Leftrightarrow v \\in V_2(p)) (Atomic Harmony)\nwEv \\land wR_1w&#039;\\Rightarrow \\exists_{v&#039; \\in \\mathcal{M}_2} vR_2v&#039; \\land w&#039;Ev&#039; (ZIG)\nwEv \\land v R_2 v&#039; \\Rightarrow \\exists_{w&#039; \\in \\mathcal{M}_1} wR_1 w&#039; \\land w&#039; E v&#039; (ZAG)\n\n\nPointed Model: denoted with \\mathcal{M}, w, is a Kripke model \\mathcal{M} with a designated world w \\in W.\nBisimilar: \\mathcal{M}_1, w and \\mathcal{M}_2, v pointed models are bisimilar if there is a bisimulation E s.t. w E v, write it \\mathcal{M}_1, w \\underline{\\leftrightarrow} \\mathcal{M}_2, v\n\nThis is a weaker but similar notion of isomorphism:\n\nwhenever it is possible to make a transition in one model, it is possible to make a matching transition in the other.\n\n\n\n\nInvariance Lemma if \\mathcal{M}_1, w \\underline{\\leftrightarrow} \\mathcal{M}_2, v then for all \\varphi we have \\mathcal{M}_1, w \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}_2, v \\models \\varphi, i.e. \\mathcal{M}_1, w \\equiv \\mathcal{M}_2, v.\n\nUndefinable properties can differ in bisimilar models, those are:\n\n‚Äúhaving a predecessor‚Äù\n‚Äúuniqueness‚Äù: there is exactly one world s.t. \\varphi.\n\n\nProve undefinability:\n\nif we claim yes: write down a definition in the modal language\nif we claim no: give two bisimular models, one with the property and one without.\n\n\n\n\nUnraveling and Contraction, one can expand a Kripke model adding an infinite tree, one can also contract it, both operations require bisimulations.\n\n4. Frame Correspondence\n\nWe have seen four notions of validity:\n\nTruth at a world in a model \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi\nValidity in a model \\mathcal{M} \\models \\varphi iff \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi for all w \\in W\nValidity on a frame \\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi iff \\mathcal{M} \\models \\varphi for all models \\mathcal{M} = (\\mathcal{F}, V)\nValidity in a class of frames \\mathcal{K} \\models \\varphi iff \\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi for all \\mathcal{F} \\in \\mathcal{K}.\n\nValidity in the class of all frames is denoted with \\models \\varphi\nDistributive of \\square and \\lozenge on \\land and \\lor are valid on the class of all frames.\n\n\n\n\nFrame Correspondence: \\mathcal{F} has P iff \\mathcal{F} \\models \\varphi, then \\varphi corresponds to P.\n\nExamples:\n\n\\square \\varphi \\to \\varphi corr. to refl.\n\\varphi \\to \\square \\lozenge \\varphi corr. to sym.\n\\square \\varphi \\to \\square \\square \\varphi corr. to trans.\n\\square \\varphi \\to \\lozenge \\varphi corr. to seriality\n\\lozenge \\varphi \\to \\square \\lozenge \\varphi corr. to euclideaness\n\n\nNot all properties (first order expressible) of frames corr. to modal formulae, not all modal formulae correspond to properties (first order expressible) of frames.\n\nthe L√∂b Axiom: \\square(\\square \\varphi \\to \\varphi) \\to \\square \\varphi) corr. to trans and converse well-foundness, the latter is not expressible in first order logic.\n\n\n\n\n\n5. Finite Model Property\n\nIs there a \\varphi that corr. to finiteness of a model? No, if \\varphi is true in a model, there is a finite model in which it is true too.\n\n|\\mathcal{M}| &lt; 2^n for n the number of connectives and operators in \\varphi.\n\nsince the language is finitary, n &lt; \\omega.\nThere are finitely many models \\mathcal{M} s.t. |\\mathcal{M}| &lt; 2^n.\n\n\n\n\nFinite Model Property: for \\mathcal{M}, w and \\varphi, there is a finite model \\mathcal{M}&#039;, w&#039; s.t. \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039;, w&#039; \\models \\varphi, furthermore it holds |\\mathcal{M}&#039;| &lt; 2^n for n the number of connectives and operators in \\varphi.\n-¬†It corresponds to compactness in Model Theory (Lecture) (not in its last part).\nSubformula Closed Sets: let K = \\{\\varphi_1, ..., \\varphi_n\\} is subformula closed if each subformula of formulae in the set is in the set.\nMethod of Filtration: \\mathcal{M}&#039;:= (W^{\\mathcal{M}&#039;}, R&#039;, V&#039;) is a filtration of \\mathcal{M} :=(W^{\\mathcal{M}}, R, V) by the subformula set K if\n\nW^{\\mathcal{M}&#039;} = \\{[w]: w \\in W^{\\mathcal{M}}\\} where for w \\in W^\\mathcal{M}, [w]:= \\{\\varphi \\in K : \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi\\}\n[w] R&#039; [v] \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{\\lozenge \\varphi \\in K}\\varphi \\in [v] \\to \\lozenge \\varphi \\in [w]\n\nwhen \\lozenge \\varphi \\not \\in K, then trivially \\lozenge \\varphi \\not \\in [w], hence such worlds are connected from each world.\n\n\n[w] \\in V&#039;(p) \\Leftrightarrow p \\in [w]\n\n\nFinite Model Property via Filtrations: for \\mathcal{M}, \\varphi and \\mathcal{M}&#039; the filtration of \\mathcal{M} on the smallest subformula-closed set K containing \\varphi, then:\n\n\\forall_{w \\in \\mathcal{M}} \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi \\leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M}&#039;, [w] \\models \\varphi\n|\\mathcal{M}&#039;| &lt; 2^{|K|-1} (|K| -1 is the number of subformulae of \\varphi)\n\n\nhence we derive \\forall_{\\psi \\in K}\\forall_{[w] \\in \\mathcal{M}&#039;} \\mathcal{M}&#039;, [w] \\models \\psi \\Leftrightarrow \\psi \\in [w]\n\n\n\n6. Consequence Relations\n\nwe defined &quot;\\models&quot; in Lecture 2 already (Kripke Semantics), also consider\n\n\\Gamma \\models_\\mathcal{K} \\varphi iff for all frames \\mathcal{F} \\in \\mathcal{K}, for all models \\mathcal{M} on \\mathcal{F}, for all w \\in W, we have: if \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\psi for all \\psi \\in \\Gamma, then \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi.\n\n\n&quot;\\psi \\vdash \\varphi&quot; if there is a Hilbert-style proof from \\psi to \\varphi.\n\neach passage can either be: (i) tautology, (ii) appl. of a rule of inf., (iii) instance of an axiom of \\Lambda.\n\n\n\\Lambda\n\n\\Lambda is a normal modal logic, i.e. a set of formulae s.t.:\n\nContains\n\n(K) \\square( \\varphi \\to \\psi) \\leftrightarrow (\\square \\varphi \\to \\square \\psi)\n(Dual) \\lozenge \\varphi \\leftrightarrow \\lnot \\square \\lnot \\varphi\n\n\nClosed under:\n\nModus Ponens\nif \\varphi \\in \\Lambda then \\square \\varphi \\in \\Lambda\n\n\n\n\n\\Lambda_K is the smallest \\Lambda, one can also add further axioms.\n\\vdash_\\Lambda \\varphi iff \\varphi \\in \\Lambda\n\\Gamma \\vdash_\\Lambda \\varphi iff exists \\{\\varphi_1, ..., \\varphi_n\\} \\subseteq \\Gamma s.t. \\vdash_\\Lambda (\\psi_1 \\land ... \\land \\psi_n) \\to \\varphi\n\n\\vdash_K := \\vdash_{\\Lambda_K}\n(Inheritance) if (\\varphi \\to \\psi) \\in \\Lambda, then (\\square \\varphi \\to \\square \\psi) \\in \\Lambda\n\n\nFurther Axioms:\n\n(T) \\square \\varphi \\to \\varphi\n(4) \\square \\varphi \\to \\square \\square \\varphi\n(B) \\varphi \\to \\square \\lozenge \\varphi\n(D) \\square \\varphi \\to \\lozenge \\varphi\n(5) \\lozenge \\varphi \\to \\square \\lozenge \\varphi\n\n\nFurther Normal Logics:\n\n\\Lambda_{KT}:= T := \\Lambda_K + (T)\n\\Lambda_{KT4} := S4 := \\Lambda_{KT} + (4)\n\\Lambda_{KT4B} := S5 := \\Lambda_{KT4} + (B) = \\Lambda_{KT} + (5)\n\n\n\n\n\n7. Soundness and Completeness I\n\nfor any \\Gamma\n\nif \\Gamma \\vdash_\\Lambda \\psi, then \\Gamma \\models_\\mathcal{K} \\psi (Soundness)\nif \\Gamma \\models_\\mathcal{K} \\psi, then \\Gamma \\vdash_\\Lambda \\psi (Completeness)\nif \\models_\\mathcal{K} \\psi, then \\vdash_\\Lambda \\psi (Weak Completeness)\n\n\nfor \\Gamma cons. set of formulae, there exists \\Delta maximally consistent set s.t. \\Gamma \\subseteq \\Delta. (Lindenbaum)\n\n8. Completeness II\n\nNote: Completeness \\Leftrightarrow every \\Lambda-consistent set has a model in \\mathcal{K}.\nCompleteness proof plan:\n\nclaim: every consistent set of formulae has a model\nBy Lindenbaum we can extend it to a maximally consistent set\n\nfor \\Gamma, let \\Delta be MCS s.t. \\Gamma \\subseteq \\Delta\n\n\nby truth lemma there is a canonical model that makes all those formaulae true.\n\n\\mathcal{M}^C = (W^C, R^C, V^C) for W^C := \\{\\Gamma : \\Gamma is MCS\\}, \\Gamma R^c \\Delta \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{\\varphi \\in \\Delta} \\lozenge \\varphi \\in \\Gamma \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{\\square \\varphi \\in \\Gamma} \\varphi \\in \\Delta and \\Gamma \\in V^C (p) \\Leftrightarrow p \\in \\Gamma.\nTruth Lemma: \\varphi \\in \\Gamma iff \\mathcal{M}^C, \\Gamma \\models \\varphi.\nExistence Lemma: \\lozenge \\varphi \\in \\Gamma iff there is a MCS \\Delta with \\varphi \\in \\Delta and \\Gamma R^C \\Delta.\n\n\n\n\n\\varphi is canonical for a class of frames \\mathcal{K} if  \\Lambda_{K + \\varphi}^C \\in \\mathcal{K}\nif \\varphi is canonical for a class of frames \\mathcal{K}, then the logic \\Lambda_{K + \\varphi} is strongly complete.\n\n\n\n9. Temporal Logic\n\n\\mathcal{L}_T = \\mathcal{L} + \\{G, H\\}\n\nG\\varphi means ‚Äúit will always be the case that \\varphi‚Äù\nH\\varphi means ‚Äúit was always the case that \\varphi‚Äù\nF\\varphi:= \\lnot G \\lnot \\varphi reads as ‚Äúit will at some time be the case that \\varphi‚Äù\nP \\varphi := \\lnot H \\lnot \\varphi reads as ‚Äúit was at some time the case that \\varphi‚Äù\n\n\nTemporal Frame \\mathcal{F} := (T, &lt;), works as intuitively should\nSemantics:\n\n\\mathcal{M}, t \\models p iff t \\in V(p)\n\\mathcal{M}, t \\models \\lnot \\varphi iff \\mathcal{M}, t \\not \\models \\varphi\n\\mathcal{M}, t \\models \\varphi \\land \\psi iff \\mathcal{M}, t \\models \\varphi and \\mathcal{M}, t \\models \\psi\n\\mathcal{M}, t \\models G \\varphi iff for all s if s &lt; t then \\mathcal{M}, s \\models \\varphi\n\\mathcal{M}, t \\models H \\varphi iff for all s if s &gt; t then \\mathcal{M}, s \\models \\varphi\n\n\nNEXT\\varphi is not definable (proof with bisimulation)\nBasic Temporal Logi (BTL) is the smallest set of formulae s.t.:\n\nContains all prop. tautologies\nAll instances of:\n\nG( \\varphi \\to \\psi) \\to (G \\varphi \\to G \\psi) (Distribution)\nH(\\varphi \\to \\psi) \\to (H\\varphi \\to H\\psi)\nF \\varphi \\leftrightarrow \\lnot G \\lnot \\varphi (Dual)\nP \\varphi \\leftrightarrow \\lnot H \\lnot \\varphi\n\\varphi \\to GP \\varphi (Converse)\n\\varphi \\to HF \\varphi\n\n\nIs closed under\n\nModus Ponens\nTemp. Gener. if \\varphi \\in BTL, then H \\varphi \\in BTL and G \\varphi \\in BTL.\n\n\n\n\nFurther Restrictions: &quot;&lt;&quot; is assumed to be:\n\nTransitive; which corresponds to G \\varphi \\to GG \\varphi and H \\varphi \\to HH \\varphi\nIrreflexivity: no corresponding modal formula\n\n\n\n10. Deontic Logic I\n\nIt determines ‚Äúobligation‚Äù &amp; ‚Äúpermission‚Äù, and is related to ‚Äúgood‚Äù\nThere is no explicit agency ‚Äúit is obligatory that‚Äù\nit adds to classical logic the operator O \\varphi ‚Äúit ought that \\varphi‚Äù\nDeontic Frames are just like serial Modal Frames, i.e. s.t. \\forall_w \\exists_v (w R v), the models and semantics are also the same. It also is sound and (strongly) complete.\nSDL, Standard Deontic Logic, is \\Lambda_{KD}, namely, a normal modal logic with:\n\n(KD) O(\\varphi \\to \\psi) \\to (O \\varphi \\to O \\psi)\n(Dual) P \\varphi \\leftrightarrow \\lnot O \\lnot \\varphi\n(D) O \\varphi \\to P \\varphi\n\n\nIt follows that:\n\nif (\\varphi \\to \\psi) \\in SDL then (O \\varphi \\to O \\psi) \\in SDL (Monotonicity)\n\\lnot (O \\varphi \\land O \\lnot \\varphi) (\\Leftrightarrow O \\varphi \\to P \\varphi) (No Deontic Conflicts)\nDistributivity of \\land and \\lor on O\n\\lnot O \\bot\n(\\varphi \\land (\\varphi \\to O \\psi)) \\to O \\psi (Factual Detachment)\n(O \\varphi \\land O(\\varphi \\to \\psi)) \\to O \\psi (Deontic Detachment)\n\n\nThe Gentle Murder Puzzle, consider the following passages:\n\nSmith ought not to kill John\nIf Smith kills John, then Smith ought to kill John gently\nSmith kills John\n\n\nWe can formalise this as:\n\n\n\nO(\\lnot k), 2. O( k \\to g), 3. k\n\n\nNot independent: in this formalisation O(k \\to g) follows from O (\\lnot k), how?\n\n\n\n\nO(\\lnot k), 2. k \\to Og, 3. k\n\n\nInconsistent: O(k) follows from 2. and 3.\n\n\n\n\nthe O operator describes how things are in the ideal world, worlds where ‚Äúkill John gently‚Äù are sub-ideal worlds that are not always supported by SDL.\nA solution is to consider proposition of the form ‚Äúif p, then it ought to be that q‚Äù with a non-material conditional, s.t. Factual Detachment holds.\n\nhence 2. becomes: k \\Rightarrow Og, this still gives rise to problem, hence:\n\n\nDyadic Deontic Logic:\n\nhas the classical logic with O(\\varphi_2 / \\varphi_1)\nframes are (W, \\preceq) where \\preceq represents ‚Äúbetterness‚Äù, hence we formalise the puzzle as:\n\n\n\nO(\\lnot k / \\bot), 2. O(g / k), 3. k\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n11. Deontic Logic II\n\nPaper: mining validity of reasoning by cases in deontic logic.\nMiner Puzzle: runs as follows:\n\n10 miners either all in shaft A or all in shaft B\nFlood is approaching, we can wither block shaft A or shaft B, consequences are:\n\nif we block the shaft with all miners, all survive\nif we block the shaft without miners, all die\nif we block none of the shaft, one dies\n\n\n\n\nTo get to the solution, we may consider the following reasoning:\n\nThe miners are in A or they are in B\nIf they are in A, then we ought to block A\nIf they are in B, then we ought to block B\n\n\nby cases it follows: we ought to block A or we ought to block B\n\n\nReactions could be:\n\nperhaps that is the right answer\nwe should reject one of the assumptions of the reasoning\nwe should reject the inference method: inference by cases\n\nthis is the path taken in the paper.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNon-Theorems of SDL:\n\nO \\varphi \\to \\varphi\nO(O \\varphi \\to \\varphi)\n\n\nExtension: SDL+, we add the axiom O(O \\varphi \\to \\varphi)\n\nthe correspondence of the axiom is secondary reflexivity \\forall_w \\forall_v (w R v \\to v R v)\n\n\n\n12. STIT Logic\n\nSeeing To It That: an agent i sees to it that \\varphi, i.e. an action of i can guarantee that \\varphi.\n\nAbl_i \\varphi reads: ‚Äúagent i is able to see to it that \\varphi‚Äù\n\n\nthis logic requires branching time frames, both acting and not acting must be considered. No probabilities or intentions are considered.\n\nBranching Time Frames \\langle T, &lt; \\rangle\n\nT is a set of moments\n&lt; is a tree-like ordering on T, i.e. s.t.:\n\n&lt; irreflexive\n&lt; transitive\n&lt; s.t. \\forall_{x, y z}((y &lt; x \\land z&lt;x) \\to (y&lt;z \\lor z&lt;y \\lor \\le y)) (Past-Linearity)\n\n\nHistory = maximal chain\nH_m = set of histories passing through the moment m\n\n\n\n\nSTIT Logic: is \\mathcal{L}_T (temporal logic) with [i-stit] \\varphi ‚Äúthe agent i sees to it that \\varphi‚Äú.\n\nFrames: \\mathcal{F} = (T, &lt;, Agent, Choice)\n\nT a set of moments\n&lt; irrefl., trans., past-lin.\nAgent a set of agents\nChoice is a function mapping each agent i and moment m into a disj. partition of H_m\nWrite Choice^m_i(h) to indicate the set of histories h belonging to the same equivalence class of h.\n\nNo choice between undivided histories (different choice bring to different histories)\nIndependence of agents:\n\n\n\n\nModels &amp; Semantics: \\mathcal{M}, m/h \\models [i -stit]\\varphi iff for all h&#039; \\in Choice^m_i(h), \\mathcal{M}, m/h&#039; \\models \\varphi.\n\n[i-stit] is an S5 operator\nAbility: Abl_i \\varphi := \\lozenge [i-stit] \\varphi\n\nAbl_i \\varphi \\to \\varphi, \\varphi \\to Abl_i \\varphi, Abl_i \\top, distributives and inverse for \\land\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n13. Epistemic Logic\n\nTo the classical language we add K\\varphi, the agent knows \\varphi\nEpistemic Model: (W, R_K, V) where R_K is an eq. relation (minimally refl.) and reads as ‚Äúepistemic equivalence‚Äù.\n\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models K \\varphi iff for all v: if w R_K v then \\mathcal{M}, v \\models \\varphi,\n\nits dual is L \\varphi ‚Äúthe agent considers possible that \\varphi‚Äù\nit‚Äôs Syntax is just like S5.\n\n\n\n\nMulti-Agent Epistemic Logic\n\nModels are (W, Agents, \\{R_K\\}_i, V), \\mathcal{M}, w \\models K_i \\varphi iff all v: if w R_{K_i}v then \\mathcal{M}, v \\models \\varphi.\nshared knowledge can be of nth-order up to common (n = \\omega), requires an infinite formula, i.e. not expressible\nDistributed knowledge (if they all share information) is not expressible, not with individual knowledge modalities.\n\n\nPositive Introspection K \\varphi \\to KK \\varphi\n\nArgument by Hintikka:\n\nwe know that if \\{K \\alpha, \\lnot K \\lnot \\beta\\} is consistent then \\{K \\alpha, \\beta\\} is consistent.\nassume that pos.intr. fails, i.e. \\{K \\varphi, \\lnot KK \\varphi\\} is consistent\nthen, for \\alpha = \\varphi and \\beta = \\lnot K \\varphi, we get that \\{K \\varphi, \\lnot K \\varphi\\} is consistent\n\n\n\n\n\n14. Dynamic Epistemic Logic\n\nKnowledge is not static, you change it constantly.\nPublic Announcement Logic.\n\nit handles the hard information, i.e. trustworthy, true and public.\n\\mathcal{L}_{PAL} adds the operator [! \\alpha] \\varphi for \\alpha \\in \\mathcal{L}_{EP}, the epistemic language.\nfor \\mathcal{M} = (W, Agents, \\{R_{K_i}\\}, V) a mutli-agent-Kripke model, then \\mathcal{M}_{|\\varphi} = (W_{|\\varphi}, Agents, \\{R_{K_{i_{|\\varphi}}}\\}, V_{|\\varphi}) defined intuitively.\n\n\\mathcal{M}_{|\\varphi} is the model restricted to the worlds where \\varphi holds.\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models [!\\alpha]\\varphi iff \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\lnot \\alpha or \\mathcal{M}_{| \\alpha}, w \\models \\varphi.\n\\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\langle !\\alpha \\rangle \\varphi iff \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\alpha and \\mathcal{M}_{| \\alpha}, w \\models \\varphi.\n\n\n\n\nAnnouncements don‚Äôt change facts on the world but change our knowledge on them\n\ni.e. truth of \\varphi may well change.\n\n[! \\alpha](\\varphi \\land \\psi) \\leftrightarrow ([! \\alpha] \\varphi \\land [!\\alpha]\\psi)\n[!\\alpha] \\lnot \\varphi \\leftrightarrow (\\alpha \\to \\lnot [! \\alpha] \\varphi)\n[! \\alpha]K_i \\varphi \\leftrightarrow (\\alpha \\to K_i (\\alpha \\to [! \\alpha] \\varphi))\n\n\nbut truth of p cannot.\n\n[! \\alpha]p \\leftrightarrow (\\alpha \\to p)\n\n\n\n\nfor each \\varphi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{PAL} exist \\varphi&#039; \\in \\mathcal{L}_{EP} s.t. \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi iff \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\varphi&#039; (Reduction Theorem)\n\nyou can get to this \\varphi&#039; by the four rules above\n\n\nThen PAL is normal modal logic S5 together with the four reduction axioms above.\nMoore-sentences, i.e. of the form p \\land \\lnot K_i p, are false if announced: [!(p \\land \\lnot K_ip)]\\lnot (p \\land \\lnot K_i p)\n\nsuch statements were in fact true before being pronounced and false the moment afterwards. There are in fact truths that cannot be known, the discussion of Gettier examples and JTB comes afterwards.\n\n\n\nExercises\n2. Truth\n2.1.\nDraw a Kripke Model \\mathcal{M} s.t. \\mathcal{M}, w \\not \\models (p \\to \\square q) \\leftrightarrow \\square (p \\to q). I need a world w where one of the two formulae is true and the other false. I need to have p \\to q true in all worlds connected, though I can have, for instance, \\lnot p in w and q true in all connected worlds. Consider for instance w \\longrightarrow v for v \\in V(p) while w \\not \\in V(p) and v, w\\in V(q), then we have \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\lnot (p \\to \\square q) since \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\lnot p and \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\square q and also \\mathcal{M}, w \\models \\square (p \\to q) since \\mathcal{M}, v \\models p \\to q and v is the only world connected to w.\n2.2.\nFollow a similar principle with more complex computations."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Modern-Philosophy-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Modern-Philosophy-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Philosophy/Modern Philosophy (Lecture).md","title":"Modern Philosophy (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Philosophy/Other-Works/Nonsense-in-a-Phenomenal-Subject"],"tags":[],"content":"Bacon\nGoal: to give foundations to the human knowledge\n\nChanges from the theoretical Aristotelean approach\nHe wants to see humanity united against the forces of nature (positivistic look?)\nNovum Organum (ne because not Aristotelic)\n\nBook 1: Man should conquer nature by understanding it.\n\nMethods: (i) anticipate nature, (ii) interpret nature,\nIdola Mentis: a study on the origin of human mistakes\n\nIdola Tribus: from the human nature\nIdola Spectus: from his own education, uses, personal tastes\nIdola Fori: from social context/role, social structure, language\nIdola Theatri: from dependence from philosophical systems\n\nempirical methods can repair\nmetaphor: three of knowledge, metaphysics, the root, is needed\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBook II: Investigation of form is the goal of sciences\n\n(ii) interpret nature: thanks to the experimental method:\n\n\n\nlist of pos. instances (should happen), 2. list of neg. inst. (shouldn‚Äôt happen, 3. list of the limits (might happen) 4. induction (search for general laws from elimination of neg. inst.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDescartes\n\nPrima Philosophia (Metaphysics for Aristotle), proof of God and of the soul.\nI. Meditation: hyperbolic doubt\n\nDoubts:\n\nDoubt the senses correspond to the object (optical illusion)\nDoubt the there are some objects outside (dreamer-argument)\nDoubt that words represent objects correctly (does a square have fours sides?)\nDoubt that words are in an objective order (gen. mal.: there are no squares!)\n\n\nCharacters of Doubt:\ngeneral, methodological, theoretical, hyperbolical, constructive function\nConsequences for sciences: doubt complex empirical principles, save arithmetics, geometry and analytical statements\nI might deceive myself believing the opposite of what it is. I must suppose there is a genius malignus for doing Prima Philosophia.\n\n\nII. Meditation: the Archimedean point: cogito argo sum\n\nsearch for the Archimedean point of the soul, the undoubtable\nThe genius malignus cannot make me believe that I am not\nI am no body, no perception, I am a thinking thing, res cogitans\nI doubt, hence I think, hence I am (same with dreaming)\nPhenomenal nature: wax example\n\nWe usually imagine the Noumenical cause of the phenomena\nI cannot doubt that I am, but I can doubt that the wax is\neach empirical perception is also self-perception (like Kant) wax example again\n\n\n\n\nIII. Meditation: on God, its existence\n\ncan we methodically expand our knowledge? At least beyond myself\nRule of truth: all that I perceive clear and distinctively is true (clare et distincte)\n\nsave Senses and Mathematics\nJustification for this rule? God\n\n\nProof of God: existence and essence of God\n\nTo start: neither ideas or wishes can be true or false but only judgements, there I can be mistaken\nIdeas are: (i) innate, from God, (ii) obtained ideas from either reason or (nature \\Rightarrow) mistakes, (iii) constructions (hyppogryphos, sirens)\n\nIdeas obtained by nature are mistaken,\n\nI am only used to those beliefs\nSun is both small (senses) and big (reason)\n\n\n\n\nDistinguish ideas on what they represent: something more objective cannot come from inside\nThere must be a cause, it must be God: cause of what has ‚Äúmore reality‚Äù, such ideas are:\n\nMaterial things, animals, other people, angles, myself, God\nOther than me and God, the rest might be result of myself only, though the idea of (i) myself and of  (ii) God necessitate a cause.\n\n(ii) I, as a finite being, cannot be the cause of the God‚Äôs idea I have clear in my mind.\n\n\\infty is not the negation of the finite, it comes first. More reality in \\infty than in finite.\n\n\n(i) I might be caused by: myself, my parents or God\n\nI can‚Äôt cause myslef or I would have no desire nor make any mistake\nmy parents cannot cause me as res cogitans only the extensa.\nhence: causa sui! he made me!\n\n\n(ii) where did God‚Äôs idea come? innate, God gave me it and the knowledge of myself\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIV. Meditation: on Mistakes\n\nOntological mistake: I think about something that is not God, thinking about finite can always mistake me\n\n‚ÄúI‚Äù entails both the God‚Äôs idea and the idea of nothing, hence we know finiteness\nA mistake is not something, it is the lack of something to get to God.\n\n\nEpistemological: I cannot make mistake as long as I use a good method.\n\nwrong relation between will and understanding, no wrong will, no wrong understanding\n\ndivinity of men‚Äôs will: unlimited\n\n\nFor the right use of Will:\n\nIf unclear \\implies hold judgement\nConsider: Understanding &lt; \\infty, will is \\infty.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nV. Meditation: on existence of the material things, a priori proof of God\n\nKnowledge of finite things: clare et distincte: geometry\nOntological proof of God: in its nature it must exist, it is clear and distinct, hence it must exist\n\nExistence of God is part of its essence, cannot be taken away like the valley from the mountain\n\n\nKnowledge of things depends on God, now that we have its description, we know it is not evil\n\n\nVI. Meditation: Existence of material things\n\nTriangle vs Thousend sides: conceive vs imagine\nimagination uses some perceptions which must come from our body\nbefore: I thought to have a body but hold that doubtable,\nnow: clare et distincte I know both res cogitans et res extensa\n\nalso: God is not deceiving me\n\n\nI perceive soul and body distictively and with no dependence:\n\nI can well imagine soul to survive without body\nI am no more than a sailor to his ship.\n\n\nSimilarly I perceive clare et distincte the outer things and God is no deceiver\nMistaken use of our possibilities\n\nI. I feel warm \\not \\Rightarrow there is a direct correspondence of the idea of warmth in the warm thing\nII. Take for nature only what comes from God\nIII. The idea of warmth does not come from warm things, but ‚Äúsomething‚Äù caused it (see I)\nIV.  We are used to invert the order (see III)\n\n\n\n\n\nI already had a course on this author, other reflection on his thought are present here: Nonsense in a Phenomenal Subject.\nSpinoza\n\nGeometrical method\n\nAxioms\n\n‚ÄúAll that is either in itself or in something else‚Äù\n‚ÄúAll that is not defined with other words, must be defined in itself‚Äù\n‚ÄúFrom a given cause a consequence follows necessarily; also if there is no cause then the consequence cannot follow‚Äù\n\n\nContent of the Ethics:\n\nCritique to the Cartesian dualism\n\nDescartes: res cogitans or res extensa, carrier of properties, causally independent.\nOnly one substance with two attributes: thought and extension.\n\n\nS.: Substantia est causa sui, there‚Äôs only one and it is God, Deus sive Natura (panthesim)\n\nNatura naturata: God as a free cause &amp; Natura naturans: caused nature\nGod‚Äôs will is a necessity, we are ‚Äúfinitely free‚Äù following God‚Äôs will\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHobbes\nI already had a course on this author and won‚Äôt take notes here.\nLocke\n\nCritique of the innate ideas\n\nProof of the Tabula Rasa thesis\nboth in the practical and theoretical sense, there are no such ideas.\n\n\nThe origin of ideas\n\nInner and external perception: reflections and sensations, there are no others\nSimple and complex perception:\n\nSimple: atoms of meaning, clear and simple\nComplex: compare, connect simple ideas\n\nOrigin from simple ideas: (i) Combination, (ii) Comparison, (iii) Abstraction\nClasses:\n\n(i) Modi: not made by themselves (triangle, thinkable, mord)\n(ii) Substances: made by themselves, collection of simple things (Army, many sheeps)\n(iii) Relations: comparisons\n\nCausality, Identity (general or personal)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nProblems:\n\nTabula Rasa cannot be proved empirically\n\n\n\n\nPrimary and secondary properties:\n\nPrimary: inseparable from the object, ‚Äúnecessary‚Äù\n\nSimple ideas of primary properties := Real\nEx. Size, number, place, motion\n\n\nSecondary: that we cannot perceive directly\n\nComplex ideas, not to trust\n\n\nProblems:\n\nValue the subject but still talk about Eigen-schaften\nBerkley and Hume don‚Äôt agree with the distinction\n\n\n\n\nTheory of personal Identity\n\nConscience: what you refer with ‚Äúmyself‚Äù, rational thing\nProblems:\n\nno continuous conscience (sleep), you may not remember who you were,\n\n\n\n\nWhat is knowledge?: collection of ideas, the rest is just perception\n\nIntuitive: white is white, analytic thoughts, highest degree of certainty\nDemonstrative: sameness or distinction of ideas, mistake is possible\nSensitive: Knowledge of bodies outside us, lowest degree of certainty\n\n\n\nHume\n\nDifferences of forms of perception\n\nImpressions: more vivid, Urbild\nIdeas: less vivid (contrary to Desc. clare et distincte), limited and dependent, Abbild, also imagination\n\nPrinciple of connection of ideas, three ways to construct new ideas\n\n(i) similitude, (ii) contact in space-time, (iii) cause and consequence\n\n\n\n\nRational determination of truth\n\nA priori truth: rule of no contradiction\nA posteriori (matters of fact), probable truth, weaker certainty\n\nAll of those involve Causality (like rule of no contr. for a priori truth), habit\n\nonly habit: (i) take an unknown obj., (ii) take Adam and ask him where the ball will go\n\nexperience the past to ‚Äúbet‚Äù on the future, assume continuity\nno contradiction in discontinuity ‚Äúthe sun might not rise tomorrow‚Äù.\n\n\n\n\nSceptical Solution: Principle of habit, reduce causality to habit and not rationality\n\ninductively, more habit brings to higher and justified degree of belief\nwe cannot recognise any rational necessity, they only seem connected\nImpression (Urbild): habit | Idea (Abbild): necessary connection\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFreedom and Necessity are compatible\n\nAny necessity comes from habit\nSimilar behaviour of men of all times and nations, such a uniformity is unseen in nature\n\n\nOn Rationality of Animals: no radical difference\n\nRationality is men‚Äôs instinct\n\n\nCritique of Substance\n\nSubstance and accidents can be distinguished in two ways\n\ntrough senses: no one would say substance to have a colour or a tone\n\n\nIt could else be: a (necessary) connection of properties\n\nCritique to the res cogitans (thinking substance)\n\nevery impression comes from perception, we have none on the ‚ÄúI‚Äù, if we had one, it should last the whole life, though there is non such constant perception.\nSolution: ‚ÄúI‚Äù denotes a collection of perceptions, ‚ÄúI‚Äù is a sort of theater on which the single perceptions take place, there is no unity nor identity of the ‚ÄúI‚Äù.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nKant\n\nThe Copernican Turn\n\nFocus on the subject, let‚Äôs forget about the objects\nObjects are shaped by our forms of perception\n\n\nIntroduction\n\nAll our knowledge comes from experience but not all our knowledge is on experience (can be on us)\na priori: pure knowledge, independent for experience (bodies are extended)\n\nstrong generality: properties of those rules without exceptions in our perceptions\n\n\na posteriori: empirical knowledge, only thanks to experience\n\nweak generality\n\n\nMetaphysics Q: S. 24-27\n\nThe dogmatic metaphysics: not falsifiable and a priori\n\n\nAnalytic: all bodies have extension (in the definition)\n\nAnalytic \\Rightarrow a priori (no anal. a post., you know the definition in advance)\n\n\nSynthetic: all bodies have weight (that is not in the definition of bodies)\n\nSynthetic a posteriori: empirical judgements\nSyn.pr.: All has a cause, math (expand our knowledge and do not need experience) unfalsifiable\n\nMetaphys. is syn.pr.: the world must have a beginning\nMathematics too\nScience has some: quantity of matter is constant (necessary (\\Rightarrow a priori) and clearly syn.)\n\n\n\n\nHow are syn.pr. possible? (Hume grounded all on caus. and believed it not necessary hence not a pr.)\n\nHow are math and natural sciences possible?\n\nThose are real, no questioning whether they exist.\n\n\nHow is metaphysics as a science possible?\n\nmetaphysica naturalis is real, though not as a science, a popular speculation\npure reason has the goal to decide whether we can or not answer questions and if yes, answ.\n\n(i) make judgements, (ii) set limits to our knowledge\ntranscendental: on how we perceive things, not on things in an a priori way\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTranscendental idealism: the distinction of Noumenon and Phenomena, must find the limits of reason\n\nNone can be said on the Noumenon, it is the limit of our experience and reason.\n\nDoes it exist? We are not able to say that.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTranscendental Esthetics: determine the forms of perception, give foundations to mathematics\n\nTwo a priori (pure) forms of perception of the pure perception Subjecktive Bedingungen:\n\nSpace\n\neach imagination of things outside or close requires space\nyou can imagine a void space but not without space\neach single space must be part of the infinite total space\nspace is imagined as infinite, you cannot imagine to be at the border of space (antique arg.)\n\n\nTime\n\nAny sort of order requires time, we cannot imagine to be without time, it is infinite\n\n\n(Subj Moment) it is not per se necessary and general, (Obj. Moment) though they are for us\nAgainst emp. (Locke): experience requires space and time, those cannot come from it.\nAgainst objectivistic vision (Newton): There are no space and time without matter and events\n\n\n\n\nTranscendental Logic: investigates the origin, the extension and objective validity.\n\nGedanken ohne Inhalt sind leer, Anschauungen ohne Begriffe sind blind\nTranscendental Analytic: forms a priori of understanding (Verstand)\n\nAnalytik der Begriffe: concepts are functions (active) which order or unify rapresentations.\n\ne.g. body contains metal., concepts can be pure or coming from experience:\n\npure concepts = categories\na judgement is a category applied to an experience.\nquantity, quality, relation and modality\n\n\nEsthetic: multipl. of perc. always is in space and time\nAnal. of conc.: mutipl. of concepts always in categories\nTranscendental Deduction: hardest problem: justification of the categories\n\n(a) each thought requires the ‚Äúich denke‚Äù, (b) the ‚Äúich denke‚Äù uses categories, (c) all thoughts use categories\nphenomena are ruled by the a priori form of our intellect.\n\n\n\n\nAnalytic der Grunds√§tze: on the highest principles of all synthetic judgements\n\nthis highest principle is: there must be a synthetical unit of the multiplicity of perception\nsynth. a pr. are possible when it is both prior to experience and shows a synthetic unit of a transcendental apperception.\ntable of principles\n\n\n\n\nTranscendental Dialectic: analysis of the pure forms a priori of the reason (Vernunft)\n\nReason want to go beyond the phenomena, what we cannot know\nIt is an necessary ambition to examine those ideas which we cannot know\nIn general the mistake is to apply forms a priori to other forms a priori instead of experience\nWe can in fact think about those ideas, but we cannot know them\nDialectic in the sophistic sense, rhetorical, no actual content.\nThe three ideas of reason are:\n\nSoul: unity of all interiori perceptions, this is the ich denke applied to itself (rational psych.)\n\nOne in fact applies the category of substance to the ich denke (paralogism)\n\n\nWorld: unity of all exterior perceptions, (rational cosmology)\n\nwe will never have all perceptions, there is nothing I can say on it (antinomy)\n\n\nGod: (rational theology, error: ideal of pure reason)\n\nOntological (Anselm, Desc): existence must derive from experience, no proof\n\nperfect in thought is not like perfect in reality (100euros example)\n\n\nCosmological (Thomas, Arist.): causal chain is emp., cannot prove metaphy. beings\nPhysical: all happens for God‚Äôs Reason: order is emp. not metaphy.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Political-Philosophy-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Political-Philosophy-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active Marra I submit the linked essay together with What a Logic Could not Be\nThe essay is available at: Overleaf.\nAbstract\nAfter some observations on the application of Tarskian Semantic to empirical statements, I argue for the equality of the interpretational and representational account. I start by showing an intuitive way to apply Tarskian Semantics to empirical statements by using some arguments in the Philosophy of Science, I then show how Tarskian Semantics requires a weak form of scientific structuralism. Finally I conclude by showing how scientific structuralism does not allow a proper distinction of interpretational and representational account.\nRelated pages:\n\nHorsten, L. (2010), Having an Interpretation\nStructuralism\nPhilosophy First Thesis Concept\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/What-a-Logic-Could-not-Be":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/What-a-Logic-Could-not-Be","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/3rd Semester/Philosophy/What a Logic Could not Be.md","title":"What a Logic Could not Be","links":["Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/4th-Semester","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/LMU-Munich","Academia/Active--and--Works/Master/5th-Semester/Philosophy-of-Logic-(Lecture)","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/The-Silent-Assumption-in-Tarskian-Semantics","Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Authors/Hans-Halvorson/Hans-Halvorson","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/4th-Semester/Questions--and--Other-Works/First-Thesis-Concept/Philosophy-First-Thesis-Concept/Structuralism","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/3rd-Semester/Philosophy/Structure-on-Models"],"tags":[],"content":"I followed a course in Philosophy of Logic by Dr. Alessandra Marra during my 4th Semester at the LMU Munich. I followed then an analogous Philosophy of Logic (Lecture). I submit the linked essay together with The Silent Assumption in Tarskian Semantics.\nThe essay is available at: Overleaf.\nRelated Pages\n\nThe Silent Assumption in Tarskian Semantics\nHans Halvorson\nStructuralism\nStructure on Models\n"},"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Documentation-on-Property/Certificato-di-Destinazione-d'Uso-Terreni-Chiappella":{"slug":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Documentation-on-Property/Certificato-di-Destinazione-d'Uso-Terreni-Chiappella","filePath":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Documentation on Property/Certificato di Destinazione d'Uso Terreni Chiappella.md","title":"Certificato di Destinazione d'Uso Terreni Chiappella","links":["Ville-Chiappella","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Casa-del-Noce","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Casa-del-Forno","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Terreni-oltre-Torrente","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Terreni-alla-Fonte","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Terreni-Lungotorrente"],"tags":[],"content":"‚ÄîEnglish below‚Äî\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nQuesta pagina analizza il Certificato di Destinazione Urbanistica (CDU), un documento ufficiale rilasciato dal Comune di Cairo Montenotte. Il CDU √® fondamentale in quanto certifica le normative urbanistiche (cosa si pu√≤ costruire, con quali indici, ecc.) e i vincoli (paesaggistici, idrogeologici) che si applicano ai terreni di propriet√† di Ville Chiappella. Questo riassunto esclude tutti i dati personali e si concentra esclusivamente sui dettagli tecnici dei terreni.\n\n\n\nCos‚Äô√® un Certificato di Destinazione Urbanistica (CDU)?\nIl CDU (Certificato di Destinazione Urbanistica) √® un documento ufficiale, previsto dal D.P.R. 380/2001, che specifica le prescrizioni urbanistiche di un‚Äôarea secondo gli strumenti di pianificazione vigenti (come il Piano Regolatore Generale - P.R.G.).\nIn molti casi, i confini delle zone urbanistiche non coincidono perfettamente con i confini catastali delle particelle. Per questo, nel certificato si trova spesso la dicitura ‚Äú(parte)‚Äú.\nL‚Äôimmagine seguente, estratta dal Geoportale, mostra un chiaro esempio di questa divisione. La particella 522 √® divisa in due zone: la parte superiore (rosa) √® in zona Bp 4 (Residenziale), mentre la parte inferiore (verde) √® in zona E (Agricola).\n\nA. Piano Regolatore Generale (P.R.G.)\nIl P.R.G. classifica i terreni nelle seguenti zone:\n1. Zona Bp 4 (Residenziale)\n\nParcelle Interessate: Foglio 29, Mappali 522 (parte), 525, 531 (parte), 532 (parte).\nPagine Correlate: Casa del Noce (per mapp. 522) e Casa del Forno (per mapp. 525, 531, 532).\nDettagli:\n\nZona Omogenea (ex DM 2/4/1968): B\nIndice di edificabilit√† fondiaria per residenza: If = 0,4~mc/mq\nNorme di Riferimento: Art. 37 Norme Generali\n\n\n\n2. Zona E (Agricola)\n\nParcelle Interessate: Foglio 29, Mappali 522 (parte), 531 (parte), 532 (parte); Foglio 46, Mappali 104, 105, 200 (parte).\nPagine Correlate: Casa del Noce (mapp. 522), Casa del Forno (mapp. 531, 532), Terreni oltre Torrente (mapp. 104, 105), Terreni alla Fonte (mapp. 200).\nDettagli:\n\nZona Omogenea: E\nIndice di edificabilit√† fondiaria per residenza: If = 0,03~mc/mq\nNota Importante: L‚Äôedificazione a fini residenziali √® esclusa negli ambiti soggetti al regime ANI-MA e ANI-CE del P.T.C.P. (vedi Sezione B).\nIndice di utilizzazione fondiaria per fabbricati agricoli: Uf = 0.03~mq/mq\nNorme di Riferimento: Art. 40 Norme Generali\n\n\n\n3. Zona Ebo (Agricola boscata)\n\nParcelle Interessate: Foglio 45, Mappali 217, 251, 45; Foglio 46, Mappale 200 (parte).\nPagine Correlate: Terreni Lungotorrente (mapp. 217, 251, 45), Terreni alla Fonte (mapp. 200).\nDettagli:\n\nZona Omogenea: E\nIndice di utilizzazione fondiaria per fabbricati agricoli: Uf = 0.01~mq/mq\nNorme di Riferimento: Art. 40 Norme Generali\n\n\n\nB. Piano Territoriale di Coordinamento Paesistico (P.T.C.P.)\nIl piano paesaggistico impone i seguenti vincoli di assetto:\n\nZona IS-MO-B (Assetto Insediativo)\n\nParcelle Interessate: Foglio 29, Mappali 522, 525, 531, 532.\nPagine Correlate: Casa del Noce, Casa del Forno.\n\n\nZona ANI-MA (Assetto Insediativo)\n\nParcelle Interessate: Foglio 45, Mappali 217 (parte), 251, 45; Foglio 46, Mappali 104, 105, 200.\nPagine Correlate: Terreni Lungotorrente, Terreni oltre Torrente, Terreni alla Fonte.\n\n\nZona IS-MA (Assetto Insediativo)\n\nParcelle Interessate: Foglio 45, Mappale 217 (parte).\nPagina Correlata: Terreni Lungotorrente.\n\n\n\nC. Altri Vincoli e Informazioni\n\nRischio Idrogeologico (P.R.G.):\n\n(Fs) Frane stabilizzate (pericolosit√† media o moderata): Identificate su Foglio 29, Mappali 531 (parte) e 532 (parte), e Foglio 46, Mappale 200 (parte).\n\n\nVincolo Incendi:\n\nSi certifica che le aree in questione non sono inserite nell‚Äôelenco definitivo delle aree percorse dal fuoco (L. 353/2000).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nThis page analyzes the Urban Destination Certificate (CDU), an official document issued by the Municipality of Cairo Montenotte. The CDU is fundamental as it certifies the urban planning regulations (what can be built, with what indices, etc.) and constraints (landscape, hydrogeological) that apply to the lands owned by Ville Chiappella. This summary excludes all personal data and focuses solely on the technical details of the land parcels.\n\n\n\nWhat is an Urban Destination Certificate (CDU)?\nThe CDU (Certificato di Destinazione Urbanistica) is an official document, required by D.P.R. 380/2001, which specifies the urban planning prescriptions for an area according to the current planning instruments (like the General Town Plan - P.R.G.).\nIn many cases, the boundaries of urban zones do not perfectly align with the cadastral boundaries of the parcels. For this reason, the certificate often uses the note ‚Äú(part)‚Äù (‚Äúparte‚Äù).\nThe image below, from the Geoportal, shows a clear example of this division. Parcel 522 is split into two zones: the upper part (pink) is in zone Bp 4 (Residential), while the lower part (green) is in zone E (Agricultural).\n\nA. General Town Plan (P.R.G.)\nThe P.R.G. (Piano Regolatore Generale) classifies the land into the following zones:\n1. Zone Bp 4 (Residential)\n\nAffected Parcels: Sheet 29, Parcels 522 (part), 525, 531 (part), 532 (part).\nRelated Pages: Casa del Noce (for parcel 522) and Casa del Forno (for parcels 525, 531, 532).\nDetails:\n\nHomogeneous Zone (ex DM 2/4/1968): B\nLand building index for residence: If = 0.4~m^3/m^2\nReference Norms: Art. 37 General Norms\n\n\n\n2. Zone E (Agricultural)\n\nAffected Parcels: Sheet 29, Parcels 522 (part), 531 (part), 532 (part); Sheet 46, Parcels 104, 105, 200 (part).\nRelated Pages: Casa del Noce (parcel 522), Casa del Forno (parcels 531, 532), Terreni oltre Torrente (parcels 104, 105), Terreni alla Fonte (parcel 200).\nDetails:\n\nHomogeneous Zone: E\nLand building index for residence: If = 0.03~m^3/m^2\nImportant Note: Residential construction is excluded in areas subject to the ANI-MA and ANI-CE regime of the P.T.C.P. (see Section B).\nLand use index for agricultural buildings: Uf = 0.03~m^2/m^2\nReference Norms: Art. 40 General Norms\n\n\n\n3. Zone Ebo (Wooded Agricultural)\n\nAffected Parcels: Sheet 45, Parcels 217, 251, 45; Sheet 46, Parcel 200 (part).\nRelated Pages: Terreni Lungotorrente (parcels 217, 251, 45), Terreni alla Fonte (parcel 200).\nDetails:\n\nHomogeneous Zone: E\nLand use index for agricultural buildings: Uf = 0.01~m^2/m^2\nReference Norms: Art. 40 General Norms\n\n\n\nB. Landscape Constraints (P.T.C.P.)\nThe landscape plan imposes the following asset constraints:\n\nZone IS-MO-B (Settlement Asset)\n\nAffected Parcels: Sheet 29, Parcels 522, 525, 531, 532.\nRelated Pages: Casa del Noce, Casa del Forno.\n\n\nZone ANI-MA (Settlement Asset)\n\nAffected Parcels: Sheet 45, Parcels 217 (part), 251, 45; Sheet 46, Parcels 104, 105, 200.\nRelated Pages: Terreni Lungotorrente, Terreni oltre Torrente, Terreni alla Fonte.\n\n\nZone IS-MA (Settlement Asset)\n\nAffected Parcels: Sheet 45, Parcel 217 (part).\nRelated Page: Terreni Lungotorrente.\n\n\n\nC.          \n\n\nLa Perizia Giurata √® un documento tecnico fondamentale che attesta la conformit√† urbanistica e catastale degli immobili e ne stabilisce il valore ufficiale ai fini fiscali.\n\n\n\nScopo della Perizia\nQuesta perizia √® stata redatta per due scopi principali:\n\nAttestazione di Conformit√†: Certifica che lo stato di fatto degli immobili corrisponde pienamente alle planimetrie catastali e ai titoli edilizi depositati, garantendo la legittimit√† della vendita.\nBase Imponibile Fiscale: Stabilisce il valore minimo su cui calcolare le imposte di registro (prezzo-valore), proteggendo l‚Äôacquirente da futuri accertamenti di valore da parte dell‚ÄôAgenzia delle Entrate.\n\nValori di Stima\nLa perizia ha determinato i seguenti valori, che sono stati strada.\n"},"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Potential/Casa-del-Caco":{"slug":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Potential/Casa-del-Caco","filePath":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Potential/Casa del Caco.md","title":"Casa del Caco","links":["Ville-Chiappella","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Casa-del-Noce"],"tags":[],"content":"‚Äî Italiano sotto ‚Äî\nThis document provides a preliminary overview of ‚ÄúCasa del Caco,‚Äù the least known and worst-condition property within the Ville Chiappella portfolio. It is important to note that this property has a different ownership compared to the other main properties.\nProperty Identification:\nThe main building is identified in the land registry at Foglio 29, mappale 523.\n\nCurrent Condition and Potential:\nThe building is currently in very poor condition and requires a complete and significant renovation. The roof, in particular, needs to be entirely rebuilt. However, a major asset is a fully approved renovation project, the details of which will be examined in due course.\nLand and Pertinences:\nThis property does not include any of the appurtenant lands that are part of the other main acquisition. Instead, it comes with the ownership of land plot 515, which is a pertinence of Casa del Noce.\nAcquisition Method:\nThe presumed acquisition method for this property will be through a mortgage assumption (accollamento del mutuo).\nFurther updates regarding this property will be provided as they become available.\n\nQuesto documento fornisce una panoramica preliminare della ‚ÄúCasa del Caco‚Äù, la propriet√† meno nota e in condizioni peggiori all‚Äôinterno del portafoglio di Ville Chiappella. √à importante sottolineare che questo immobile ha una propriet√† diversa rispetto alle altre principali.\nIdentificazione Catastale:\nL‚Äôedificio principale √® identificato al catasto al Foglio 29, mappale 523.\n\nStato di Fatto e Potenziale:\nL‚Äôedificio versa attualmente in pessime condizioni e necessita di un intervento di ristrutturazione completo e significativo. Il tetto, in particolare, deve essere interamente rifatto. Tuttavia, un punto di grande valore √® la presenza di un progetto di ristrutturazione gi√† approvato, i cui dettagli verranno presi in esame.\nTerreni e Pertinenze:\nQuesto immobile non viene con alcuno dei terreni pertinenti che si otterrebbero tramite l‚Äôaltra operazione di acquisto per le altre case. Viene invece ceduto con la propriet√† del terreno 515, di pertinenza alla Casa del Noce.\nModalit√† di Acquisto:\nSi presume di procedere all‚Äôacquisto di questo immobile tramite accollamento del mutuo.\nAggiornamenti futuri riguardo questa propriet√† saranno forniti non appena disponibili."},"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Renovation/Doors/Doors-Renovation":{"slug":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Renovation/Doors/Doors-Renovation","filePath":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Renovation/Doors/Doors Renovation.md","title":"Doors Renovation","links":["Ville-Chiappella","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Renovation/Safety/Safety","ColivingLiguria/People/Team/Software/Software-Team","ColivingLiguria/People/Team/Architecture/Architecture-Team","ColivingLiguria/People/Team/Construction/Construction-Team"],"tags":[],"content":"‚Äî Italiano sotto ‚Äî\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nThis document outlines a plan for a major internal renovation project: the in-house design and manufacturing of all new doors for Ville Chiappella. This is envisioned as a long-term, low-risk, and high-impact project suitable for volunteers and residents. The core idea is to combine simple woodwork (for the door slab) with 3D-printed components (for handles and latch mechanisms) to dramatically reduce costs and create custom, high-quality fittings.\n\n\n\n1. Why Focus on Doors?\nDoors are a critical component of any home, and in our project, they serve several functions beyond just closing a room:\n\nTactile Experience: The handle of a door is one of the most frequently touched objects in a house. We want this to be a high-quality, pleasant experience.\nThermal Insulation: Well-fitted doors with proper gaskets (seals) are essential for maintaining room temperature and saving on heating costs.\nSound Insulation: To make shared living comfortable for all residents (especially remote workers), good acoustic insulation between rooms is non-negotiable.\nGeneral Safety: Doors provide privacy and a sense of security. While our overall approach to security is community-based (see Safety), functional, lockable doors are a basic need.\n\n2. The Problem &amp; The Opportunity\nThe Problem: The existing doors in the houses are either missing, broken, or too old to be functional. They all need to be thrown away and replaced.\nThe Opportunity: Buying new, high-quality doors for an entire complex is extremely expensive. However, manufacturing doors is a feasible in-house project.\n\nIt is a low-risk activity (primarily woodworking and 3D printing).\nIt is time-intensive, making it a perfect long-term project for dedicated volunteers.\nIt is a fun, creative process that combines digital design with hands-on manufacturing.\n\n3. Project Scope: Internal vs. External Doors\nThis plan makes a clear distinction between two types of doors:\n\nExternal Doors: These have high-security and weather-proofing requirements. This project does not cover external doors for now, which will be part of a more elaborate, security-focused plan.\nInternal Doors: These are the primary focus of this project. The goal is to replace every single door between rooms, bathrooms, and corridors.\n\n4. The Manufacturing Plan (Internal Doors)\nThe core of the project is to break the door down into manageable components, manufacturing each one ourselves.\n\n\n1. The Digital Design (Fusion 360):\n\nA detailed, parameter-based 3D model of a complete door system (slab, frame, handle, latch) will be designed in Fusion 360.\nThis digital model will serve as the master blueprint for all parts.\n\n\n\n2. The Door Slab (Woodworking):\n\nTo keep costs minimal and manufacturing simple, the main body of the door (the slab) will be constructed from a single, complete layer of quality wood.\nThis will be a straightforward woodworking task: cutting the slab to size, routing edges, and creating pockets for the 3D-printed latch mechanism.\n\n\n\n3. The Handle &amp; Latch (3D Printing):\n\nThe entire mechanism‚Äîthe handle, the internal latch, the lock (if any), and the faceplates‚Äîwill be 3D printed.\nThis allows for full customisation, rapid production, and near-zero cost compared to buying dozens of metal locksets.\n\n\n\n4. The Frame &amp; Gasket (Finishing):\n\nWe will also manufacture the door frames (the jambs that attach to the wall) ourselves.\nThis allows us to create a perfect fit and, most importantly, integrate a rubber gasket (seal) around the entire frame, ensuring excellent sound and thermal insulation.\n\n\n\n5. Team &amp; Collaboration\nThis is a multi-disciplinary project that requires close collaboration between several of our core teams:\n\nüë®‚Äçüíª Software Team: Will be responsible for the technical 3D modeling, creating and managing the parametric Fusion 360 project files.\nüèõÔ∏è Design Team: The designers within our architecture team will lead the aesthetic and material choices. This includes selecting the wood, the paint colours, and designing the ergonomic and visual shape of the 3D-printed handles.\nüõ†Ô∏è Construction Team: Will oversee the hands-on physical manufacturing, from woodworking to assembly, and provide practical feedback on the design‚Äôs ‚Äúmanufacturability‚Äù and durability.\n\n6. Project Goals &amp; Benefits\nBy taking this in-house approach, we aim to:\n\nDrastically Reduce Costs: Avoid the massive expense of purchasing 20-30+ new, pre-made doors.\nEnsure High Quality: If we do it well, we can produce a final product that is of higher quality (especially in terms of sound/thermal insulation) than a cheap commercial door.\nCreate a Scalable Model: This project will serve as a template for a future, more complex project for manufacturing our own external doors.\n\n\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nQuesto documento delinea un piano per un importante progetto di ristrutturazione interna: la progettazione e la produzione interna di tutte le nuove porte per Ville Chiappella. Si tratta di un progetto a lungo termine, a basso rischio e ad alto impatto, adatto a volontari e residenti. L‚Äôidea centrale √® quella di combinare la semplice falegnameria (per il pannello porta) con componenti stampati in 3D (per maniglie e meccanismi di chiusura) per ridurre drasticamente i costi e creare accessori personalizzati e di alta qualit√†.\n\n\n\n1. Perch√© Concentrarsi sulle Porte?\nLe porte sono un componente critico di ogni home, e nel nostro progetto svolgono diverse funzioni oltre alla semplice chiusura di una stanza:\n\nEsperienza Tattile: La maniglia di una porta √® uno degli oggetti pi√π toccati in una casa. Vogliamo che questa sia un‚Äôesperienza piacevole e di alta qualit√†.\nIsolamento Termico: Porte ben installate e dotate di adeguate guarnizioni sono essenziali per mantenere la temperatura della stanza e risparmiare sui costi di riscaldamento.\nIsolamento Acustico: Per rendere confortevole la vita in comune (specialmente per i lavoratori da remoto), un buon isolamento acustico tra le stanze non √® negoziabile.\nSicurezza Generale: Le porte offrono privacy e un senso di sicurezza. Sebbene il nostro approccio generale alla sicurezza sia basato sulla comunit√† (vedi Safety), porte funzionali e chiudibili a chiave sono una necessit√† di base.\n\n2. Il Problema e l‚ÄôOpportunit√†\nIl Problema: Le porte esistenti nelle case sono mancanti, rotte o troppo vecchie per essere funzionali. Devono essere tutte buttate e sostituite.\nL‚ÄôOpportunit√†: Acquistare porte nuove e di alta qualit√† per un intero complesso √® estremamente costoso. Tuttavia, la produzione di porte √® un progetto fattibile da realizzare internamente.\n\n√à un‚Äôattivit√† a basso rischio (principalmente falegnameria e stampa 3D).\nRichiede molto tempo, rendendolo un progetto a lungo termine perfetto per volontari dedicati.\n√à un processo creativo e divertente che combina la progettazione digitale con la produzione manuale.\n\n3. Scopo del Progetto: Porte Interne vs. Esterne\nQuesto piano fa una chiara distinzione tra due tipi di porte:\n\nPorte Esterne: Queste hanno requisiti elevati di sicurezza e resistenza alle intemperie. Questo progetto non copre per ora le porte esterne, che faranno parte di un piano pi√π elaborato e incentrato sulla sicurezza.\nPorte Interne: Sono l‚Äôobiettivo primario di questo progetto. L‚Äôobiettivo √® sostituire ogni singola porta tra stanze, bagni e corridoi.\n\n4. Il Piano di Produzione (Porte Interne)\nIl cuore del progetto √® scomporre la porta in componenti gestibili, producendo ognuno di essi internamente.\n\n\n1. Il Design Digitale (Fusion 360):\n\nUn modello 3D dettagliato e parametrico di un sistema porta completo (pannello, telaio, maniglia, serratura) sar√† progettato in Fusion 360.\nQuesto modello digitale servir√† come master blueprint per tutte le parti.\n\n\n\n2. Il Pannello Porta (Falegnameria):\n\nPer mantenere i costi minimi e la produzione semplice, il corpo principale della porta (il pannello) sar√† costruito da un singolo strato completo di legno di qualit√†.\nQuesto sar√† un semplice compito di falegnameria: tagliare il pannello a misura, fresare i bordi e creare le sedi per il meccanismo di chiusura stampato in 3D.\n\n\n\n3. La Maniglia e la Chiusura (Stampa 3D):\n\nL‚Äôintero meccanismo ‚Äî la maniglia, il meccanismo di chiusura interno, la serratura (se presente) e le placche ‚Äî sar√† stampato in 3D.\nQuesto permette una personalizzazione completa, una produzione rapida e un costo quasi nullo rispetto all‚Äôacquisto di dozzine di serrature in metallo.\n\n\n\n4. Il Telaio e la Guarnizione (Finitura):\n\nProdurremo internamente anche i telai delle porte (gli stipiti che si fissano al muro).\nQuesto ci permette di creare una corrispondenza perfetta e, cosa pi√π importante, di integrare una guarnizione in gomma lungo tutto il telaio, garantendo un eccellente isolamento acustico e termico.\n\n\n\n5. Team e Collaborazione\nQuesto √® un progetto multidisciplinare che richiede una stretta collaborazione tra diversi dei nostri team principali:\n\nüë®‚Äçüíª Software Team: Sar√† responsabile della modellazione 3D tecnica, creando e gestendo i file di progetto parametrici in Fusion 360.\nüèõÔ∏è design team: I designer all‚Äôinterno del nostro team di architettura guideranno le scelte estetiche e materiche. Ci√≤ include la selezione del legno, dei colori di verniciatura e la progettazione della forma ergonomica e visiva delle maniglie stampate in 3D.\nüõ†Ô∏è Construction Team: Supervisioner√† la produzione fisica e pratica, dalla falegnameria all‚Äôassemblaggio, e fornir√† feedback pratici sulla ‚Äúfattibilit√† costruttiva‚Äù e sulla durabilit√† del design.\n\n6. Obiettivi e Vantaggi del Progetto\nAdottando questo approccio ‚Äúin-house‚Äù, miriamo a:\n\nRidurre Drasticamente i Costi: Evitare l‚Äôenorme spesa di acquistare 20-30+ nuove porte prefabbricate.\nGarantire Alta Qualit√†: Se lavoriamo bene, possiamo produrre un prodotto finale di qualit√† superiore (specialmente in termini di isolamento acustico/termico) rispetto a una porta commerciale economica.\nCreare un Modello Scalabile: Questo progetto servir√† da modello per un futuro progetto, pi√π complesso, per la produzione delle nostre porte esterne.\n"},"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Renovation/Horse-Shelter/Horse-Shelter":{"slug":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Renovation/Horse-Shelter/Horse-Shelter","filePath":"ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Renovation/Horse Shelter/Horse Shelter.md","title":"Horse Shelter","links":["ColivingLiguria","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Terreni-oltre-Torrente","ColivingLiguria/System/Archive/Discarded-Plans/Normative-Detenzione-Equini","ColivingLiguria/Diary/2025/Pre-Start/November/Week-Before-Purchase","ColivingLiguria/People/Team/Construction/Construction-Team","ColivingLiguria/People/Team/Architecture/Architecture-Team","ColivingLiguria/Houses/Chiappella/Properties/Casa-del-Noce"],"tags":[],"content":"‚ÄîItaliano sotto‚Äî\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nThis page outlines the project to accommodate three horses at ColivingLiguria from the very beginning of operations. We are designing a dedicated facility on the Terreni oltre Torrente, verifying regulatory compliance (see Normative Detenzione Equini), and planning the construction of a high-tech, energy-autonomous stable. Final verification will take place on-site during the Week Before Purchase.\n\n\n\nThe Project: Horses at Coliving Liguria\nWe have established a contact with a horse owner who wishes to join our community immediately. To accommodate her three horses, we are developing a specific plan to ensure their well-being and legal compliance using our available land.\nLocation and Feasibility\nThe designated area is Terreni oltre Torrente (Particelle 104 &amp; 105), chosen for its flat terrain and proximity to water.\n\nSurface Area Verification: The total available area is 1,240 m¬≤. Based on regional standards (approx. 500 m¬≤ for the first horse + 200 m¬≤ for each additional one), the minimum requirement is 900 m¬≤. Our terrain is therefore sufficient to serve as a comfortable paddock.\n\nConstruction Potential &amp; Horse Capacity\nBased on the CDU 2025/102, the area is in Zone E (Agricultural) with a Land Utilization Index (Uf) of 0.03 mq/mq (covered surface per land surface).\nThis index dictates the maximum footprint (covered surface area) we can build, not the volume.\nScenario 1: Current Status (Particelle 104 + 105)\nThis is the land we currently own.\n\nParticella 104: 600 \\, \\text{m}^2 (06 are 00 ca)\nParticella 105: 640 \\, \\text{m}^2 (06 are 40 ca)\nTotal Land Area: 1,240 m¬≤\n\nBuilding Potential (Surface Area):\n\nMax Covered Surface (1240 \\times 0.03): 37.2 m¬≤\n\nCapacity Analysis:\n\n37.2 m¬≤ is sufficient for a shelter housing 3 horses (standard is ~9-12 m¬≤ per horse), though it will be compact.\nLegal Paddock Capacity: Up to 4 Horses based on land area.\n\nScenario 2: Expansion (Acquiring Particella 106)\nWe are evaluating the purchase of the adjacent Particella 106.\n\nParticella 106: 2,360 m¬≤ (23 are 60 ca)\nNew Total Land Area: 1,240 + 2,360 = \\mathbf{3,600 \\, \\text{m}^2}\n\nBuilding Potential (Expansion):\n\nMax Covered Surface (3600 \\times 0.03): 108 m¬≤\n\nCapacity Analysis:\n\n108 m¬≤ allows for a spacious, professional stable with ample storage and service areas.\nLegal Paddock Capacity: Up to 16 Horses.\n\nConstruction Plan: The Enclosed Smart Stable\nWe plan to construct a fully enclosed and insulated structure utilizing the allowable surface area.\n\nHeight: The maximum height is determined by the municipal PUC/PRG regulations, which we will verify. Assuming a standard agricultural height (e.g., 3-4 meters), we can create a comfortable volume within the allowable footprint.\nDesign: Materials and design will be defined by the Construction Team and Architecture Team.\nStructure: Enclosed for climate control, potentially with an additional external canopy (tettoia) if permitted outside the main index.\n\nTechnology &amp; Amenities:\n\nClimate Control: Insulated walls + Summer forced ventilation (fans).\nEnergy Autonomy: Solar panels + Battery storage.\nMonitoring: Cameras and thermometers connected via internet.\nAutomation: Water sensors.\n\nInfrastructure &amp; Logistics\n\nWater Supply: Electric pump drawing from the adjacent stream.\nConnections: Wired connection to the main house for Data (internet) and Power (grid feed-in).\nAccess: We will clear a path along the stream bank connecting to Particella 522 (garden of Casa del Noce).\n\nNext Steps: Regulatory Verification\nDuring the Week Before Purchase and subsequent planning phases, we will progressively update this page with precise rules on:\n\nHeight Limits: Confirming max height from the PRG/PUC.\nBuilding Type: Verifying specific constraints for constructing stables in Zone E.\nPermitting: Confirming the exact procedure for agricultural annexes.\n\n\n\n\n                  \n                  Abstract\n                  \n                \n\n\nQuesta pagina delinea il progetto per ospitare tre cavalli a ColivingLiguria fin dall‚Äôinizio delle operazioni. Stiamo progettando una struttura dedicata sui Terreni oltre Torrente, verificando la conformit√† normativa (vedi Normative Detenzione Equini) e pianificando la costruzione di una stalla ad alta tecnologia ed energeticamente autonoma. La verifica finale avverr√† in loco durante la Week Before Purchase.\n\n\n\nIl Progetto: Cavalli a Coliving Liguria\nAbbiamo stabilito un contatto con una proprietaria di cavalli che desidera unirsi alla nostra comunit√† immediatamente. Per ospitare i suoi tre cavalli, stiamo sviluppando un piano specifico per garantire il loro benessere e la conformit√† legale utilizzando i nostri terreni disponibili.\nPosizione e Fattibilit√†\nL‚Äôarea designata sono i Terreni oltre Torrente (Particelle 104 &amp; 105), scelti per la loro natura pianeggiante e la vicinanza all‚Äôacqua.\n\nVerifica Superficie: L‚Äôarea totale disponibile √® di 1.240 m¬≤. Basandosi sugli standard regionali (circa 500 m¬≤ per il primo cavallo + 200 m¬≤ per ogni aggiuntivo), il requisito minimo √® di 900 m¬≤. Il nostro terreno √® quindi sufficiente per fungere da comodo paddock.\n\nPotenzialit√† Costruttiva e Capacit√† Equina\nIn base al CDU 2025/102, l‚Äôarea ricade in Zona E (Agricola) con un Indice di Utilizzazione Fondiaria (Uf) di 0,03 mq/mq.\nQuesto indice determina la superficie coperta massima che possiamo edificare, non il volume.\nScenario 1: Stato Attuale (Particelle 104 + 105)\nQuesti sono i terreni attualmente di nostra propriet√†.\n\nParticella 104: 600 \\, \\text{m}^2 (06 are 00 ca)\nParticella 105: 640 \\, \\text{m}^2 (06 are 40 ca)\nSuperficie Totale Terreno: 1.240 m¬≤\n\nPotenziale Edificatorio (Superficie):\n\nSuperficie Coperta Max (1240 \\times 0,03): 37,2 m¬≤\n\nAnalisi Capacit√†:\n\n37,2 m¬≤ sono sufficienti per un rifugio che ospiti 3 cavalli (standard circa 9-12 m¬≤ per cavallo), anche se sar√† compatto.\nCapacit√† Legale Paddock: Fino a 4 Cavalli in base all‚Äôarea del terreno.\n\nScenario 2: Espansione (Acquisto Particella 106)\nStiamo valutando l‚Äôacquisto dell‚Äôadiacente Particella 106.\n\nParticella 106: 2.360 m¬≤ (23 are 60 ca)\nNuova Superficie Totale: 1.240 + 2.360 = \\mathbf{3.600 \\, \\text{m}^2}\n\nPotenziale Edificatorio (Espansione):\n\nSuperficie Coperta Max (3600 \\times 0,03): 108 m¬≤\n\nAnalisi Capacit√†:\n\n108 m¬≤ permettono una stalla spaziosa e professionale, con ampie aree di stoccaggio e servizio.\nCapacit√† Legale Paddock: Fino a 16 Cavalli.\n\nPiano di Costruzione: La Stalla Smart Chiusa\nPianifichiamo di costruire una struttura completamente chiusa e isolata utilizzando la superficie consentita.\n\nAltezza: L‚Äôaltezza massima √® determinata dai regolamenti comunali (PUC/PRG), che verificheremo. Assumendo un‚Äôaltezza agricola standard (es. 3-4 metri), possiamo creare un volume confortevole all‚Äôinterno dell‚Äôimpronta a terra consentita.\nDesign: Materiali e design saranno definiti dal Team di Costruzione e Team di Architettura.\nStruttura: Chiusa per il controllo climatico, potenzialmente con una tettoia esterna aggiuntiva se permessa al di fuori dell‚Äôindice principale.\n\nTecnologia e Servizi:\n\nControllo Climatico: Muri isolati + Ventilazione forzata estiva (ventole).\nAutonomia Energetica: Pannelli solari + Batterie.\nMonitoraggio: Telecamere e termometri connessi via internet.\nAutomazione: Sensori acqua.\n\nInfrastrutture e Logistica\n\nAcqua: Pompa elettrica dal torrente adiacente.\nConnessioni: Cavo verso la casa principale per Dati (internet) e Corrente (immissione in rete).\nAccesso: Puliremo un sentiero lungo il torrente collegato alla Particella 522 (giardino di Casa del Noce).\n\nProssimi Passi: Verifica Normativa\nDurante la Week Before Purchase e le fasi successive di pianificazione, aggiorneremo progressivamente questa pagina con regole precise su:\n\nLimiti di Altezza: Conferma dell‚Äôaltezza massima dal PRG/PUC.\nTipologia Edilizia:
