G and limit \\beta s.t. \\omega &lt; \\beta &lt; o[M] then (\\beta* is reg.*)_M \\rightarrow (\\beta is reg.)_{M[G]}.\n\n\nIf \\mathbb{P} preserves cf then \\mathbb{P} preserves cardinals.\n\n\nLemma 3. let I, J \\not = \\emptyset, \\mathbb{P} = Fn (I, J) is ccc iff J is countable.\nLemma 4. if \\mathbb{P} preserves card. and G is \\mathbb{P}-generic, then \\forall_{\\alpha, h &lt; o(M)} M \\models k = \\aleph_\\alpha iff M[G] \\models k = \\aleph_\\alpha.¬†\nTheorem: if \\mathbb{P} \\in M and (\\mathbb{P} is ccc)_{M} then \\mathbb{P} preserves cofinalities and hence preserves cardinals.\nLemma 5. let \\mathbb{P} \\in M, (\\mathbb{P} is ccc)_{M} and A, B \\in M, et G be \\mathbb{P}-generic over M and f \\in M[G] with f: A \\rightarrow B. Then there is F: A \\rightarrow \\mathcal{P}(B) s.t. F \\in M s.t. for all a \\in A, then f(a) \\in F(a).\nIt also holds that for each a \\in A, (F(a)is countable)_M\nDefinition: for an infinite cardinal k, a set J, we name col(k, J) the forcing poset \\mathbb{P} = \\{f: I \\rightarrow J | I \\subseteq k \\land |I| &lt; k \\}, \\le : = \\subseteq, \\mathbb{1} := \\emptyset.¬†\nProperties of this are:¬†\n\n\nin col(k, J) we find partial functions from k to J of size &lt;k\n\n\ncol(k, J) clearly is a forcing poset\n\n\nit is atomless if |J| \\ge 2\n\n\nit is not absolute for k &gt; \\omega\n\n\ncol(\\omega, J) = Fn(\\omega, J)\n\n\nSo for M a ctm and G a (col(k, J))_M-generic over M, f_G = \\bigcup\\{p| p \\in G\\} is a function with domain k and range J, then remember the argumetn for Fn(I, J).\nf_G \\in M_G so M[G] \\models |J| \\le |k|, we‚Äôll use col(\\omega_1, \\lambda) where (\\lambda = 2^{\\aleph_0})_M, M[G] \\models |\\lambda| \\le |(\\omega_1)_M| but \\lambda &gt; (\\omega_1)_M, so (\\omega_1)_M&lt; \\lambda so M[G] \\models |\\lambda| =|(\\omega_1)_M|. So, in order to prove M[G] \\models CH we now need to show (2^{\\aleph_0})_M = (2^{\\aleph_0})_{M[G]} and (\\omega_1)_M = (\\omega_1)_{M[G]}.\nDefinition: A poset \\mathbb{P} is &lt;k-closed iff every sequence \\langle p_\\gamma| \\gamma &lt; \\alpha \\rangle of lenght \\alpha &lt; k s.t. \\gamma \\le \\delta &lt; \\alpha, p_\\delta \\le p_\\gamma has a lower bound, i.e. \\exists_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}} \\forall_{\\gamma &lt; \\alpha}p \\le p_\\gamma.\nLemma: If k is regular col(k, J) is &lt;k-closed.\nProof. let \\langle p_\\gamma | \\gamma &lt; \\alpha \\rangle be as above, the conditions in the sequence are over all comparable, so p:= \\bigcup\\{p_\\gamma| \\gamma &lt; \\alpha\\} is a partial function. By regularity of k, p has size &lt;k, thus p \\in col(k, \\lambda), also p \\le p_\\gamma for each \\gamma &lt; \\alpha by def. \\square\nLemma: suppose (\\mathbb{P} is &lt;k-closed)_M, G is a generic, then every cardinal \\beta \\le k of M is a cardinal of M[G], i.e. for \\beta \\le k, (\\betais a cardinal)_M \\rightarrow (\\betais a cardinal)_{M[G]}, it preserves only cardinals smaller of a certain \\beta.\n13th Lecture\nDefinition: a poset \\mathbb{P} is &lt;k-closed iff every sequence \\langle p_\\gamma| \\gamma &lt; \\alpha \\rangle, of lenght \\alpha &lt; k s.t. \\gamma \\le \\delta &lt;\\alpha \\Rightarrow p_\\delta \\le p_\\gamma has a lower bound, i.e. \\exists_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}} \\forall_{\\gamma &lt; \\alpha}p \\le p_\\gamma.\nLemma 1. if k is regular, col(k, \\lambda) is &lt;k-closed\nLemma 2. suppose (\\mathbb{P} is &lt;k-closed)_M, G is \\mathbb{P}-gen. over M, let \\alpha&lt; k and f: \\alpha \\rightarrow \\beta s.t. f \\subset M[G], then f \\in M.\nCorollary: suppose (\\mathbb{P} is &lt;k-closed)_M, G a \\mathbb{P}-generic over M, then every cardinal \\beta \\le k of M (i.e.(\\beta is a cardinal)_M) is a cardinal of M[G].\nTheorem: Let M be a ctm of ZFC, (\\lambda = 2^{\\aleph_0})_M, (\\mathbb{P} = col (\\omega_1, \\lambda))_M and G a \\mathbb{P}-generic over M, then M[G] \\models CH.\nNote: this theorem brings us from a model of \\lnot CH (M) to a model where CH holds (M[G]). The reverse direction, namely from a model of CH to one of \\lnot CH can be done as preaviously shown by Fn(\\omega_2 \\times \\omega, 2).\nProof. let f_G = \\bigcup_G, we know f_G is a surjection form (\\omega_1)^M onto \\lambda (since we are in the poset col(\\lambda, \\omega_1)). As \\lambda \\ge (\\omega_1)^M and f_G \\in M[G], so M[G] \\models |(\\omega_1)^M| = \\lambda. By lemma 1. we know that (\\mathbb{P} is &lt;\\omega_1-closed)^M, so, by cor. (\\omega_1)^{M[G]}= (\\omega_1)^M. By lemma 2 we know that for every function f: \\omega \\rightarrow 2, s.t. f \\in M[G], f \\in M thus (^\\omega 2)^{M[G]} \\subseteq (^\\omega 2)^M \\subseteq (^\\omega 2)^{M[G]}, so (^\\omega 2)^{M[G]} = (^\\omega 2)^M. Hence in M[G] we have: 2^\\omega = |(^\\omega 2)^M| = |\\lambda | = |(\\omega_1)^M| = (\\omega_1)^{M[G]}, hence M[G] \\models 2^\\omega = \\omega_1 i.e. M[G] \\models CH.\n\n\nOn col(\\lambda, \\omega_1), take f_G:= \\bigcup_G: (\\omega_1)^M \\rightarrow \\lambda surj.\n\n\nSince we have f_G \\in M[G] and f_G is surj. and \\lambda \\ge (\\omega_1)^M, then M[G] \\models |(\\omega_1)^M = \\lambda.\n\n\nLemma 1: (\\mathbb{P} is &lt;\\omega_1-closed)^M, so, by cor: (\\omega_1)^{M[G]} = (\\omega_1)^M\n\n\nLemma 2: \\forall_{f: \\omega \\rightarrow 2}f \\in M[G] \\rightarrow f \\in M, hence (2^\\omega)^{M[G]} = (2^\\omega)^M\n\n\nThen in M[G] we have: (2^\\omega)^{M[G]} = (2^\\omega)^M by above and (2^\\omega)^M = |\\lambda| because \\lambda = |\\mathbb{R}|.\n\n\nAlso: |\\lambda| = (\\omega_1)^M by 2. and hence, since we are in M[G] IDK\n\n\nHence M[G] \\models 2^\\omega = \\omega_1. \\square\n\n\nThere is a recap with the bigger picture of the whole procedure on the Notes, there is not much advantage in writing all of this down here again, since some things are just not relevant for the exam and other are clearer on the sheet.\nClaim (trivial)\nBy lemma 1. in Lecture 13 we know that for k regular then col(k, J) is &lt;k-closed, i.e. all decreasing sequences of cardinality less than k are bounded. No decreasing sequence in col(k, J) can be longer than k, since the longest would start from \\emptyset and start mapping elements in k, at most k can get mapped, hence we can state:\nLemma 1. All decreasing sequences in col(k, J) are bounded.\nSince col(k, J) is a partial order where every chain (decreasing sequence) is bounded, we can apply the Zorn‚Äôs lemma and find out that:\nLemma 2. \\exists_{l \\in col(k, J)}\\lnot \\exists_{p \\in col(k, J)} k \\le l.\nThis element has no reason to be unique though. In order to get some sort of uniqueness we would need the partial order to be ‚Äúdownward directed‚Äù, namely, for a forcing poset \\mathbb{P}:\nLemma 3. If every chain in \\mathbb{P} has an lower bound and \\forall_{x, y \\in \\mathbb{P}} \\exists_{z \\in \\mathbb{P}}x \\ge z \\land y \\ge z holds then the least element l is unique.\nProof. here \\square\nWe get this exact kind of structure, by definition, in a filter, in fact:\nLemma 4. If G is a filter and all decreasing sequences are bounded, then there is a unique least element.\nRecall that the first condition for G to be a filter is \\forall_{p, q \\in G} \\exists_{r \\in G} r \\le q \\land r \\le p,¬†\nLemma 5. Let G be a filter in col(k, J) then there exists a unique least element l.\nProof. By lemma 1. we see that every sequence in G must be lower bounded too, then we apply lemma 4. \\square\nThis result shows that for every chosen generic G, there will be one element only which carries all informations of the generic, this is the case since we know that (l \\le p \\land p \\Vdash \\phi) \\rightarrow l \\Vdash \\phi. Then:\nTheorem Let G be col(k, J)-gen. then there is a unique l \\in G s.t. M[G] \\models \\phi \\leftrightarrow l \\Vdash \\phi.\n&quot;\\Rightarrow&quot; If M[G] \\models \\phi, then by TL there is a p \\in col(k, J) s.t. p \\Vdash \\phi. There is a unique least element by lemma 5., and since l \\le p we know l \\Vdash \\phi.\n&quot;\\Leftarrow&quot; If l \\Vdash \\phi, since l \\in G by TL we have M[G] \\models \\phi. \\square\nIn conclusion we notice that for two col(k, J)-generics, G and H and the respective least elements l_G and l_H, we have M[G] = M[H] iff l_G = l_H.\nThose elements for col(k, J) simply are what we denote with f_G := \\bigcup_G = l_G and their prove of both existence and uniqueness are far more trivial if done in the classical sense. My theorem could be a generalisation but it is probably even simpler to just prove it by imagining how a filter looks like instead of going through this harder process.\nIf we think about \\mathbb{P} := Fn(I, J), we could notice that all generics can be identified with complete functions and therefore we could simply take any complete function and consider them to be those that generate the M[G] since they force the set of all (and only those by TL) propositions that are true in M[G].\nCheck Exam\nHazel Mail\nNow regarding the content of the exam. The focus will be on understanding of the concepts in the course and general structure of the arguments. Thus I will mostly be asking only for sketch proofs - you do not need to learn any proofs given in the lectures in detail (I may ask for an easy, short proof to demonstrate understanding of some concepts/definitions, but that is something you should be able to do on the spot).¬†¬†\nI will ask you to give at least one explicit definition, such as inaccessible cardinal, (in)compatibility, dense set, filter, generic filter, ccc, &lt;\\kappa-closed, p forces phi‚Ä¶ You do NOT need to know the definition of the forcing* relation (the one defined recurcively), but you should know the role of this definition in the proof of the Truth and Definability lemmas - i.e. that it is definable within M and we can prove that p forces* phi iff p forces phi (you don‚Äôt need to know anything about the proof of this equivalence). You should know the statements of the Truth and Definability lemmas, and be able to give an informal description of the Downward-L√∂wenheim-Skolem Theorem, Mostovski-Shepherdson Collapse, and Montague-Levy Reflection (these latter three are a bit technical to state correctly, so I won‚Äôt ask for a precise statement). Importantly, you should know the role of these results in the proof of the independence of CH from the existence of an inaccessible cardinal, as we discussed in the last lecture.¬†¬†¬†\nI will set a few exercises (computation or simple proofs), such as relativising a formula to a set, showing a formula is absolute for transitive sets, showing a set is dense, giving the valuation of a name etc. I will also ask for at least one sketch proof, such as using forcing to produce a model of not-CH from a ctm of CH or vice-versa. You should then give the relevant definitions and main lemmas/theorems (such as on preserving cardinals) and how they fit together.\nQuestion to myself\nDefinitions\nQuestion 1. Define inaccessible cardinal\n\n\ninacc. from smaller cardinals trough: +/\\cup, \\cdot/\\times, func.\n\n\nstrongly inacc. if (i) k \\ge \\aleph_0, (ii) is inacc. (iii) \\alpha &lt; k \\rightarrow 2^\\alpha &lt; k.\n\n\nFor an inacc. cardinal k, (V_k, \\in ) \\models ZFC.\n\n\nfrom K: weakly inacc. if k is a regular limit cardinal\n\n\nstrongly inacc. if k &gt; \\omega, k is reg., \\forall_{\\lambda &lt; k} 2^\\lambda &lt; k.\n\n\nif \\beta is a successor, then cf(\\beta) = 1\n\n\nreg. if \\beta is a lim. ord and cf(\\beta) = \\beta.\n\n\nGCH:= \\forall_{\\alpha} 2^{\\omega_\\alpha} = \\omega_{\\alpha + 1}.\n\n\nQuestion 2. Define (in)compatibility\n\n\nDef. \\mathbb{P}\n\n\nif \\exists_{r \\in \\mathbb{P}} r \\le p \\land r \\le q then p \\bot q.\n\n\nAtom, Atomless definitions and examples, [[Advanced Set Theory (Lecture)#5th Lecture#Definitions]]\n\n\nQuestion 3. Define a dense set\n\n\niff \\forall_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}} \\exists_{q \\in D} q \\le p.\n\n\nD_i := \\{p \\in \\mathbb{P} | i \\in dom(P)\\} is a dense set in Fn(I, J) for I infinite.\n\n\ngoto: filter, gen. filter\n\n\nQuestion 4. Define a filter\n\n\n(i) \\forall_{p, q \\in G} \\exists_{r \\in G} r \\le q \\land r \\le p, (ii) \\forall_{p \\in G} \\forall_{q \\in \\mathbb{P}} q \\le p \\rightarrow q \\in G.\n\n\np, q \\in G then p and q agree on dom(p) \\cap dom(q).\n\n\nQuestion 5. Define a generic filter\n\n\n\\forall_{D \\subset \\mathbb{P} \\land D \\text{ dense}} D \\in M \\rightarrow G \\cap D \\not = 0.\n\n\nExistence Lemma + Proof.\n\n\nQuestion 6. Define the ccc property\n\n\ndef. antichain, all antichains are countable, examples\n\n\n|J| \\le \\omega \\rightarrow Fn(I, J) has ccc.\n\n\nif \\mathbb{P} \\in M and (\\mathbb{P} has ccc)^M, then \\mathbb{P} preserves cofinalities and hence cardinals\n\n\nQuestion 7. Define the &lt;k-closed property\n\n\niff all sequence in \\mathbb{P}, are \\langle p_\\gamma| \\gamma &lt; \\alpha \\rangle of length \\alpha &lt; k s.t. \\gamma \\le \\delta &lt; \\alpha, p_\\delta \\le p_\\gamma has a lower bound, i.e. \\exists_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}} \\forall_{\\gamma &lt; \\alpha}p \\le p_\\gamma.\n\n\nIf k is regular col(k, J) is &lt;k-closed.\n\n\nQuestion 8. Define \\mathbb{P}-names\n\n\n\\tau is a \\mathbb{P}-name iff \\tau is a relation s.t. \\forall_{(\\sigma, p) \\in \\tau} \\sigma is a \\mathbb{P}-name \\land p \\in \\mathbb{P}.\n\n\nDefine V^\\mathbb{P} and M^\\mathbb{P}.\n\n\nQuestion 9. Define p \\Vdash \\phi\n\n\nso p \\Vdash_{\\mathbb{P}, M} \\phi(\\tau_1, ..., \\tau_n) iff \\forall_{G \\text{ } \\mathbb{P} \\text{-gen. }\\land p \\in G}\\phi^{M[G]}(val(\\tau_1, G),..., val(\\tau_n, G))\n\n\nIf p \\Vdash \\phi and q \\le p then q \\Vdash \\phi &amp; proof\n\n\ngoto: TL\n\n\nQuestion 10. Define M[G].\nM[G]:= \\{ \\tau_G | \\tau \\in M^\\mathbb{P}\\}.\nFor M[G] it holds:\n\n\nM \\subset M[G]\n\n\nG \\in M[G]\n\n\nM[G] is countable and transitive\n\n\nM[G] \\models ZFC\n\n\nM[G] is minimal (for any set N with the above features we have M[G] \\subset N)\n\n\nGeneral questions\nQuestion 1. What is the role of p \\Vdash^* \\phi in DL and TL, give an approximate definition\n\n\nM[G] \\models \\psi there is a p \\in G s.t. p \\Vdash \\psi\n\n\n\\Rightarrow is ez from def of &quot;\\Vdash&quot;.¬†\n\n\n\\{(p, \\mathbb{P}, \\le, \\mathbb{1}, \\theta_1, ..., \\theta_n)|(\\mathbb{P}, \\le, \\mathbb{1})\\text{ is a forcing poset }\\land p \\in \\mathbb{P} \\land \\theta_1, ..., \\theta_n \\in M^\\mathbb{P} \\land p \\Vdash_{M, \\mathbb{P}} \\phi(\\theta_1, ..., \\theta_n)\\}is definable without parameters in M.\n\n\nWe need \\Vdash^* in order to define within M the forcing relation, it would otherwise require knowledge of every generic.\nQuestion 2. Give the context of the equivalence p \\Vdash \\phi \\Leftrightarrow p \\Vdash^* \\phi, no proof required\nWe showed:\n\n\nif p \\in G and p \\Vdash^* \\phi then M[G] \\models \\phi\n\n\nif M[G] \\models \\phi then there is some p \\in G s.t. p \\Vdash^* \\phi¬†\n\n\nand hence the equivalence follows\nQuestion 3. State and give context to both TL and DL, what are they for?\n\n\nM[G] \\models \\psi there is a p \\in G s.t. p \\Vdash \\psi, defines truth of forcing from a given p.\n\n\nThe DL states then that every forcing relation can be defined without parameters in M.\n\n\nQuestion 4. State and give context to the Downward L√∂wenheim-Skolem Theorem\n\n\nfor inf. \\mathcal{M} and inf. |M| \\ge k \\ge |\\mathcal{L}| then exists \\mathcal{N} s.t. |N| = k, \\mathcal{N} \\subseteq M.\n\n\nProof in 3 steps\n\n\nwe need this theorem to find a M s.t. it gives us all \\phi are absolute in M. This is hence a model of any finite subset of ZFC, though some defs are not absolute, like infinity.\n\n\nQuestion 5. State and give context to the Mostowski Collapse Theorem\n\n\nan extensional relation is R s.t. \\forall_{x, y \\in A}\\forall_{z \\in A}(zRx \\leftrightarrow z Ry) \\rightarrow x = y\n\n\nFor W, a rel. R on W ext., exists a unique tran. set M and an isom. \\pi:(W, R) \\cong (M, \\epsilon).\n\n\nQuestion 6. State and give context to the Montague Reflection Theorem\n\n\nZF \\vdash \\forall_\\alpha \\exists_{\\beta &gt; \\alpha}(\\phi_1, ..., \\phi_n are absolute for V_\\beta).\n\n\nTarski Vaught Test: \\forall_{y_1, ..., y_l \\in M}(\\exists_{x \\in N}\\phi_j^N(x, y_1, ...,y_l) \\rightarrow \\exists_{x \\in M}\\phi_j^N(x, y_1, ..., y_l))\n\n\nQuestion 7. State approximately the procedure from the existence of an inacc. cardinal to CH\nPars I\n\n\nDefine Fn(I, J), |I| \\ge \\omega, J \\not = \\emptyset.\n\n\n... \\rightarrow dom(\\bigcup_G) = I \\land ran(\\bigcup_G) = J\n\n\nSet \\mathbb{P} = Fn(k \\times \\omega, 2), \\bigcup_G: k \\times \\omega \\rightarrow 2, f_\\alpha(n) := \\bigcup_G(\\alpha, n)\n\n\n\\{f_\\alpha | \\alpha &lt; k\\} \\in M[G] by abs.\n\n\nD_{\\alpha, \\beta} is dense\n\n\nG \\cap D_{\\alpha, \\beta} \\not = \\emptyset, hence f_\\alpha \\not = f_\\beta¬†\n\n\nThen we have (2^\\omega \\ge |k|)^{M[G]}\n\n\nPars II\n\n\nDefine ccc¬†\n\n\n|J| \\le \\omega \\rightarrow F(I, J) has ccc\n\n\nDef. preserves cardinals\n\n\nDef. preserves cofinalities\n\n\ncof \\rightarrow card\n\n\n... \\rightarrow cof\n\n\n(\\mathbb{P} has ccc)^M pres. cof and card\n\n\nPars III\n\\mathbb{P}:= (\\omega_2^M \\times \\omega, 2) has ccc, hence \\omega_2^M = \\omega_2^{M[G]}, hence (2^\\omega \\ge \\omega_2)^{M[G]}, hence M[G] \\models \\lnot CH.\nQuestion 8. When do we say that we preserve cardinals?\nsee. 2. ibid\nExercises\nQuestion 1. Show some \\phi relativized to some set M.\nCare about existentials and forall only, the rest is the same\nQuestion 2. Show some \\phi absolute for any transitive set\nRemember the definition of \\Delta_0, if FV(\\phi) = \\emptyset, then it is absolute for transitive sets. Else, for FV(\\phi) = x_1, ..., x_n you need to compute \\phi^M and then show that \\forall_{x_1, ..., x_n} \\phi^M \\leftrightarrow \\phi.\nQuestion 3. Show some set x to be dense.\nSimply that \\forall_{p \\in \\mathbb{P}} \\exists_{d \\in x} d \\le p, with Fn(I, J) think about the extensions of functions\nQuestion 4. Give the valuation to some name \\tau\nRemember that p \\in G \\rightarrow \\{(\\sigma, p)\\}_G = \\sigma and p \\not \\in G \\rightarrow \\{(\\sigma, p)\\}_G = \\emptyset.\nQuestion 5. Use forcing to produce a model of \\lnot CH from a ctm of CH and reverse\nLet M be a ctm of ZFC, (\\lambda = 2^{\\aleph_0})_M, (\\mathbb{P} = col (\\omega_1, \\lambda))_M and G a \\mathbb{P}-generic over M, then M[G] \\models CH. This theorem brings us from a model of \\lnot CH (M) to a model where CH holds (M[G]). The reverse direction, namely from a model of CH to one of \\lnot CH can be done as preaviously shown by Fn(\\omega \\times \\omega_2, 2)."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Analysis-II-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Analysis-II-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/2nd Semester/Mathematics/Lecture Notes/Analysis II (Lecture).md","title":"Analysis II (Lecture)","links":["tags/UniKonstanz","tags/2nd_Semester"],"tags":["UniKonstanz","2nd_Semester"],"content":"Hold by Prof. Reinhard Racke at the UniKonstanz during the 2nd_Semester. Q:? see script, p.119.\ndef. OS if \\langle u_n, u_m \\rangle = c_n\\delta_{nm}, ONS if c_n = 1 i.e. ||u_n||_2:=\\sqrt{\\langle u_n, u_n \\rangle} = 1 .25\nGram-Schm. want (w_i)_{i \\in I} w_1 = v_1, w_2 = v_2 - \\frac{\\langle v_2, w_1\\rangle}{|w_1^2|}w_1, w_3 = v_3 - \\frac{\\langle v_3, w_1\\rangle}{|w_1|^2}w_1 - \\frac{\\langle v_3, w_2 \\rangle}{|w_2|^2}w_2.\nL^2 := \\{C(\\bar{I}, \\mathbb{R}), ||\\cdot ||_2\\} closed under convergence (vervollst√§ndigt)\n\\{u_n\\}_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subset L^2 an ONS: f_n := \\langle f, u_n \\rangle \\in \\mathbb{R} and s_n [f](x):= \\sum^n_{j = i} f_ju_j(x), so: s_n \\rightarrow f .26\n\\sum_{j=1}^m |\\int_a^bf(x)u_j(x) dx|= \\sum_{j = 1}^n |f_j|^2 \\le ||f||_2^2 = \\int_a^b f^2(x) dx\n||s_n[f]||_2 \\le ||f||_2, we are approaching from below since we sum pos elements.\n\\sum^\\infty_{j= 1}|f_j|^2 = ||f||_2^2 \\Leftrightarrow||f - s_n||_2 \\rightarrow 0 , boh &amp; (s_n)_n conv.\n\\{u_m\\}_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subset L^2(I, \\mathbb{C}) ONVS \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{f \\in L^2(I\\mathbb{C})} \\sum^\\infty_{j =1} = ||f||^2_2 (.28) \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{f \\in L(I, \\mathbb{C})}\\forall_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} f_n = 0 \\rightarrow f = 0 .30\nbut .29?\nThe Fourier Serie is the best .32\n\n9.6\n\nfor \\mathbb{R}: f(x) = a_0 + \\sum_{j=1}^\\infty (a_j \\cos(jx) + b_j \\sin(jx)): a_0 = \\frac{1}{2\\pi} \\int_{-\\pi}^\\pi f(x)dx; a_j = \\frac{1}{\\pi}\\int^\\pi_{-\\pi}f(x) \\cos(jx)dx; b_j = \\frac{1}{\\pi}\\int^\\pi_{-\\pi}f(x)\\sin(jx)dx\nfor \\mathbb{C}: f_n := \\langle f, u_n \\rangle = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi}} \\int^\\pi_{-\\pi}f(x)e^{-inx}dx; a_0 = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi}} f_0; a_n = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi}}(f_n + f_{-n}); b_n  = \\frac{-i}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi}}(f_n - f_{-n})\n||f - \\sum_{j = -n}^n f_ju_j||_\\infty \\le \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{\\pi n}}||f&#039;||_2 .33 make Bsp. .34\n\n10\n10.1 Normed VS\n\nNormed spaces examples\n\n(C(\\bar{I}, \\mathbb{R}), ||\\cdot||_p), ||f||_p := (\\int_I |f|^p)^{\\frac{1}{p}} is normed space\nThe space of sequences (l_p, ||\\cdot ||_p) s.t. || \\cdot ||_p: x \\mapsto (\\sum^\\infty_{j=1}|\\xi|^p)^{\\frac{1}{p}} &amp; infinite vectors in \\mathbb{C}, l_p := \\{x = (\\xi_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}}|\\forall_{j \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\xi_j \\in \\mathbb{C}, \\sum^\\infty_{j = 1} |\\xi_j|^p &lt; \\infty\\}, bounded seq. in \\mathbb{C}, similarly for p \\rightarrow \\infty\n\n\n\\frac{1}{p} + \\frac{1}{q}  =1 then (watch)\n\nYoung: \\forall_{a, b &gt; 0 (\\in \\mathbb{R})} a \\cdot b \\le \\frac{a^p}{p} + \\frac{b^q}{q}\nH√∂lder: \\sum_{ i = 1}^\\infty |\\xi_i \\cdot \\eta_i| \\le ||x||_p \\cdot ||y||_q (\\Leftrightarrow ||xy||_1 \\le ||x||_p \\cdot ||y||_q)\nMikowski: ||x + y||_p \\le ||x||_p + ||y||_p\n\n\n\n10.2 Stetigkeit und Kompaktheit\n\nBolzano-Weierstra√ü: (x_k)_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n bounded \\Rightarrow there is a converging sequence in (x_k)_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}}.\nK \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n clos. and boun. \\Leftrightarrow K is compact \\Leftrightarrow every (x_k)_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} has (x_{k_j})_{j \\in \\mathbb{N}} s.t. \\lim_{j \\rightarrow \\infty} x_{k_j} \\in K .5\nf cont. \\Leftrightarrow f: op/cl comes from op/cl \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{(x_k)_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subset X}, x_k \\rightarrow x, f(x_k) \\rightarrow f(x) .6\nf: X \\rightarrow Y cont., K \\subset X compact \\Rightarrow f(K) compact &amp; f|_K glm. stet.\nNichtzus. \\Leftrightarrow \\exists_{A, B \\not = \\emptyset} A \\cap B = \\emptyset \\land X = A \\cup B (A, B both open or both closed) .11\nZwischenwe.: X zusam., f: X \\rightarrow Y cont. R(f) (=Im(f) as a space) is zusam. .12\na cont. fun \\gamma: [a, b] \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^n is a Weg; for all m_1, m_2 then \\gamma: [a, b] \\rightarrow M s.t. \\gamma(a) = m_1 \\land \\gamma(b) = m_2\nwegzusamm \\Rightarrow zusamm. .15; a lin. func. is cont. iff it is bounded\nL(X, Y) lin. bound. cont. func.; ||\\cdot ||: L(X, Y) \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^+_0, A \\mapsto \\sup_{||x|| = 1}||Ax||(=\\sup_{x \\not =0}\\frac{||Ax||}{||x||} = \\sup_{||x||\\le 1}||Ax||)\nFor A lin.: A stet. \\Leftrightarrow A stet. in 0 \\Leftrightarrow \\sup_{||x||_X =1} ||Ax||_Y &lt; \\infty \\Leftrightarrow \\exists_{c \\in \\mathbb{K}}\\forall_{x \\in X} ||Ax||_Y\\le c||x||_X (Blatt 3.)\n\n11\n11.1 Diff. Func.\n\n(f_k)_{k \\in \\mathbb{N}} glm con. iff \\lim_{k \\rightarrow \\infty}||f_k - f||_\\infty = 0\nSequences of continuous functions glm. converge to continuous functions .2\nf is diff. if there is such A(x), r(x, \\cdot) s.t. f(x + h) = f(x) + A(x)h + r(x,h)|h| .3\nFor im(f) \\subset \\mathbb{R} but also im(f) \\subset \\mathbb{R}^m if f always part. diff \\Rightarrow f diff.\nNote: A(x) is unique and r(x, 0)=0 stet. in 0 \\Rightarrow f^{-1} is defined\nFor im(f) \\subset \\mathbb{R} but also im(f) \\subset \\mathbb{R}^m if f always part. diff \\Rightarrow f diff.\next. all \\partial_i are stetig \\Rightarrow f diff. (A(x) = \\nabla f(x) \\Rightarrow f&#039;(x, h) \\not = \\langle \\nabla f(x) , h \\rangle why??)\nf diff in x \\Rightarrow f cont. in x\next: \\lim_{t \\rightarrow 0}\\frac{f(x + t) - f(x)}{t} der. in \\mathbb{R} in x, in \\mathbb{R}^n, h \\in \\mathbb{R}^n s.t. |h| = 1, D_y(h):= \\lim_{t \\rightarrow 0} \\frac{f( y + th)- f(y)}{t}, f diff. \\Rightarrow \\forall_{h \\in \\mathbb{R}^n}D_y(h) = \\langle \\nabla f (t), h \\rangle\nf: U(\\subset \\mathbb{R}) \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}, \\frac{\\partial f(x)}{\\partial x_i}:=\\lim_{h \\rightarrow 0}\\frac{f(x+he_i) - f(x)}{h}  .6\n\\nabla f(x) := (\\frac{\\partial f(x)}{\\partial x_1}, ..., \\frac{\\partial f(x)}{\\partial x_n})^T =: (\\partial_1 f(x), ..., \\partial_n f(x))^T\nNote: f&#039;(x) = (\\nabla f(x))^T if f: U(\\subset \\mathbb{R}^n) \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R} so f&#039;(x) is an orisontal vector.7\nJ_f(x):= \\begin{pmatrix}  \\partial_1 f_1(x) &amp; ... &amp; \\partial_n f_1(x)\\\\  \\vdots &amp; &amp; \\vdots \\\\ \\partial_1 f_m(x) &amp; ... &amp; \\partial_nf_m(x)  \\end{pmatrix} =: (\\partial_1 f, ..., \\partial_n f)(x) =: \\frac{\\partial f(x)}{\\partial x}for f: \\mathbb{R}^n \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^m, it is a gen. of the \\nabla-operator .8,\nalso f&#039;: U \\rightarrow L(\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathbb{R}^m), x \\mapsto f&#039;(x), or similarly f&#039;: (x,h) \\mapsto f&#039;(x)\\cdot h (matr. mult) .10\nf: U (\\subset \\mathbb{R}^n) \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}: (fg)&#039; = gf&#039; + fg&#039;  \\land (g \\circ f)&#039; = (g&#039; \\circ f) \\cdot f&#039; \\land (f + g)&#039; = f&#039; + g&#039; \\land (\\alpha f)&#039; = \\alpha f&#039; .11\n\\nabla f(x_0) \\cdot h_0 for |h_0| is the Richtungsableitung von f  in Richtung h_0 an der Stelle x_0 .12\n\nTo Compute: D_x(h) = \\lim_{t \\rightarrow 0} \\frac{f(x  + th) - f(x)}{t}, f diff in x, \\forall_{h \\in \\mathbb{R}^n} D_x(h) = \\langle \\nabla f(x), h \\rangle\n\n\nH√∂helinien: N_f(c) := \\{x \\in U | f(x) = c\\} clear, U is the domain of f: \\mathbb{R}^2 \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}\nFalllinien: for \\beta: \\mathbb{R} \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^2 s.t. \\beta&#039;(t) = \\nabla f(\\beta(t)) uhm\ndiv f : \\mathbb{R}^n \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}, x \\mapsto div f(x) := \\sum_{i = 1}^n \\partial_i f_i (x); rot f: \\mathbb{R}^3 \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^3, x \\mapsto (\\partial_2f_3(x)-\\partial_3f_2(x),  \\partial_3f_1(x) - \\partial_1f_3(x),  \\partial_1f_2(x) - \\partial_2f_1(x))^T; \\Delta: C^2(\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathbb{R}) \\rightarrow C(\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathbb{R}), f \\mapsto \\sum_{i = 1}^n \\partial_i^2 f_i, \\Delta(f) = div(\\nabla(f)), called Laplace-Operator .14\nf: U (\\subset \\mathbb{R}^n) \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^n inj. diff in a s.t. \\det f&#039;(a) \\not = 0 (so that f&#039;(a) is an inv. matrix), for b := f(a) for f(a) is an inner point of f(U) (or you can‚Äôt derivate) def. g: = f^{-1}:f(U) \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^n. then g&#039;(b) = (f&#039;(a))^{-1}, see those as matrices. Maybe it is to say when \\cdot^{-1} and  \\cdot &#039; commute .16\nActually you need only \\det f&#039;(a) \\not = 0 .17\nQ! dom(g) wtf? .18\nf \\in C^1(U, \\mathbb{R}^n), inv., f(U) open, f^{-1} \\in C^1 then f is a Diffeomorphismus on U. .19\n\n11.2 Mittelwertsatz\n\nfor a, b \\in \\mathbb{R}^n, t \\in (0, 1): \\gamma_{ab}(t) := a + t(b-a); \\Gamma_{ab} := \\{x \\in \\mathbb{R}^n| \\exists_{t \\in (0, 1)} x = \\gamma_{ab}(t)\\}\nMittelwertsatz: \\exists_{c \\in \\Gamma_{ab}} f(b) = f(a) + f&#039;(c)(b-a), \\Gamma_{ab} is a the Gerade from a to b, for Im(f) \\subseteq \\mathbb{R}\nIt‚Äôs ok \\gamma: [0,1] \\rightarrow U s.t. \\gamma(0) = a \\land \\gamma(1) = b with \\gamma diff. so f(b) = f(a) + f&#039;(\\gamma(\\theta))\\gamma&#039;(\\theta), \\theta \\in (0, 1)\nfor f: U \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^n, f&#039; = 0 \\Leftrightarrow f = k for k \\in \\mathbb{R}\n\\partial_1 f, ..., \\partial_n f cont. around a \\Rightarrow f diff. .23, comp both lim. \\partial_i f(a), for Im(f) \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n\n\n11.3 H√∂here Ableitungen\n\nf&#039;&#039;&#039;: U \\rightarrow L(\\mathbb{R}^n , L(\\mathbb{R}^n, L(\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathbb{R}^m))) or f&#039;&#039;: U \\times \\mathbb{R}^n \\times \\mathbb{R}^n \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^m, (x, h, k) \\mapsto f&#039;&#039;(x, h, k) = (f&#039;&#039;(x)h)k\nIn general f^{(p)}: U \\times (\\mathbb{R}^n)^p \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^m, (x, h_1, ..., h_p) \\mapsto f^{(p)}(x, h_1, ..., h_p)\nalso remember: \\partial_j\\partial_i f(x) = f&#039;&#039;(x, e_i, e_j) .24\nSchwarz: if f \\in C^2(\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathbb{R}^m) \\land U open \\Rightarrow \\forall_{i, j \\in \\{1, ..., n\\}} \\partial_i \\partial_j f(x) = \\partial_j \\partial_i f(x) .25\ncheck .26\nTaylor: f(x + h) = f(x) + f^{(1)}(x, h) + ... + \\frac{1}{p!}f^{(p)}(x, h, ..., h) + R_p(x, h), .27 where R_p(x, h) = \\frac{1}{(p+ 1)!}f^{(p +1)}(x +\\theta h, h, ...,h ) for \\theta \\in (0, 1); Similarly for any U \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n instead of \\Gamma we call \\omega an 1-Form.\nfor \\omega(x, h) = \\langle \\omega(x), h \\rangle, \\omega(x) = (\\omega_1(x), ..., \\omega_n(x))^T for \\omega_i := \\omega(x, e_i)\next: example: for any f diff. then (x, h) \\mapsto \\langle \\nabla f(x), h \\rangle is an 1-Form\ncall \\int_\\Gamma \\omega := \\int_b^a \\omega(\\gamma(t), \\gamma&#039;(t)) dt Kurvenintegral; then lin. and for \\Gamma = \\Gamma_1 + \\Gamma_2: \\int_\\Gamma \\omega = \\int_{\\Gamma_1} \\omega + \\int_{\\Gamma_2} \\omega\n\nCompute: \\int_\\Gamma \\Omega = \\int_\\Gamma \\langle \\omega(\\gamma(t)), \\gamma&#039;(t) \\rangle dt, like a vectorfield \\cdot the directon of \\gamma. (M(b, \\underline{v}))_{i, j} = b(v_i, v_j)\nb^\\rightarrow: v \\mapsto b(\\cdot, v), it fixes first the right variable, b^\\leftarrow does the opposite.\nM(b, \\underline{v}) = M(b^\\leftarrow, \\underline{v}, \\underline{v}^*) = M(b^\\rightarrow, \\underline{v}, \\underline{v}^*)^T, and b^\\rightarrow = (b^\\leftarrow)^*\nb not deg. \\Leftrightarrow b^\\rightarrow inj. \\Rightarrow ker(b^\\rightarrow) = 0 \\Rightarrow (b(\\cdot, v) = 0) \\rightarrow v=0.\n\n13.4 Quadratical Forms\n\nQuad forms \\cong Symmatrix \\cong Symm bilin. forms,\nsee 13.4.6, b(v,v) converse is \\frac{1}{2}(q(v+w)- q(v) - q(w))\n\n13.5 Cholesky\n\nSee the scritp, remember the form of D and P and the ways to reform the quadratic form.\nin P there can be blocks \\{\\{1,1\\},\\{1, -1\\}\\} with correspondance of \\{\\{\\lambda, 0\\},\\{-\\lambda, 0\\}\\} in D\nCor. M(f,\\underline{v}) is diag. \\Leftrightarrow f normal\nA orth. \\Leftrightarrow exists \\underline{v} ONB s.t. M(f, \\underline{v}) diagonal with every |\\lambda_i| = 1.\nf orth. is a VS with \\langle \\cdot, \\cdot \\rangle isomorphism in \\mathbb{R} and f unitary in \\mathbb{C}, \\langle f(v), f(w) \\rangle = \\langle v, w \\rangle 11.2.19\nR \\in \\mathbb{R}^{n \\times n} is orth. \\Leftrightarrow R^T = R^{-1}; and C \\in \\mathbb{C}^{n \\times n} is unitary \\Leftrightarrow C^* = C^{-1} also: (ext, and ext)\next: for C \\in \\mathbb{C}^{n \\times n}: C normal \\Rightarrow C diag.; (C^* = C^{-1}) \\lor (C = C^*) \\lor (C^* = -C) \\Rightarrow C normal\nblue table:\n\nf orth. also in ID p \\not = 0 and prime \\Rightarrow p is irr.\nDef \\alpha: \\mathbb{P}_A \\Rightarrow \\mathbb{N}_0 supp(\\alpha) := \\{p \\in \\mathbb{P}_A| \\alpha(p) \\not = 0\\}. \\mathbb{P}_A^\\alpha : = \\prod_{p \\in supp(\\alpha)}p^{\\alpha(p)}, fac(a) = (c, \\alpha) s.t. a = c\\mathbb{P}^\\alpha_A\nin any ID the factorisation (c, \\alpha) is unique\nin an FD every a \\in A \\setminus \\{0\\} has a (c, \\alpha) \\in A^\\times \\times \\mathbb{N}_0.\nin a FD c\\mathbb{P}_A^\\alpha | d\\mathbb{P}_A^\\beta \\Leftrightarrow \\alpha \\preceq \\beta; PID \\Rightarrow FD\nA FD \\Leftrightarrow irr. \\rightarrow prime \\land for every (a_n)_{n \\in \\mathbb{N}} s.t. (a_1) \\subseteq (a_2) \\subseteq ... then k \\in \\mathbb{N} s.t. (a_k) = (a_{k + 1}) = ...\n\n17\n17.1 Smith\n\nDefine Spalten- Zeilenoperationen, add and sub. and mult. it by \\lambda \\in A^\\times.\nZ \\cdot A \\cdot S = B for inv. mat. Z and S, A \\sim B, |det(A)|=|det(B)|, |det(Z)| = |det(S)| = 1.\nWe get a new \\sim and create new equivalence classes, rappresentative is Smith\nSmith: . \\lambda_1 |...|\\lambda_l for l =\\min(m, n) (16.4.17), it always exists.\n17.3.5\n\n17.2 Cauchy-Binet\n\nA_{I, J} you forget useless rows and columns, it must not be square.\ndet(AB) = \\sum_{J \\subseteq \\{1, ..., n\\}, |J| = m}(det(A_{I, J})(det(B_{J, I})) for AB \\in \\mathbb{K}^{n \\times n}; m&gt;n \\Rightarrow det(AB) = 0.\nm&gt;n \\Leftrightarrow det(AB) = 0, m = n \\Leftrightarrow det(A)det(B).\nMinoref.: for |L| = |I|, det((AB)_{I, L}) = \\sum_{J \\subseteq \\{1, ..., n\\}, |J| = m}(det(A_{I, J})(det(B_{J, L})), AB mustn‚Äôt be n \\times n\nminor_k, the ideal of every minor of order k, ideal are decreasing for &quot;\\subseteq&quot; (Elementarteiler).\nM \\sim N \\Leftrightarrow d(M) = d(N) .7.b, ez criterion for checking \\sim.\n\n17.4 Cayley-Hamilton\n\nA \\approx B \\Leftrightarrow B = P^{-1} A P where P is a change of basis \\Rightarrow they share everything\nP_iA =AP_i \\Rightarrow (PQ)_A = P_A Q_A\n==17.4.8 P_A = 0 \\Leftrightarrow \\exists_{Q \\in K[X]^{n \\times n}} P = (XI_n -A) Q==\n==P\\cdot ch(b) = ch(A) \\cdot Q \\Rightarrow AP_A = P_AB, 17.4.9==\nA \\approx B \\Leftrightarrow ch(A) \\sim ch(B) \\Leftrightarrow d(ch(A)) = d(ch(B)) \\Leftrightarrow same Smith.\next: A \\approx B \\Leftrightarrow B = P^{-1} A P where P is a change of basis \\Rightarrow they share everything\nAlgorithm .12\n\nCompute Smith(ch(A)|I_n) which gives you (S|L)\nCompute Smith(ch(B))=:T note the Zeilenoperationen.\nNow take L and inverte the Zeilenoperationen noted before this gives you P\nDecompose P \\in K[X]^{n \\times n} in X^{n-1} P_{n-1} + ... + P_0, for P_{n-1}, ..., P_0 \\in K^{n \\times n}\nNow evaluate B in P to get R:=P_B and define R^{-1} B R =A.\n\n\nA \\approx_K B \\Leftrightarrow A \\approx_L B, for K \\subset L fields .14\n\n17.5 Frobenius\n\nSmith(ch(C_p)) is easy I_n con p in fondo. Frob(A) is like smith but with C(p_1),...,C(p_m).\nAlso Smith(Ch(Frob(A))) is I with p_1, ..., p_m on the end of the diagonal; A \\approx Frob(A).\nc(ch(A)) = (1, ..., 1, p_1, ..., p_m) then c_m = \\mu_A and \\chi_A = \\prod c.\nHow to findFrob(A): compute Smith(ch(A)), then read p_1, ..., p_m.\nFor any quad. A, there‚Äôs (p_1, ..., p_n), p_1|...|p_n with Frob(A), \\mu_A = p_m, \\chi_A=(-1)^np_1\\cdot ... \\cdot p_m.\nTo find (p_1, ..., p_m), compute Smith(ch(A)), there you have p_1, ..., p_m.\n\n17.6 Weierstra√ü\n\nWei(A) eind. bis auf Reih. and p_1, ..., p_m are powers of prime polyn. in K[X]; A \\approx Wei(A).\nHow to compute: compute Frob(A) then for every block (&gt; 1 \\times 1) split it in prime polyn .3.b\n\n17.7 Jordan\n\nJ(\\lambda, n), \\chi_{J(\\lambda, n)} = \\mu_{J(\\lambda, n)} = (x -\\lambda)^n. For any Eigenwert you build a block respecting the mult.\nIf we are in no ACF and \\chi_A doesn‚Äôt zerf√§llt, then the Jord(A) is not defined.\n\nArithmetic Tricks\n\nxy = \\frac{1}{4}((x + y)^2 - (x -y)^2), for Sylv. Sign and Cholesky\nx^d - y^d = (x -y)(x^{d-1} +x^{d-2}y +...+y^{d-1})\n(AB)^T = B^T A^T 11.3.5\nfor V, W F-VS, |V|=|W|&gt;|F| \\Rightarrow V \\cong W\ndeg(\\chi_A) = n for A \\in K^{n \\times n}\nI \\cap J is an ideal\n\nTo Memorise\n\nGram-Schm. want (w_i)_{i \\in I} w_1 = v_1, w_2 = v_2 - \\frac{\\langle v_2, w_1\\rangle}{|w_1^2|}w_1, w_3 = v_3 - \\frac{\\langle v_3, w_1\\rangle}{|w_1|^2}w_1 - \\frac{\\langle v_3, w_2 \\rangle}{|w_2|^2}w_2.\ndet(AB) = \\sum_{J \\subseteq \\{1, ..., n\\}, |J| = m}(det(A_{I, J})(det(B_{J, I})) for AB \\in \\mathbb{K}^{n \\times n}; m&gt;n \\Rightarrow det(AB) = 0.\nMinoref.: for |L| = |I|, det((AB)_{I, L}) = \\sum_{J \\subseteq \\{1, ..., n\\}, |J| = m}(det(A_{I, J})(det(B_{J, L})), AB mustn‚Äôt be n \\times n\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Model-Theory-(Lecture)":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Model-Theory-(Lecture)","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/2nd Semester/Mathematics/Lecture Notes/Model Theory (Lecture).md","title":"Model Theory (Lecture)","links":["Academia/Notes--and--Papers/Universities/University-of-Constance","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/2nd-Semester"],"tags":[],"content":"I‚Äôm following this course by Dr. Vincent Bagayoko on Model Theory at the University of Constance during the 2nd Semester. A recap of the material relevant for the exam follows.\nBriefly, Theorems and Defs.\n\nDef. Filter: (i) \\emptyset \\not \\in \\mathcal{F}, I \\in \\mathcal{F}, (ii) Closed under \\cap (iii) Closed under supersets in I\n\nPrincipal Filter: If¬†x \\in I then \\mathcal{F} is generated by x, if x is a singleton, then \\mathcal{F} is ultra\nFr√©chet Filter: F = \\{A \\subseteq I | I \\setminus A \\text{ is finite}\\}\nFree Filter: Contains a Fr√©chet filter\nUltrafilter: (i) \\forall_{A,C \\subseteq I} A \\cup B \\in \\mathcal{F} \\Rightarrow A \\in \\mathcal{F} or B \\in \\mathcal{F} (prime filter on \\cup) or (ii) is a maximal filer\nFIP: If the intersection over any finite subcollection of I is non empty\nCreation of a Filter:  If \\mathcal{A} \\subset \\mathcal{P}(I) has the FIP, then there is a filter \\mathcal{F} on I with \\mathcal{A} \\subseteq \\mathcal{F}\nExtension of a Filter:  \\mathcal{F} \\cup \\{A\\} is contained is a filter on I.\nUltraproducts: \\prod_{i \\in I} \\mathcal{M}_i / \\mathcal{U}\n\n≈Åos Theorem:¬†\\prod_{i \\in I} \\mathcal{M}_i / \\mathcal{U} \\models \\phi (m_1,‚Ä¶,m_n) \\Leftrightarrow ¬†\\{i \\in I:M_i \\models \\phi (m_{1,i},‚Ä¶,m_{n,i})\\}¬†\\in¬†\\mathcal{U}.\n\n\nUltrapower:  \\prod_{i \\in I} \\mathcal{M} / \\mathcal{U}\n\n\nEmbedding:(i) constants (ii) functions (iii) relations but only injective for the variables\n\nI. Type: p is a n-type of Th(\\mathcal{M}) \\Leftrightarrow e.ext. \\mathcal{N} of \\mathcal{M} s.t. \\exists_{b \\in N} \\mathcal{N} \\models p(b) \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{p_0 \\subset p} \\exists_{b \\in M} \\mathcal{M} \\models p_0(b)\nII. Type: tp^\\mathcal{M}(a) is the complete type of a in \\mathcal{M}\nElementary Embedding: \\mathcal{M} \\models_h \\phi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{N} \\models_{\\tau \\circ h} \\phi\nElementary Equivalence, \\equiv**: \\mathcal{M} \\models \\phi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{N} \\models \\phi\nElementary Extension**: \\mathcal{M} \\subseteq \\mathcal{N} s.t. for all \\bar{a} \\in \\bigcup_{n \\in \\omega}M^n, tp^{\\mathcal{M}}(\\bar{a}) = tp^{\\mathcal{N}}(\\bar{a}).\nSubstructure: N \\subseteq M, \\mathcal{N} closed and same outputs on everything \\mathcal{M} has.\nElementary Substructure: \\mathcal{M} \\models \\phi \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{N} \\models \\phi and \\mathcal{N} substr. of \\mathcal{M}\n\nE. Emb \\Rightarrow E. Eq p. 72\n\n\nCompactness Theorem: Any finite subset of T is consistent \\Leftrightarrow T is consistent.\nCorr. to Comp. If \\Gamma \\models \\phi then there is a finite \\Gamma_0 s.t. \\Gamma_0 \\models \\phi.\nL√∂wenheim-Skolem Theorem: Inf. \\mathcal{M}, inf. k, then there is an E. Ex. or E. Sub. |\\mathcal{N}| = k.\nDefinable Choice: \\mathcal{M} has def. choice over A if for every form. with param. in A \\phi(v_0, ..., v_n) there is a partial func. (not def on all M^n) f: M^n \\rightarrow M, \\mathcal{M} \\models \\phi(m_0, ..., m_{n - 1}, f(m_0, ..., m_{n- 1}))\n\n\nQuantifier Elimination: For \\phi \\in \\mathcal{L} there is \\psi \\in \\mathcal{L} w.q., s.t. T \\models \\psi \\leftrightarrow \\phi and with FV(\\phi) = FV(\\psi)\n\nQE \\Rightarrow Model Completeness: For every str. s.t. \\mathcal{M}, \\mathcal{N} \\models T: \\mathcal{M} \\subseteq \\mathcal{N}\\Rightarrow \\mathcal{M} \\preceq \\mathcal{N}.\nT.-V. test: \\mathcal{N} \\preceq \\mathcal{M} \\Leftrightarrow \\forall_{\\phi(c, y_1, ..., y_n)}\\forall_{b_1, ..., b_n \\in N}\\mathcal{M} \\models \\exists_x \\phi(x, b_1, ..., b_n) \\rightarrow \\exists_{a \\in N} \\mathcal{M} \\models \\phi(a, b_1, ..., b_n).\nQE \\Rightarrow Def. Sets without Quantifiers are all Def. Sets.\n1. Criterion for QE, T has QE \\Leftrightarrow If \\mathcal{M}, \\mathcal{N} \\models T, \\mathcal{A} \\subseteq \\mathcal{M}, \\mathcal{N}: for \\bar{a} \\in A^n, \\mathcal{M} \\models \\phi(\\bar{a}) \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{N} \\models \\phi(\\bar{a}).\n2. Criterion for QE: Just prove you can eliminate \\exists.\nO-minimality on \\mathcal{M}: Every definable¬†subset¬†X¬†\\subseteq M is a finite union of intervals and points.\nO-min \\Leftrightarrow \\mathcal{M} \\models \\phi(v_0) \\leftrightarrow \\psi(v_0) where \\psi(v_0) \\in \\mathcal{L}_&lt;‚Ä¶ true?\nO- min on T: Every model of T has O-min\nT complete \\Rightarrow just one O-min str. needed\nUse QE for O-min: QE \\land Sets def. by atomic \\phi(v_0) are finite unions of intervals \\Rightarrow O-min.\nWe know: abelian groups, DLO, algebraically closed fields, real closed fields are QE\nWe know: DLO in \\mathcal{L}_&gt;, real closed fields are o-min\nRCF: \\mathbb{F}[i] is ACF \\Leftrightarrow \\mathbb{F} \\equiv \\mathbb{R}\n\n\nCategoricity: T is k-cat. iff any two models of T of card, k are isomorphic.\nVaught‚Äôs test: if all \\mathcal{M} \\models T \\Rightarrow |\\mathcal{M}|  \\ge \\aleph_0, k \\ge max(|\\mathcal{L}|,\\aleph_0) and T is k-cat. then T is complete.\n"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Philosophy/Other-Works/Nonsense-in-a-Phenomenal-Subject":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Philosophy/Other-Works/Nonsense-in-a-Phenomenal-Subject","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/2nd Semester/Philosophy/Other Works/Nonsense in a Phenomenal Subject.md","title":"Nonsense in a Phenomenal Subject","links":["System/Attachments/Nonsense_in_a_Phenomenal_Subject.pdf","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/1st-Semester/Philosophy/Essays/The-Frequency-of-Telling-Stories","Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Mathematics/Lecture-Notes/Model-Theory-(Lecture)"],"tags":[],"content":"The PDF file can be downloaded here Nonsense_in_a_Phenomenal_Subject.pdf, its \\LaTeX code is at the bottom of this page.\nReference to Former Writings\nI exposed in The Frequency of Telling Stories what is a denotation of ‚ÄúI‚Äù in different contexts, though, what remained constant in that essay, was that I regarded the ‚ÄúI‚Äù as being external. I always gave examples where ‚ÄúI‚Äù was said by an outer subject or it was me but at a past time or referring the the future. Ultimately I have treated the proper, present ‚ÄúI‚Äù and described it in ‚Äú5.3 The Actual World‚Äù:\nI define the actual world as being the world in which there is nothing counterfactual and, as I have shown before, every proposition containing qualia implies that I am someone that I am not. Therefore the actual world would be the world in which I‚Äôm able to denote precisely the things as I perceive but, as shown, I can‚Äôt communicate them to anyone or even myself at a later time. So if you consider the limit of two subjects to their being the same (two very similar people or the same subject after an infinitesimal fraction of time), they would be able to communicate their actual world with qualia. On the other hand the world of ideas, because of its lack of indexicals, would also be a partial description of the actual world.\nHere we see that I regarded the actual world as being something I cannot comunicate. I still agree with that idea but I want to give a different argument in order to get to a similar conclusion, this should show how obvious it already was that, in the context I built, there was no space for a definable present proper ‚ÄúI‚Äù.\nDefinability\nSimilarly as I have seen in Model Theory (Lecture), in order for something to be definable there should be a proposition that satisfies it and nothing else, a remarkable example of the concept is the following: Consider the language of ordered groups \\mathcal{L}_{og}:=\\langle +, &gt;, 0 \\rangle and the ordered group (\\mathbb{Q}, +, &gt;) . In this case we have no way to define 1, since there is no \\phi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{og}  s.t. \\phi(1) is true and false for any other variable.\nI want to use here a similar concept of definability, which would then become exactly the same if I would be able to write my theory formally. In particular I should notice that there some sort of propositions that have a free variable and are therefore of the desired kind, but that are true for any inserted variable. For the former example we may for example take \\psi(y):= \\exists_y y&gt;x , we notice that whatever we insert in the free variable y it would always be true. Though I see convenience in statin that, a proposition \\phi(x) defines something, only if there is something that it is not defining, therefore \\psi(x) would not be a defining proposition. It would be a defining proposition, e.g., in the ordering (\\mathbb{Z}/(5), &gt;) where \\lnot \\psi(4)  holds.\nThe Subject\nWhen asking whether the subject is definable we must first well specify the language we are speaking in. There may well be different ways to define subjects if we are talking a more externalist language or simply referring to others, though, if we consider the present self, in a completely internalist language, like the one I‚Äôm trying to write in [unpublished writings], then one immediately notice that what we mean by subject is including everything that is present in our domain of discourse. Therefore we will find no defining proposition fo subject, since it would hold for any element of our discourse.\nApplication to Descartes\nI regard the Cartesian cogito ergo sum as: from the presence (in my sensations) of any thoughtful activity, it must follow that there is a subject who produced it. And yet, here, i just gave a model where the former sentence can‚Äôt turn out to be true, since subject, as shown, is not definable. Two objections come first to my mind: (i) I am not referring to the same subject Descartes is meaning and (ii) the Cartesian claim is then not true, which doesn‚Äôt strictly mean to be false. For (i) I need first to state the disclaimer that I have no historical pretence and secondly that I suppose that Descartes wants to denote with subject, either the totality of the res cogitans, for which my argument holds, or the author of such a totality, which would not be part of the domain of discourse and therefore not definable either. For (ii) I would first underline that what Descartes needed is something to be true in any model of our perception, s.t. no sceptical scenario could still both explain our sensations and not satisfy. My scenario though explains all our sensations, by just assuming the presence of such phenomena, and doesn‚Äôt satisfy the existence of a subject, therefore I would be enough of a sceptical scenario to falsify the Cartesian claim.\n\\LaTeX code\n\\documentclass{article}\n\\usepackage{amsthm}\n\\usepackage{csquotes}\n\\usepackage{amsfonts}\n\\usepackage{amsmath}\n\\usepackage{setspace}\n\\usepackage[greek,english]{babel}\n\\usepackage[letterpaper,top=2cm,bottom=2cm,left=3cm,right=3cm,marginparwidth=1.75cm]{geometry}\n\\usepackage{graphicx}\n\\usepackage[colorlinks=true, allcolors=blue]{hyperref}\n\\title{Nonsense in a Phenomenal Subject}\n\\author{Simone Testino}\n\\date{July 2023}\n \n\\begin{document}\n \n\\maketitle\n\\begin{abstract}\n    In this short writing I try to give a counterexample to the Cartesian cogito ergo sum, by showing that there are models where there are thoughts and no subject producing it. In such models talking about subjects becomes nonsense since, as I will show, it won&#039;t be a definable word. The attempt of the writing is not to give a conclusive explanation of why things appear in the way they appear, I will rather do the opposite: I will bring \\emph{one of the many} scenarios one could give that explain our perception; the particular feature of my model will be that thinking will require no subject and will therefore deny the Cartesian \\emph{cogito ergo sum}.\n\\end{abstract}\n \n\\subsection*{I. Reference to Former Writings}\nI exposed in \\enquote{The Frequency of Telling Stories} what is a denotation of \\enquote{I} in different contexts, though, what remained constant in that essay, was that I regarded the \\enquote{I} as being external. I always gave examples where \\enquote{I} was said by an outer subject or by me in the past or referring to the future. Ultimately I have treated the proper, present \\enquote{I} and described it in \\enquote{5.3 The Actual World}:\n \n\\begin{quote}\nI define the actual world as being the world in which there is nothing counterfactual and, as I have shown before, every proposition containing qualia implies that I am someone that I am not. Therefore the actual world would be the world in which I‚Äôm able to denote precisely the things as I perceive them but, as shown, I can‚Äôt communicate those to anyone or even myself at a later time. So if you consider the limit of two subjects to their being the same (two very similar people or the same subject after an infinitesimal fraction of time), they would be able to communicate their actual world with qualia [and therefore communicating the \\enquote{I} as I mean it in this writing]. On the other hand the world of ideas, because of its lack of indexicals, would also be a partial description of the actual world.\n\\end{quote}\n \nHere we see that I regarded the actual world as being something I cannot communicate. I still agree with that idea but I want to give a different argument in order to get to a similar conclusion. This should show how obvious it already was that, in the fully internalist context I built, there was no space for a definable present \\enquote{I}.\n \n\\subsection*{II. Definability}\nSimilarly as I have learnt in the Model Theory course, in order for something to be definable there should be a proposition that satisfies it and nothing else, a remarkable example of the concept is the following: Consider the language of ordered groups $\\mathcal{L}_{og}:=\\langle +, &gt;, 0 \\rangle$ and the ordered groups $(\\mathbb{Q}, +, &gt;)$. In this case we have no way to define $1$, since there is no $\\phi \\in \\mathcal{L}_{og}$  s.t. $\\phi(1)$ is true and false for any other variable.\nI want to use here a similar concept of definability, which would then become exactly the same if I would be able to write my theory formally. In particular I should notice that there are some sort of propositions that have a free variable and are therefore of the desired kind, but that are true for any inserted variable. For the former example we may for example take $\\psi(y):= \\exists_y y&gt;x$ , we notice that whatever we insert in the free variable $y$ it will always be true. Though I see convenience in stating that, a proposition $\\phi(x)$ defines something, only if there is something that it is not defining, therefore $\\psi(x)$ would not be a defining proposition. It would be a defining proposition, e.g., in the ordering $(\\mathbb{Z}/(5), &gt;)$ where $\\lnot \\psi(4)$  holds.\n \n\\subsection*{III. The Subject}\nWhen asking whether the subject is definable we must first well specify the language we are speaking in. There may well be different ways to define subjects if we are talking a more externalist language or simply referring to others, though, if we consider the present self in a completely internalist language, then one immediately notices that what we mean by subject is including everything that is present in our domain of discourse. Therefore we will find no defining proposition of the subject, since it would hold for any element of our discourse.\n \n\\subsubsection*{III.I. Collections of Phenomena}\nOne might argue that constructing a defining formula is well possible, since it would be the one satisfied only by the \\emph{set} of all phenomena and unsatisfied by all other sets that don&#039;t contain the totality of the phenomena. To argue against this attempt I underline the fact that one can, as want to do for this model, consider collections a distinct element. Now, the former proposal for a defining formula would look like this $\\phi(x):= \\forall_y y \\subseteq x$. Clearly what we need here is a partial ordering of these collections like &quot;$\\subseteq$&quot;. I claim that there are models that still coherently explain our perception that would have not such an ordering, for instance, consider the processed image I have of an object, say, my keyboard. I could clearly say, that there are some other processed images that take part to the image I am right now having of keyboard: one might simply mention its colour, or the material or the sound it is making. These are all phenomena that put together \\emph{compose} the final object I am now looking at. Two things to notice here: first it should now be clear what I mean when claiming that the collection is a distinct object from the phenomena which is \\emph{composing} it. Is \\emph{composing} the right word? We could say that $1, 2$ together compose $\\{1, 2\\}$ but I doubt that grey, metal and a clicky sound compose my keyboard. The pretence of having such an ordering between composite and simpler phenomena is something that clearly brings a few difficulties that one may simply prefer not to solve. Remember here the methodological maxim, I am not pretending to explain how things are but just giving \\emph{one of the many} scenarios that explain our perception.\n \n\\subsection*{IV. Application to Descartes}\nI regard the Cartesian \\emph{cogito ergo sum} as: from the presence (in my sensations) of any thoughtful activity, it must follow that there is a subject who produced it. And yet, here, I just gave a model where the former sentence can&#039;t turn out to be true, since the subject, as shown, is not definable. Two objections came first to my mind: (i) I am not referring to the same subject Descartes is meaning and (ii) the Cartesian claim is then not true in the shown model, which doesn&#039;t strictly mean that it is false. For (i) I need first to state the disclaimer that I have no historical pretence and secondly that I suppose that Descartes wants to denote with subject, either the totality of the res cogitans, for which my argument holds, or the author of such a totality, which would not be part of the domain of discourse and therefore not definable either. For (ii) I would first underline that what Descartes needed is something to be true in any model of our perception, s.t. no sceptical scenario could still arise: both justifying our sensations and not satisfy his claim. Though my scenario both explains all our sensations, by just assuming the presence of such phenomena, and does not satisfy the existence of a subject, therefore I am convinced that it is a sceptical scenario able to falsify the Cartesian claim.\n \n\\end{document}"},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Philosophy/Other-Works/Realism-and-Causality":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Philosophy/Other-Works/Realism-and-Causality","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/2nd Semester/Philosophy/Other Works/Realism&Causality.md","title":"Realism&Causality","links":["tags/2nd_Semester"],"tags":["2nd_Semester"],"content":"This writing are unfinished notes on formalisation of different possible theories of causality and reality. I am not currently working anymore on those notes, written during the 2nd_Semester but, in case I would come back reasoning to connected themes, I will consider rewriting some of these notes in an essay form.\nRealism Defined\nGiven:\n\n\\sim_C a causality relation\nE a set of events\n\\phi a predicate individuating physical events\n\\psi a predicate individuating mental events\n\\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon := \\langle \\land, \\lnot, \\in, T \\rangle the language of set theory as usually defined\nI define the language of realism by expanding the language of set theory to \\mathcal{L}_r:= \\mathcal{L}_\\epsilon \\langle E, \\sim_C, \\psi, \\phi \\rangle, where \\phi: E \\rightarrow \\{T, F\\}, \\psi: E \\rightarrow \\{T, F\\}, \\sim_C: E\\times E \\rightarrow \\{T, F\\}.\n\nThen I define the following theories:\nTheory of Dualism T_d := \\{\\forall_x(\\psi(x) \\lor \\phi(x)), \\forall_x(\\lnot (\\psi(x) \\land \\phi(x)), \\exists_x\\phi(x), \\exists_x\\psi(x)\\}\nTheory of Causality T_c := \\{\\forall_x\\forall_y((x \\sim_C y)\\rightarrow \\lnot(y \\sim_C x)), \\forall_x(x \\sim_C x), \\forall_x\\forall_y\\forall_z(((x \\sim_C y) \\land (y \\sim_C z) \\rightarrow (x \\sim_C z))\\}\nSo (E, \\sim_C) is a partial ordering.\nTheory of Realism T_r := T_d \\cup T_c \\cup \\{\\forall_{x}\\forall_{y}((\\psi(x) \\land \\phi(y))\\rightarrow \\lnot(x \\sim_C y))\\}\nCubic Variant\nExtend \\mathcal{L}_r to \\mathcal{L}_r^R := \\mathcal{L}_r \\cup \\langle \\chi_s, \\chi_t \\rangle, \\chi_s: E \\rightarrow \\mathcal{P}(\\mathbb{R}^3), \\chi_t: E \\rightarrow \\mathcal{P}(\\mathbb{R}), namely the functions that give the spatio-temporal cordinates of an event. Now define:\n\\chi(x) := \\chi_s(x)\\cup \\chi_t(x),\nx=_\\chi y:= (\\chi_s(x) = \\chi_s(y)) \\land (\\chi_t(x) = \\chi_t(y))\nx =_e y := x =_\\chi y \\land ((\\phi(x) \\land \\phi(y)) \\lor (\\psi(x) \\land (\\psi(y)))\nx \\sim_C^0 y := x \\sim_C y \\land \\forall_{i \\in [1,4]}(max(\\chi(x)_i) = min(\\chi(y)_i), for min and max as usually defined,\nTheory of Cubic Events: T_e^C:= \\{\\forall_x\\exists_{r_1, ..., r_8 \\in \\mathbb{R}}(\\chi(x)=([r_1, r_2], [r_3, r_4], [r_5, r_6],[r_7, r_8]), \\forall_x\\forall_y((\\phi(x) \\land \\phi(y) \\land \\lnot(x =_e y)) \\rightarrow \\lnot(\\chi(x) = \\chi(y))\\}\nGiven the usual set theoretic definition of \\mathbb{R} and of closed set [\\cdot, \\cdot], I define for r_1, ..., r_{16} \\in \\mathbb{R} and x, y \\in E s.t. \\chi(x)=([r_1, r_2], [r_3, r_4], [r_5, r_6],[r_7, r_8]) and \\chi(y)=([r_9, r_{10}], [r_{11}, r_{12}], [r_{13}, r_{14}],[r_{15}, r_{16}]):\nx \\cup_\\chi y := z s.t. \\chi(z)=([r_1, r_{10}], [r_3, r_{12}], [r_5, r_{14}],[r_7, r_{16}]),\nI define E^\\chi := \\{\\chi(x)| x \\in E\\}, every x \\in E has its equivalence class x^\\chi := \\overline{x}^{=_\\chi} and it holds that E/=_\\chi \\cong E^\\chi, also notice that given E^\\chi_\\phi := \\{\\chi(x) | x\\in E \\land \\phi(x)\\} and E_\\phi := \\{x | x\\in E \\land \\phi(x)\\}, then \\chi\\restriction_{E^\\chi_\\phi} is injective and \\chi(E_\\phi)=E_\\phi^\\chi; I then define \\chi^{-1}_\\phi: E_\\phi^\\chi \\rightarrow E_\\phi which is bijective.\nThen given x, y \\in E and x \\sim_C^0 y, I define \\overline{x \\sim_C^0 y}:= \\chi(z) := \\chi(x) \\cup_\\chi \\chi(y) and \\chi(z) \\in E^\\chi and \\chi(z).\nTheory of Cubic Causation: T_c^C:= T_c \\cup T_e^C \\cup \\{\\forall_x\\forall_y((x \\sim_C y) \\rightarrow max(\\chi_t(x)) \\le min(\\chi_t(y)), \\forall_x\\forall_y((x \\sim_C y)\\rightarrow \\exists_z(x \\sim_C^0 z \\land z \\sim_C^0 y)), \\forall_x\\forall_y((x \\sim_C^0 y) \\rightarrow \\exists_z(\\chi(z) = \\chi(x) \\cup_\\chi \\chi(y) = \\overline{x \\sim_C^0 y}))\\}.\nTheory of Cubic Dualism: T_d^C:= T_c^C \\cup \\{\\forall_x\\forall_y ((\\phi(x) \\land \\psi(y) \\land x \\sim_C^0 y)\\rightarrow \\chi(x) =_\\chi \\chi(y)\\}\nTheory of Cubic Weak Realism: T_r^{Cw} := T_d^C \\cup T_r\nTheory of Cubic Strong Realism: T_r^{Cs} := T_r^{Cw} \\cup \\{\\forall_x(\\psi(x) \\rightarrow \\exists_y(\\phi(y) \\land (y \\sim_C x)))\\}\nNotes:\nThis variant begins by considering events as fractions of the space-time which was the Russelian definition, I don‚Äôt attribute to B. Russel any of the other definitions. This is a theory that starts by the definition of events as cubic pieces of the space-time, I made them cubic for semplicity. The assumptions I made in defining causation are: one says that cause comes before of the effect, the second that if cause and effect are far apart in space and time there must be a continous chain of causations that connects the cause with its effect and the third claims that causation is an event itself (which is needed for realism to be stated).\nThe main problem one gets with such a definition of event is to give enough space to mental events. It makes sense to speak about realism when we have the a theory of dualism, at least as presented in T_d. When we have no mental events or physical events then realism becomes a trivial matter. Here, where dualism seems to not well fit the context, there are a couple of options: one could see mental events as fractions of space and time where those coordinates are the same as their closest cause (\\sim_C^0), e.g. when a certain chemical activity takes place in the brain, call it x, and it causes a certain feeling, call it y, then it might be that \\phi(x) \\land \\psi(y) \\land \\chi(x)=\\chi(y) so we could say that x =_\\chi y even though x and y are two distinct events. Then in the theory of strong realism I say that any mental event (call it y) must have a physical event and therefore there will be one (call it z s.t.z \\sim_C^0 y) will determine its coordinates (\\chi(z) = \\chi(y)). Though in the theory of weak realism it is possible that there are some mental events that are competely disconnected, with no physical cause, though might create a causal net in the same coordinates of some other physical event even if they‚Äôre causally disconnected from it.\nStatistical Correlation Variant\nExtend \\mathcal{L}_r to \\mathcal{L}_r^S := \\mathcal{L}_r \\cup \\langle \\tau, \\sim_\\rho \\rangle, where \\tau: E \\rightarrow \\mathcal{P}(E), e \\mapsto e^\\tau where e^\\tau is called the type of e and \\sim_\\rho: \\mathcal{P}(E) \\times \\mathcal{P}(E) \\rightarrow \\{T, F\\}, if x^\\tau \\sim_\\rho y^\\tau we saywe say that x^\\tau and y^\\tau are statistically correlated.\nTheory of Statistical Causation: T_c^S:= T_c \\cup \\{\\forall_x\\forall_y((\\tau(x)\\sim_\\rho\\tau(y))\\rightarrow((x \\sim_C y)\\lor(y \\sim_C x)\\lor(\\exists_z(z \\sim_C x \\land z \\sim_C y))))\\}\nBy extending \\mathcal{L}_r^S to \\mathcal{L}_r^{SC} := \\mathcal{L}_r^S \\cup \\mathcal{L}_r^R, I can define:\nTheory of Cubic Statistical Dualism: T_d^{SC} := T_d^C \\cup T_c^S\nOne may do similarly for Weak and\nTheory of Cubic Statistical Strong Realism: T_r^{CsS}:= T_r^{Cs} \\cup T_r^S\nNotes:\nThis is simply a characterisation of causation which, on a theoretical level at least, doesn‚Äôt particularly enrich the discussion, since there is not much I can a priori state on statistical correlation. Though I think that the Theory of Statistical Cubic Strong Realism is a rapresentative theory of the usual scientific praxis (one should first quickly fix the approximation of cubic to any shape on \\mathbb{R}^3 and an interval on \\mathbb{R} for time). What is probably still missing in order to get to the actual practical notion of cause we have is the possibility to distinguish two events happening at the same time, e.g a ball spinning and heating up; those two events have different causal networks and can‚Äôt be distinguished in the Russelian way, for more see SEP\nD. Lewi‚Äô Variant\nExtend \\mathcal{L}_r to \\mathcal{L}_r^L:= \\mathcal{L}_r \\cup \\langle W, \\sim_S, \\square \\rightarrow \\rangle, where \\sim_S: W \\times W \\rightarrow \\{T, F, P\\}, where T and F denote the usual True and False as in the domain classical connectives, though P denotes tie. In order to use only two-valued relations, for any w_1, w_2 \\in W, I define:\nw_1 \\vartriangle w_2 := (w_1 \\sim_S w_2) = P\nw_1 \\vartriangleright w_2 := (w_1 \\sim_S w_2) = T\nw_1 \\vartriangleleft w_2 := (w_1 \\sim_S w_2)=F\n\\square \\rightarrow: \\mathcal{P}(W) \\times \\mathcal{P}(W) \\rightarrow \\{T, F\\}, notice that an A \\subset W is called a proposition, A is the set of worlds where it holds.\nTheory of Determinism: T_{det}^L:= T_c \\cup \\{\\forall_{x \\in E}\\exists_{y \\in E}(x \\sim_C y)\\}\nTheory of Possible Worlds: T_w^L:= T_{det}^L \\cup \\{idk\\}\nTheory of Comparative Similarity: T_s^L := T_w^L \\cup \\{\\forall_{w_1,w_2 \\in W}((w_1 \\vartriangleright w_2)\\lor (w_1 \\vartriangleleft w_2)\\lor (w_1 \\vartriangle w_2)), \\exists_{a \\in W}\\forall_{w \\in W}(a \\vartriangleright w), \\forall_{w \\in W} (w \\vartriangle w), \\forall_{w_1, w_2 \\in W}((w_1 \\vartriangle w_2) \\leftrightarrow (w_2 \\vartriangle w_1)), \\forall_{w_1, w_2, w_3 \\in W} (((w_1 \\vartriangleright w_2) \\land (w_2 \\vartriangleright w_3)) \\rightarrow w_1 \\vartriangleright w_2), \\forall_{w_1, w_2, w_3 \\in W} (((w_1 \\vartriangleleft w_2) \\land (w_2 \\vartriangleleft w_3)) \\rightarrow w_1 \\vartriangleleft w_2)\\}\nSo (W, \\vartriangleright) and (W, \\vartriangleleft) are strict partial orderings and \\vartriangle is an equivalence relation on W.\nLewis underlines ‚Äúwe do not impose the further constraint that for any set A of worlds there is a unique closest A-world, or even a set of A-worlds tied for closest.‚Äù immediatly after he suggests: ‚ÄúWhy not an infinite sequence of closer and closer A-worlds, but no closest?‚Äú. Let‚Äôs define such structure: Let A \\subset W and state \\lnot (\\exists_{\\alpha \\in A}\\forall_{a \\in A}(\\alpha \\vartriangleright a \\lor \\alpha \\vartriangle a)) then there is a (a_i)_{i \\in \\mathbb{N}} \\subseteq A, s.t. a_i \\vartriangleleft a_{i+1}. Now if A is bounded under \\vartriangleright then (a_i)_{i \\in \\mathbb{N}} must be converging by Bolzano-Weierstrass-Theorem, therefore we might consider simply the closure of A, \\bar{A} and it will contain such a maximal \\alpha. For finite clsoed sets the ‚Äúconstrain‚Äù is a theorem in Th(T_s^L), otherwise not.\nTheory of Counterfactual: T_{con}^L := T_s^L \\cup \\{\\}\nNotes:\nTheory of Determinism\nI regard this point as coming from p. 559 where D. Lewis writes ‚Äúthe prevailing laws of nature are such that there do not exists any two possible worlds which are exactly alike up to some time, which differ tehreafter, and in which those laws are never violated.‚Äù I considered it to be equivalnt to affirm that every event must be causated since all such natural laws are causal laws (laws stating that all events of a sort cause events of another sort); therefore clearly if there are no uncaused events then two alike worlds will still be alike and if we assume he‚Äôs statement it follows that there cannot be any uncaused event (or it will definetely excape the causal laws)."},"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Philosophy/Essays/An-Historical-Discourse-on-Phenomenological-Platonism":{"slug":"Academia/Active--and--Works/Bachelor/2nd-Semester/Philosophy/Essays/An-Historical-Discourse-on-Phenomenological-Platonism","filePath":"Academia/Active & Works/Bachelor/2nd Semester/Philosophy/Essays/An Historical Discourse on Phenomenological Platonism.md","title":"An Historical Discourse on Phenomenological Platonism","links":["System/Attachments/An_Historical_Discourse_on_Phenomenological_Platonism.pdf"],"tags":[],"content":"Here you can download the PDF: An_Historical_Discourse_on_Phenomenological_Platonism.pdf\n\\documentclass{article}\n\\usepackage{amsthm}\n\\usepackage{csquotes}\n\\usepackage{setspace}\n\\usepackage[greek,english]{babel}\n\\usepackage[letterpaper,top=2cm,bottom=2cm,left=3cm,right=3cm,marginparwidth=1.75cm]{geometry}\n\\usepackage{graphicx}\n\\usepackage[colorlinks=true, allcolors=blue]{hyperref}\n\\title{An Historical Discourse on Phenomenological Platonism}\n\\author{Simone Testino}\n\\date{June 2023}\n\\begin{document}\n\\maketitle\n \n\\begin{abstract}\n\tParmenides definitely played a crucial role in the formation of the platonic thought and therefore my analysis will start from a couple of his verses, which I comment on, referring to E. Husserl. After this analysis of text I will consider the subject more conceptually, aiming to show that Platonism can be well interpreted in a phenomenological way.\n\\end{abstract}\n \n\\section{Parmenides in Two Verses}\nI have two aims in this section: first I want to give an intuition of the Parmenidean \\textgreek{Œµ·º∂ŒΩŒ±Œπ} through just two verses and their analysis\\footnote{Original sentences have been taken from \\emph{Parmenide, Sulla Natura}, Bompiani, G. Reale 2021 and I used the vocabulary \\emph{GI}, Vocabolario della Lingua Greca $3^a$ Edizione, Franco Montanari. Books that helped the interpretation are \\emph{Storia della Filosofia Greca e Romana}, G. Reale, Bompiani, 2018 and \\emph{Platone, Alla ricerca della sapienza segreta}, G. Reale, i Fari, 2019 and \\emph{La Filosofia dai Greci al Nostro Tempo}, E. Severino, Rizzoli, 2021.}; secondly I want to sketch a connection between Parmenides and Husserl in order to provide reasons to believe that even the Platonic groundings in Parmenides have at least a very phenomenological taste. Such a palatable intuition will then become a concrete thesis when I analyse the two definitions of \\emph{objectivity} and see how Platonic realism relates to the phenomenological conception.\n \n\\subsubsection*{I. The Circularity}\n\\begin{quote}\n\t\\textgreek{ŒûœÖŒΩœåŒΩ Œ¥Œ≠ ŒºŒøŒØ ·ºêœÉœÑŒπŒΩ, ·ΩÅœÄœÄœåŒ∏ŒµŒΩ ·ºÑœÅŒæœâŒºŒ±Œπ¬∑ œÑœåŒ∏Œπ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ œÄŒ¨ŒªŒπŒΩ ·ºµŒæŒøŒºŒ±Œπ Œ±·ΩñŒ∏ŒπœÇ.}\\footnote{Parmenides, B. 5}\n\\end{quote}\nOnly after having well captured the Parmenidean picture, one can actually read in such brief sentences the whole system. The sentence begins in a weak adversative (\\textgreek{Œ¥Œ≠}) since the author well knows that what he&#039;ll state is against common sense. He affirms that \\emph{to him} (\\textgreek{ŒºŒøŒØ}) it is \\textgreek{ŒæœÖŒΩœåœÇ}, which denotes the \\emph{least significance of something}, often translated as \\emph{common to many} or \\emph{indifferent}; the object of this is \\textgreek{·ΩÅœÄœÄœåŒ∏ŒµŒΩ ·ºÑœÅŒæœâŒºŒ±Œπ}, where the first word denotes a \\emph{starting point}\\footnote{Remark: for a more proper translation one should consider it as an adverb, not a noun}, though as often happens in many languages, and in Greek even more, locative locutions are mostly to be understood metaphorically, this will be of most significance for the interpretation; the following verb, \\textgreek{·ºÑœÅŒæœâŒºŒ±Œπ}, which comes from the well known word \\textgreek{·ºÄœÅœáŒÆ}, is a declination of the verb \\textgreek{·ºÑœÅœáœâ} denoting sometimes, like the Latin \\emph{duco}, the action of \\emph{command} and \\emph{being in control} but also \\emph{being the first} both in significance and time (we shall again notice that locality is one of the many meanings that \\textgreek{·ºÑœÅŒæœâŒºŒ±Œπ} as \\textgreek{·ΩÅœÄœÄœåŒ∏ŒµŒΩ} have); the mediopassive voice shifts the meaning to the one involving less action by the subject, we shall here therefore understand it as \\emph{to begin} (for more precision, one might identify it, the mediopassive voice only, with the deponent Latin verb \\emph{orior}). The next sentence begins recalling \\textgreek{·ΩÅœÄœÄœåŒ∏ŒµŒΩ}, we can here simply translate \\textgreek{œÑœåŒ∏Œπ} as \\emph{there} and \\textgreek{Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ} adds emphasis to his statement. On the other hand, \\textgreek{œÄŒ¨ŒªŒπŒΩ} has two main meanings which can be reassembled in the German distinction between \\emph{wieder} and \\emph{wider}, the precise meaning is remarked by repetition by the last word \\textgreek{Œ±·ΩñŒ∏ŒπœÇ} denoting recurrence, it may be interpreted as never ending. The verb \\textgreek{·ºµŒæŒøŒºŒ±Œπ} which comes from \\textgreek{·ºµŒ∫œâ}, or \\textgreek{·º±Œ∫ŒΩŒ≠ŒøŒºŒ±Œπ} it mediopassive voice; in order to understand better its meaning we can compare it with another Greek verb meaning \\emph{to come}, namely \\textgreek{·ºîœÅœáŒøŒºŒ±Œπ}: our verb has a more passive meaning, denoting that this \\emph{return to the starting point} is not in the will of the author but instead imposed by more powerful strengths.\\\\\nThe interpretation I want to give to this sentence in order to let it span the whole Parmenidean system is the following: one should completely drop the locative and instead consider every dimension of the being so that time will recur on every predicate we can assert and therefore all that is, will be and has been is all part of \\textgreek{·ºïŒΩ}; and time itself is, not ruler of \\textgreek{œÄŒ¨ŒΩœÑŒ± œáœâœÅŒµ·øñ}\\footnote{All that changes, moves, becomes, from Heraclitus, Fr. 402.a}, instead anything but part of it.\\\\\n%PRENDI L‚ÄôULTIMA VERSIONE DA TEOLOGIA, HO CORRETTO UN PAIO D COSE\n\\subsubsection*{II. The \\textgreek{ŒΩœåŒ∑ŒºŒ±}}\nIn order to have a deeper understanding of the limits (if they shall be called so) and the context of what \\textgreek{Œµ·º∂ŒΩŒ±Œπ} denotes, one should understand its relation to \\textgreek{ŒΩŒøŒµ·øñŒΩ} which is captured in the following passage:\n\\begin{quote}\n\t\\textgreek{[...]œÑ·Ω∏ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ Œ±·ΩêœÑ·Ω∏ ŒΩŒøŒµ·øñŒΩ ·ºêœÉœÑŒØŒΩ œÑŒµ Œ∫Œ±·Ω∂ Œµ·º∂ŒΩŒ±Œπ.}\\footnote{Parmenides, B. 3}\n\\end{quote}\nThis brief passage ends an unknown sentence with a crucial equality: the well known (yet unclear) \\textgreek{Œµ·º∂ŒΩŒ±Œπ} with \\textgreek{ŒΩŒøŒµ·øñŒΩ}. Two are the words that form Greek into English could be simply translated with the verb \\emph{think}: the just met \\textgreek{ŒΩŒøŒ≠œâ} or \\textgreek{œÜœÅŒøŒΩŒ≠œâ}. The former has in Greek a broader meaning, can be translated as \\emph{feel}, \\emph{acknowledge}, \\emph{know}, \\emph{understand} and, not least, \\emph{see}\\footnote{Remarking the hypothesis on the strong bond present in the Greek culture between thought and visual perception.}. On the other hand \\textgreek{œÜœÅŒøŒΩŒ≠œâ} ranges over a way narrower set of meanings, all referring solely to mental activities, from proper actions of the mind, like \\emph{think} or \\emph{understand} to some states like \\emph{have something in mind}, \\emph{being wise} or, more generally, \\emph{have mental faculties}.\\\\\nThe interpretation of such a passage requires certainly a solid knowledge of the context, there are definitely too many ways to interpret such a statement if taken by itself. In order to do so, I want to relate this passage to a couple of paragraphs by E. Husserl in which he gives his (\\emph{offenbar}) interpretation of the verse.\n\\begin{quote}\n    Die ersten Keime eigentlicher vernunftkritischen Problematik, die wir vor allem uns etwas n√§herbringend m√ºssen, einer Problematik, die nicht auf Wahrheit und Sein, nicht auf Theorie und Wissenschaft im Sinn eines theoretischen Systems gerichtet ist, sondern eben auf das Vernunftbewu√ütsein selbst, treten uns im Altertum bei Parmenides und vor allem in wirksamer negativistischer Form in der Sophistik entgegen. Ihr Skeptizismus hinsichtlich der Wahrheit und des Seins als Korrelates der Wahrheit hat seine Parallele in einem Skeptizismus hinsichtlich des Erkennens, n√§mlich hinsichtlich der M√∂glichkeit eines auf Seiendes im Sinne einer bewu√ütseinstranszendenten Objektivit√§t gerichteten Erkennens.\\\\\n    Gegen die Parmenideische These von der &quot;Identit√§t&quot; von Denken (noein) und Sein, deren Sinn offenbar der war, da√ü das im &quot;vern√ºnftigen&quot; Denken Gedachte und das wahrhaft Seiende unabtrennbare Korrelate sind, endet Gorgias, indem er das Sein im nat√ºrlichen Sinn als objektives (bewu√ütseinsjenseitiges) Sein versteht, ein: Denken ist Vorstellen, Vorstellen ist aber nicht Vorgestelltes.\\footnote{E. Husserl, \\emph{Ph√§nomenologie und Erkenntnistheorie}, 1916, Kapitel II, 6}\n\\end{quote}\nThis passage outlines a debate I regard as very central in the whole ancient philosophy, though in ancient times it remained very clouded, there were not yet the means to shed light upon the essence of the question. This brings me to make a jump in time but trying to keep the focus as closed as possible to the original Platonism.\n\\section{Plato, G√∂del and Husserl on Reality}\nBefore getting into the core of the topic I need to define those words that will be necessary to state the question properly; in fact the following are two very different attempt to define objectivity which will show particular features of the metaphysical context they are inserted in.\\footnote{The upcoming distinction has been sketched both in E. Husserl, \\emph{Phenomenologie und Erkenntnisstheorie}, 1916, Kapitel II, 6 but also in Tieszen, R., 2011, \\emph{After G√∂del: Platonism and Rationalism in Mathematics and Logic} Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press. That this lays in the very centre of both writings is though not surprising: as I will later better explain, Phenomenology has been of great influence in later G√∂del&#039;s philosophy who, probably more than any (or most explicitly), synthesised Platonism and Phenomenology. For more, see: \\url{plato.stanford.edu/entries/goedel/goedel-phenomenology.html}}\n\\subsection{Objectivity Defined}\nBefore distinguishing two very different definitions of objectivity, I want to list a couple of remarks that hold for both: first I have to make clear what \\emph{can} be objective, namely the domain of our predicate and I think that this is a feature that the two definitions, at a first sight\\footnote{I will later give a reason why one shall not believe so, though, for now, it is simpler to assume their domains to be the same.}, have in common. They both are predicates on propositions, namely those that we call true or false\\footnote{That is to say that the domain of objectivity is the same as the one of truth. One can alternatively regard objectivity as being a predicate on definitions of truth, as one might notice in the following definitions by E. Husserl, though no relevant difference will occur for the coming reasoning.}. One might alternatively say that those are predicates on events or on objects, though I see no relevant differences for the next stages and I want to stick with the following writings, which regard objectivity as being predicate on propositions.\n\\subsubsection*{Transcendental Objectivity}\n\\begin{quote}\n    [...] eine Wahrheit, die &quot;Objectives&quot;, n√§mlich au√üersubjektive Gegenst√§nde, betrifft.\\footnote{E. Husserl, ibidem}\n\\end{quote}\nThose propositions whose truth we regard as being \\emph{outside} of the \\emph{subject} are to be called transcendental objective. Both words \\enquote{subject} and \\enquote{outside} are to be better clarified, I&#039;ll avoid to make a proper excursus on what we should call a \\enquote{subject}, I just refer to the Descartes consciousness as being made solely by \\emph{res cogitans}. Though \\enquote{outside} really captures the idea of objectivity and is to be understood as a sort of independence of the truth from the subject. As anyone would notice from the just stated sentence, objectivity is, in this context, a synonym of \\enquote{real} from the well known theories on realism\\footnote{First of all, it is common to see realism as a theory on events and not on propositions (or definitions of truth), this particularly holds when one considers that realism must be defined through causality (independence can be understood as \\enquote{there being no causal relation}), which usually has events as domain, for more see: \\url{plato.stanford.edu/entries/causation-metaphysics/}}. The philosophical object that most of all is to be considered \\emph{outside} of the subject, is definitely the \\emph{noumenon} by Kant and similarly any form of materialism.\n \n\\subsubsection*{Phenomenological Objectivity}\n\\begin{quote}\n    [...] Wahrheit, die an sich gilt.\\footnote{E. Husserl, ibidem}\n\\end{quote}\nPhenomenological objectivity is a predicate that we attribute to those propositions that, no matter what happens to us, we&#039;ll always regard them as true, it is absurd to deny them. In order to give a more precise description of this predicate, like I did previously when I connected transcendental objectivity with realism, I can now compare phenomenological objectivity with the predicate \\emph{$x$ is believed by the subject to be necessary}.
